Questo libro mi ha fatto scendere talmente tanto il latte alle ginocchia che ero lÃ¬ a fare il tifo per una catastrofe naturale che mi togliesse di dosso 'sta manica di disadattati..Sono andata avanti solo perchÃ© la narrazione di Sandra Burr merita e rende tutto questo pappone infinito molto piÃ¹ digeribile!
WOW! I can not believe how much I loved this book. This was completely out of my comfort zone. But I am Anxiously awaiting book 2 to come in the mail.

Incredible. Ayla is about 5 years old when a massive earthquake leaves her motherless and alone. She is found by a group of Neanderthals and adopted into their Clan. As a child born to the Others (a Cro Magnon group living in another area), Ayla's differences are always apparent to everyone else, but she grows to be a respected and integral part of the Clan. What. A. Character. Ayla's story isn't without struggle and difficulty, but it also contains strength and love and a ferocity that I absolutely adore. She's way up there in my new favorite characters list and I'm excited to watch her continue to grow in the subsequent installments in this series. From start to finish in this installment, Ayla ages only a few years, but during the course of that time, she becomes a woman in the eyes of the Clan. This means that she undergoes many things, changes, and events that we do much later in our lives in this day and age. I LOVE her. And honestly, I can't remember ever reading anything from this prehistoric time period before so I was not sure what to expect when I began this book. With the earthquake event happening in the opening chapter, I was immediately hooked. The story never let up, even with the few instances of repetition scattered throughout. I was never bored. The descriptions of the culture and customs of these people and their ways of life fascinated me. It felt obvious to me that the author took great pains to research details and present them as accurately as possible. (After finishing the book, I sought out interviews with Mrs. Auel and found where she talked about her research-very cool.)The part that I easily loved most about this story was its characterization. I was able to form easy connections with them even though there was ~30,000 years between their time and mine. Sure, they are wildly different from me in terms of customs, religion, ways of life, etc. - but these characters have emotions and behaviors that are very much on par with us today. This is something that I've never thought about before...until now, when I've actually taken the time to think about this time period, these people, and the challenges that they faced when compared with the comforts of living in this period of history. I had no trouble at all visualizing this book in my head as I read and found myself wanting to read it anytime that I couldn't be. This book was a complete joy to read (and listen to, as I added the audiobook) and I know that I'll be rereading it in the future. Audiobook Notes: The audiobook format of The Clan of the Cave Bear by Jean M. Auel is published by Brilliance Audio and is 19 hours, 36 minutes, Unabridged. It is narrated by Sandra Burr who was new to me. She was a fine narrator and I became very used to her reading for Ayla and the other characters. Not my very favorite, but certainly enjoyable. I'll read/listen again in the future, for sure.

It's amazing to me all the crazy comments made around here...all the brouhaha and spittle dumped at the doorstep of this dowdy, undistinguished mass-market paperback series ..all the hare-brained theorizing going on this book's Goodreads page... everyone sharpening their axe for this-or-that pet theory they're harboring....And so far I see NO ONE even mentioning that Jean M. Auel is not even the originator of the kernel at the base of this tale. She merely put a sexy-gloss on it; put a fashion-plate heroine at the front of it; and turned the whole thing into a rather cheap historical fiction franchise intended for supermarket check-out aisle racks.That credit for the fundamental idea behind the larger story, though (cro-magnon culture vs neanderthal culture) should go --if to anyone--none other than William Golding. Heard of Golding? Have you? Yes, 'Lord of the Flies'--that William Golding. We're talking a real author now, an author of note. Auel surely knew of Golding's novel; and not for the least of which reason is that he already advances the idea of an orphan from one tribe being adopted by a tribe from the other evolutionary branch.So if you want to 'trash' Jean M. Auel and take-her-to-task and shout 'hooey!' to all her ideas; you're wielding your pitchforks in the wrong direction. Take your blabber to William Golding. His ability--and his vision of how to tell this tale--are more than a match for all this gum-flapping, ballyhoo, and finger-pointing. First of course, ya gotta read his novel though. And it's not an 'easy' read like the works of Auel. The title of his work is 'The Inheritors'. There are other authors who took on this theme (Bjorn Kurten, etc) but Golding is surely the best. For those of you who want a neolithic-age plot narrated with 'more authentic language' this is where you'll find it. For those of you who want a 'more realistic presentation of female roles' in a prehistoric tribe, this has it for you. So go ahead...go on, go home, go do your homework... and then come back here and foolishly spout off more contemporary babble about racism and sexism and chauvinism.

I donâ€™t give up on a book easily. I can count on one hand the times this has happened. But this book and I have come to a parting of the ways. And this is sad, because I really wanted to like this book.Iâ€™ve always been curious about The Clan of the Cave Bear. I love the idea of setting a sweeping epic story during the time of cavemen. And the covers for this series by Jean M. Auel are absolutely beautiful and practically call to readers, promising adventure within. On a recent trip to Manhattan, I found an old paperback copy at The Strand which was autographed and figured it was finally time to dig in.The writing is fine. Utilitarian in places, but the pacing and flow and economy of words is polished. The story, itself, begins well enoughâ€“ a Homosapien girl loses her tribe and is adopted by a clan of Cro-Magnons on the great steppes of the Mammoth fields. But as interesting a world as Auel creates, I practically had to force myself to read on. Three hundred pages in, it began to feel like work. Why? This story has no ticking clock. Her protagonist, Ayla, is not given a goal or mission, other than to try to fit inâ€“or notâ€“as a member of the Clan. As a reader, we donâ€™t really know why weâ€™re reading, other than to understand Auelâ€™s theories on Ancient society. There is simply nothing driving the narration.To me, this book read as an experiment by a great historian to write a novel in order to get other people as excited in the things she studied as she was. And, given the success of the book in the 80â€²s, it worked. But it didnâ€™t work for me. Unfortunately.

This is the first of a series of four books based in Europe during the Ice Age that follows the journey of Ayla, a woman of apparently many talents and abilities.While I was mesmerized by the story, I was bothered by some reviews (not just on Goodreads) that claim it is a racist series. Sometimes reviews ruin reading... The fact that I was aware enough to spend time looking for racist overtones distracted me. Upon reading, here is what I decided. If I can read the book and enjoy it, anyone should be able to enjoy it (probably not archaeologists or anthropologists though). The book is in the fiction section. Yes, the author does not make it clear where reality ends and where fantasy picks up. Yes, there are some inconsistencies to the portrayal of Neanderthals, but it was also written prior to a few major discoveries. Either way, it is still fiction- never claiming to be fact. As for the blue-eyed, blond haired mammoth hunters... Well, This book is about ancient Europe, not ancient North America, so I think it is easy for an author to visualize early Cro-Magnons to look European. I can't prove they weren't blue-eyed, so I just kept reading.Side note: When my boyfriend read the back cover of the book, he raised an eyebrow and said, "Blond hair and blue eyes?..." I just sighed.That is my two cents.
Loved this book.

Objectively, this is probably a terrible novel. It's terrible in some ways, without a doubt. It is overlong and oddly paced. It is repetitive. Its omniscient narration justifies and excuses a lot about behaviour with biological, reductionist evo-psych mumbo-jumbo. It is, if not explicitly racist, then at least enamoured of whiteness: its racially-ambiguous Neanderthals function as a darker, "primitive," maladapted backdrop against which the whiter-than-white, blue-eyed, blonde-haired, highly intelligent heroine can stand out all the starker. And the less said about its representation of rape, the better - it is very much an old-fashioned and offensive plot device here, serving to show who the villain and who the saintly martyred heroine is.At the same time, even now, reading it as an adult with much more advanced critical skills, I cannot help being engrossed in the story. It is an old narrative structure of heaping misfortunes upon the heroine to turn her into a diamond of womanhood, and I see all that's wrong with it, and yet it's just so, so compelling to read. In addition, Ayla, for all her obvious narrative not-like-other-girlness (which, granted, is a story fact - not many homo sapiens girls get raised by Neanderthals!), is relatively complex and granted a lot of agency. She discovers paternity and sexual basis of reproduction! She modifies hunting techniques! She designs a bra! (Yes, she is a beautiful, slim, tall, large-bosomed blonde doctor, a character with superpowers beyond what she could feasibly have. My teen self forgives her for being too perfect, and my 30+ year old self does, too.)The story has some really silly or annoying tendencies, but it also features some truly interesting plot twists or narrative climaxes. I found the last hundred or so pages quite tough to read (what with protagonist's depression and sadness of the story) but the conclusion is rendered quite well. The conflict is resolved in a way that is both seemingly inevitable and satisfying. I particularly liked that Oga and other secondary characters (like Brun and Creb) got to experience some narrative growth by the end.If I had specific shelves for this, I'd rank this "so bad it's good". Sort of. If you close one eye.And now I'm off to read my favourite volume. The one with all the domestication of animals and solitary living. YES.

I feel quite conflicted about this novel. The premise is what drew me to it. I had never come across a novel set in this particular time period that had as its characters Neanderthal humans and Cro-Magnons. I didn't go into this expecting anything in particular, just curious really about where this was heading. I am impressed by the information that the author has supplied to support the novel's story world: the flora and fauna, the anatomy and physiology of her characters, and the suppositions around what sort of culture and society they had. The protagonist, Ayla, certainly maintained my interest and sympathy, and I actively rooted for her. What I had trouble with was reading the near constant belittlement, powerlessness, violence, and rape of the women in the novel because the author predicated it on the theory that Neanderthals' social structure was misogynistic. To date I believe we still suspect that Neanderthals were patrilocal which isn't advantageous to women in general but I don't know that we know much more about their social structures. Even the evidence for patrilocality seems tenuous. The evidence for our societies being misogynistic though is pretty well entrenched and I can't help but think that the author took the easy way out and just modeled her characters after what she imagined 'we' must have been like back when. She really piled it on on her poor female characters and even Ayla was reduced frequently to a pathetic mess especially in the first third of the novel.Other points of detraction include the writing style that sometimes didn't quite manage to slip seamlessly between the science and the fiction, and the repetition of information. I am curious about (view spoiler)[what happens to Ayla after she leaves. I can't believe she left Durc behind (hide spoiler)]. It is solely this curiosity that might lead me to read the book although I can imagine more rote misogyny leading me to hurl it against the closest wall. In closing, I can't bring myself to say this was an okay read. I did not enjoy it as a whole but I did dig out parts of it that were interesting. See, conflicted.

I don't even know where to start. I know, I'll start with the good. I liked the way the author describes the Clan cooking and eating, making things, and other daily details. It's like the Boxcar Children or Little House on the Prairie or any of those self-sufficiency stories - it gives a cozy feeling. I also liked the ability of the medicine women to heal and help using only what they had at hand ... not that I believed all of it, but again, it was pleasant to read.Okay, that's about it for the good. As for the bad :- Psychic. Mind-melding. Neanderthals. You hear a LOT about Neaderthal brains, particularly the fact that the Clan has "ancestral memory" inherited from all the Neanderthals who previously lived before. Do I need to say more?- Actually, I do need to say more about Neanderthal brains. When I read that the Neanderthals don't learn new things because it will make their babies' brains bigger and therefore the women won't be able to give birth, I almost gave up on the book right then and there.- This book was SO repetitive. I think 200 pages could've easily been edited out by removing the fourth, tenth, or hundredth time that a common theme was stated yet again. - Related to the point above, there was way too much "telling, not showing". The author is literally TELLING you what happened, what it means, why it happened, and how everyone should feel about it. It's bad enough when the telling regards the characters or their bizarre internal monologues, but it gets downright boring when it's yet another encyclopedia-like dump of information about the environment, the flora and fauna, biology, evolution, or whatever piece of research the author couldn't bear to leave on the editing room floor. - What sealed the two-star review was the ending. No spoilers, but be warned, it just ENDS. After all that repetition and padding and meandering through the day-to-day life of the Clan, it's like the author looked down and realized, "oh hey, I hit 500 pages! Better wrap this sucker up!" I will definitely not be continuing with the series.

I should probably start with a caveat. I finished the book less than 20 minutes ago, so my emotions are a little...strong, to say the least. Overall the book is fine. Auel does include quite a bit of detail about the environment and items used by the Clan and how they make all of their tools, which was interesting. As for the social structure and rules...well I didn't care for that as much. In fact it infuriated me on a number of occasions and I wonder where she got the idea for it - research or mostly her own creation. As for the rating, this was going to be a 4 star until the very end. (view spoiler)[ I cannot believe the ending! I nearly threw the book across the room when I was done. Broud has been made leader and makes Ayla his second mate (and really how did he not die?! He's beyond terrible!), and because he is totally horrible he refuses to allow her son to stay and then he says Creb has to move to a hearth that would aggravate his health problems just to spite Ayla. And when Ayla fights to keep Creb at his hearth, he orders the new mog-ur to curse her. An earthquake breaks up the party and kills Creb just cause things weren't crappy enough. And right before the book ends, Ayla is cursed and forced to leave.  (hide spoiler)] Let's just say I'm quite upset and it'll take me a bit before I can start the second book. I enjoyed the interaction and relationships between most of the characters, but overall I'm not sure I'd recommend this book. If you're curious about what life might have been like, it'd probably be better to read a non-fiction book written within the last few years since research is constantly being updated. I'll give it at least one more book because I really like Ayla, but I'm very unhappy with the story thus far. >:(

I really wanted to like this one. I thought I would. But after reading the first 50 pages/3 chapters I just can't go on. It's the 6th book I have abandoned in over 4 years. It is long-winded, way too descriptive (lots of telling, no showing), so much repetition, chunks of encyclopedic knowledge thrown in every other page, and when I read about the clan women having the memories from their ancestors and clan members not being able to learn new things because that will increase brain size and their brains won't fit in their skulls and heads increase even more in size and child birth will become impossible, my eyes roll backwards so much it hurts. I have to admit I haven't been in much of a reading mood lately and when I read something I feel extra critical and more easily annoyed by anything I don't like. If I read this a couple of months ago or would read it a couple of months from now, perhaps I would have liked it. Or at least finished it.

Forgive me for not liking this book. The subject matter was intriguing (I was an anthropology minor as an undergraduate), but I just could not connect with the main character. The preponderance of asides was kloogy and interrupted the flow of the story. Honestly, my anthropology textbooks were far less boring. The prose seemed too "clean" and florid for the subject matter, as well. I give it a reluctant two stars for the subject matter and some little bit of (largely inaccurate) knowledge one might gain from it. Unfortunately, this fragmented information isn't enough to hold the book together. Nor is the plot. Nor are the characters. "Clan of the Cave Bear" falls apart like a poorly-excavated fossil.

I find it sad that this story could have been staged in any period of history. The toxic masculinity that leads to Ayla's sufferings is nothing unfamiliar. The attitudes of the men involved in her subjugation are present, if not prevalent, today. Needless to say, this was difficult for me to finish. Ayla's journey made me very uncomfortable. I kept hoping she'd stand up and say, "No!" I had to remind myself repeatedly that the story begins in her fifth year. She's known nothing but the strictures of the Clan. She does the one thing she can, and thus achieves nobility and strength her persecutor can only envy.

I couldn't finish it. Ayla and her Mary Sue-ish antics irritated the hell out of me. I'm not going to believe an 8 year old invented everything. Think you're good at anything? You suck compared to her. Screw Ayla.
If there were other fictional accounts set in the Ice Age, I would have read those instead. But Auel has the market cornered.

I am..Pro-Ayla, our book's heroine.Pro-hunting by sling.Pro-medicine woman descriptions and the awesome members of the tribe who support Ayla.Pro-wilderness survival scenes because I loooved books like Julie of the Wolves and Hatchet. I actually wish this had been recommended to me in high school in a similar vein, because this isn't always a middle school read...I am...Anti-Broud and every stupid, cruel sentence he manages to piece together in this book.Anti-violence, especially against women for no reason, although I don't doubt events like this actually happened.Anti-long-winded descriptions about plants and having the plots spelled out for you. But really, not bad.Overall, I'd recommend this if you like pre-history or survivalist fiction books, and turns out, I do! The second half gets HARSH in some parts (violence, childbirth stuff, animal/human sacrifice), so be prepared for that.

3.75 starsAyla is only 5-years old when an earthquake happens and her mother is swallowed up. She doesnâ€™t know what to do, but when Iza, a medicine woman, and her Clan find a starving and passed out Ayla, Iza knows she must help. Ayla looks very different from the Clan and she does her best to fit in and be accepted. But Broud, the son of the leader, hates her with a passion and will do anything he can to knock her down. This was really interesting. Not fast-paced, but a time period Iâ€™ve not read about before (the Ice Age); Iâ€™m actually not sure how much is out there TO read on this time period, to be honest! I had a hard time with the hunting (particularly the pregnant mammoth), but I know they would have had to back then. With the way it ended, I would like to continue with the next book in the series. Even if I wasn't going to read the next book, I can't see myself forgetting this one anytime soon.

I know so many people love this book, but after 150 pages I'm just bored. I wanted to read more about the characters and their relationships and less about plants, hunting, religious rites etc. I may come back to it sometime.

I love this book...still...after so many years! I still have it, along with all the rest of the books in this Earth's Children series by Jean M. Auel.The Clan of the Cave Bear was given to me many years ago by a friend, and although I was, at the time, a prolific reader of all kinds of books, it was not a book I would normally have gravitated towards as my tastes at that point in time were anything and everything to do with espionage...you know, Nelson De Mille, John Le Carre, Tom Clancy, Robert Ludlum, to name a few of the type of reading 'diet' that I was on at the time, and rapidly devouring. Mmmm.Quite a contrast from Clan of the Cave Bear!))!However, my friend told me to just read the first two pages and if I wasn't intrigued enough to read on then she would understand.I think I finished that book in record time and couldn't wait for the follow up one!! I have since employed that same strategy when promoting this book to others....try it, at the library if you can't find a copy elsewhere.I must confess that, in hidsight, I did like the first two books...maybe three... the best, but still hung out for the rest of them to complete the series, and was not disappointed.The story has been made into a television movie, but in my opinion it was a very poor, lacklustre and rather off-putting portrayal of what could have been...in the right hands...akin to Peter Jackson's screen version of Lord of the Rings. Well, at least nowadays I believe it could be!It is a saga which spans generations and needs to reflect the consequences of time.I am eternally grateful to my friend for feeling motivated to share that book with me at that point in my life, and so grateful to the author for having inspired in me an abiding interest and passion for Herbs and Herbal Remedies which in turn led to an equally strong love for cooking and experimenting with all types of Herbs. It was then a natural progression into the wonderful world of Spices and, other Cultures.Resulting effects were that my senses of taste and smell had been introduced to brand new and exciting highs as I went on to discover a world of Herbs and Spices with their myriad qualities and applications. Everyday, I still enjoy the effects of those earlier influences.I noticed from the reviews that other people were also inspired in different and positive ways from reading this book.NEVER underestimate the power of a well written  and researched  book! Regardless of topic, genre or source...what do they say...."When the pupil is ready, the teacher appears".Thank you Izzy.. you know who you are.. For introducing me to The Clan of the Cave Bear. [image error]Thank you Jean M.Auel, for not only giving us these stories, but for the absolute lengths that you went to in order to do so.It was sometimes a long wait between books, but this is because your research took you so far and wide in order to make the stories as authentic and credible as you possibly could. You do fine service to your work. They are all BIG books and offer very good value to your avid readers. I am richer for having enjoyed them...Namaste..[image error]

Esperar ha sido mala idea. Esperar tanto tiempo para leerlo (bueno, en este caso fue audiolibro) y esperar tanto de una novela icÃ³nica en una Ã©poca en la que se me iban los ojos con libros de todo tipo (es del 80 pero se puso de moda a finales de los 90, si no recuerdo mal). Si lo hubiera leÃ­do en su dÃ­a lo habrÃ­a disfrutado mÃ¡s. Sin embargo, a dÃ­a de hoy, este libro es para mÃ­ un "sÃ­ pero no".Entre la ficciÃ³n y el documental, gana este Ãºltimo. Eso hace que a veces resulte Ã¡rido, dejando la trama en segundo plano como una excusa para centrarse en lo que realmente quiere: mostrar el mundo, la sociedad y la cultura de la tribu. En fin, que resulta muy interesante, tiene detalles geniales sobre el funcionamiento de su sociedad neandertal (como esa mente colmena capaz de recordar a travÃ©s de generaciones) y la trama es correcta, pero en conjunto me resulta insatisfactorio como novela. Tal vez la monÃ³tona voz que locutaba el audiolibro ha tenido algo que ver, pero se me ha hecho bastante pesado. En el fondo, creo que le sobra bastante al libro. La historia en sÃ­, desprovista de su maravilloso maquillaje, se queda en poca cosa. A veces me resultaba simplona su narrativa, que no serÃ­a un inconveniente de no ser por el contraste con la profesionalidad con la que detalla por otro lado esos aspectos documentales. ConclusiÃ³n:-Me ha gustado la parte mÃ¡s documental y me ha aburrido la mayor parte de la trama. No me parece mala, sino reguleramente ejecutada para mi gusto. Es difÃ­cil lograr un buen equilibrio entre la asepsia cientÃ­fica y los sentimientos de los personajes. -Creo que le sobra "metraje". No porque sea muy largo, sino porque la historia en realidad no da tanto de sÃ­. -Mi nota personal estÃ¡ entre 2 y 2,5 no porque sea una novela regular, sino porque no me ha terminado de gustar del todo. Es una puntuaciÃ³n basada en mi gusto. Si le pusiera nota en funciÃ³n de su calidad, le pondrÃ­a un poco mÃ¡s.-Para "wordbuilding" en fantasÃ­a viene bien porque ves puntos que funcionan y otros que es mejor omitir.

This book is the first in a series, to which I strongly suspect I am hooked. (How convenient I was looking for a new series to become engrossed it, being up to date with all my the series Iâ€™m currently reading). The series follows Ayla a bright, engaging girl who must fight to survive in a challenging and often hostile world. In this the first book she loses her family aged 5 in an earthquake and is taken in by another group, in this case Neanderthals. In many respects it is a story we have heard before. Human child loses family and is left unprotected only to be rescued by another group. Jungle Book for instance instantly springs to mind.I read a lot of historical fiction but I think itâ€™s safe to say I have never read one set during the Stone Age. It is not a period Iâ€™m particularly familiar with. I remember covering it briefly in history as a child but it was quickly passed over in favour of the later periods of which we know more and of which there is more evidence in Ireland. My first thoughts when I began reading this was to wonder how accurate was it. We of course have some idea how people lived, what they ate and the tools they used. But to what degree can we now how they communicated or how their society was structured. I was amazed to discover that much within the book is fact in fact true, or at least was considered true when it was published over 30 years (some things have since been disproved through more recent discoveries). The degree of research is evident throughout. Detailed descriptions are often provided about how something was done. While this was interesting I do have a gripe with it. At times I felt these explanations became too technical and interfered with the flow of the story and I often found myself skimming over these sections. A notes section explaining may have been more beneficial and less disruptive to the story.This is my only real compliant however. Overall I really enjoyed it. Ayla is an engaging and likeable lead character. It may not be world class literature, but it certainly addictive and engrossing. Perfect escapism.

I've been wanting to read it for years, ever since I saw my father read it. So when an anthropology course got me interested in prehistoric humans, this seemed like the perfect choice to read. Now, having read it, I'm a little unsure what I think about it. On the one hand, I really liked the concept of the book, and I'm definitely planning to read the next one in the series, not because it ended on a cliffhanger, but also because I'm genuinely interested in just where the series is going. On the other hand, there were some aspects of Auel's writing that really bothered me. I think that the book would have really benefited from an editor to cut out some of the repetitive descriptive passages. I thought that her foreshadowing was really heavy handed as well. I'm not usually too observant about that kind of thing, but knowing whenever something was going to go wrong took some of the fun out of the book for me. There were also times when Ayla's character grated on my nerves. However, there were also times when I didn't want to put the book down at all. I guess my real rating of this is a 3.5: it's not quite a 4 because of the problems I mentioned above, but I did enjoy it a bit more than just a 3 indicates.

What a loathsome book.I wanted to put this down about 10% of the way through but I kept reading because an aquaintance told me this book was about angels, and time travel, and a war or something, so I kept reading because I thought something interesting was coming. Nope. Wrong book or something.This is a book about a human girl who is orphaned and taken in by some Neanderthals. She is raised as one of them, becomes a prodigy, and is generally accepted by everyone. Except the bad guy, who is just an angry man who is completely defined by his goulish hatred of the main character.It spends so much time repeating itself, which is tiresome. And it defeats its own ability to create suspension of disbelief by having no coherent POV: it switches between people, and also to a weird narrator voice that talks like a BBC show about people's frontol lobes or lack thereof, and dehydration, and the need for oxygen.I mean the content was also garbage. I didn't need to read pages and pages in which the main character deduced that babies don't come from a woman swallowing the essence of a man's spirit animal and having her spirit animal subdued: they come from a "man's organ". **Gasp**. What utter bilge. I do not understand why this is a 4 star book.

Je zult maar als eenling tussen een andere stam terecht komen. In de prehistorische wildernis van het Europa van 35.000 jaar geleden vindt de Stam van de Holebeer een klein meisje. Ze is moederziel alleen; haar familie is bij een aardbeving om het leven gekomen en ook zelf is ze gewond. Hoewel het kind niet tot het volk van de Stam behoort, neemt Iza, de medicijnvrouw haar op. Ze krijgt de naam Ayla.Haar pleegmoeder is de heelmeester(es) van de clan en deze leert Ayla de heelkundige kennis die ze heeft. Ayla is een leerlinge die graag leert. Al begrijpt ze niet altijd wat wel en niet mag binnen de clan. Iets dat haar vaak duur komt te staan.De hoofdpersonen zijn zo goed uitgewerkt dat je het hele verhaal als een film aan je voorbij ziet gaan. De gebruiken en de omgeving en de gebeurtenissen van de stam worden prachtig verteld. Ook de manier waarop tijd verstrijkt (een stuk langzamer als nu) is mooi omschreven. Ik raad dit boek van harte aan. Het is een boek uit een serie. Ik raad wel aan ook de volgorde aan te houden van de boeken. Dit omdat er dan een geschiedenis tijdlijn in zit en de ontwikkeling van sommige hoofdpersonages dan beter te volgen is.

This book and its' sequel are beautiful, original and evocative novels that document the coming of age story of a young girl in the neolithic period. This book is something of a classic in historical fiction and for good reason. The exploration of kin, family, sex, gender roles, biology, identity and spirituality result in novels that are rich and complex. However, my favourite aspects of the first two books in the season was the intensely evoked loneliness I felt for the MC. I read much of this book and the next with a lump in my throat. Her confusion, her isolation and her constant attempts (and inevitable failure) to appease her adoptive family is painfully relatable. There are certain elements that are a little dated, however by and large this story is unique and strongly realised. Anyone even remotely interested in historical fiction, evolution, hunter-gather cultures, books about family, books about culture, or coming of age stories should give this one a go. It made me cry quite a few times which has only happened with one other book in the last four years.

this is one of my favorite series out there. The first book here is in my opinion the best book out of the series as well. You can easily just read this one and have a fantastic story without having to continue on with the others. Ayla is such a memorable character. She is bold, and kind hearted. She is thirsting for knowledge and longing for the feeling that she belongs somewhere. She desires friendship, siblings and caretakers and gets a little bit of each of these things through different members of the clan, but most of all she makes an enemy. Just for existing. It made me laugh and cry and I recommend this series every chance that I get. This first book is somewhat basic, there is a little tiny bit of sex, but not too detailed, as the series progresses and she becomes older those will become more mature in nature.

Oh. My. Gosh. This book blew my mind. I saw the movie years ago and remember enjoying it but somehow I never read the book. It's incredible, so atmospheric and vivid, Auel paints the life of the clan so vividly I could picture the cave and the food and the clan. I love Ayla, she is such a brilliant, strong, dynamic character. It was wonderful reading about the differences between the Clan and the Others, imaging the changes that took place at this time in history. I loved the pacing, that this story wasn't rushed but also doesn't drag, and that there is just enough development and conflict to never feel bored but not so much where it feels overly burdened. The story tells itself, it feels natural and the characters feel genuine. I can't wait to reads the 2nd book in the series!

Absolutely amazing! What a roller coaster of emotions reading this, especially the end. This just became my favorite book. I've never read anything with such depth in so many ways. History, anthropology, biology religion, the human spirit, and more. I think I had something to say to my wife about almost every page and I was constantly thinking and comparing the people of the Clan's time to our own. We're not really all that different though we'd like to pretend we are. The same themes appear in their lives with different content. Ayla is, by far, the strongest character I've had the fortune of reading about. I can't wait to read the rest of the series!

5 StarsOne of my absolute favorite books. I have read it multiple times and listened to it even more. It has very well written characters transferring you to a time and place where there was no cars, no machines and no electricity. There is nothing I can say to make this book justice. Itâ€™s very hard to pick one favorite book, but this one is one of my top contenders.

Para acercarse a la Prehistoria de forma amena y entretenida. Me ha gustado que la protagonista sea una mujer fuerte, inteligente, luchadora, curandera y cazadora. Si tuviera que criticar algo dirÃ­a que se hace pesada, a veces, por querer describirlo todo al detalle.MÃ¡s informaciÃ³n, aquÃ­: http://revistadeletras.net/biblioteca...

It is one of my favorite books. It is an arduous read and requires true dedication. Ayla is a literary hero who triumphs through her obstacles with spirit and intelligence. The descriptions of the book can be a bit difficult, but I did love Ayla's story.

4/5 Perhaps I'm too fresh off of closing this book, but as of now I'm absolutely delighted. The issues I had at the start with the pacing made me wary at first, but they completely disappeared after page 100-ish and I had so much difficulty putting the book down. Most of my problems with the story ended when the pacing troubles did, starting with...CHARACTERS. Our protagonist, a Cro Magnon girl named Ayla, is only five years old when the Neandrathal clan adopts her. Her acquiescence to authority figures (read: everyone, but especially the males of the clan) is at odds with her inquisitive, defiant nature at the start, to the point where it feels like Auel is showing you one Ayla and telling you of another. However, once she (view spoiler)[ begins to hunt  (hide spoiler)] she becomes far more self-assured and becomes a delight to read. The novel closes with Ayla around age 13-14 ish, and she is oddly mature for that age then, but it stands to reason given that (1) she's officially a woman by age 10 for the clan and (2) (view spoiler)[ her several near death experiences, Broud's abuse, rape, losing all her loved ones in quick succession, etc. (hide spoiler)]The other characters, especially Iza, Creb, Brun, and Broud, are very interesting to read from. I buddy read this novel with a friend and both of us were struck with how little we knew about cavemen. Auel's author's note says she spent years researching humanity's prehistoric ancestors, so for the purposes of this story I will accept her assertions about the differences in neandrathal and Cro Magnon thought as fact. PLOT.As I mentioned, the plot took a while to build up, but when it got going, BOY did it go fast. The consistent escalation of risk and the scope of the potential consequences kept me on the edge of my seat, and I was never really not afraid for Ayla. Auel's Prehistoric Europe was equal parts beautiful and dangerous, so I felt a consistent sense of fear for all the character's lives. As Ayla matured and overcame greater and greater obstacles, I started to fear for her less, but when (view spoiler)[ her allies began to die off (hide spoiler)] that fear came back tenfold. Even with that escalation, no plot point felt unnecessary. The Clan ascribe to totems/spiritual protectors what I call "character development." It was a little on the nose when Ayla (view spoiler)[ would come back stronger after a challenge/risk/death curse and thank her Cave Lion totem (hide spoiler)], but I DID feel that each episode of that was necessary to her growth as a character and the culmination of the plot as a whole. One small complaint I have is that the story felt oddly incomplete. The ending wrapped up a CHAPTER of Ayla's story, but when I reached it I felt as though I was missing a few pages wherein the story would REALLY come to a close. I know that CotCB is part of a 6 book series, but I prefer for the first book of a series at least to be able to stand alone if it must. I DID enjoy seeing all the various plot points wrap up by the end (e.g.; (view spoiler)[deformed children, how a cro/neandrathal baby happens, Ayla seeing the men's ceremonies, Ayla FINALLY getting for-real death cursed, Broud losing to her for good...... (hide spoiler)])SETTING (and Writing Style).As I mentioned earlier, Auel's prehistoric Europe is meticulously researched. I'm a big fan of rich, extensive worldbuilding in all of my fiction, and I've never seen it quite this thorough except in high fantasy or heavy sci fi. In addition to being oddly idyllic in one sense, the cave and its surroundings never felt safe or secure the way a modern home does. The wildness of the setting lent the story a sense of urgency even in "safe/dull" moments (e.g.; when the Clan was snowed in for the winter). Auel's descriptions of the landscape and some of the actions were jarring at first. It's as though she has an encyclopedic knowledge of, say, shaping caveman tools, and feels she HAS to include it or else all the research is for naught. The paragraphs long listing of the animals, both edible and not, near the cave also made little sense where it was, for similar reasons (what does this add to the plot?). But after a while, even the unnecessary feeling descriptions began to grow on me. Things I Could Have Done Without/With Less Of: - Ayla being called ugly all the time. We get it. After the first three or four repetitions it becomes old. ESPECIALLY when we get a description of her later and she looks basically like Brooke Shields in Blue Lagoon. Yeah... so ugly... (also the description of her mature/adult female body happens when she's 10/11.)- Repetition in general, actually. Broud being "the son of Brun's heart" is understandable after the first mention, for example. For all that the Clan are supposed to have infallible memories, they sure do like to repeat themselves. Also, there were a few instances of unnecessary clarification, where Auel would "show" something in the narrative, and then in the next sentence "tell"/explain it as though it hadn't JUST HAPPENED. - ...I was going to say the misogyny but honestly? I think it's addressed and fought against pretty effectively, especially considering the time period and the people involved. TW for rape/assault for sure, though - I would have liked a more distinct voice for Ayla, but that's nitpicky considering Auel's style.
Read long ago.
I loved it.

It's a kind of stiff and formal read, but the story is excellent and imaginatively written. Set in a time period of about 25,000 years ago, it concerns a young female orphan, obviously from a Cro-Magnon family, who is taken in by a clan of Neanderthals. The girl, Ayla, grows into a woman, and is taught by the clan how to survive and fit into their tight and complex society. Weaving, cooking, caring for babies and children, gathering edible plants, making leather and fur into clothing, etc. - these are all the approved and expected activities for normal female Neanderthals. Their society is strictly patriarchal and divided into rough family units made up of a man and his mate and any children the mate has.There is one exception to this male-dominated society, lineage is determined by one's mother. The children of a man's mate is referred to just that way: the children of his mate. This is because the Neanderthals are really on the wrong page when it comes to how children are conceived. It involves totems and the spirit world, and it's hard to explain. It was one part of the book I just didn't 'get.' (Hence, the father of any child could be any mature man in the clan, except for a woman's male siblings. They're very particular about that.)However, it's a well-researched book as regards the plants and animals of the time, the topography, and the way the lives of these people might have been. However, our little orphan girl doesn't fit in that well; she's different. She's blond and tall; she's also 'ugly' - no brow ridges! and such a flat face! But she can also do things the other women can't. For one, she's smart and curious, traits not compatible with proper female Neanderthal behavior. Eventually she becomes at odds with one of the male members of the clan who feels...Well, into spoiler territory here. It's an excellent book, if a bit verbose. This can't be an easy topic to write about, seeing how a lot of what we 'know' is based on so little evidence. But what we do know Ms. Auel handles quite well, expertly in fact. I intend to read the next book in this series.Four stars.

I've heard people talk about Jean Auel's Clan of the Cave Bear for eons and have resisted reading it, as historical fiction about Neandertals and Cro Magnon groups sounds, erm, fictional and silly. Probably much of Cave Bear is not historically accurate; on the other hand, it provides an interesting window into a different world, whether or not it is accurate. With this in mind, Cave Bear has the ability to be as useful â€“ as defined as increasing my understanding of different perspectives â€“ as any book written by any member of a marginalized group. This was an interesting and unexpected conclusion.Keep in mind that Ayla, a Cro Magnon child adopted by a Neandertal tribe following an earthquake killing her family, was played by Daryl Hannah in the 1986 movie of the same name. From the perspective of most people of my age (at least), Daryl Hannah is lovely; nonetheless, her looks and behavior are seen as strange and wrong: Standing up at her full height, the girl was even taller than Izathought. Her legs were long, spindly with knobby knees, and straight. Iza wondered if they were deformed. The legs of Clan people were bowed in an outward curvature, but, except for a limp, the child had no problem moving around. Straight legs must be normal for her too, Iza decidedâ€” like [her] blue eyes. (p. 43).  Similarly, Ayla's assertiveness, independence, style of thinking, and smiling were all seen as different and, often, bad, just as were her flagrant violations of gender norms. The chief's son, for example, was jealous and resentful of Ayla's greater successes in many realms, and beat or raped her as a result. Rape and assault here and elsewhere is about power and degradation.In sum, Auel offers an interesting view of one possible world, a view that helps us understand our own more fully. Cave Bear was a very pleasant surprise.

When I was a little girl, my mom had a copy of this book on her bookshelf. I remember it catching my attention because it was so thick. I peeked inside and was surprised to see that there were no pictures and the words were so small. I couldn't ever imagine being old enough to read a book like this. About 5 years ago, I was surprised to see this book on a few people's "Best books I ever read" lists. I remembered the book from my childhood and decided that I was probably old enough to read it now. ;) Wow, this book was really good! It was very different than anything I have read. The story, set in pre-historic times, is about a young girl who loses her family during an earthquake and is left to fend for herself. She is on death's doorstep when she is rescued/adopted by another clan of people who look very different than she does. This book tells her story. This book started out a little bit slow for me, but really picked up after a few chapters. It got to the point that I had a hard time putting it down. Then it lost a little steam during parts of the Clan Gathering. It picked back up in the end, until it ended with a cliffhanger- I was NOT expecting that, but came to the realization that it was coming when I saw the number of pages remaining was dwindling and things were no where near wrapped up! I knew this was book #1 in a series, but didn't expect that it would leave me hanging in the end. Despite the ending, I enjoyed this book and it will stay with me for a long time. I will have to do some research into the rest of the series and decide if I am going to continue.

Tengo que decir que todo me gustÃ³: el argumento, los personajes, la ambientaciÃ³n, la manera de contarlo. Todo. No es perfecto, ni mucho menos, le encuentro algunas cosillas, pero sin ellas, la historia no serÃ­a la misma.El libro es bastante fiel a la realidad de la Ã©poca. Tanto, que muchas cosas que le pasan a nuestra protagonista tienen un toque de cruda realidad en cuanto a ser mujer se refiere. SÃ­, hay escenas malas. Escenas que tienes que decidir si saltÃ¡rtelas, y perder ese pedacito del rompecabezas que forma toda la historia, o apechugar y vivir con Ayla tanto los momentos buenos, como los malos.TambiÃ©n hay muchos personajes y es algo que por una parte me gusta, porque hay muchos diÃ¡logos a lo largo de la historia. No es el tÃ­pico libro que durante un capÃ­tulo se pasan describiendo el paisaje. No, hay interacciÃ³n, acciÃ³n, informaciÃ³n, detallesâ€¦ TambiÃ©n hay descripciones, pero no largas y pesadas.No os quiero crear muchas expectativas y que despuÃ©s no se cumplan, pero si estÃ¡is pensando si leerlo o no, os digo que merece totalmente la pena.ReseÃ±a completa: https://armasdetinta.wordpress.com/20...

This book has been on my 'to read' radar for at least 20 years so I was glad to finally get to it.Mixed feelings about this overall. With a story line set in the time of early man there is really no way that some of the writing cannot come off as anachronistic. But, I found a few cases where glaring references could have been avoided. For example, describing a shard of flint as being 'as sharp as broken glass' just seemed out of place. The author seems to have done her research and is a good storyteller. A couple of things were a little predictable, but those fit in with the natural flow of the story.This is a 3.5 star book. I enjoyed it and will read the others at some point but don't feel the urgency to rush out at read them right now. (TBH I never feel like that as I hate binge reading.)

This is the book I read for book club at school and it was a student pick! I love when students pick books that I probably never would have read without their recommendations and picks!The book takes place during the Ice Age? The Neolithic Age? I was a little unsure which one, but it takes place way back when people were living in caves. Ayla gets lost from her mother and ends up with a different clan, The Clan of the Cave Bear. The clans people didnâ€™t want to accept her because sheâ€™s so different, but the medicine woman takes her in and raises her as her daughter. I liked the theme of acceptance and other that carried throughout the book. I also liked how strong the main character was, and how she didnâ€™t want to accept the gender norms put in place by the clan. She wants to hunt, but knows that she cannot because sheâ€™s a woman. It made me think about how thousands of years later women are still fighting for equality! If youâ€™re looking for an interesting book that takes place back during the time of Mammoths, then definitely check it out! It was a little long, and hard to follow some of the characters because the names were so different, but overall an enjoyable book!
Primero de una excepcional saga
Too many thoughts - review to follow

The only things that are accurate in this book are contained in the endless infodumps. The facts may be well-researched, but the ideas Auel is pushing are both unscientific and obnoxious.First and foremost, her take on evolution should be kept away from our young, who don't know any better and would believe that evolution has a purpose, from which it is but a step to intelligent design. Phrases like "nature's experiment", "in an effort to postpone extinction nature tried...", and even "destiny" creep up all the time. Look, no one knows for certain what caused Neanderthal extinction, but it was most probably a combination of external and quite random factors. Like being forced through a bottleneck by disease and then being hit by a climate change - just an example, and could have happened to us just as easily; could even happen still, actually.I was going to cite the whole "genetic memory" as a second example, but on reflection it really doesn't need my pointing out that this is where we get firmly into the realm of fantasy, leaving speculative fiction far behind.But even considered as a work of literature, this would be noticeably below standard. The writing is unnecessarily repetitively redundant, and leafing through the thesaurus at every opportunity doesn't make it any better. The tone and atmosphere don't exist. Whenever a feeble attempt is made by either, up pops an infodump or a disruptively modern, scientific-sounding term. And every single inference is spelled out for us stupid Cromagnons - wait, we are innovative and brilliant Cromagnons, not hidebound in tradition at all, never, never...And don't let me forget the whole "white supremacy" message. I'll allow that Ayla's being blue-eyed blonde while everyone else is relatively swarthy may be just the author's working out a kink, to make her "ugly" when we know she's in fact beautiful, and not real true racism. But as far as I'm concerned she could be bright green and still have offensively "white" connotations. Do you guys really enjoy reading about someone who is best at everything, and I mean everything, exclusively by the right of her birth? Mastering all the Neanderthal skills of both sexes while still a kid, inventing new things, not losing anything in the emotional side of her life with all that intellect, even being the only one who sensed the earthquake! What's the challenge then? What could make an effective plot with a protagonist like that and an antagonist like a small bit of carefully blacked tough-cured hide? Ayla always wins and is always best, I'm sure the slowest reader would have grasped that after about five repetitions, and we get scores.This is the kind of book some people recommend to young readers, thinking that the repetitions and the spelling-out are intended for them. In fact both are bad for them, disabling them as interested and active readers and conditioning them to like bad literature in general. Too bad there's so little fiction in prehistoric setting - this wouldn't have been nearly so popular else.***Update: I had a look at the reviews for further books in this series and found out that there is no mention of the fate of Broud's clan. What? At the end of the book, their position is almost as critical as Ayla's. What would they do next? While the clan consists of not very well-developed, frequently interchangeable characters, I was disappointed to find that even the author herself cares nothing for what would become of them. Only the blue-eyed girl matters, that's right. This would make me rate this book further down if that were possible.
I hate Broud, with everything inside me, I hate Broud and I hope his character dies a thousand deaths in the sequel. (I hate Broud!!)

I have very mixed feelings about this book. On one hand, I'm tempted to read the next book in the series to find out what happens next (although I probably won't). But on the other hand, I'm deeply disturbed by some of the subject matters of the book. An author who writes about pre-history has a definite choice about how to create her characters and what they do because there are no written records to tell us how they behaved. The subject matter of the story is interesting enough. A young girl whose clan was killed in an earthquake is rescued by a The Clan of the Cave Bear whose physical traits are very different from her own. The Clan of the Cave Bear has great difficulty in accepting the girl, Ayla, because she is very different from them. She has blonde hair and blue eyes, isn't as short and stout as they are, uses more language than them, laughs and cries, and doesn't have the collective memories that they have. While eventually accepted by most, she's constantly loathed by Broud who is slated to become the next leader of the clan. He constantly showers her with hate and violence, despises her upcoming status as medicine woman, hates the luck that follows her, and wishes death upon her.The author has obviously done much research in order to show the medicinal qualities of the plants of the region and the weapons used by the people of the time. However, sometimes the book reads more like an encyclopedia when the author chooses to emphasize some of these things. I like the attention to detail, but it seems extremely awkward in places. It also disturbs me that this author chose to emphasize infanticide and the physical and sexual violence of cave men toward their women. The clan seems to take infanticide and abuse as normal. What really made me angry was that the author seemed to try to write the violent scenes in an erotic way that I've only ever seen in this series and the Outlander series. It disturbs me that, in both series, rape is commonplace, accepted, and eroticized. What's even more disturbing is that nobody seems to mention them in their reviews of the book. Someone said to me that these violent acts are placed in the book to show the people moving away from violence. However, I didn't see any evidence of anyone reacting negatively toward the violence except for Ayla. I had difficulty determining if the author was writing from a feminist perspective that assumed all men to be sex-crazed and violent or if the author was glorifying these things. I'm not sure how to rate this book because I hated some components of it, but I want to find out what happens in the next book as Ayla searches for people of her own kind. So I'll rate it thusly:*Cliffhanger ending = 4 stars*Unnecessary violence toward women = 1 star*Research = 5 stars*Awkward use of research = 1 stars*Story idea = 4 stars*Fantasy elements = 1 starAVERAGE = 2.6 stars, rounded DOWN to 2 stars Eh.

I read this book when I was a teenager but don't remember much about it except for "assume the position." I am not sure exactly why I decided to read it again after so many years but I think it is probably because it is so much of a classic that I wondered what it was really about. If the goal of an author is achieved in writing a Siri's when she gets you to read the second book, this first book seems to have been a success for me.I don't remember much from the one anthropology class I took in college. I think I got a C. But the experience of looking back to the Neanderthal days I found quite interesting. And the mixing of the two generations of humanoids I found fascinating. Having them meet indirectly and having them walk a mile in the others shoes was an interesting thought piece.The book begins with an earthquake and ends with an earthquake. And our Advanced heroine Who wandered into the land of the cave people as a naked five-year-old was cast out as a teenager to seek out her own people having already born a child and become an honored medicine woman. A short and crowded lifespan played havoc with our three score and 10 so I guess the evangelicals of the world must think very little of this series. To have the lead character not only be a woman but an incipient feminist definitely scores some points. She gets a fair amount of criticism from other readers for being at the cutting edge of so many advances in human evolution. I am willing to cut her a good deal of slack since this is a relatively short time frame. Although a series of six books is relatively long it is nothing compared to the length of time these changes presumably actually occurred. The idea that the Neanderthal brain contained significant stores of memory practically at birth made me wonder what divides scientific fact from fiction in this book.I listen to this book in the audible for Matt and also but the second book in audible. According to the book the cave people had relatively few spoken words and much of their communication was by sign. It was hard to convey this effectively in the book of course since the book is all about words. But overall I enjoyed reading the book. I am simultaneously listening to The Brothers Karamazov so you can see how something comparatively simple might be welcome!

Anthropology has always interested me. In college, I earned a degree in Anthropological Sciences, studying subjects like paleoanthropology, archaeology, primatology as well as as hunting-gathering societies and human culture. It was this interest that led me to the Earth's Children series, when I recently glimpsed "The Land of Painted Caves" (book 6) in a new releases newsletter. Intrigued, I decided to pick up book 1, The Clan of the Cave Bear.I'd never read a historical fiction like this, featuring Neanderthals and prehistoric anatomically modern humans as the main characters. That already earns this novel a full star in my book, since I've seen nothing else that tackles this time period. The first thing I noticed was that this book was very carefully researched. There were some inaccuracies, most notably anatomical ones, but I also remind myself that this book was written in 1980. As well, Auel takes many artistic liberties with Neanderthal social behaviors, especially with those relating to gender roles. But on the whole, the facts were well done. While much of the paleoanthropological facts in the book are mostly of a general nature, reading it did bring back some fond memories of school, like the time I got to learn to knap my own flint tools (it's harder than you would expect, by the way).But that's as far as my enjoyment of the book went, I'm afraid. I think I understand what the author was trying to do, showing the straightforward way prehistoric hominins might have communicated or conveyed their thoughts, but after a while the repetition and the internal dialogue really grated me. I also felt the story was good, but it was told in a long, drawn out manner, using mostly descriptions of the characters' every-day life and relationships. Ironically, at times it felt like I was reading an ethnography instead of a novel.

I've read this book a long, long time ago, I was 11 year-old when the book was published. I still remember clearly some passages and - lo and behold - I have the book yet. Ayla was the first bad-ass heroine I came upon, and I loved her. She was caught in between times/places where/when Cro-Magnon interacted with Neanderthals. Is this historically correct? I have no idea. And really, I didn't care at that time.There are things that are meant to be experienced just once. I remember a time when I was a kid and I did a ballet presentation. The theatre seemed huge and with a swarm of spectators. I was impressed - with everything and with myself - and a bit scared.When I took my daughter to dance in the same theatre, years later, I had a total different experience - of course! - but what stroke me more was, Is this the enormous, bright place that made me fell so important and yet so small?Yes, it was. Although it was a very, very happy moment for me as a mother and it was great to have had that experience so I could share it with my daughter, I have to confess, for my inner child it was a disappointment. I still wanted to think I had been in that immense theatre, an important ballet dancer, who didn't miss a step and received a round of applause. But I digress.The Clan of the Cave Bear is not a book on paleontology; it is not a historical book. But I loved it. The five star rating is based in my impressions from decades ago and I wouldn't be able to do an accurate review of it today. Yet, I won't spoil the fun I had at that time, re-reading it with my older eyes so I could review it better. I'll keep treasuring it.If I hadn't read it before, were looking for a nice, uncompromising reading, and had time, I would give it a try again.

Such a joy to revisit a beloved book from my teenage years. I must have read it a few times in quick succession back then, but had not read it for a good fifteen years.It is easy to get lost in Aylaâ€™s world. She, a girl of the Others, survived an earthquake and was found my a group of Neanderthals and is adopted by them. She grows up as she struggles to adher to their Clan ways.This is such an interesting unique book. The author clearly has done thorough research into prehistoric humans and she painstakingly explains many of the methods those people may have used in their daily lives to make tools, find food or treat hides. On occasion this distracts from the story, but most of the times it enriches the image of Aylaâ€™s world.To share Aylaâ€™s story is to feel like you are walking a path your own ancestors may have walked tens of thousands of years ago. She lives in a changing world, where one era is ending and another beginning. You cannot help but feel Aylaâ€™s frustration as she attempts to adjust to living amongst a people so different from the ones she was born to.Of course it is the authorâ€™s imagination that depicts the Neanderthals as a people reliant on traditions and history, but who is to say that they were not? The way she portrays them is believable and you feel a real warmth towards them and a sadness to know their story has long ended.The last 30 pages are heart wrenching and I am not too proud to admit I cried like a baby. This book holds a special place in my heart.

The deeper I got into this, the more I realized how much it sounded like a fairy tale/Disney movie in several ways:  orphaned by tragic circumstances taken in death of a loved one evil leader/villian prone to evil doings when he doesnâ€™t get his way oppression of the little guy death curses super superstitious super jealous spirit guides, like fairy godmothers, who grant wishesSo you see, it does read like a fairy tale in a way, but not one youâ€™d read to your little innocent darlings by the light of the moon. Mainly because it also had: young girl with poor body image repeated rape violence toward women free sex cannibalismOkay, okay, some of that too is found in darker fairy tales. I'm sure I could add to this list, but nothing else is coming to mind.There were also a couple of scenes that stabbed at my memory of an old Mel Brooks movie I saw way back when. So I had that playing in the background of my mind, and because of that, it was a little hard to take this seriously. What I did find interesting was the science of this. I am sure this book took an incredible amount of research and knowledge. I appreciated the feeling of having learned something I didnâ€™t know before; that is one of the many reasons I love historical fiction. But I didnâ€™t love this.

Maybe it's because I love learning about the prehistoric people from which we came. Maybe it's because I love stories about strong women who survive almost unbeatable odds to become even stronger. Or perhaps it's because there's something about the daily doings of people, doings with which I can relate, where mothers love their children, fathers protect their families, elders teach the young. These are the ordinary doings of living that have breached the bigness of time from 25,000 years ago to the present and continue today to provide a peaceful place for us. I really don't have much desire to figure out why I loved this book, but I did.Others might look down on The Clan of the Cave Bear. It's not a classic, in the truest sense of the word. Sometimes Auel gets a bit flowery with her words. This is why I didn't give it a five star rating. Yet, the story drew me in and drew me back, day after day, to where I intentionally slowed my reading to make it last longer, even tho I was aware that there are five additional sequels. I'm already dreading the time when I've finished all six books and have to let Ayla go.I've sorely missed having this kind of book, the kind that ENTRANCES. For me, this is precisely what feeds my love for reading.

I absolutely loved this book. Due to it's setting, it was extremely unique and refreshing, and I found most of the characters realistic enough to be drawn to them (with the exception of Broud, who was a little over the top in his childlessness). The book itself reminded me strongly of Outlander in that it was set in a place I was rather unfamiliar with, and also in the perhaps overzealous account of plants and their medical uses- which I personally found fascinating. Though much research was put into this book, it is clear that Auel took liberties in the construction of her Cro-Magnon and Neanderthal depictions, which I was more than willing to overlook considering that this was a.) published in 1980, and b.) a historical fiction. Besides that, that the whole story was fascinating to me. I was completed compelled by this Ice Age world, and Auel definitely earns a token of respect from me for even tackling this time period. Definitely reading the next in the series, and soon.

My mother was an avid reader and a stunted fan of archaeology. She took me to the King Tut exhibit in the 1970s, and she owned this book. I first read it in high school and I credit this book and our trips to the Field Museum in Chicago as the inspiration for my BA in anthropology and religious studies, and my many years working in museums.As an anthropologist by training, what really fascinates me is the idea of being dropped into an entirely alien culture or environment, and how do we as humans adapt and survive. This book shows how Ayla is dropped into a world as absolutely alien to her as to modern people. We see this world and learn about it through her eyes. We get to see how she learns to adapt, how she suppresses her natural self in order to be accepted and even loved. We get to learn how these people live along with Ayla.I periodically reread the entire series and I never get tired of it.

Het duurde een twintigtal pagina's vooraleer ik gewend was aan de schrijfstijl, maar eens daaraan gewend werd ik het verhaal van Ayla ingesleurd. Wat een tijdperk om als vrouw in op te groeien en te leven. Die constante onderdanigheid die ze moeten houden jegens die mannen, het zou niet aan mij besteed zijn. Aan het personage van Broud heb ik me zo vaak geÃ«rgerd dat ik werkelijk het gevoel kreeg om hem er eentje tegen zijn oren te draaien. Geweldig als een boek me zo in verschillende emoties kan brengen. Deze reeks is me aangeraden Door verschillende mensen en ze hebben geen ongelijk. Ik ben dan ook heel benieuwd naar het tweede deel en hoe het verder zal verlopen met Ayla.Schrijfstijl: 3,5/5Cover: 4,5/5Plot: 4/5Originaliteit: 4,5/5Leesplezier: 4/5Spanning: 3,5/5Psychologie: 3,5/5TOTAAL: 3,9/5

This is one of those books that sucks you in from the start. I enjoyed feeling a part of the time that the story is told in, and learning about how things were done. I did not notice the typographical errors that some other reviewers have commented on. The story really does take you to a different time, allowing you to feel like you are there. I could smell the smell the woolly mammoth on the big hunt, and felt the shock of the other clan members when Ayla took out the sling and saved the little one's life. I could feel the isolation when she was sent away, and shed a tear at her sadness when her family was gone. I highly recommend this book to anyone who likes to be transported in their reading and wants to feel a part of what they are reading.

I really have mixed feelings about this book! Parts of it I liked...and I liked a lot of the characters. However....the author could have made this a shorter book...she's very repetitive! I felt like the Clan acted like cave people some of the times...gestures and thoughts on sex and childbirth were very fitting, but the conversations and many thoughts were very "today" and it made the book awkward for me. I listened to it and the narrator was sometimes annoying when things were said over and over. I think I enjoyed learning about all the uses of plants and animals for medicinal and healing purposes the most. I think I'll wait awhile and maybe try the second book in the series and see if I like that story better!

I read and could see and understand, the world of people more than 35,000 years ago; civilization is such a thin veneer. I couldn't put the book down because the Author brought this world to life for me. Take away everything we rely on and fail to appreciate and you will still find the same heart of what we are, good and bad.Five year old Ayla is left "really" alone when her parents are crushed to death when their cave collapses during an earthquake. Another clan of humans happens upon the injured little girl who is close to death almost a week later; what would you do? Forget about race-- what would you do if she was another species?

Schitterend eerste deel van prachtige boeken over de prehistorie. In de prehistorische wildernis van het Europa van 35.000 jaar geleden vindt de Stam van de Holenbeer een klein meisje. Ze is moederziel alleen; haar familie is bij een aardbeving om het leven gekomen.Hoewel het kind niet tot het volk van de Stam behoort, ontfermt Iza, de medicijnvrouw, zich over haar. Ze krijgt de naam Ayla, en Iza onderwijst haar geduldig in heelkunde en kruidenleer. Jean M. Auels serie De Aardkinderen vertelt het verhaal over het mysterie van het ontstaan van de mensheid en de harde strijd om in de prehistorie te overleven.Dit deel en deel twee vind ik de beste uit de serie.

I got the unabridged version of this book out of the library on tape to listen to while I was painting several rooms in my house one summer. I loved it. I thought it was a unique look at the author's idea of what life could have been like for neanderthal and cro-magnon man. Jean Auel obviously did a lot of reasearch for this book and it comes out in her descriptions of flora and fauna and what certain herbs were used for and how things might have been cooked, etc. A truly fascinating story about a cro-magnon orphan girl raised by neanderthals, and the hardships she endured for being different. I have read it several times, and enjoy it every time.

...The combination of meticulous research and an emotionally powerful story has made this novel into something specially. Although I have read the other books in the series and enjoyed them, I don't think any of these books quite manage this same mix. I can't honestly recommend the other books in the series but The Clan of the Cave Bear is an unusual novel. Not without it's flaws perhaps, but still something of a landmark. One of those books one ought to have read. It works fine as a standalone so even if the others do not interest you, give this one a try.Full Random Comments review

I first read this series when I was about 10 and I have been wanting to read it again for some time. It was one of those books that made a great impression upon my young mind and I was curious to see how it read as an adult. Surprisingly I also really enjoyed it the second time around. I have been disappointed in the past with re-reads of my childhood faves but this time the book has stood the test of time. The author has a gift in describing the natural world that I particularly enjoy. The characters are well constructed and I guess I have always had a soft spot for an independent strong woman main character such as Ayla. Five stars for an engaging, pleasurable trip down memory lane.

This book is one of my all time favorite books. Jean Auel's Earth's Children almost drove me insane - there was something akin to 8 years wait between each book. This, the first one, was my favorite. The fact that I read this eons ago and still remember the characters as if I just read it yesterday is because it touched me that deeply. Ayla, Jondalar, Broud, Brun...all live at the dawn of civilization. Their day-to-day lives interested me to no end. Auel put incredible thought and research into what our long ago ancestors did to survive. It is a book I highly recommend.

I read this series in high school. It was one of my mom's favorites and I just picked Clan of the Cave Bear off her pile one day and never looked back. There is no other series of books that I've read that could compare to these. You fall right into the prehistoric era, and you truly feel like you are there. Since I was reading this in junior high and high school, the sex scenes were also a plus. I'm sure if I re-read these books now I'd find the sexual parts a little to over the top for me. I've stated before that I like to leave some things to the imagination.

This book was so completely tedious for me. It felt like half the time I was reading a not-very-interesting Wikipedia description of the first humans and their way of life, and the rest of the time I was left with poor writing and even worse dialogue. I can't believe this book was so popular .... Was there nothing to read in the '80s? I had expected something amazing, as I had heard so much about this book, but was sorely disappointed. Not recommended.

I loved this book. It took me over a month to read because I was so engrossed in every single word. I loved the story, I loved the characters and I definitely love that it's a series. I can't wait to see the movie even though I have heard it is not so spectacular. It was nearly perfect but it took me a long time to begin to comprehend who the names were referring to, which was slightly distracting.

I first read this when I was about 12 years old, and loved it then. I re-read it just now, 25 years after my initial reading of it, and loved it just as much. A book that stands the test of time. Based on our ancient ancestors, and a strong woman who helped our race succeed

Unlike any other book I've read. I really enjoyed reading about The Clan but could have done with less descriptions of plants/climate etc. overall a great read and I'm looking forward to reading the next one to find out how the story continues.

My longstanding rule is to file a (non-erotica) book under "quit reading" should it contain both the phrases "heaving alabaster bosom" AND "mound of pleasure". One or the other, ok; both puts it in the trash. And "Clan of the Cave Bear" went into the trash.

Upon reflection, I think this book relied entirely on a great premise. I'm not so sure about the plot, and a lot of the writing was pretty heavy handed. But what an interesting way to think about the origins of modern humans.
loved the whole series!!!!
A four-star read when I read it, a couple of decades ago. I did like it enough to try to keep going in the series, but really, the part I actually liked, was the first part of this first book....
