I'd say 4.5/5, but I gave it 5 because we can't do 1/2 stars.I can't believe I took so long to discover and read this book. I vaaaguely remember buying it almost twenty years ago when I was in college and halfheartedly trying it, but it did not grab my interest at that time.I recently picked up a battered copy from the '80s at a thrift store near me for $.19 when they had a sale, along with several vintage romances and scifi. When I posted the haul to my Facebook, the consensus was that I start with Clan of the Cave Bear. I listened to the hivemind, and I'm glad I did! This isn't necessarily a traditional review, so much as a running commentary of all the thoughts I had while reading it. It does include spoilers, so fair warning if you are interested enough to read on.**********The writing style kind of felt like reading a textbook that was engaging and interesting instead of dry and boring, which sounds weird to say, but for me it totally worked and felt natural.The book wastes no time in getting to the point. By the second page, Ayla is already an orphan. I was like O_o.I know the author did a lot of research, and that shows in the loving detail she incorporates. Not gonna lie... At times, it was a little tedious where descriptions of wildlife and the changing seasons were concerned, but I just skipped those paragraphs if I got tired of it. I did enjoy immensely the long descriptions of herbalism and medicines, as I found that very relevant to my own interests. Though she did tons of research, I am sure it is not entirely historically accurate, but I don't know a historical fiction novel that is. To me, a book like this needs a little creative license, particularly since I view our understanding of early humans as an inaccurate and interpretive science, anyway. Whatever stretches there might have been were worked in pretty seamlessly with no glaring oddities (at least for my limited knowledge of this topic).Based on the subject matter, I knew there would be rape in this book and I was a little worried since usually I avoid media that involves it. However, I must say that it was nothing like when we are exposed to rape today in the media, particularly in movies or TV. The scenes involving or discussing it were violent, but not as bad as I had feared. I think because, for once, it was rape that seemed to make sense, given the context in which they were living and the circumstances that led up to it. That sounds horrible, like I'm condoning it, but that is not what I mean. I just mean that the textbook, matter-of-fact writing style of this book coupled with the fact that the rapes did not seem gratuitous turned the descriptions about them almost into neutral pieces of data that were simply being documented, rather than unbearable acts of violation that kept happening over and over for no reason other than to be violent and dramatic. I am probably not explaining myself very well here, but oh well. I wanted to address it, particularly since it may be a trigger for some people.Reading this book was exciting for me because it is the first time in recent memory that I really had no idea what was going to happen and I really felt that ANYthing could happen to anyone. It is hard to explain. It was both predictable and suspenseful at the same time somehow. I knew vaguely what would happen (I knew Iza would die in this book or that Broud would end up raping Ayla and getting her pregnant, for a couple of examples, because all that was predictable), but in the larger scheme of things this whole world was so unfamiliar to me that I just had no idea where it was going to go and what adventures they would have.I think some people dislike Ayla, claiming that she is a Mary Sue, but I did not think that about her at all. I did not find Ayla annoying, too smart for her own good, or unrealistically intelligent. For one thing, she might have been intellectually smart (because she was biologically made that way, which is hardly her fault!), but socially... she struggled a lot and wasn't too smart in that area. She often risked herself and her loved ones through her inability to adapt to the clan ways because her intelligence prevented her from functioning within them (she questioned things too often and was not a sheep!) and the concept of relinquishing who she was just to "fit in" was not in her nature and so had to be learned for survival reasons through tough lessons. As a result, she made big, cringe-worthy mistakes and she wasn't perfect, all of which made her more relatable and, if I might go so far as to say, human. ;) For another thing, although she was favored at times and often clan law did not seem to apply to her, I felt the allowances they made for her made sense in the context that Brun kept coming back to: what was best for the clan, not because they were necessarily favoring her. Yes, Ayla made some big leaps:- Constantly saving children from disaster through her eccentricities and earning the respect of the clan (I almost said "ingratiating herself with the clan," but I don't feel that's accurate because it was her nature that drove her to do those things and not a desire to please the clan)- Figuring out that babies come from intercourse and are not acts of immaculate conception (like the rest of the clan thought; according to the clan, sex was for men to "relieve" themselves whenever they wanted as a dominance thing, whether the woman wanted it or not, though sometimes they enjoyed and encouraged it)- Catching on to ideas (like counting) quickly and surpassing the adults (even Creb) in many aspects like that- Teaching herself to hunt after watching a clansmen give a small child one lesson- Learning all of the herbalism knowledge despite not having the programmed memories for it- Basically inventing the braBut, to me, it was only natural for her to do all that, given her increased capacity to think things through and the basic concept of necessity being the mother of invention. I have no problem with how smart Ayla is because 1) she does have flaws and 2) that is the point of the whole book. She is a link to the future of the human race; it would make no sense for her to be stupid and make no big leaps. What Ayla is doing is no different than the leaps that the great thinkers of our time have made; no one calls Albert Einstein or Steven Hawking a Gary Stu, for example. I could see how Ayla could have been an extremely unlikable, unrelatable protagonist, but I felt the author did a great job of skirting that possibility altogether through the sensible way that everything fits together and culminates. I can think of three VERY annoying protagonists off the top of my head right now who are much better examples of Mary Sue types.I was kind of surprised about how spiritual it was. I am not sure if that was invented for the purposes of Ayla's story, or if there is evidence that early humans really believed in spirits and totems and if they were the center of their life like they were in this book. Like I said, I have limited knowledge in this area.I kept being thrown off guard by how young the characters were. Iza was considered old, but she was only 26 when she died (12 years younger than me!). Creb, Iza's oldest brother and the spiritual leader of their clan, was maybe 30 when he died and considered seriously ancient. Brun (the middle child and the only one still alive) is I'm going to guess 28 or so, but is no longer the clan leader because he's "too old" for the job. Even trying to allow for the fact that they were younger than expected while I was reading, I kept thinking Creb was like late 40s/early 50s, Brun was in his early 40s, and that Iza was maybe mid- to late-30s. Nope. They were at least 10 years younger even than that. Children were mating and having babies at eight-years-old and basically acting like adults who nowadays would be in their late 20s/early 30s. Their entire lives were lived in approximately 20 years and, if you made it past that, you were considered old. Really hard concept to grasp and understand, but I found it fascinating.My biggest criticism is that there were two major bits of endless waffling: one surrounding Ayla deciding whether to be a hunter and the other surrounding Brun deciding whether Broud should be a leader, especially since it was patently obvious that even though both of those things were really bad ideas, they had to happen so the story could go where it needed to go.After finishing the first book, there was no closure and it was obviously left as a (really good) cliffhanger. But, rather than feeling annoyed, I am left with wanting to know what happens to Ayla next, as well as Durc (her son), Broud (I keep hoping he will be killed off in a satisfying way), Brun (who I really grew to like a lot), and the clan itself. So, I plan to read the next two in the series, but I'll likely stop after that, given what I've read in reviews about the final three books.

This is a great book. I have read numerous online reviews obsessed with questions of anthropology, of evolutionary biology vs. creationism: Did the author get it right about the Neanderthals and Cro-Magnons? Is this thing just a racist tome, where the blonde-haired girl represents the brilliant conquerors of the future, and the darker Neanderthals are dying out? And what about the occasional non-fiction-style exposition wherein the author explains bits of science or anthropologyâ€”how dare she write with the dispassionate tone of a scholar! You canâ€™t put that stuff in a story!But why write a nasty review for a book that is so easy to enjoy? Novelists traffic in words and voices. The ones spending so much time reading scholarly works are naturally going to employ the voice of a scholar from time to time. Can't a novelist expect a literate reader to be accustomed to such a voice, particularly when used sparingly? Why put so many rules on literatureâ€™s most free-wheeling genre, the novel? Last time I checked, writers could do pretty much anything in a novel, provided the story works and the readers are willing to accept it.I disagree with elements of this book on a most fundamental level. I canâ€™t even explain how faulty I find the bedrock principles of so-called â€œevolutionary biologyâ€ and anthropology (though the quotation marks are a clue). But taken for what it is, I enjoyed this book. When I got to the end, I began reading the opening chapters of book two of the saga (included by the publisher to entice readers to buy the next book). I was engaged: What will happen to Ayla? Itâ€™s a good story. And not a bad illustration of an evolutionary point of view that, agree with it or not, is practically a religious origin story for many, many people. I was happy to find this window into another way of looking at the world.This book is entertaining from beginning to end. I cared about the characters. There were moments of humor and sadness, triumph and defeat, pride and joy. There were touching moments of love and tenderness, moments of hurt, and periods of despair. There is anger, hate, betrayal, and cold-blooded vengeance. There are heroes, villains, and moments of suspense that often made the book hard to put down. Thatâ€™s a significant accomplishment for a book set in a bleak ice age, based on core beliefs I do not share, and with a dawning sense (the further I read) that the ending might not be satisfyingâ€”because it would leave me in suspense. (Though it contains a neat little ending, the final page is something like the hated phrase from television: to be continued. Even with these negatives, I had a blast reading this book--at home, at lunch, on treadmills at the gym, at the car repair shop...I canâ€™t figure out whatâ€™s wrong with some of these reviewers. If you never read non-fiction, not to mention an occasional scholarly article, do you really have the fluent comprehension of written English required to write a reliable book review?I have to add that the author's research is astounding. Her grasp of plants used for medicinal purposes is extraordinary, not to mention the details, recipes practically, explaining how these herbal remedies, poultices, teas, and more are prepared and administered. Clearly she sought out experts on such things. Thus, the book becomes filled with the sights, sounds, tastes, and smells of all the plants of an ice-age world. Such detail adds a great deal of vivid imagery to the novel--this is a place you can see, taste, touch, and smell. But of course, these details also make the book a legitimate resource of its own. I would not exactly choose the book as a survival guide, were I to be lost during the summer in a valley in the Alps. But it is an amazing read if you have any interest in understanding the medicinal practices of aboriginal people the world over.Is this an accurate reporting of the medicinal practices of the Neanderthals? No. These are suppositions. For that matter, did the Neanderthals really have generational memories encoded in their brains? No. That's a theory based on extrapolations derived from skull fragments--maybe their brains were bigger in the memory area, and therefore.... Were Neanderthals unable to cry as portrayed? Were they unable to laugh or use a spoken language? Did Neanderthals even exist? Or are scientists still so desperately trying to find that missing link? It is my belief that anthropologists make far too much of far too little evidence.But so what? It's a great book, taken for what it is. Finally, I can't believe how many people I have run across on the internet (YouTube, mostly) writing comments about naming their child Ayla, or about the fact that their parents named them Ayla, and it meant so much once they read the book. Named after a fictional character? You do not hear THAT every day.

An entertaining tale with some irksome things.World: I will say that the world buidling for this book is pretty stunning and the best thing about this book. I donâ€™t know how scientifically accurate it is but itâ€™s entertaining. The depth and the well thought out nature of the book is really well done and it is internally logically consistent which I enjoyed. I did not like however that the writer would constantly somewhat break the forth wall and explain to the reader the comparisons of what our modern idea and what the characters in the book would be feeling, those moments, which are often, would take me out of the book and also point out to me some character and story issues I would have (but more of that below). Mostly absolutely amazing, but not so great when the writer talks to us.Story: The story is fun, itâ€™s a tale familar if you read enough pulp adventure and books set in this era, set in the old west, just any era where different cultures clashed and you had a character that was thrown into a different culture, this is that tale. It immediatly reminded me of Tarzan of the Apes by Burroughs and also Dances with Wolves the film so this is what you are getting but set in the pre-historic with Cro-Magnon and Neanderthals. Itâ€™s an interesting tale and the story plays out like the books above it where the main character goes through learning the ways of the tribe, is challenged for her oddness and also is seen to excell because of that oddness, itâ€™s all there. There is a level of Mary Sue to Ayla the character when sheâ€™s surrounded by Neanderthals and Auel constantly talks to us to remind us that Ayla is surperior and talks of the modern times even of how eventually the Neaderthals will die out, itâ€™s in these moments that I find myself losing my love for the book when it jarringly yanks be away from the story and into the writers exposition. As I said Ayla is a Mary Sue and much like this archetype of character it canâ€™t be helped (more below). Overall the story is interesting, itâ€™s fun and expected but the writing is sure and steady and leads readers by a firm strong hand. The book plays out much like the first half of Tarzan of the Apes where little Tarzan is found by a mother, raised and even finds a rival and then leaves the tribe, this is that story here. Itâ€™s good, but itâ€™s a tale as old as time.Characters: Ayla is an interesting character and much like most fish out of water and the odd man out stories she lives and dies by how sheâ€™s written. Her situation is interesting so that will always serve her well and this is the case in this book. Her learning the ways of the clan and how she and the clan interact with her is the main part of the story and a main part of her character. Her finding her place and identity is a main part of her arc and itâ€™s a slow and steady one. Yes this book was feminist for itâ€™s time and honestly is a bit heavy handed, but itâ€™s like that because sheâ€™s a Mary Sue. Just like Tarzan and John Carter and Mowgli these characters are raised by savages and animals and itâ€™s the human side of them that wins out and always makes them superior and nearly always wins because of who they are. Itâ€™s fun, but this level of always winning eventually does get old. The struggles that Ayla faces here compared to the things she wins at is skewed and thatâ€™s just the way these characters are. The rest of the cast is interesting and falls well into the archetypes of these types of books with the mother the father, the proud and wise leader, the young angry rival, the clan that is wary of Alya and eventually stands by her, itâ€™s all here and serves itâ€™s purpose. Itâ€™s solid and expected stuff.I enjoyed the book, itâ€™s not perfect but the world building was good and the world the book takes place in is interesting to me so I think Iâ€™ll keep reading.Onward to the next book!

Way back in Junior High or perhaps early High School, I remember going on a family trip down to Myrtle Beach. Dad (the driver) had grabbed the audio cassettes of this book from the library for the trip and I fell in love with it. Upon returning, I grabbed a copy of this one to read for myself, and then the next book in the series, and then the next one... This was the first series I purchased with my own money and was the beginning of my collection that would one day eclipse 1000 books (now sadly gone)Coming back to the series to read again decades later, I had doubts if this would be as good for me now as it was in my teen years. Well, those doubts can be put to rest. This book is sooooooo good. Jean Auel is excellent at helping you step into the world she is building. Some might say that her descriptive narrative is a little too much information as she describes each and every flower or plant along with their medicinal uses or as she explains how the hunters will stalk and catch their prey but for me it gives a touch of reality. I don't think anyone is as well researched for this type of book as she is. The book is not just a description of prehistoric neanderthal life. The plot itself is very gripping and well paced. It begins with a five year old girl who loses her family in an earthquake and after near starvation is found and adopted by a clan of "flatheads". It then follows her life over the next 6 or seven years as she learns and grows and has adventures unique to a human child being raised by a group who live and think and act in completely alien ways. The only reason I have not given this five stars is because I could not get past the fact that this girl at the oldest is only twelve. I understand that in this time and age life was lived quicker. People matured earlier and the old folks in this book are late twenties up to an "ancient" mid thirties. Even still some absolutely horrible things happen to this girl and while it fits into the story I could not get past the fact that she was ten years old, or later eleven years old when they happen. It is not OK for anyone at any age to suffer some of what she suffered but for a ten year old child... It just reminds me that not all cultures are created equal. Good and evil are absolutes and not necessarily culturally determined.Anyways, this is an excellent book. I understand that there was once a movie made from it. I never saw that movie but I would strongly recommend reading the book instead. I cannot imagine even the greatest producer with an unlimited budget and perfect actors being able to come close to touching the things that make this such an excellent masterpiece.

I sort of understand the hype around this series. And by hype I mean the intermittent popularity of the series with customers at work. Colleagues have said they only continued to the third book in the series and after completing this one, I don't think I'm in any rush to read any of the others. The book got repetitive for me. There were a few instances where a character would explain something in one situation and then explain it again in another situation. There were even instances where the narrator explained lengthy things more than once. I know the following is an irrational reason to dislike this book in particular but I can't help it. I just couldn't deal with the de-elevation and treatment of women in this book. There is supplication, rape, abuse etc. I realise its set in the stone age and these were normal behaviours for cave men and early Neanderthal, so yeah. Irrational dislike. I also struggled with the amount of wilful killing, both of animals and babies in this book. They'd kill things "for the spirits" or if it came too close to the cave or the fire or the skins they were drying. Then they'd kill babies if they were twins or triplets. Or if they had a slight deviation in appearance or were as they called them "deformed babies" Ayla had a baby that looked like her (an early human similar in appearance to modern man) and they wanted to kill it. Just annoyed me a lot, but is also probably a result of them missing parts of what we know as the modern brain. And a good explanation for why they died out. The writing was decent enough, but I struggled with the execution of the concept itself. In general, not really a series for me.

3.5 stars.I find the study of early humankind fascinating. In this novel, Auel weaves a story of a homo sapien child who is adopted by a clan of Neanderthals. After a major earthquake, Ayla (a toddler), was seriously wounded and almost dead when the Neanderthal clan stumbled upon her while looking for a new cave to settle into. Ayla is taken in by the medicine woman and becomes part of their clan. Ayla follows in her adoptive mother's footsteps and also becomes a medicine woman. She identifies with her adoptive clan more than she identifies with "The Others" (homosapiens) although her physical characteristics are distinctly different. She cries tears, laughs, and has advanced language skills which are lacking among the Neanderthals. After she is brutally raped by a Clansman (a common occurence in clan society), she gives birth to a son (Durk). The Clan believes he is deformed because he is a mix of Neanderthal and homosapien, but Ayla is allowed to keep him.Although the writing was a bit simplistic and redundant at times, the storyline kept me enthralled, and I may move on to the next one in the Earth's Children series.

When this book was released in 1981, it seemed like everyone I knew read it - except me.Â  Even as the years went by and I found myself loving historical fiction, I still didn't bother to pick it up.Â  Somehow, I couldn't imagine a story of cave-dwellers would interest me.Â  Luckily, I succumbed to readingÂ The Clan of the Cave Bear this month when a book challenge required the word "cave" in the title.Â  I figured so many rave reviews couldn't be wrong.Â  And they weren't.Approximately 25,000 years ago, the ancestors of our own human race lived at the same time as the Neanderthal race, which eventually became extinct.Â  Author Jean Auel ponders the mingling of the two races in this text.Â  After an earthquake kills off all the member of her clan, young Ayla is left to fend for herself.Â  After a narrow escape with a mountain lion, she stumbles upon a clan of Neanderthals and is eventually adopted into the clan.Â  Auel manages to create a timeless human story.Â  Fitting in, growing up, love and loss are themes the author weaves throughout this excellent novel.Â  I'm so glad I finally read this one!

DNF'd 10% I just don't think this one is for me. I just feel that either you make a historically accurate book or you make a fantasy book. Either you do the first and yeah, it makes sense that its a horribly misogynistic society where women are oppressed and not allowed to do anything. Or its the second and there should be no reason to have it that way, right? I just felt very annoyed while reading this. I also hated how the woman literally couldn't hunt because that's just how their brains work. Give me a freaking break. Also the description of young boys just hitting puberty having sex with girls who haven't even started their periods yet is so disturbing to me on so many levels. Just no. And even if that is whats happening, must you describe it? ğŸ¤¢

I enjoyed this book much more than I anticipated. I thought cave men would be a boring read, but hell, I was sucked right in. Jean M. Auel did an insanely impressive job immersing the reader into a highly complex and intricate world in which survival is not guaranteed. Ayla may not have been born into the clan tribe (she clearly looks different, she's lean, tall, and has blond hair), but she begrudgingly gets their acceptance after she is taken in as a child by the clan's medicine women. Ayla learns to communicate with them using movement, not sounds, and learns the clan hierarchy and tools for survival. It's a coming of age story set in the ice age and it is way more engrossing then I ever thought. I'm honestly tempted to continue on with the series! The ending was a bit of a shock!

This book just goes on and on and on We get it! Ayla is not clan. Bloody hell I think this is the most repetitive book Iâ€™ve ever read. That fact is probably mentioned in every single page and this book is 502 pages long. Itâ€™s just the same old rubbish all the way through. I thought at one point Ayla was going to die and I honestly was so excited. The love from Iza is nice, I find Brun a good leader. Broud is portrayed well and is a good olâ€™ mean character that everyone loves to hate. It was just so repetitive and it was tendinous to read. This was recommended by a co-worker as her favourite book...... I wonâ€™t be listening to her again

A really good read undercut by a pretty weak ending. It was a little cliffhanger-ish (and predictable) after 450-odd pages.Parts of it reminded me of Quest for Fire, the 1981 movie about interactions between a Cro-Magnon tribe and various outsiders. The tip-off that this was written by a woman and Quest filmed by a man:Among Ayla's inventions: The world's first sports bra.Among Ika's (the character played by Rae Dawn Chong in the movie): The world's first blow job.

I can tell already that I'm not in the mood for this book. My grandmother on my mom's side recommended me these a long time ago a said "read these when you're older, you'll like them", and I think she's right, but right now I don't have a lot of patience when it comes to books so I'm going to wait until I get that patience back to read this.
Read this and then stop here. Its pretty amazing. But I read it at 12 or 13. I need to reread.

My mom loved this book in the 80's. I've been intrigued by it ever since, but recently I finally decided to read it in her memory on the anniversary of her death. See my blog post for more on that and on the first half of the book: http://examinedworlds.blogspot.com/20...I may not be entirely objective given my reasons for reading this, but I can honestly say that I loved this book. It's a surprisingly deep and emotionally poignant imagining of women and men not that different from ourselves who lived about 30,000 years ago.Although this book was well researched for the time (circa 1980), in my blog post (http://examinedworlds.blogspot.com/20...) I also wrote about the aspects of Auel's story that have turned out to be inaccurate.But, as much as I love the paleoanthropological aspects of the book, this is a novel, not a textbook. And as a novel, it works. I love the style, the characters, the plot, and the bigger ideas.The style isn't everyone's cup of tea. If you're one of those readers who complains about authors who violate some sacred "show don't tell" rule, then Auel's detailed descriptions of flora, fauna, inner thoughts, omniscient narration, etc. is going to bother you. I think that sort of thing is essential world building, which I appreciate as a science fiction fan. Auel isn't just telling a story, she's transporting the reader deep into a forgotten world of the past. I also find Auel's style to be occasionally beautiful, especially her descriptions of the landscape and passing of the seasons.The characters are fleshed out people not entirely different from characters you meet in the 21st century. That most of them are Neanderthals makes little difference. Part of what's so amazing about this is just the thought that there were living, breathing women and men who lived, loved, and thought just like people today. As a Cro-Magnon adoptee into a Neanderthal clan, Ayla is a permanent outsider, but she forms deep and complex connections with members of the clan, especially her adoptive parents, medicine woman Iza and Creb, who is the clan's shaman or Mog-ur. Both are fascinating characters in their own right. Ayla's main nemesis, Broud, is a misogynistic bully who would be as at home on some 21st century MRA/Gamergater/Rabid Puppy blog as he is on a pleistocene mammoth hunt. The ways in which Ayla challenges and navigates her patriarchal society is, I imagine, one of the things my mom identified with most, especially as a single mother pursuing a business career in the 80's and 90's.The plot is engrossing, even during the several stretches when it seems like not much is going on (there's always *something* going on, even if it's more to contribute to the world building than the plot per se). The conclusion is, while not entirely surprising, entirely heartbreaking.Besides all this, the novel raises a lot of questions about gender, culture, differences, and what it means to be human, whether of the modern or Neanderthal variety. Ayla and Creb have some deep thoughts (and a few hallucinations) about what to make of the differences and relations between the Clan and the Others. Can they get along? Must one die for the other to live? Can there be future for both in some sense?As much as I love most things about the book, I admit that I'm a little disturbed by the hint that a blonde-haired blue-eyed person is part of a superior race. You could say that this is merely a trope to highlight Ayla's permanent outsider status, but now that we know that blonde hair and blue eyes are much more recently developed traits, this is factually inaccurate in addition to its touch of subtle racism. There is also frequent violence against women, but it's not usually too graphic and does add to the intentionally(?) troubling aspects of the plot. For a series that people often describe as soft core cave man porn, sex is usually only mentioned in this book. There are a few brutal rape scenes, which are disturbing but not terribly graphic, but that can't be what people are talking about. I guess the fun sexy times must happen in the later books.Speaking of the later books, the near-universal consensus seems to be that they take a huge nose dive in quality after the first book. I'll probably pick up the second one just to see what happens next, but I'll keep my expectations low.In the meantime, I am in awe of Auel. The research may be outdated and there are some problems, but over all The Clan of the Cave Bear is an engaging, well-written novel that somehow makes bestseller material out of paleoanthropological speculation. Auel must be a Mog-ur to have made this magic happen.
2,5 stats

Este libro lleva tantÃ­simo en mis estanterÃ­as pero es que siempre lo miraba y me decÃ­a a mi misma dos cosas: 1) me gustara? 2) es tan tremendamente gordo que me pillara mucho tiempo!. Este libro llego a mis estanterÃ­as gracias a una compaÃ±era de trabajo que siempre me decÃ­a que estaba leyendo este libro y que le encantaba la niÃ±a de esta historia, que estaba totalmente enamorada. Ahora la entiendo. HarÃ¡ unos 6 aÃ±os de esa primera conversaciÃ³n y un dia fui al fnac y me traje los tres primeros, luego fui trayÃ©ndomelos todos poco a poco pero muy poco a poco ya que la gente manosea mucho los libros en esta tienda y estaban tan mal cuidados. Al final me traje todos menos el ultimo. Este aÃ±o he decidido no hacer ningÃºn reto, fuera del reto got que acabo el mes que viene. Y he decidido leer tochos , ya que siempre los voy apartando y leo pequeÃ±os o no superiores a 500.Bueno he leido algunos pero siempre por el reto got. Bueno el caso es que este tambiÃ©n lo agarre porque necesitaba un libro que tuviera un oso en la portada y no tenia en casa ninguno excepto este asÃ­ que decidÃ­ que era el momento adecuado. Y no he podido enamorarme mas, es de estos libros que tras vas ir leyendo la historia, ves como la autora describe, y como hace que sean los personajes te vas enamorando poco a poco y no puedes dejar de leer. De echo este libro lo empece creo que por ahi por diciembre y lo deje simplemente porque segÃºn los retos que tenia que cumplir solo me dejaba al dia la posibilidad de leer 13 paginas diarias y no lo estaba saboreando lo suficiente, siempre era un "ya?tengo que parar ya? pero si yo quiero seguir leyendo". Refiriendome a la historia a sido muy bonito ver como esta niÃ±a Ayla va creciendo poco a poco y se va introduciendo en un clan que no es el suyo.
