Es cierto que parece que esta niÃ±a esta un poco maldita porque todo va de mal en peor, y cuando ve un poco de luz al poco otra vez todo vuelve a ir mal. Durante la historia no para de perder gente a su alrededor, algunos me rompieron el corazoncito. La historia tiene personajes de todos los estilos, dulces, crueles, tristes, etc. Te puedes sentir identificado con multiples. Quiero destacar altunos Iza, una madre que aunque no es su verdadera madre trata a Ayla como si lo fuera, estando para ella en todo momento. Crug no es su padre pero es tan agradable ver que hay posibilidad de que un hombre tan duro pueda ablandarse tanto al tener un beber cerca. Brun un gran jefe que llevare en mi corazÃ³n siempre, me ha parecido tan increÃ­ble como era duro, blando, amable, siempre cambiando cuando se necesitaba. Y por ultimo seÃ±alar a uno de los personajes mas crueles que he visto en mi vida Broud que pena no poder sacar a un personaje del libro y poder quemarlo vivo!. Voy a empezar a contar las cosas que no me ha gustado tanto y que han hecho que en vez de ponerle un 5 redondo le haya bajado un poco la nota: Resulta que esta autora pues a veces repite una misma idea varias veces, es capaz de hacer que Ayla se de cuenta de una cosa y la repita varias veces, y eso a veces pues no es que se ponga pesado pero si dices Â¿otra vez?. Otra de las cosas que he visto que me ha chirreado un poco es que ha alargado el libro, al repetir cosas y poner cosas poco interesante que podÃ­a haber dejado tal vez en 300 paginas. Por estos pocos motivos le he quitado un punto aun con la esperanza de que el siguiente sea tan tementramente que supere al primero.

This book is set in pre-history and is about a clan of Neanderthals who adopt a young girl from a different species â€“ Homo Sapiens. The story is an interesting one of survival, tradition, male â€“ female relationships and how a tight knit small community hangs together for survival. Life in the Neanderthal clan is fascinating. Their rigid code of conduct, their survival techniques and their reliance on faith is prevalent on every action each member of the clan makes. The most interesting part of the book was the reliance of the clan on spiritual guidance. It gives an insight of life before organised religion and to an extent, also why religions were so readily accepted. The clan is extremely patriarchal, which in itself could have been realistic, but its depiction left me unconvinced. The main attraction for me was the question on how and when patriarchy became so deeply entrenched in human psyche. In the book, it was already codified into human behaviour around 35000 years ago. Iâ€™m not convinced it happened so early but itâ€™s an interesting question the book raises. Most of the characters are brilliant and it was a pleasure to read about them. Each of them have a different function to fulfil in the clan, and the fulfilment of those functions also makes them who they are. It is brilliantly depicted at every turn how different they are to each other and the interpersonal relationships are also very interesting in such a hierarchal setting. However, when it comes to Aylaâ€™s character, the author missed the boat. Ayla is a mixture of Emmeline Pankhurst, Alexander Fleming, Hippocrates, James Bond, Jim Corbett, Charles Darwin, Socrates, Marilyn Monroe, Leontina Albina, Michael Phelps and the average housewife. Then she becomes God and is today known under the names of Buddha, Jesus, Allah, Krishna, Yahweh ... well, not really, but almost! She is an ace swimmer, ace hunter, ace cook, ace doctor, ace everything! Ayla can survive anything at all and she is oh, so strong, that no amount of abuse can break her. Even being serial raped leaves her disinterested and bored as if she were just brushing off flies. She rescues two babies (TWO!) â€“ one might happen to anyone, but TWO babies. She can survive all alone in a cave by herself â€“ in WINTER â€“ twice! She also discovers how the reproductive system works and single-handedly sets the course of evolution. Okay, Iâ€™ll stop now and talk about the cave lions and cave bears and woolly mammoths who roam this world. The author has beautifully brought forth the appeal and character of these amazing creatures which are now extinct. I never thought I would enjoy a story that has so much hunting in it, but I really loved the hunting scenes. The way the animals and plants were used with absolutely no wastage was intriguing. The relationship between early humans and nature is beautifully depicted. The respect shown to these animals by their hunters is now only a distant memory in our history. The author has really drawn a way of life that has been practically done away with today. In spite of the Mary Sue main character, it is an interesting book which deals with some very interesting questions about life, leadership, survival and relationships. I do highly recommend it as it was an enjoyable read. Even the main character is toned down a little once we reach the last part of the book, which leaves you with a sense of believability.

I really wanted to like this book, especially after all the good things I'd heard. However, unfortunately, this was just not for me. Way too long, too much description, not enough dialogue/action... Won't be reading the other parts of the series. Simply not the read for me.

The Clan of the Cave Bear, by Jean M Auel, is an enthralling tale set at dawn humanity, that will captivate within it's first few chapters. The story follow the life and trials of Ayla, a young, Cro-Magnon girl, as she develops into a young woman, following an earthquake that separates her from family, leading the girl to find refuge within a Neanderthal clan.The book sets a slow pace from the very beginning and continues much the same throughout the remainder of this 502 page novel. Though written well for the most part, it does occasionally stumble. Details are frequently reiterated, which quickly becomes tedious; and let's not forget those large excerpts of heavy info-dumping where Auel will Linger on fauna or the surrounding landscape, resulting from the Author's renowned in-depth research of this time period. This, although noticeable and often irksome, surprisingly doesn't detract from the overall narrative and despite the intermittent periods of lag, there is plenty along the way to keep you turning the pages.As a reader you'll quickly find yourself drawn into the intricacies of Clan life and it's memorable characters who dwell within the Cave. You will grow attached to Ayla's adoptive mother, Iza and her brother, the menacing Mog-ur (Creb); come to respect Brun's wise and stoic leadership; and detest the cruel actions of his successor, Boud. Though, with names like Zoug, Vorn, Oga, Norg and Ebra, it can sometimes prove difficult to remember who belongs to which hearth when it comes to some of the background characters.This novel really shines bright when it comes to the dialogue, or lack-there-of, between characters. The followers of Ursus communicate via hand gestures and this proves to be one of the many cultural barrier between the two species, as the young Ayla struggles to suppress her instinctive nature and adopt Clan behavior. You'll find yourself relating to her struggles as she battles between what comes to her naturally and what is expected of her.My only grip: There isn't a semblance of plot to be found, seemingly. This book never sets a clear direction for it's main character and leaves you feeling as though you're just there existing with the Neanderthals, taking each day (or chapter in this case) as it comes. Though there is no shortage in terms of world-building, with plenty to delve into, you may find yourself left wondering where this series is going and if it can sustain itself.I pray that Auel's sequel, second in a series of six, 'The Valley of Horses', can build upon the foundations that she has so expertly built in her debut, The Clan of the Cave Bear. This series shows a lot of promise and is worth a read simply due to it's uniqueness and setting in a relatively unexplored time-period.

Allora. Io giÃ  conosceva Ayla e giÃ  avevo una vaga idea di cosa la aspettava e cosa doveva succederle, quindi non ho avuto una grande sorpresa sul finale. In ogni caso.Questo libro ha dei punti forti: ha una bella trama, con colpi di scena sparsi, uno stile piuttosto piacevole e scorrevole, e dei comprimari molto ben costruiti e molto affascinanti. IN pratica, il libro merita anche solo per la divina triade Iza, Creb e Brun, tre fratelli porcellini che si vogliono tanto bene e che hanno tutti e tre la stessa aura di rispetto e saggezza. E, diciamocelo, per le descrizioni dei vari espedienti di sopravvivenza e delle usanze del Clan. Se si trattasse solo di questo, direi WOW.No. Non dico WOW. Dico porcami dioca mavaffa grazie agli Dei ho finito. Sostanzialmente per due motivi. Il primo, purtroppo piuttosto rilevante, Ã¨ che la Auel, che benedetta donna si Ã¨ fatta i suoi bravi studi ma ormai purtroppo sono superati, si dilunga troppo nelle descrizioni dei paesaggi, dell'ambiente naturale e tutto il resto, che sembra un catalogo della vita dell'Homo Neanderthaliensis. E' un elenco di nomi di piante. Ora, Jean, ho capito che hai studiato, non c'Ã¨ proprio bisogno che mi ripeti ogni due pagine del boschetto di nocciole o dell'infuso per curare il mal di denti. Per caritÃ , tutte cose utili, ma Ã¨ un romanzo, non archeologia sperimentale. Salvatemi dalla caparbietÃ  dei nani dal catalogo di preistoria, c'ho giÃ  dato de esami e mi Ã¨ bastato.Il secondo sono Ayla e Brud. Questo romanzo ha uno sviluppo sorprendente: all'inizio ami Ayla e odi Brud dal piÃ¹ profondo del cuore. Alla fine Brud ti fa quasi pena e Ayla ti sta sul cazzo: a parte il fatto che lui ti deve stare antipatico, Ã¨ costruito apposta, e la cosa mi fa girare, ma poi lei sembra scamparla sempre. E' il ritratto sputato della Mary Sue: dicasi Mary Sue il personaggio femminile perfetto che la scampa sempre e sa sempre tutto piÃ¹ degli altri, Ã¨ piÃ¹ speciale di tutti gli altri e tutti la amano tranne lo stronzo di turno. Che in questo caso, letteralmente, non Ã¨ cattivo, Ã¨ che lo disegnano cosÃ¬: Brud Ã¨ uno stronzo costruito ad arte per fare risaltare lei ancora di piÃ¹. Ed Ã¨ una cosa insopportabile.Alla fine dÃ² un voto piuttosto alto perchÃ¨ comunque come romanzo non Ã¨ male, se riesci a farti piacere Ayla e salti i cataloghi da villaggio del Neolitico. Preferisco comunque La Valle dei Cavalli, lÃ¬ almeno ci sono membri a ogni piÃ¨ sospinto.

How do I end up reading creative books by terrible Oregonian authors? I finished this book only because it was obvious the research was well done and the author had a good creative vision for it. But the writing was painful. Even more painful than 'dies the fire' because at least the action in that series was great. Dies the fire was written by an amateur writer who focused all his energy on creativity and action and despite his mistakes it was a fun read. In this all the energy of research and well developed characters was thrown out the door with narration and obvious statements. I regret reading Clan of the cave bear. The author is not an amateur writer and she chose to lecture on Neolithic culture and she chose to bounce constantly between views and voices. Only for the respect of the well developed characters did I finish the book. There was also a weird dimension where the narrator would describe the root cause or fullest line of info, for example the narrator voice spent time describing brain sizes and flower types of the ancient past, as well as tuberculosis and telepathy. There is no way the the characters benefited from this. Also, as a language the whole clan used sign language and one syllable words, yet they communicated words and emotions they didn't have words for. It was a consistent plot hole for me.  Maybe it was an editor that messed this book up. because I could tell the structure was good and the author did excellent research and character back stories, but instead of introducing a character through the eyes of a main character she would jump first person into a random character that will never matter again. And after a scene she would consistently summarize the whole scene with a single sentence which disrespected the reader and made the whole paragraph pointless. So either she is just a terrible writer or an editor asked for odd summaries frequently and it ruined it. Either way there are better books out there to read.

This is one of those books I'd heard of growing up and felt compelled to read because of its unique setting. I don't know many other books whose main characters are cave people. Before reading this, I read up a little on the author and her research and was impressed with the amount of time she put into this endeavor, as well as her commitment to stick closely to the truth or at least what was believed to be the truth back then. I read all 500 pages of this tale sort of waiting for something to happen. Weird enough since stuff happens to Ayla, the tall, thin, big boobed, blond girl heroine, all the time, but yet, nothing made me feel anything. Yes, the book is vividly alive with descriptions of scenery, shrubbery, fauna, flora, scents, weather, and of course, the author's dedication to honing a "real" story is evident and applauded by this writer here, but damn, I still feel the bruise on the back of my head where Auel beat the tale into me. How many times can one read the same passages over and over again placed in different parts of the book and felt by different characters? The struggle for Ayla to be accepted became so redundant, I wanted her to pack her shit up and go look for the Others about halfway through the book. I don't know if at the time Auel wrote this, she was trying to write an affirmative book about a female heroine, but if she was, here's my 2014 opinion on it: FAIL. Oh anyway, I don't feel like ranting about this. Not worth it. But, if you are looking to be transported to another time and place and maybe learn a thing or two about plants, making tools, and skinning animals, and if you are vaguely interested about our ancient ancestors, this is a "classic" I suppose.However, I still feel I had a much better time with Quest for fire.

It's been a long time since I've sat down and completely devoured a book. You know how it goes. You crack open the book, and from the first few words, you're hooked. You can't stop. You stay up until 2 a.m. even though you have a work appointment bright and early the next morning. You keep the book in your purse so you can sneak in a few paragraphs at an especially long red light.That's what this book was for me.It was an absolute treat. From the first sentence to the last, I enjoyed every single word Jean Auel wrote. In fact, I'm thinking about adding her to my Christmas card list. I love her that much.The plot was fantastic. (A young girl left to fend for her own is assimilated into a family group, resulting in all sorts of conflict.) The setting was insane. (This book is written in pre-historic times. Like, mammoth hunts, cave dwellings, the whole shebang.) The characters are brilliant. (They have personalities that practically jump off the page.) The climax blows your mind. (Not going to tell you, because that would ruin it, and I don't want to do that to you.)The best part of all, though, in my opinion, was that Ms. Auel created a world that was essentially a biology lesson. Seriously, I wish my science teacher had described neanderthals and cro-magons like this when I was in school. I might've passed the class.In conclusion, let me say this. When I die, I hope God sits me at the table with Ms. Auel, Ms. Diana Gabaldon and Ms. Margaret Mitchell. I think that would be pure heaven.

Clan of the Cave Bear is the story of Ayla, a 5 year old Homo Sapien who is stranded in the wild after an earthquake killed her family. She is adopted by the Clan (i assume, considering the time period, that this is Homo Erectus. i don't believe it's mentioned in the book) who take her in and teach her their ways.i was a bit put off when first opening this book. Ms Auel uses very clinical language in her narratorial descriptions, which i found distracting. once i realized that this was on purpose however, i got used to the language and actually found it extremely interesting.Auel goes into incredible depth regarding everything from landscape & character descriptions to the flora & fauna characteristic of the time period. some of the most interesting tidbits i thought were her explanations of the Clan-folk themselves; her reasoning behind the extended occipital lobes, memory and extrapolation, the differences between the minds of H. Sapiens and H. Erectus. as (not even) a layman of human evolution, i found it very compelling.the story itself is a bit dry at times, riveting at others; i found myself struggling in the middle of chapters, waiting for a good place to break and go to bed, only to be sucked back in by the end and continuing right on into the next. while i'm not sure i would rave about it, Clan of the Cave Bear is quite good, and i look forward to continuing the series.

I bought this book along with the rest of the series (bar one) on a whim. It looked interesting as the series was almost complete. My wife took the lead and read the first book. I was soon confronted with empty supper tables and an empty space next to me in bed at night. This was a sure sign that she was caught in the ban of the Earthâ€™s Children. When she was again communicative to the outside world, she said: â€œYouâ€™ve just got to read them; they are just what you would love.â€ If anyone knows my hates, likes and loves, it is she. This said I opened the book and started to read. The first hundred pages went slowly and I was constantly looking for the moment I would get caught up in the tale. It was along time in comingâ€¦. I donâ€™t know if the strange and confusing names were the cause or maybe I just wasnâ€™t inspired by the repetitive and boring life of the hunter/gatherer. Interactions between Neanderthals and the Cro-Magnons were almost certainly a common occurrence but the plight of the young girl Ayla didnâ€™t initially inspire me. Child mistreatment and slavery isnâ€™t a very inspiring base of existence but thankfully the circumstances changed as the story progressed. Probably not having a mental picture of the heroine slowed the process. When I substituted the image of Eila Adams (one of the regular anchors from Naked News) onto the main character, my imagination took off.

This, when I received it as a gift was not my sort of book at all, it took me forever to pick it up. However once I did I was glad I had, I flew through it and rushed out to get the sequels, of which 4 more were available at the time. I enjoyed each book, though I did find some points a little tiresome by book 5. Really? Is there anything Ayla doesn't know more about that=n anybody else, can nobody else invent some life changing method/tool? Also I felt Ayla didn't develop very much in the last book it felt a bit forced and could have been smaller. The sixth book that I waited a good few years for I hated, pre-ordering the book and rushing to get it as soon as the shop opened. Disappointed didn't cover it, it took me months to finish it, I just wasn't interested. I am now re-reading the whole series to see if it is any better the second time round. I felt the author had obviously put a lot of time into researching to be able to accurately describe parts of the book and I enjoyed how much detail she had put in. As somebody who is very ignorant in that part of history, it was probably easier for me to enjoy than somebody who is more educated in the area. Overall I really enjoyed this first book and the characters within it as a fiction book with a storyline that interested me and main characters that kept me reading.

I am starting my umpteenth re-read of CotCB. This book is engrossing, and I believe that many people write it off prematurely due to the subject matter. I assure you, I was skeptical the first time I read this book. Cavemen. Ok. The way that the lives and experiences of the characters, Ayla (main character) especially, are described in this book is just amazing. One of my teachers gave me this book to read shortly after it was removed from the high school reading list (I believe) and let me know that it was removed because the subsequent books in the series were too racy to be high school reading. Well, I was reading VC Andrews and my mom's romance novels at the time, so let's revise that to say typical high school reading. As I have read the entire series, I will go ahead and agree with her. The rest of the books in this series are half smut to say the least! This book though...if I can just make a plea with you, reader of my review. If this book has ever crossed your path....if you have ever seen it and thought "blech" or thought "meh" - just give it a try! I am a firm believer in not wasting your time on a horrible book, so, you can always DNF! Ayla deserves a chance. Also, I am in no way speaking out against smut - just might not be what you are thinking when you think "cavemen". I'm going to repeat my plea here. Give Ayla a chance. She's an amazing woman!!

This is one of my favorite books of all time. I've read it so many times that I have the first paragraph committed to memory. I can remember the first time I read it, I was maybe 12 or so, and I could not put it down. I remember feeling shock, awe, fear, sadness, and warmth throughout the book, and I was inconsolable at the end. Ever since, I have wanted to name my daughter (assuming that I have one) Ayla, after the main character. I just really love the premise of this book, the meeting of Neanderthals and modern humans, and I fell in love with the characters (I even had a one-eyed cat that I named Creb). I did not, unfortunately, love the sequels. I read them, of course, b/c I care so much about Ayla and what happens to her, but I did not care for the turn that the sequels took. They got a little smutty, almost a romance novel, each one worse than the preceding one, and I didn't like the way that she made Ayla so perfect. Ayla was a compelling character before, Auel had no need to make her so...well, I said it- perfect. Like, it turns out that she's the first one to tame horses, and lions, she invented the sewing needle, and the spear thrower, and she's the most beautiful human on Earth, etc...it just got to be too much, and it aggravated me. Which is sad, b/c I love Ayla so. Well, Valley of the Horses wasn't bad, I liked it OK.

I've read this book twice before, as far as I recall. The first time was probably eighth grade? The second time was probably high school? I don't remember exactly when. I was surprised at how much of the story was completely familiar to me. I was even more surprised I read it when I was young and wasn't completely disgusted by the sex talk ("his pulsing organ"). Oh yeah, and that one section of the book where she was continually raped for like a year.Yeah...There's a lot of repetition and explaining. Almost the entire book is blocks of paragraphs. The story manages to make a ton of bad things happen to Ayla, but her inner monologue made me cringe every time it came up, so I did not find her easy to sympathize with. I realize now that I remember the EVENTS of the story, but the characters were completely forgettable. There were entire story arcs that I remembered but had no clue it involved other people. Every character had the same voice, and they never really grew. Broud was introduced as a jerk and stayed a jerk. Brun was introduced as a thoughtful leader who took his time, and stayed that way. No one evolved.

Este libro me encanto mÃ¡s que nada por la Ã©poca que retrata. Creo que es el primer libro en mi vida que habla del Neanderthal y del cromagnon asÃ­. Retrata todo a detalle, realmente me vi en esa Ã©poca, realmente olÃ­ la humedad de la cueva y sentÃ­ el frÃ­o de los inviernos.Lo mejor de todo es que ademÃ¡s los personajes cautivan, todos. Brun, Broud, Ovra, Creb, Ayla, Iza, todos cautivan, tienen bien definida su personalidad y cada uno a su forma se lleva una parte de mi o yo me quedo con una parte de ellos.Me gustaron varias cosas, una, la Ã©poca, dos los totems, tres el problema social que representÃ³ Ayla para el clan y el tiempo que les tomo aceptarla no se aleja mucho de lo que HOY nos toma aceptar las cosas nuevas, digan lo que digan, nos parecemos mucho a esos hombres de las cuevas. Es probable que mÃ¡s de lo que creemos.Me gustÃ³ todo, no le doy todas las estrellas porque no es el Ãºnico libro de la serie, y quiero ver si el que sigue es igual de intenso que el clan del oso cavernario.Se lo recomendarÃ­a a cualquier persona que se este iniciando en la aventura de la lectura.

The Clan of the Cave Bear remains one of my all-time favorite books. The story is rather simplistic, but it's elemental to anyone who has ever felt like an outsider. When I discovered it in my teenage years, I was just coming to accept that I was gay. Living in Idaho in a society that viewed me as a pariah, I immediately connected with Ayla and her struggles to conform to a culture that was as alien to her as she was to it. This is not a quick and easy read by any stretch. It's rich with lavish detail, often lapsing into long, descriptive passages about the flora and fauna, or the invented culture of the Clan. I personally never balked at this, but it may not be to some readers' tastes. Ultimately, though, the message--that one can rise above a lifetime of ostracism and emerge with a sense of self-worth founded on familial love--guided me through my formative years and still serves me today.Later books in the series resonated less with me, but this one... this one will always hold a special place in my heart.

I recently bought a house so I've had a lot less time to write book reviews. Well, I've also read a string of crumby books which almost choked me of my passion to read. That is until now. This is the best book I've read in months.Firstly, it's about ancient man and neanderthals. It's a lot like THE WORLD'S OLDEST VAMPIRE TELLS ALL except without the orgies... and it had a good story. But the best thing is that this book stars an excellent strong female character. The biggest problem with the modern strong female character is that it is written, for the most part, by third wave feminists. This means that string female characters are written as men. This is not only dumb but it's boring. Women are not men. They're not worse or better than men. They are their very own wonderful thing and though the MC in this book did best a man or two at traditionally male activities she is still written as a female. Not a strong chick that acts like a dude but a genuinely strong and interesting WOMAN... Well, cave-woman...HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

It took me a little while to get into this book, but I think that's because I was reading it on and off in my lunch breaks at work and could only read a couple of chapters a couple of times a week. By the time I was about 150 pages in, though, I was hooked.I loved Ayla's character and the way she evolves during the story. It is a journey the reader really does take with her and I was full immersed in her tale. I'm not surprised this book was turned into a film as it really lends itself to the screen with interesting characters and plenty of dramatic action. I'm keen to try to check out the film version in the future and see what it's like - even though it was a box office flop.But back to the book - great story-telling, believable and well-rounded characters and a big finale make this a series I look forward to continuing with. This is highly recommended and I shall be adding the rest of the series to my wish list.

So this has been on my list of stuff to read for an incredibly long time - I even borrowed it from work a few times, intending to read it, but was caught up in other stuff or simply put off by the length (anything over 350-400 pages is 'long' in my book) - finally forced myself to sit down with it for a few hours and get stuck in, and I was engrossed almost immediately.Still took me a week to finish, but when I did read it I couldn't put it down and had many a night with less sleep than I ought to have because I had been up til 3am reading. More like a prehistorical drama than a fantasy novel, the amount of research and effort that has been put into it beggars belief. As a self-professed dinosaur/anything prehistorical nerd, I learned some stuff, and that's impressive. There is a bit of a fantasy slant to it, with a bit of magic and mindready stuff going on, but yeah read more like a caveman Neighbours. Not that that's a bad thing at all.

I value the honesty of portions of this novel very highly. My mother was brutally held hostage and repeatedly raped when she was 18-19. Reading about Ayla gave me a place to understand some small portion of what my mother went through. My mother also was able to move beyond her rape and rapist to lead a full and satisfying life, though the effects will always be with her, like with Ayla. Speaking of the "unspeakable" helps both those who've experienced such harm and those who haven't to have a shared "vocabulary" if you will and being able to relate to a relatable fictional character who went through something very realistic to ease the difficulty of the conversation helped us many times over.The visceral way in which these characters live and breath has been with me for over 22 years... and I am grateful for them and to Ms Auel for sharing them with us! This is probably my all time favorite "what if this is what happened" ancient times series ever.

This book gave me huge highs and lows. I loved the setting, and the way I felt I knew the characters, even the secondary characters. Jean M. Auel's description of life in prehistoric Europe is engaging, both full of awe and danger. The mystical side of the beliefs of the Clan is interesting and adds an additional layer to the characters. What robbed the book for me was that it suffers from 'Chosen One' syndrome. While the main character, Ayla, is a really sympathetic and interesting character. She does suffer from loss and setbacks, but it felt that every other chapter was her bucking the system and sticking it to the man. While it was inspiring and made me root for her, after a while it became expected. I love stories of people changing their society by challenging norms, but I'm surprised this prehistoric character didn't invent writing, gunpowder, and architecture. I don't plan on reading the rest of the series.

The story is basically about a people in prehistoric time; the first in a series of six books. This is where the main character at only 5 is orphaned due to a huge earthquake. The author goes into a lot of detail into the prehistoric animals and plants and the ways of prehistoric peoples. The story is good and interesting to read. But they think and talk like 21st century people in a prehistoric settle. I don't think that is very realistic. But that is not why I gave it only one star. I cannot recommend a book that is porno in nature. The author is very into graphic sex (even for the animals)and it is a total turn off to me. And bringing 21st issues of "the pill" into the story only they use a plant brewed into tea. I guess you can skip the graphic sex and it is then a good read but I would not knowingly pay for a book with this sort of crude in it. To me the author has prostituted herself in order to sell her book. I have put her on my "Do not read this author" list.

Ayla is an outsider among the clan. Found and adopted by the medicine woman of the clan during their migration, Ayla finds herself the target of an ambitious man hoping to become leader, training to be a medicine woman in her own right in hopes of earning some status within the caste, and challenging the set gender roles of her adopted culture.I was impressed by Auel's research on flora and fauna. The first time I read this I was in seventh grade and stuck home convalescing from an injury. I had read everything I owned and found this in my mother's room. The home-study program that I was forced into because of a lack of wheelchair accessibility facilities at my middle school was impressed that I had not only read it but could speak on a variety of themes I found in it. They moved me to the senior English class.

This book is easily 4.5 *'s.First thing's first, I FINISHED THIS BOOK! I'm so proud. Ok, moving on... I really really enjoyed the story of Ayla as she grows up and learns to live with, and within the rules of, the Clan of the Cave Bear. I loved most of the members of the clan, especially Isa & Kreb, but even the interactions with the antagonist (I have no idea how to spell his name, you know who I mean) helped to round out all the characters and elucidate the nuances of the Clan's structure/heirarchy. All the differences/similarities between Clan and the Others as observed by Ayla vs Clan people made the overall story especially interesting. My main complaint here is about the audio version. I really disliked the way that each chapter/section ran into each other. A breath by the narrator or a few seconds silence in the recording would have helped a LOT, IMHO.

I heard someone recommend this book because of the descriptive food scenes in it. The story is set in prehistoric times, so all the food is hunted and gathered which does make for very tantalizing food scenes. As a historical novel, this book does a really good job of describing life in prehistoric times as well as drawing you in through the story. She gives you a good description of Neanderthal and Cro-Magnon humans that was very interesting.Ayla, the protagonist, is a kick butt female role model to any girls or women reading the series. At times the actions of the antagonist got a little repetitive and annoying but I understand why Auel did this. Overall, I really enjoyed reading The Clan of the Cave Bear. This book has also really made me want to learn about foraging and herbal medicine, just a heads up.

I read it because someone I know told me it was her favorite book from her youth. Although I enjoyed reading it, I couldn't help feeling its' undertones of white supremacy. Ayla is considered to be Big&Ugly, but she is actually beautiful with long straight legs. She is much, much smarter than Short&Dark Clan people. I know Auel wanted to display the difference between Neanderthal and Cro-Magnon, but does Ayla have to be tall, Golden hair, and blue eyed? About 45,000 years ago, when they co-existed, as far as I know it was not common for Cro-Magnon to have light colored eyes. It started as mutation. To portray as tall white human as superior to short stocky brown eyed sub-human seems to me quite insulting because it gives American young readers that impression. I was uncomfortable in the beginning, but when I started to read #2 of Earth's Children, it became disturbing.

Hooked from page one, I enjoyed the entire exotic, exciting, and unpredictable ride with The Clan. Few books have stayed with me in vivid detail like this one. Auel's painstaking re-creation of this inter-evolutionary time, with an unlikely female heroine at its heart, was visionary for its time, and holds its magic even today - perhaps more so, the further we travel into the digital age. While the magic diminishes with each sequel, they all warrant a read if you must know what happens next - at least read Plains of Passage. However, I must admit that after two attempts, I am unable to get through the final book of the series, released two years ago. Even so, this has not dampened my enthusiasm for The Clan of the Cave Bear. Immensely satisfying, this remains one of the few books I recommend to everyone!

It's been many years since I've read this book but I remember it as being rather lame. It was like any other romance novel only it happen to be set in pre-historic times. The characters are purely good or completely bad, with a stereotypical heroine, like most stories of this genre. I realize many women like books like this as I think they like to fantasize that they are the incredibly beautiful but deeply misunderstood heroine. I also think the book is somewhat racist as the intelligent heroine is light skinned and blonde while the "bad" people are dark and stupid. No offense meant to those who liked it. Romance, or "fluff" books as I call them, have never been books that I enjoyed and this one in particular I really thought was a bunch of rubbish.

Primero que nada. LeÃ­ este libro porque fue un regalo, realmente no se si de haberlo visto lo hubiera comprado, lo hubiera leÃ­do pero... Â¡menos mal llego a mi! que historia mas hermosa, profunda, interesante. EL solo hecho de ser contada desde un tiempo mucho mas antiguo de lo que alguna vez pude recordar, es increÃ­ble. Te abre la mente a una realidad de como fue el mundo antes, cuando eramos apenas una especie que surgÃ­a.Los lazos de amistad y amor, y familia, al igual que el odio son descritos en este libro de una manera Ãºnica, no creo que exista mejor libro para empezar este aÃ±o. Â¡excelente!Ilya, gracias, muchas gracias por este hermoso regalo mi amor. Â¡ahora quiero el segundo eh!

hmm,What to say about this one.Well first off I did like it and please don't get confused by the title as it is not great.The story is good and I enjoyed the read very much.I usually don't explain the story in my reviews but maybe I will have to in this case.The main female characters coming of age and survival in the hard world that she lives.It has some very interesting situations and interactions between two human species living on the planet at the same time.I did not like everything and that is why only the 3 stars but 3.5 is not out of the question as the 2nd and third books are equal as interesting Sadly the last two are not so good :(

Historical fiction is a genre I try to avoid as much as I can. It's just not my cup of tea. This book was different. I wanted to read it and see whether I'd like it or not. It took three pages, then I knew I was gonna love this book. Even though this is a pretty long book, it was a pleasure reading it. I'm so glad I decided to pick it up. I had to get used to the writing, because it did have some very long and describing parts, but when I got through them, it was all good. There were a lot of characters and I had a bit of a hard time keeping track of all of them. Uba, Iza and Broud - I liked all of them. I know you're supposed to dislike Broud, but for whatever reason, I didn't.

Read this in my freshman year of high school and found it to be fun and captivating. Despite knowing, even at the time, that it was far from perfect, and that Ayla is something of a 'Mary Sue', she is hardly the real character of the story. It's the world, its overall cast of people, mythos, and practices, that occupies the foreground here. It is palpable and vivid, highly energetic. The rest of the books are not as good, but that doesn't matter. This is a standalone. Of course I saw the 1986 move with Daryl Hannah before reading it though, ha.

I read some reviews that said some negative things about this book. I, however, really liked it. The only part that bugged me was the five or so pages about stone tool making. I just could not convince myself to care.The major characters go through good amounts of character growth, the story-line flows very well, and it brought me to tears at the end, a feat not many books can accomplish. It's not perfect, and I don't know that I want to read more from the series, but I am happy to have read this one.

Extraordinarily sensual, perspective and perceptual storytelling. The young Cro-Magnon Ayla, faces hardships, trials and tribulations, being reminiscent of destiny's determination to plummet her, into depressive defeat. I found myself quickly indulged in the meticulously described environment, making fictional attachments to certain clan-members (Creb and Iza, #neverforget) and being sympathetically swayed, by the easily lovable characteristics of Ayla, and watching her develop throughout hindrances, as well as celebrations.

The Clan of the Cave Bear by Jean M. AuelThe clash of civilizations, one ancient and a new and upcoming race of men is embodied in a deceptively simple tale. The story of a young child rescued by a troop of Clan members driven from their home by the same earthquake that stripped the girl child of her home and hearth. Simple charity driven by love and a nurturing soul bring the girl of the Others into the Clan's home. A Mother's love, striving for acceptance, jealousy and hate come together to weave this gripping tale of survival. Recommended.

This is a wonderful storytelling, giving us an educated glimpse of what early Homo sapiens and Neanderthal could have been liked. Of the six books in this series this one and the next, are the strongest of the series. There is so much great research that has gone into these books, that that in itself is a wonderful. Not just research of early humans but how the earth was like in that age of time.

For some reason I couldnâ€™t define, the recent election made me want to revisit this book, which I first read about twenty years ago. Now that Iâ€™ve finished it, I think I understand why I felt pulled to read it again. I think something in my subconscious knew that I really needed a story about a brave, resilient, resourceful, brilliant woman who triumphs over a venal little man ruled by his fragile ego.
I have no idea how to rate this book...I just read a 500+ word books in a sitting (an afternoon in fact) and it was so unlike anything I've read recently...Stars could change!

Not even going to write a review for this piece of unadulterated twaddle that was superhyped into a runaway bestseller. It's all been said by another reviewer here on Goodreads, so this is all I need to say:Click this...[blows sound of ripe raspberry in Ms. Auel's general direction, and goes out for tea...]

I first read this book as a young teenager and I remember liking it, but then I didn't fully appreciate the research and attention to detail the author put into this. While we will never know details of early human day-to-day life, Auel does a good job of describing what it could have been like, based on what we know from anthropological and archeological research. She also wraps her pre-historical world in an interesting tale of personal interactions and experiences.

Okay, seriously. What the hell was I thinking, reading these books at an impressionable age? Like The Godfather, this is a book I didn't know I didn't want to read until I was several sequels in. I still regard this book with an inexplicable fondness (note the four stars!), despite having learned the concepts of "Mary Sue" and "what a pointless and poorly-done sex scene" in the intervening years.

This book was recommended to me as a good resource for learning primative skills. I'd have to strongly disagree with that. There were a few medicinal plants mentioned but you have to slog through hundreds of pages of lame story-telling to find them. The book gave a very idealized veiw of the lives of cavemen. Everything was milk and honey and wonderful rather than brutish, ugly and short.

Ohhh-M-Geeee!!! This book was so good! The tensions between Ayla and Broud geesh. I just can't even explain in words how much I loved this book. I'm going to buy the rest of the series ASAP!!! Thank you for recommending this book...it's the second book recommended to me by my coworker that has been awesome! And to think this came out 1980 and I never heard of it until this year! Insane!!!

Despite some odd pacing, especially towards the end, this was a deeply entertaining and meticulously researched novel. Ayla is the very definition of a Mary Sue - although she gets way worse in future novels - but she is certainly a character you can follow and appreciate.

Terrible book! I have no idea how it became so popular. The writing style is awful and the storyline is weak. I only read it (and am reading the next in the series) so that I can give it away with a clear conscience.
Recommended to me by my high school English teacher. Read it and loved it. Was and still is one of my favorite books. I think it's time for a reread!
Must read again after visiting Lascaux.
A very good book, with interesting characters and a fantastic plot. It's a great book to read if you love historical fiction novels.
Some parts were just boring, all the descriptions of forests and so - so the beginning really wasn't amazing. But for the rest of the book, the main character completely changed my mind: I loved her!
A great adult read but the movie sucked. Not realy my cup of tea now days but I loved it when it was first writen and read it about 5 times.
I shall give a review later this day. Be Blessed.
Click here for the Midnightfaerieâ€™s Review
Reading it again after many years, just brilliant information on the Neanderthal and Cro Magnon period
I read this so long ago but I remember so much about it. I loved it.. timeless so it is well worth the time to read.
Interesting. 4.5 stars.

My fascination with this book is somewhat random. Growing up, this was a popular enough book that I'd see it for sale at numerous used book stores, and always kept it in the back of my mind that I would read it someday. No particular reason why besides a title that implied there'd be some people that had some involvement with bears. I never bought it as a kid though, who knows why when I picked up so many other books that have sat on my shelves for years and either been read or are still waiting for the long payoff. When my wife was looking for a book about a primitive culture I looked this one up (really never even knowing what it was about for sure until then) and got a copy for both of us. While she's reading the excellent Crime and Punishment I thought I'd zip through this one before she got to it. That's a long buildup before ever discussing this book, but I'm wanting to be honest in discussing my thoughts as I read this.First, I'm giving this book five stars. I give a lot of books I enjoy five stars, but they're generally books I enjoyed and lived up to what I was hoping for, or took a series that was good and made it better. This was one of those rare books that made me wish I'd be a bit pickier with my five star ratings as I enjoyed this book a lot more than many other books I've given five stars to. I'd say it's on par with Nick Hornby's Ten Years in the Tub for the best book I've read in the past few years.However, I could see how this book would not be for everyone. Auel has a writing style here that I LOVED. It was very simple to follow, heavily based on advancing the narrative. However, Auel also has a habit for interjecting a modern reader's sensibility into the story, discussing things like advanced medical science, or biology of the neanderthal brain. I could see how some readers will be taken out of the story by this, but I appreciated the interjections as a good narrator explaining the inner goings of the characters and the society they inhabit. The group of neanderthal (Clan) people also have some abilities that are rooted in fantasy, but the book tries to stay as grounded as possible in reality. While that mixture of modern science with fantasy abilities all taking place in a historical fiction type of narrative is unlike anything I've read, Auel (for this book at least) managed to bring it all together in an exemplary manner.Clan of the Cave Bear  features a small cast of about 20 characters, of which five are significantly developed and about another five are treated as important but also fairly static (along with the other ten or so characters). Ayla is the protagonist, a Cro-Magnon girl who gets adopted by the neanderthal tribe. Iza is the medicine woman who adopts her, Creb is the shaman type character for the clan, Brun is the tribe leader and Broud is his son and in line to be the next leader. I found myself loving four of these characters and hating the fifth, which I expect will be the same reaction for most who read this book.I can see by the average Goodreads scores, that most people find the quality of this series to be of diminishing returns as it advances. I'm tempted to forego reading more of the series and just enjoying what a great book this is on its own. However, I already know I'll be tracking down at least the next book as this one ends on enough of an open ending that I'd like to see what happens to the characters that are still alive from the group above, as well as the offspring of those characters.

So my ACTUAL feelings about this book are "it was okay I guess," but it was advertised to me as soothing explanations of nature things, and I am happy to report, all of this is true! That being said: Auel explains in her notes that she spent an immense amount of time doing research for this, and I'm sure that's true, but the repeated assertion that Neanderthals were intensely patriarchal just feels very uncreative to me. Like I don't know anything about the research she did, but I don't think the Neanderthals had any idea of gender--and it would be more interesting that they did.I also wasn't warned there were rape sequences in this book, so I want to make sure I say they exist. It felt very "what the fuck why is this in this book" (like what in her research made her go "hm I guess rape exists in this universe"--although maybe she was like "hm since they're Very Patriarchal that seems like a thing.") I guess what bothers me about these things is they don't come off as creative or interesting choices, and it posits humanity as this group that is like "better" because they're presumably less patriarchal and like not quite ma'am! BUT, as I said: the descriptions of herb-gathering and hide-preparation was all very soothing, so if you're down with that and can ignore the weird gender stuff going on in this book, it may be really interesting to you!

I read The Valley of the Horses when I was about 15. I liked it and after finding The Clan of the Cave Bear at a used book sale, I decided to try and read the series.This book took me three months to read despite all my best efforts. I REALLY liked it but it was also very detailed and there were times when I just didn't want to read an in-depth description of the skinning of an animal or the various plants collected. I either skimmed or I took breaks and read a different book intermittently.The other thing I really struggled with is remembering the ages of the characters. It's VERY realistic and follows everything that anthropologists have discovered (as of the time of publishing). Therefore, the characters are WAY younger than the narration makes them seem. There were times when I was thinking about the age, thought someone was x number of years, and then read a few pages further to be told I was off by a decade or two.Over all, I really liked it. It's a true historical fiction that closely aligns with fact.

This was an interesting read. Interesting in a good way, not bad. The concept of a story surrounding the lives of cavemen right after the ice age (I think that was the timeline), is different and not one I thought I would find very interesting. I was pleasently surprised however by the ease of Auel's writing style and although it was long, I fell right into the story and wanted to see how it would end. The characters were easy to like, except Broud, I couldn't stand that guy but that might have been the point. My favorite by far was Ayla, she was strong willed and followed her own path (or at least tried to several times) because she was not like the Cave Bear Clan, she was one of the Others. The contrast between thier two worlds was refreshing and I absolutly loved the revelation Creb has in the end about the future of the two type of people. I will say that there were intense times throughout the book where I wasn't sure I wanted to be reading what was written, but these scenes didn't last too long. The ending was not my favorite and although I realize this is a series, I wish the author hadn't left things they way she did at the end of this story. I might pick up the next book because I'm curious to see how everything plays out. This isn't a book that I would normally pick up and read, but I'm glad I did!

This is my new favorite book! Jean Auel paints picture after detailed picture of her Ice Age setting using mostly prosaic language and all 1,000 words each picture is worth. I have never gotten so immersed in a book, or as attached to the characters, as this. It's a slow build to some very powerful moments and ideas that I know will stick with me for a long time.I haven't cried at a book since Where the Red Fern Grows or Wringer (Jerry Spinelli, 1996, 1 star, and mostly because someone (lookin' at you, Mom and Dad) forced me to speak aloud the name of the book I hated so much for the fact that it's about kids breaking pigeons' necks), but I came close a couple of times near the end.I can see the book not being for everyone. The writing style sometimes edges on clunky. One page in particular lists just about every species of mammal living in the vicinity of the protagonist's cave, listing "red deer, known to some people as elk... and elk, called moose by those who know red deer as elk," culminating with a single sentence listing about 30 smaller species that were not given their own paragraphs. By the second half, though, I had a hard time putting the book down.I don't think I'll read the sequels, I'd rather not know what happens next.If you like prehistoric fiction, also read Jack London's Before Adam!

Een mooi geschreven verhaal over de avonturen van het meisje Ayla dat opgenomen wordt in een Neanderthaler stam. Auel beschrijft de leefwijze van de stam heel mooi. Hoe ze omgaan met alles wat de natuur te bieden heeft en de diepgewortelde angst voor de totemgeesten. Het blijft natuurlijk fictie, maar ik vind dat Auel een realistische mogelijke leefwijze van de Neanderthaler weet neer te zetten. Het hele verhaal van de herinneringen die gdnetisch worden doorgegeven slaat wetenschappelijk gezien natuurlijk nergens op, maar ik vond het niet storend. Wat me wel stoorde was de jomge leeftijd waarop de meisjes 'vrouw worden'. 7 jaar is gewoon te jong en het idee dat een 8 jarig kind al kinderen krijgt vind ik geen prettig lezen. Het feit dat Ayla pas 10 jaar is tijdens de beruchte scene met Ayla en Broud voelde erg ongemakkelijk. Ik hield altijd het beeld in mijn hoofd dat ze rond de 15/16 was en dat las een stuk fijner.Ik heb erg meegeleefd met Ayla, Iza, Creb en Brun tijdens het verhaal. Ik ga de vervolgen toch links liggen, want die zijn nog dikker dan dit boek.

I wasn't sure I would be able to read this seemingly immense first book of a series. A dear friend leant me her copies of I believe the first four (and the hardcovers occupied a formidable portion of a shelf). Once I got started it was comforting to know the next book was within sight and reach. The books were very different than anything I'm drawn to, but these stories absolutely hooked me in. The characters became real.Their experiences were so vividly described you felt as if you were sitting on their shoulders with each of them. Each step along the way to fight for survival, you read of strength, fear, confusion, adaptation, constant challenges, learning, love, companionship and adventure. An excellent first book and lead into subsequent volumes. I highly recommend the Jean Aurel books. I plan to re read them, which I seldom do.

While I read a lot of books on history, Iâ€™m not often a reader of historical fiction. So, reading pre-historic fiction was a new one for me. Modern humans meet Neanderthals in Jean Auelâ€™s Clan of the Cave Bear. It follows young human Ayla as she is left orphaned by an earthquake and injured by a cave lion. The Neanderthal Clan of Cave Bear takes her in and raises her as one of their own, despite some hesitation and dissent within the group. Aylaâ€™s connection with the clanâ€™s powerful magician and medicine woman endures her status in the group even as her outsider origins and physical and mental differences continually cause friction with other members of the clan. Supposedly this novel is well researched, but thereâ€™s clearly a lot of literary license taken as so little is known about pre-historic life. Auel does a good job of making the characters relatable, but there is little depth to them and only Ayla has even a whiff of character development. Before picking this up, I was told it would also have some trashy Neanderthal romance components, but unfortunately those apparently only start up in the second book of the series. This is a multi-book series, but I wonâ€™t be continuing, cave romance or not.

Es uno de mis libros favoritos. Lo he leÃ­do al menos tres veces: la primera, cuando lo comprÃ©, la segunda cuando conseguÃ­ los pdf de los 4 que continuaban (antes de que saliera el sexto) y la tercera, este aÃ±o cuando ingresÃ© a un grupo de whatsapp donde se lee la saga a la que pertenece.Es una historia muy interesante y entretenida, aunque a algunos a los que se lo he recomendado lo encuentran demasiado descriptivo, y lo es. La historia de Ayla y de su proceso de adaptaciÃ³n al clan de neandertales es maravillosa. Se describen muchas costumbres y caracterÃ­sticas asociadas a ellos que difieren de la niÃ±a (y de nosotros). Es un excelente texto para introducirnos en la vida prehistÃ³rica. SegÃºn la clasificaciÃ³n de novelas, Ã©ste serÃ­a una novela de ambientaciÃ³n histÃ³rica.De los que le siguen en la saga ("Los hijos de la Tierra"), los dos siguientes son muy buenos tambiÃ©n (El valle de los caballos y Los cazadores de mamuts).Totalmente recomendado.

Listened to the audio.I've read this book a couple of times, along with other books in the series. This is the strongest book of the series by far because of Auel's ability to create a realistic depiction of Neanderthals and the possible differences they had from modern humans. There is great character development of the main protagonist (Ayla) who despite the bonds of unchanging society about her, cannot deny her own heritage. But what was most interesting for me was the way in which she describes Neanderthals and how their brains work differently with the fullest expression of instinct as part of what they called memories.Highly recommended. Very nice speculative fiction.

I saw the film with my father when I was ten and read the book for the first time when I was 14 or 15. I think the film and the novel had fused together in my memory, and it was fun to go back and reread it more than 20 years later. I still enjoyed it, perhaps not as much as I did when I was a teenager. Parts of it read like YA fiction but the story was still entertaining. I haven't read the rest of the series but I'll certainly request book two from the library! I am curious to see how 11 year old Ayla fairs.

I loved this book! However, I'm very happy that I waited 'til now to read it because of the rape scene. Though I could sense it was coming, for those who are closer to their attack it would probably be triggering. I thoroughly enjoyed getting to know the central characters and wanted to know what happened next so much that I checked out the next book in the series and consumed it in nothing flat!

4.5 This is book 4 completed from the Great American Read list. All the feels! I really enjoyed it, but found the rape too much to bear. I loved that this coming of age story is of a young woman and walks alongside her through childhood, young adulthood and motherhood. Very interesting perspectives on the life and times of the first humans.

I don't need to know every mammal that used a foot path or every single tree species in a forest - some descriptions went on a bit too long for me. A thrilling, energetic read. When you think the pace for the characters/family is about to slow, there are unexpected rumblings on personal, Clan, and environmental levels.

The Clan of the Cave Bear is a non fiction book in disguise as historical fiction. Jean M. Auel gives you a multitude of details about the lives of the clan, everything from how they gathered food, made implements and took mates, to their spiritual beliefs, secret man ceremonies and how the medicine women worked.Auel spent many years researching the details in her Earthâ€™s Children series to bring the most up to date and informative knowledge about how Neanderthalâ€™s lived and survived. There were a few facts relating to their brain size, and past life memories which Iâ€™m skeptical on (Reminds me of Aang being able to talk to past Avatarâ€™s in The Last Airbender â€“ different concept though). But for the sake of storytelling it adds to the mystery and intrigue of this different species who are closely related to humans.There are three main characters in the novel; Ayla, Iza and Creb. All of which are featured in the blurb. *gasps* I havenâ€™t written my usual blurb bash. Shocking right?! But for once they have hit the nail straight on the head. Possibly because my edition was published thirty years after the original publication date, and they had time to get it right. My mum might have an original or close to original copy of it. Sheâ€™s got the one with Ayla on the front.The Clan of the Cave Bear cover 2Clicking on the cover will take you to Jean M. Auelâ€™s site where you can read all about the entire Earthâ€™s Children series. Clicking on the cover at the top next to my rating will take you to the Goodreads site where you can read reviews by other members.I donâ€™t have any issues with the blurb on my edition. I like the way it says Iza and Crebâ€™s titles before their names. Tip for any writers writing a blurb or something like it: if you have to mention lots of characters call them by their titles only. Policeman, Mother, Teacher, Boyfriend, Best friend. Names are great, but itâ€™s hard to keep track of them and remember who they are and why we should remember them. Titles make it simpler until the reader delves into the story.Back to the review!The Clan of the Cave Bear follows Aylaâ€™s life as she grows from a little girl into a young women. One of the things I loved about this book was by the end pages you actually feel as if Ayla has grown up. Her thoughts, actions, emotions, and words, have matured from five toâ€¦umâ€¦I think sheâ€™s fourteen maybe?When I said young women I didnâ€™t mean teenager. By the end of the book Ayla is by no means a teenager anymore. Because Neanderthals only lived to around thirty (according to recent findings. I am definitely not a science wizard) fourteen is almost middle aged. She might even be younger, at the end of the novel she could be anywhere between ten and sixteen. In our species Iâ€™d think of Ayla as anywhere between eighteen and late twenties.Okay that is a weird end sentence. Ayla is our species. How about I say, in our day and age expediency sheâ€™d be between eighteen and late twenties. Again that is how I perceive it. Auel doesnâ€™t actually state to you how old Ayla is. Occasionally during the front half of the novel sheâ€™d say an age to help you gauge, but by the end of it she just uses significant events in a femaleâ€™s life to give the readers an idea of Aylaâ€™s maturity.The book opened by eyes to many things like the age perceptions I wrote above. It also made me think differently about Neanderthals. I always pictured them as these large scary beings. When in actual fact they are shorter than humans. It was quite an eye opener when Ayla is described as taller than all the men. Iâ€™d probably fit in right at home with their size ;PAs you can tell by the rating I loved The Clan of the Cave Bear. Iâ€™ll definitely be reading The Valley of the Horses. I just read the blurb on Auelâ€™s page and Iâ€™m super keen! I love horses :) But unfortunately I donâ€™t know when that will be since my TBR pile is giant.Auelâ€™s storytelling is engaging. There was rarely a time when I found my eyes slipping from the page. Although it took me longer to read this book than most it wasnâ€™t by choice. I had other commitments. I guess that tells you it wasnâ€™t an I-canâ€™t-put-down-this-insane-amazing-book, but I did love reading it. It reminds me of the feeling I get with Mary Grant Bruceâ€™s Billabong series. I could sink into it and feel peaceful. It was definitely a book that lived up to reading reducing my stress levels by 68%reducing stress levels You guys are all my friends, I recommend this book to you. No book is for everyone of course. Historical fiction fans should like it, and if itâ€™s not your cup of tea it never hurts to read outside your comfort zone. So in other words read it :PIf I didnâ€™t I wouldnâ€™t have found another four star book!Talk to you guys on Sunday, if not sooner! Iâ€™m off to do some more Tafe and maybe start the second last Skulduggery, Last Stand of Dead Men. The end of one of my favourite series is in sight! Iâ€™m sad, but also very interested to see how Derek Landy ties this up.Which favourite series have you finished this year? Which books lived up to your expectations based on other peopleâ€™s recommendation? Which didnâ€™t? Tell me in the comments below!Have an awesome day! :) xJo Carter xFor more reviews and reading/book/writing related things head over to by website at www.writerjocarter.com

Read many years ago this book encouraged me in a lifetime interest in anthropology, pre-history, evolution and human origins. I thoroughly enjoyed reading it again in light of new discoveries since it's publication relating to Cro-Magnon and Neanderthal..

First, I should mention that historical fiction is not a genre I typically seek out. Much like travelogue fantasy, it seeks to continually remind the reader that life in the yesterday and/or camping is hard and gross and generally inconvenient, which I am aware of and have no desire to read about. If, therefore, you are asking yourself why I would read this, it's because it has been in my TBR pile for several years as a result of an impulse buy at Barnes & Noble - as so many of my TBR pile is.The plot was compelling enough to keep me interested, although I liberally skimmed some sections where the author fell into exhaustive detail about medicinal plants, cleaning and dressing an animal carcass, etc. The pace is relentlessly slow, as the main action is frequently interrupted by long dissertations about plants and animals. It's obvious that the author did a lot of research and has a great depth of knowledge about this period, but half the book read like an anthropological textbook rather than a work of fiction. Since I don't care about those topics, it was only mild curiosity about the MC that kept me going.Five-year-old Ayla's family dies in an earthquake, and she's alone and wandering in the Ice Age wilderness until she is taken in by the Clan. The Clan is a more primitive species of mankind described as having large brains but no capacity to adapt or change. Ayla is "Other," so her body is shaped differently, her eyes are blue, her brain processes abstract concepts at age 5 that her guardian Creb still struggles with in his sixties, and she's capable of crying, smiling and laughing which the clan doesn't/can't do. Because of various events, the Clan considers Ayla lucky, although most of those events were really just Ayla using the analytical parts of her brain that they lack. Jealous of the attention her luck and intelligence bring her, the Clan leader's son beats Ayla often, even raping her later in the novel, although it's not considered rape in this society.Ayla and her transformation during this book are the only reason I kept going. She's very young when they find her, and as she grows and develops, it's very apparent that she's different from her "family." She's taller, leaner, and infinitely more intelligent. She's also unwilling to be forced into the traditional role of women as meek, mild food preparers who aren't allowed to use weapons or resist the sexual advances of men. Auel sets up the reader to sympathize and relate to Ayla, telling us that she's a homo sapien and her brain is much like our own. It does, however, give the author an "out." Every time the character encounters trouble, her smarter brain finds a way out. She can kill any animal, find food, seek shelter, etc even though none of the Clan can, because of her smart brain. Maybe it's my exposure to five-year-olds in first world countries or just my cynicism, but Ayla reads like a teenager at age seven and an adult at age fourteen. Sure, I can appreciate that their life cycles are shorter in the Ice Age but I'm pretty sure your average seven-year-old can't fight off hyenas and live alone for a month in the wild.The author seemed torn between a strict historical fiction novel or one with a touch of fantasy. If the women get pregnant by inhaling the man's totem [spirit] through their mouths and then his totem overwhelms theirs, then that would suggest sex plays no part in impregnation. However, the clan leader makes the men and women sleep separately while they're looking for a new cave because he doesn't want any of the women to get pregnant while they're traveling. They still walk together and eat together and communicate so by their breathing-spirit theory, the women could still get pregnant. The Clan also claims that medicine women and their spiritual leader have access to the memories of their predecessors because of their large brains, which is magic and not an evolutionary trait. This GoodReads review had some particularly good criticism.The inconsistent use of language and advanced vocabulary was slightly irritating and took me out of the story a couple of times. They use words like "human" and "nerve ending" in their dialogue which are too scientific for the setting. Their culture's language is based primarily on hand gestures, so it's considered rude to stare while people are conversing. The author adjusts most of the dialogue because it would be intolerable to read an entire 500 page novel full of sentences like, "Bad. Not stare. Not like. You bad." Yet some conversations were conducted in that broken, two or three word structure, which was difficult to read. The author is not consistent with one or the other style, using both interchangeably, which frustrated me.The Clan of the Cave Bear was fine, but it's not a book I'm ever likely to revisit. It was enjoyable despite my problems with it, and anyone who likes historical fiction or has an interest in Ice Age plants or animals may enjoy this book.The review "The Clan of the Cave Bear" appeared first on StarlightBookReviews.com.

I read this on the insistence of a friend. I really struggled to get into the book, and I almost put it down at several points. Although things got much better once I got past the first 1/3, the writing dragged for me throughout as I found this book to be overly descriptive. Having said that, the setting, characters, underlying themes, and story concept were great. Sadly, I think the true potential of the story was lost because of the unnecessary detail and lethargic writing. Though I greatly appreciate all the research that went into writing this book, it could have done without 50% of the detail and description it contained.

My interest was piqued when I saw that this was ranked #38 on the Great American Read top 100 list. I wouldnâ€™t put it my top 100, but it was better than you might expect for a novel about Cro-Magnons and Neanderthals. I enjoyed it, but not enough to continue the series.

Ayla is found by a stream aged five, picked up by the great medicine woman Iza, and is accepted into the close-knit Clan. Her totem is none less that the great Cave Lion. As she grows up, she learns Clan ways, and becomes a Clan woman. Despite this, she can't shake the hatred of Broud, son of the leader's mate, who can't wait to get rid of her.It starts off slowly. The first five pages in which we only hear of "the naked girl" is incredibly tedious. Then when she is found, Iza's unwillingness to leave the child is completely uncharacteristic to every other time Iza speaks. Women cannot speak out against any man without punishment, there are rules with which a woman can speak to a man. Iza does not adhere to any of these.So, a bad start.I keep reading and I like the way in which Auel documents Ayla's growing up and slow acceptance into the clan. Her love for Creb, contrasted with the rest of the Clan's fear is a good way to show differences between Clan/Others. It's also a good way of showing Brun's acceptance along with Broud's hatred. Now I think back to it, I see why the slow-burning of Ayla's growing up was necessary. However while reading I found it dull.Then (view spoiler)[Ayla hunts. (hide spoiler)]It's quite easy to see the motivation behind it. It seems like it was inevitable to happen, and I half expected her to get too big for her boots and parade her talent around. It was nice to have to wait until the Mammoth Hunt. Also, the circumstances in which her talent is revealed is a good reflection of Iza's first meeting of Ayla.But then the next bit is a tad predictable. Half the Clan hates it! The other half are willing to sweep it under the carpet! It is up to the wise leader to decide!Considering five more books attach onto the one I was half-way through reading, it was basic common sense that told me she would come through the other end of it unscathed.Then,(view spoiler)[ Broud takes a sudden interest in her and begins having sex with her on a regular basis.Giving you this fact alone, it's pretty obvious what the next major plot point is.Then, the baby is born "deformed". Or mixed-race, as we call it.More predicatble plot points follow.Ayla wants to keep the baby! This goes against Clan tradition! The fearless Ayla runs away!This is cute, and probably the most interest Ayla ever takes in her kid.Surprise surprise, Brun lets her keep the baby, Broud is shocked and hates her even more. (hide spoiler)]So, after the incredibly obvious plot point, the Clan Gathering happens.Once our attention is brought away from ohsoprecious Ayla and her ohsoprecious life, we discover they're just about to go away on a Clan Gathering. You'd think, as it happens only once every seven years, there'd be more of a build-up?Nope, we get a few milliseconds of "Iza is too ill", and then they're off, marching away.More predictable plot points(view spoiler)[The other clans aren't willing to accept Ayla! Creb and Brun have to win her support! Ayla meets a woman with a Clan/Other child! It happens to be a girl! Ayla's child shall have a mate after all! Ayla finds out some things that is forbidden for a woman to know! She gets away with it! (hide spoiler)]Considering the Clan Gathering is a BIG DEAL, you'd expect some more background information? The spotlight taken off ohsoprecious Ayla?Nope.They go home to a few more predictable plot points.(view spoiler)[ Iza dies! Ayla neglects her son and gets a fever that makes her milk dry up! Broud becomes leader! He fucks shit up! (hide spoiler)]Of course we knew the final one would happen, but within three milliseconds of the plot point before it? Really?Then ohsoprecious Ayla defies Broud (The shock! The spontinaity! The horror!) and gets clouted around the head, to be defended by Brun.Then the final part is just a big mess (big spoiler alert guys)(view spoiler)[An earthquake happens as Broud is demanding Ayla be cursed. Creb dies. Broud's leadership is challenged. Ayla suddenly take a conviently large interest in her son again, after he spends a lot of his time just being a plot point, and tries to save him by running into the cave. She screams "Motherr!" as a throwback to her Others days. Ayla is cursed, and leaves the Clan and son behind (hide spoiler)]I had to trawl through hundreds of pages for two pages of THAT? I get that action scenes are meant to be fast-paced, but that much plot squeezed into so few words deserves some kind of medal. It gets to the point in which it's not fast-paced, but just a big jumble of mess. 3/5Auel can present good character development, but needs to work on plot spacing and side character development.
