Fronds, I found myself asking time after time, for the past several days, "at what point do I just give up and not finish?" I've only not-finished a book about 4 times. But then I read Guillermo Del Toro's highly inspirational quote on his favorite video games this morning: "If it doesn't engage me, I leave it. I do not do homework with my life."FOLKS. THIS. WAS. HOMEWORK.I remember seeing one of the sequels at a thrift store years ago and buying it because I thought it looked cool. Never read it. My manager mentioned Clan of the Cave Bear a few months ago when I mentioned I enjoyed reading fantasy, and I pretended like I'd read it. Then it went on sale in Audible's first-in-a-series sale, so I bought it.Yikes.This group of Neanderthals finds a lost little Cro Magnon girl in a storm and decide to raise her. They have an incredibly, horribly sexist society, explained as "that's the way it's always been for millenia upon millenia." First of all, that's fucked, because if there's one thing we know about cultures and history, it's that they adapt and change and evolve.Secondly, this book has a horrible problem with deciding how it wants to tell the story. It'll start talking in third-person with the characters, and then suddenly we're switching to omniscient encyclopedia voice as a faceless narrator monotonously describes the science behind, say, astor plants, or a spear. It can never decide if it wants to be a narrative or a scientific journal. And that is especially bad; I could FEEL almost every single professor I've ever had cringing when I was listening to this book. The science is SO BAD. And there's not even the excuse of it being published in the 1980s; the Hobbit was published in 1937, and it's a more informed and nuance scientific text on the cultural differences between difference hominid species. Dwarves and their earthen love vs. hobbits who love their meals and staying at home? Oh, and there's always exceptions to each race there, too. The couple of Tooks that were adventurous, Bilbo, Frodo, Merry, Pippin, even Sam, goddammit. The Hobbit and Lord of the Rings are a much more fascinating anthropological series of texts than this hot garbage.So, Clan is not only narratively bad, it's scientifically bad.Then we have the protagonist. Ayla, who is "blonde and blue-eyed," as opposed to the Neanderthals who are all darker. Racist undertones, much? I lost count of how many times it was stated that she has a much larger and more advanced frontal lobe and that's why she has the potential for brain intelligence. Literally, that is what it says. It's so bad. I'm not going to say that Neanderthals were grunting at each other and saying "fire, bad! Boar, yum!" but they weren't saying shit like that. No one says shit like that except for Jean M. fucking Auel.She is magically so good at everything. Invents the atlatl, bras, flint and fire, you fucking name it. It's too bad she never met Steve Jobs. She's such a magical savior; she is the iconic Neolithic Mary Sue.I've never read Rhapsody, but my friends have told me to read it, because of how bad it was. Apparently, the main character is such a Mary Sue that her beauty causes a cart accident (the horse equivalent of a car wreck, natch). Well, Ayla rivals that for sure. One of the villains has to beat her and assert his manhood because she is beautiful and always defying him. Oh, did I mention that the females are always disparaged because they can never accomplish as much as the men? Fuck that. I worked for two years at a fairly physically demanding job, and my friend, coworker, and all-around lovely human being Kaori and I were the best there. Even told so by several dudes who admitted they thought we wouldn't be able to pull our weight. I don't need to constantly listen to this garbage even in a dryly "isn't this interesting because we know this to be wrong today case" nofuckthatshit. Plus, that leads to all sorts of false stereotypes about historical sexism which interferes with modern-day progress. "It's always been this way!" noitfuckinghasntshutyourlyingmouththeadultsaretalkingIt's so obvious that Ayla is being developed to invent Neolithic feminism, but folks, I'm not going to stick around to see it. I'm not doing homework with this horse shit.

This is the first in a series of Earthâ€™s Children books set 30,000 years ago. Ayla, a 5 year old girl, is separated from her people (the Others) by an earthquake. She is found alone & near death by Iza, the medicine woman of the Clan of Cave Bear, a Neanderthal group. Iza takes Ayla under her wing and eventually adopts her as her daughter. The Clan members share memories and knowledge with others in their group without actually telling them to each other, but Ayla (not born with that Clan ability) learns many skills through observation. The Clan of the Cave Bear is a story of survival, acceptance, love and courage. I liked the story but I had difficulty preventing myself from skimming over the long descriptive passages about the setting. I dislike skimming, but this is a long book with many repetitive descriptions of the vegetation Ayla encounters on her root & plant gathering expeditions. This was one of the 100 books on the Great American Read, and it was an interesting journey into a prehistoric world. 3.5 stars

I think Jean Auels Clan of the Cave bear is a solid 3.5 stars - maybe 4. A list of what I love and did not love is written below so please read on if you care to know my opinion.  I felt Jean writing was beautiful. It was engaging from the first paragraph. Her style is easy to read, yet intelligent and deep. She has written a beautiful story, describing a time period, a people and way of life so lost to us. She painted very descriptive pictures with her words and I had no trouble imaging whatever bit of the story she was describing at the time.  I was thoroughly invested in the relationship between Ayla, Iza and Creb. I was intrigued with their parent-daughter interaction and the way they tried to understand and assimilate to one another. It was obviously difficult to understand the different way of thinking between Ayla and the Clan born parents. So I loved reading about Iza and Crebs reasoning, trying to understand why Ayla acted certain ways and why she would cry -her eye sickness. I thoroughly hated Broud. He was ignorant and unintelligent. Instead of looking at his own actions and learning from his mistakes, he blamed Ayla for every lecture he ever received. Every reprimand was her fault somehow in his twisted mind. So instead of learning to become a better leader he simply brooded over her actions, always blaming her for everything. It was childish and annoying to read and it was clear that he was going to treat her horribly when he become leader.  I really enjoyed learning about their way of life to a certain extent. I had a difficult time getting super absorbed into their life though. I understand they are supposed to be a different branch of homo evolution than modern man, but I found myself simply getting frustrated at their thinking. I understand they had their theology of spirits and luck and omens, but when it surpassed logic and reasoning it frustrated me. Like when they thought Aylas baby was deformed and had no clue about reproductive ways.  I just also couldn't appreciate the deeply misogynistic society. The men literally hunted and that was it - the women butchered the meat, prepared the meals, made the clothes, made tools bowls and utensils, raised and fed all the children, made the medicine and provided healthcare. Everything. Yet they were lesser than men. Women could easily survive without men, but men would die without women. The feminist in me was completely turned off by this way of life. So bc of these ridiculously misogynists, I didn't really feel a connection to the clan. I was glad when Ayla finally left because I couldnt feel any appreciation or understanding towards their ways. Creb started to understand - the clan way was dying - and I was glad when Ayla was free of them.  Speaking of, I feel like there were times when the writing dragged. I was not surprised by the ending at all, but rather felt as though it was coming literally the whole book. It probably could have happened in about half the pages, ever since we first learned that Broud didn't like Ayla we knew he would torture her when he become leader. We also knew that he would be a terrible leader and make a horrible choices that would ruin the clan way of life. There was sooooo much foreshadowing that it was like "about frigging time" when the end came, "took you long enough". I know that there are more Children of Earth books, so it makes me feel like this whole book was simply a warm up for Aylas next adventures after the Clan and with the Others. Not sure if I'm going to add the next book to the list or not, we'll see. So in summation - beautiful writing that dragged a bit at times and became a little overly descriptive. Really interesting characters and way of life but the physical abuse, sexual abuse and subjugation of women was a little ridiculous and made me unattached to the Clan and their illogical religious ideas. The ending was incredibly predictable and took entirely too long to get there.

A very entertaining read. I recognized lots of survivalist techniques and herbs used. I would be interested in all of the research that went into the book. I felt this was a great feminist novel. Long book but an easy read.

In my opinion, the most overrated book of all time. Why?Well, for a start it is considered THE prehistoric classic of all classics, as if it is "The Lord of the Rings" of the prehistoric genre. It really, really isn't. In comparison:1) I will be the first to admit that LOTR is also too long winded and not one of my favourite books for that very reason, but Auel takes this level of boredom to a whole other level of yawn with unnecessary details that should be put in a science manual, not a fiction book. And way too many 'God's Eye View' details that seem to come from the POV of a modern Paleontologist, or a (shock horror) modern day author who has studied prehistory a lot and spent not one day learning how to keep their reader truly engaged. At least Tolkien's descriptions make sense from the POV of the character.2)I've read LOTR 4 times because of all of the other things that make it great(near perfect grammar being one of them, and also the fact that it actually deserves to be respected as a book).COTCB is the ONLY book that I have thrown in the bin 3 times because I did not want to torture some other hapless reader into reading it (I'm deadly serious) after trying to endure the first chapter. It has terribly written disjointed sentences that are often way too long. It is obvious that the author hasn't taken the art of writing fiction very seriously at all.The ONLY reason I finally forced my way through it was because it was needed for research.3) LOTR could have had a fair bit of it removed, you know, a chunk, like one slice out of a cheesecake and it wouldn't have any wasted reading time.COTCB needs to have over half of it removed, partly due to overly long sentences with not a scrap of grammatical art to them at all, but mainly due to the ridiculous amount of extra detail on things such as plant types and their uses that belong in a documentary, not a compelling work of fiction.4) LOTR feels like a work of brilliance despite its shortcomings; you really feel what the characters are going through and what's at stake.COTCB feels sometimes in the character, and sometimes like some kind of alien staring down at the Earth taking down science notes.I know I sound harsh here, but harshness where harshness is due. This book deserves harsh treatment, especially because it has been given such a high status.I could tell from the very first sentence that the author cannot write. The ONLY redeeming factor is that if this book was written by an author who had studied how to write properly got their hands on it, it would be an intriguing read; the story itself and what the characters go through is quite interesting. But these interesting parts are few and far between.I'm trying to work out whether the author refused to release COTCB if any editor changed the manuscript she sent in, or whether the editor looked at this mess before them and threw their hands up in disgust saying, "OMG, how am I going to fix this." I suspect the former. Just speculation.This is easily the worst (published) book I have read in my life.I would rather read "The Eye of Argon." At least you can get a laugh out of that one.If I could give this book a 'no star' or even better -1 star rating I would, but I can't. Oh, what the hell:-*If you want a much, much better read (quite brilliant really), check out "Shaman" by Kim Stanley Robertson - He's obviously done his research in the Prehistoric and writing field, and the POV is just about impeccable. That book is a 3-4 star read.

Set in the ancient world, The Clan of the Cave Bear tells the story of Ayla, who is orphaned after a giant earthquake and taken in by a group of cave dwellers who call themselves the Clan of the Cave Bear. Tall, blonde and blue-eyed Ayla is one of the Others and is considered ugly by the short, bow-legged, dark colored, neanderthal Clan people. Over and over again in the story, Ayla (either by accident or design) comes up against the traditions of the Clan people, who are set in their ways and unable to change. I was kind of fascinated by the culture of the Clan, which believes in and worships animal spirits and has a strict hierarchy with men as entirely dominant over their docile and obedient women. The clearly sexist culture of the Clan seems to have been designed to show that this is the stone age and thus be "realistic," while setting it up for Ayla to be more progressive as a woman capable of being equal to men. It's an oversimplification in order to easily play on the reader's sympathies, but for all of that (and for Broud being a single minded and one-dimensional villain), there are some lovely characters in the the clan, such as Creb, the deformed shaman, and Iza, the medicine woman who takes Ayla in. Both, but especially Creb, had some wonderful complexities of character that I rather enjoyed. Ayla her self was a little too perfect. She's good at just about everything she does, except for being docile and submissive. She screws up again and again in terms of Clan traditions, but these screw ups are positives from a modern mindset, so as readers we are clearly meant to take her side against the less evolved Clan. Also, the story got to be a bit repetitive as she screws up, is nearly rejected by the Clan, and then is fogiven..., several times. There were a few things that made me very uncomfortable while reading this book. One, was the concept of racial memory prevalent in the book and the idea that the Clan cannot change their ways, because their culture is genetically endowed in them, a rather disturbing concept, especially in regard to continuing discussions of race. Two, is that Ayla, as blonde and blue-eyed, is set up as the future of the human race, while the dark hair and eyed Clan people are doomed to death because they can't change. I don't care that they are meant to be less evolved and that this is the stone age, the author didn't have to set Ayla off by making her so starkly blonde. It could have been just as clear that she was more evolved by showing her height and body structure as by her coloring. Another thing that was far more minor, and something I'm note entirely sure of, is that I kept scratching my head in terms of the mixture of geography, plant life, and animal species. I mean, I associate the lynx with either Europe or North America and lions and rhinos with Africa, and I'm not entirely sure they ever mixed in natural settings. Maybe they did and I just don't know it, but I kept getting confused about how certain animals ever came in contact with each other. So..., this book is flawed in many big ways, but it was also compelling enough to keep me reading to the end, which left me wondering what the heck happens to Ayla next and willing to pick up the next book The Valley of the Horses to find out. So, I would say, the author has done her job in terms of keeping things entertaining and keeping me reading.
Did not even bother to finish this book. Not sure why it was on the GAR list. Surely there are better sci-fi young adult books out there. And yes, I didn't like the movie (1986) either.

In preparation for the final book in the series coming out, I decided I would reread the books of the series again. I've read them many times and they continue to be one of my favorite collections of books that I've read. Of course its not the most perfect series ever written, but I find it so entertaining that I am able to forgive a lot of its problems.Ayla is a young girl who has been left alone in the world after a horrible earthquake steals her family for her. She sets off alone at the tender age of five and after being attacked by a cave lion and collapsing, she is found by a tribe of Neanderthals who are searching for a new cave after their previous one collapsed in the earthquake. At first they aim to leave her behind, but the clan's medicine woman Iza finds some tenderness for the child and begs to bring her with them. Brun the clan leader decides that she may but feels (and will continue later) like he doesn't know if he has made the right choice or not. Since Ayla is of the "Others" she doesn't have concept of the Clan's language (which is mostly done through sign) and with Creb's (the clan's Mog-ur spiritual leader) help, Iza teaches her not on the language but how to be a proper clan woman as well. Ayla grows quickly and learns at the same pace and Iza decides that she will be a medicine woman as well and begins to teach her the art. In secret though, Ayla begins learning another skill that could put her in danger with the clan. She learns to hunt with a sling. Such things are forbidden to woman and clan woman would never think to hunt, nor to disobey or do anything that isn't of a domestic art, but Ayla is different and cannot abide by such restrictions. Her secret skills are not the only danger to her however; Broud, the proud son of Brun hates Ayla with a passion and will stop at nothing to make her miserable because of his jealousy. Between him and several other trying instances while she lives with the Clan, Ayla has yet to discover if she is truly in her proper place in the world.The characters in this series are developed really well and every one is important to the story. They all evoke some emotion as well. For example, I can't stand Broud, respect Brun, have affection for Creb and feel that Iza is a motherly figure. Ayla, is a good mix of character and has actions and emotions that are both good and bad and keep her seeming real (this will change in other books of the series but for this one, is done well).The writing is very descriptive but doesn't slow the story down. There is some violence and rape scenes and if this bothers you, you should probably not read this book. I'm sure there are discrepancies with some historical, botanical, etc. facts within this book, but as I don't know much about any of those subjects, it didn't make a difference in the enjoyment of the book for me.Overall I highly recommend the series and even the worse of the books is still entertaining. This edition, Clan of the Cave Bear, especially is one of the better books of the series and a good read even if you don't plan on reading the rest.Clan of the Cave BearCopyright 1980468 pagesReview by M. Reynard 2011

I've passed this novel on my hallway bookshelf everyday for around 30 years and always been intrigued by the name and the illustration on the front cover. As I got older and my interests in reading increased, so did my curiosity about this book. I decided to finally take a stand and end my 3 decade-long curiosity, and let me tell you, I'm so glad I did.This book is a real slow burner and doesn't move much from cover to cover, but don't let that put you off as it doesn't mean it's a bad book, quite the opposite, because during those chapters you learn so much and a lot of it, I am led to believe, is based on real research and discoveries.The story is set around 25,000 years ago when the earth was inhabited by both Neanderthal and Cro-Magnon humans, when their evolutionary lines ran parallel with one another and the earth was pure and untainted. The story follows, Ayla, a young cro-magnon girl who is separated from her parents following an intense earthquake that leaves her struggling to navigate the harsh wilderness alone. Ayla is located by a clan of Neanderthal humans who have also been affected by the recent earthquake and are also searching for a new home. The Clan of the Cave Bear, as they are known, struggle to accept Ayla at first, but throughout this book we see a gradual acceptance as Ayla and the Clan learn much of each others ways and personal qualities. BUT, will everyone accept Ayla? The book goes on to follow Ayla into adulthood and deals with some very series issues. I won't say what, as that would ruin parts of the book, but I wasn't expecting such things to happen as the book had been so pleasant to read throughout. It was a bit of smack in the face to start reading such scenes but felt it helped re-enforce that in this age the earth is a harsh and unforgiving land with primitive communities.Jeam M. Auel's writing is beautiful. Her sertences just flowed over me and made this such a pleasant read. She really painted a stunning picture of the earth during those early days, and I often found myself googling information I'd read, to see if it matched the historical aspects she had described. I really enjoyed learning about the clan and felt sad once the story ended, not to mention the way it ended. I felt like part of the clan myself. I will definitely be continuing with the series and can't wait to see what lies ahead.I've given this 4 stars because I felt that, despite it being a slow burner, some chapters had only a faint pulse and could have used a sub-plot running in the background to make it a bit more captivating. Nevertheless, it was still and interesting read and anyone who likes strong female leads will love this book.The book is easy to read and I would recommend it to anyone (including young adults) but be warned it contains scenes of a sexual nature.Peace out x

"But when did you see her talk to me? When did you see her go into the cave? Why did you threaten to strike a spirit? You still don't understand, do you? You acknowledged her, Broud, she has beaten you. You did everything you could to her, you even cursed her. She's dead, and she still won. She has a women, and she had more courage than you, Broud, more determination, more self-control. She was more man that you are. Ayla should have been the son of my mate."This book was amazing!! I can't believe that I've waited so long to read these books...and now I have five more to read. It's going to be a very busy next couple of months :)This is the first book in the Earth's Children series by Jean M. Auel. She wrote the book back in 1980 (eight years before I was born!) and the final book in the series didn't come out until a couple of years ago in 2011. The books are essentially the story of cavemen - the first people to walk the earth about 25,000 years ago. The first book in the series tells the story of a young Cro-Magnon girl who is orphaned when the rest of her people are killed by an earth quake. She is discovered by Iza, the medicine women of a clan of Neanderthals who call themselves the clan of the cave bear.Iza and her brother Creb, the clan's Mog-ur or magician, become Ayla's adoptive parents and Iza begins to train her as a medicine women. Ayla is excepted as one of the people by the leader, but no everyone agrees, particularly the leader's son Broud. As Ayla grows up, she struggles to conform to the ways of the clan. My favorite part of the book was not only the complex character interactions, but Auel's description of life thousands of years ago. Her writing of the difference between Cro-Magnons and Neanderthals is insightful and draws on scientific evidence of evolution and the development of man kind. Intermingled in her story are numerous culture references to religion, family, sex, language, and survival techniques such as hunting and craftmanship. Auel brought up interesting concepts regarding the mind and physical characteristics of the clan how it resulted in little change of the people over hundreds of thousands of years. I'm not sure if other books are out there or not, but this is the first historical fiction novel that I have heard about of read focused on this time period - or anything similar to it.I can't wait to read the rest of the books in the series and have already checked out all of the audio books so that I can listen to them on my way to work! From what I have seen so far, the series is very well researched and took over 30 years to complete. You can see some of Auel's sources that she used on her website.See the full review on my blog: http://onceuponatime-bookblog.blogspo...

Before Katniss from the Hunger Games was the role model for strong girls, there was my beloved Ayla, the Women Who Hunts.This book, and the first four of the series, were formative books of my adolescence. I think I was 13 when I first read Clan of the Cave Bear and re-read them dozens of times in my teens. Now in my 30's, I'm re-reading the series to the end to see if they still hold the same value to me.Ayla is strong, stubborn and smart. Everything a teenage girl wishes to be- an adult in the body of a 12 year old. I still admire her and credit her with being a huge inspiration in my life.While other find Auel's love of detail excruciating, I have always relished the descriptions of the scenery and detail of the everyday aspects of life. This was where I first had an inkling that there was a way to live in harmony with the earth, and wanted to learn how to be sufficient like Ayla was. I still am not, but my desire runs deep - it's just not matched by my time or effort :)I adore the juxtaposition of the Clan and the Others. Ayla's struggle for recognition as a person of skill and value in the Clan resonates with women's ongoing struggles for equality with men, while the traditionalists want to pull us back into the patriarchal dark ages because they don't like the changing of the status quo tipping against them. The men of the Clan knew this too - they'd stolen the secrets of the spirits from the women and knew they had to keep them in the dark to keep them suppressed and doing all the cavework so they didn't have the ability to take back what was rightfully theirs. And like religious fundamentalists of today, the Clan women were complicit in their suppression and could not even comprehend why Ayla, this Other, could imagine things being different than they were. But despite my feminist slant on the novel which is nothing more than my reading and personal resonance of it, this book remains an engaging read and a story that brings tears to my eyes even though I know it almost word for word. This is not a book to suit everyone, and that is fine by me. It will always be my favourite and will relish rereading it again sometime. With so many new books clamouring for my attention, it is a rare book I will re-read as an adult. In my youth I could love my favourite books over and over, because time and lack of funds were on my side. Now time poor and book rich, dedicating time to revisit my favourite characters is a luxury I'll always take for my Ayla.With every reading I hope for a happy ending, and my heart lurches and she makes the brave breakaway, choosing the painful future that she believes is best for her son and beloved Clan. Walk with Ursus, strong lady. I'll see you again soon in your valley.
A good read

The Earth's Children series has been on my to read list for quite a while, and I'm very happy to have finally finished the first book. I read somewhere that the novels are historical and somewhat accurate when referring to geological and humanitarian traits. I am a bit disturbed by that to put it mildly. I honestly know nothing about this prehistoric period, so I wouldn't be abel to identify weather the novel is accurate or not. I simply can't imagine having lived in a time where women couldn't even speak to a man without permission and where a male leader of a clan can decide weather your babies can live after childbirth and condemn you to death for not killing your newborn child after being instructed to do so. Not to mention how they can casually rape you anytime they feel like it. I think the scary part is that it all seamed to become so natural after a while of reading a book, almost to the point where the reader starts sympathizing with some of the male members of the clan, and then when you really think about it, they are all quite barbarian and demeaning. Ayla is a great main character. She is surprisingly bright and has a crazy good memory. The reader really feels for her. Her narrative voice is very honest and engaging and while I found that the plot moved way too slow, her voice made the passtime of repetition of clan ways much more interesting. I kept hoping that Ayla would finally get enough of her poor treatment and leave the clan, but the power of her love for Creb and Iza kept her there. I almost couldn't bear the scene where Broud severely beat and raped Ayla the first time, but it also stirred an anger inside me that just really wanted her to take revenge on him and kept me reading. I had honestly considered putting the book down for good at that point, but I wanted to know his ultimate punishment, so I kept reading. I would like to say that I was satisfied, but that would be a lie. I was disappointed by the ending. I love the power and self-respect that Ayla obtains in the end, but I can't say that I had hoped for something else. I would have so liked to see Broud broken. He is sure to have obtained a place on a list for most horrible book characters of all time. The book is well written in my opinion, why I gave it 3 stars. I wanted to give it higher in the beginning, but I felt that the second half of the book was not quite as intersting as the first story wise. I am hoping for a strong and independent Ayla that won't let men treat her like she is property in the second book. I want to keep reading and find out what happens to Ayla, but I am still undecided if I want to finish the series or not. We will see after the second book. I have never been so grateful for living in the twenty first century!

I read this in high school and enjoyed it a lot, even though at the time I was unaware that Ayla, the protagonist, is a giant Sue. I found her compelling without really thinking about the implications. You know, because literature really needs another super-special savior-type character who's smarter than everyone and braver than everyone and better than everyone . . . who just so happens to be a light-skinned, blond-haired, blue-eyed beauty. Which may sound odd coming from a white blue-eyed blonde girl reviewer. But I digress.Ayla was pretty cool as a character. I liked that she depended on the kindness of strangers as a lost child after an earthquake, and I liked that the Clan of the Cave Bear took her in and eventually accepted her for the most part. I thought she was an interestingly complex character who figured out that she could suffer silently in her situations or learn to master them--most notably when she was faced with sexual abuse from a very dominant male in her clan and she realized what he got off on was forcing her to be subservient. (She dealt with this by pretending she wanted his attention, and he was unable to get excited about her after that. She figured out his game.) I also liked the complexity of the culture Auel figured out, especially since I've heard she at least did a lot of research. (I don't know how accurate it is. I've never studied such things. But since she did frequently dive into textbook-style recitation, I imagine a lot of it was straight out of whatever she studied. Not the best writing style, but I learned from it.) The mixture of vocal and gesture-based language, the idea of animal totems and matriarchs who heal and have authority, the relationships the characters had with each other . . . it was engaging. Not sure what to think about the Neanderthals' "racial memories," though. I couldn't tell if that was supported by science or what . . . it seemed weird.However, even though I liked her and cared what happened to her, I did get a little tired of how special she was all the time. Look how cool Ayla is! She can hunt and she invented the bra during the Ice Age! So smart and pretty and daring! 'Kay. But I found it acceptable enough in the first book because she was, after all, exceptional, and got treated the same way most exceptional people are treated by their xenophobic societies. It was good enough to make me want to read the rest of the series.People always talk about how much detailed sex there was in these books, which I literally don't remember. I think I skipped over what other people thought were "the good parts," because to me that was "the boring parts."

When I read this book, in January 1981, I was a part-time columnist for a community newspaper. Book reviews were not my thing in those days, but I was so disappointed and irritated by The Clan of the Cave Bear that I made an exception and turned in the following reaction to my editor (I have not touched the book since, but recall the movie as being infinitely better, and quick peeks into Auel's sequels were sufficient to know I would never waste further time on them):For the past four months our county's library has been in possession of a remarkable new novel, one which is now soaring on the best-seller list.The Clan of the Cave Bear, by Jean M. Auel, is based on a probable meeting between two prehistoric branches of the family of man. The Clan is a tribe of Neanderthals, and the strange girl Ayla reared by them is one of the Others -- perhaps a Cro-Magnon.The Clan stands at the end of long centuries of development. It is set in its ways and doomed to extinction in a changing world. The conflict resulting from Ayla's insistence on new (and better) ways typifies problems faced by so many innovators down through the ages.Could this be a feminist novel? It certainly lends itself to that interpretation, if only because the newcomer who challenges her hide-bound elders happens to be female.But alas, in spite of the provocative story line, the novel is flawed by mediocre writing. Auel's prose is sometimes cumbersome as she labors to explain things, and sometimes it is extravagant to the point of being ludicrous:"With a silent prayer to their totems as the frightened, trumpeting, gigantic animal stampeded toward them, the brave young men raced into the face of the charging mammoth, waving smoking torches in front of them. They had the difficult and dangerous job of turning the petrified animal into the canyon."That passage goes on with combinations like "panic-stricken pachyderm" and "bellowing behemoth," but that is enough for our purposes. Clearly, any writer claiming credit for those lines is simply trying too hard.The Clan of the Cave Bear is the first book in Auel's Earth's Children series. In some respects it represents a good start. The underlying story is interesting, even moving. Surely there are many aspiring writers who would envy her success thus far.But this kind of success bodes ill for the language. We can only hope that she will improve on her writing by learning a few inglorious mechanics of good usage.

I really wanted to like this book, and I gave it my best effort, but it just never clicked for me. I think the concept is unique and there is great potential here but Auel spends much of the book focusing on longwinded descriptions of anything and everything Neanderthal that the story gets lost for me. Every time I would start to get into the plot, Auel would insert a tedious description of the scenery or animals or the creation of their tools. It was interesting at first, but the flow of the plot was constantly interrupted.There was so much repetition. Ayla is different, Ayla is smart, and she can grasp new concepts better than the clan. Ayla and Broud hate each other. I kept waiting for something to happen, for it to come to a boil but all I gained was another detailed account of how much Ayla and Broud despised each other for most of the book. When something finally happens and I already had it figured out because it was foreshadowed for four hundred pages.I did find parts of it very interesting such as the Neanderthalâ€™s capacity for memory. Their brains were much larger than humans and much of their learning was inherited through genetic memory and the assertion is it prevented them from storing new memories and thus adapting to the ever changing world, leading to their extinction.The medicine woman was very intriguing and for me this was one part that made me appreciate the wonders of the human race. The ability to survive and to learn the healing arts through the use of plants and other herbals is just incredible. That we have endured for hundreds of thousands of years through our adaptability and our basic instinct for survival is astounding when you look at it from the point of a Neanderthal.There are parts of the book that practically scream sequel to me. It could also be that Iâ€™m reading it over twenty years after it was first published, but maybe not. Ayla constantly defies the clan by teaching herself to hunt and make weapons and I know Auel is demonstrating Aylaâ€™s differentness and her lack of conformity, but I also feel like she is preparing her for life on her own, and giving her the survival skills to make it for another book.I feel like this could have been a really great book, but Auelâ€™s research weighs the story down and it falls short for me. I think the author does a great job on the research and it shows she knows what she is talking about but its fiction, not a history text. Granted, itâ€™s historical fiction, but Iâ€™m not a caveman, donâ€™t beat me over the head with the research.

What a tremendous novel! I have been meaning to read these for a long time, but have just now embarked on the journey. (There are 6 books in the series.) This book works in so many positive ways. It is a story that is full of heart. I love the character development and the way prehistoric life is portrayed. The book does indeed have a lot of details, but I do not mind that in a novel. It intrigues me. What a powerful story!

I don't really ever write reviews of books. Not for the books I love, not for the books I dislike. But I just had to make an exception. Because this needed to be said. This book isn't even worth the one star I am giving it. It's worth 0 stars. It managed to very successfully alienate me on the first few pages, when the author tried to assure me that Neanderthals possess some sort of telepathic ability to communicate, and a supernatural racial memory, that enabled them to relieve events that happened to their ancestors. Which, if youâ€™ve ever heard of Assassins Creed, thatâ€™s pretty much what it is. You can tell an author has little skill in her craft when she needs to resort to a deus ex in the first few pages of his book.But I powered through it, because I had heard the book was good, and the reading was just barely captivating enough for me to be slightly interested. But then it turned out that the book is basically 500 pages of beating on this poor girl. Small spoilers ahead: she gets beaten near to death by a gorilla sized monkey person several times, she gets left to die, detested by the people she loves above all else, works as a slave for men, is abused in every way you can think of, physically and mentallyâ€¦ I mean, basically think of any bad chauvinistic thing you can, and you can bet it happened to her. And all she ever did was being absolutely useful, and helpful and saved several lives. But fine, I said to myself, I guess the author is just trying to convey the old patriarchal societies. But then I came to about midpoint in the book---Before now I have never stopped reading a book because it was too disgusting. And I have read some disturbing things in fiction books. But this book easily took the what-the-hell-is-wrong-with-you cake. This 10 year old girl gets raped by a retarded gorilla monkey human 3 to 4 times a day. And he beats her face to a pulp doing it. Itâ€™s sickening. Face cringing. I literally had to stop reading for a while. And then she gets pregnant with his mutant monkey baby. And then I had to stop reading for good. And itâ€™s literally been haunting me since. I do not ever want to see into the sick twisted mind of the perverse author who wrote this. This is not fiction, this is just disgusting sadism. I wish I had never read this book, because the author made me care for the protagonist with the cheesy writing, and then brutally beating her down in every imaginable way. Itâ€™s depressing, messed up, and should be rated R.

I was in need of an audiobook, so I turned to a coworker and asked which book I should listen to next. She turned a little red and told me about this series that has, like, a million books and she's read all of them and loved every single one. She then went on to explain that the books take place in caveman days and things that happen explain why things are they way they are today. It sounded pretty cool, so I checked it out.The voice acting was mediocre. The voice used for Kreb (sorry about the spelling - I'm not 100% on them) was ridiculous, and not in a good way. His voice made me laugh a couple times. It was like a ... creature voice. It's hard to explain. Maybe if a troll and a gremlin had a voice baby, this is what it would sound like.The names were confusing to me. They were all really similar (again, I apologize for the spelling) Kreb, Ayla, Issa, Goov, Brun, Broud, Vorn, Vorg. These last four were really hard for me to keep straight. Wait, who said that? Wait, who did that?The story was so slow. The tempo was way too slow for me to be excited about anything. I wasn't surprised by anything that happened, even by the surprising parts and I attribute this to the slowness. The action was action-y, but there was too much time in between - I was bored.Ok. We get it. She's not built like the rest of the Clan and everyone thinks she's insanely ugly. We get it. She won't have a mate because she's ugly. We get it. Her totem is very strong. The repetition in this book only added to the slow tempo and to my antsy-ness. I only need to be told once, maybe twice - but this was too much. At every turn Auel seemed to find a way to squeeze in that Ayla is ugly. Stop.Overall, this book was pretty meh for me. I could have lived my life happily without having read it. I thought it was going to blow me away because it came highly recommended and has a pretty high average rating on goodreads. I can see the appeal, but I wanted speed. I wanted something that was going to keep my attention a little better.My rating and why: I gave this book 2.5/3 stars. It was pretty meh for me. I wasn't excited to get into the car. I wasn't invested in any of the characters or story lines. I didn't really care what happened to any of them. I did finish the book, though I'm not sure why. I will not be continuing with this series.

It's amazing. I read this book when I was 13 or 14 and I loved it. I couldn't put it down. After a rereading, I'm mystified that I loved it so much.This is a hard review to write because what I feel about this book is more 'feels' than words and paragraphs so forgive me if I totally fail to get what I'm trying to get across.The overarching problems with this book is two fold: all the characters are one dimensional and she states one thing than does another. Yes. All the character are one dimensional and, as a result, it's rather boring. Ayla is the 'Madonna' of this book. She's perfect. She's better at everyone than anyone else. The rest ... well, I ascribe this to laziness on the authors part. She says all the clan members have 'memories' so she doesn't actually have any of them learn anything. Indeed, she states in numerous places that they can't learn near things and then she goes on how they refuse to learn new things. I felt this was BS.As a result, all the characters remain the same throughout. In fact, I got the feeling that this was one of the reasons why the author believed they 'died out'. But putting that aside, the moment you meet the characters, just know that that's how they are throughout the whole of the book. The second part is a plot thing. She continuously states laws in this world and then proceeds to break them one after another. Pretty much everything she said she later broke in some part of the book. Or what she says makes no sense with reality. But, more than that, I thought her views on the daily life of the clan were ridiculously stupid. Over the top stupid. They were hunter gatherers. That's actually a misnomer. It should really be a gatherer hunters (but men made up that title so naturally they changed it.) It takes a family a four an acre, maybe more, to feed them. They wouldn't be hanging around the entrance and, as a result, the women would've know how to protect themselves.I think the biggest area I have with this book is the views on women. I don't think women were at the top but they certainly didn't drop and spreed whenever a man wanted it. You have that sort of society, yet the author says that unless the woman is mated, that baby is unlucky? What? Those two ideas DO NOT fit together. Sorry. I should stop before I start really ranting ...

Well, this book gave me a lot to think. Not to much about the theme, really -the setting of the story was pretty much all I needed to be interested in it, and I did enjoy it- but as to the nature of narrative and the creative process. This is a coming of age story, the story Ayla, a CroMagnon girl who is adopted by a Neanderthal clan and educated as a Neanderthal. Their differences are almost too big to bridge, but they manage it. Sort of.And that's the real issue. They do sort of manage to bridge their differences, and there are some positive messages in the book -how love conquers all, for example, I suppose- but I did read the reviews here in Goodreads before reading the story and I was primed to see some of the problems that might not have bothered me so much had I discovered them for myself. For one, Ayla is a total Mary Sue. She can do anything, learn anything, she's beautiful -except not in context, because she's different, but she's A Tall Blond Woman- and her total Whiteness Majesty teaching the dark Neanderthals their limitations is iffy at best. She can defeat any test, beat all adversities. And in some ways that's good, you know, I don't really want to read a book where the female lead is totally useless, but there's a small line between capable and Mary Sue, and Ayla crosses it. Then there are the actual narrative vices, like the fetish for listing things. I know the author did a LOT of research for this book, and hey, I'm happy to read a book that's well researched, but I don't really need to read page after page of lists (trees, herbs, what each herb is for, what kind of rocks are good for tools). There is, again, the small line. A good, well researched story gives enough information to make the story grounded, but this book does tend to get bogged down with it. Still, it does have some inspired moments, some of the characters are really likable -I'm very fond of Creb and Iza and Brun and Uba- and there are some really beautiful sparks of writing every now and then. It's not terribly purple either! just.. sometimes! So, I don't know. I did enjoy the story and I am considering getting the next book because this one ends so openly, but then again... Mary Sue and lists and research fetishes! don't I see enough of that in fic? A question for the ages...

I've been eyeballing this book for years; it fits the usual profile of the SF-survivalist-utopian popular fiction that tends to rouse my interest, but I was always turned off by a foul whiff I got (probably from a movie trailer somewhere) of Daryl Hannah grunting her way through a feature-length film, this sense of the narrative bringing on an unbearable promise of tedium.When a thoughtful (but anonymous) student put the paperback in my mailbox at the end of the spring term, though, the active recommendation and the easy availability of the text overcame my semi-conscious resistance and I quickly became immersed in what is, in fact, a remarkably engaging book. Though unapologetically "popular" (dare we say "lowbrow"), the book strikes a nice balance between plot and description. There's a strong feeling of suspense over the fate of Ayla, the main character, (presumably homo sapiens), a female living with a non-homo-sapiens hominid group, as she develops from crisis to crisis, almost a Jane-Eyreian quality to the text, which might legitimately might be read as bildungsroman. At the same time, there's quite a bit of survivalist description Ã  la Robinson Crusoe (1719) or evoking a post-apocalyptic novel like George R. Stewart's Earth Abides (1949), and Auel does well with the description, providing enough detail to hint at authenticity but not too much to overwhelm the solid plotting.I was especially intrigued by the disability angle of the book. The protagonist, Ayla, fundamentally different from the other hominids of the Clan, is regarded as ugly and her son, sired by one of the men of the Clan, is thought to be deformed and is initially slated for death. So, too, the powerful spiritual leader of the clan, Creb, is born with a disability and is further disabled by an animal attack in youth; while the Clan generally rejects physical disability, though, it recognizes in Creb a powerful spiritual and intellectual force and even his anomalous physicality is ultimately respected and understood in terms of power, rather than merely tolerated or seen in terms of compensatory balance.A thoroughly enjoyable read and one that kept me thinking without offering too much of a challenge. Thanks, Student X!https://bcc-cuny.digication.com/julia...

Le rÃ©cit est alerte. Lâ€™intrigue est bien menÃ©e et est ponctuÃ©e dâ€™un rebondissement final inattendu qui donne envie de se jeter sur le deuxiÃ¨me opus de cette saga dans lâ€™instant. Amateurs de prÃ©histoire, je vous recommande chaudement ce premier tome de la saga Les Enfants de la Terre si vous voulez initier un voyage Ã  travers le temps et revenir aux origines de lâ€™humanitÃ© ; en espÃ©rant que vous lâ€™apprÃ©ciez tout autant que moi.Je vous invite enfin Ã  ne pas perdre de vue, si vous nâ€™Ãªtes pas habituÃ©s Ã  ce genre de littÃ©rature, que le contexte de cette histoire prend racine il y a 35 000 ans.
