SPOILERS AHEADThis one was strange for me. I went into it knowing next to nothing about it.I will start where the book starts: with Hanna & Michael's relationship. I just thought it was icky. To me, it wasn't erotic or passionate; it was a 36 year old woman using a 15 year old boy for sex. I found the balance of power off the whole time, no matter how much Michael said he was in love with Hanna - and Hanna made nearly no effort to reciprocate his feelings. I thought I was in love at the age of 15. With Justin Timberlake. Obviously, that never panned out for me, and having actually been in love later in life, I can now clearly say that I was not actually in love with Justin Timberlake.The thing is, though, that I can sort of relate to Michael. I was sick a lot as a kid. I spent a lot of time out of school. I was prone to pneumonia and three years running missed two or three weeks of school consecutively. After a prolonged illness that had me on my back for weeks, I was usually a little off for a while. My brain didn't always like to cooperate. Around the age of 15, I was also going through all the hormones that teenagers deal with - and having a bit of a sexual awakening. Having said all of this, I don't think Michael was entirely mentally sound when he decided that it would be a great idea to sleep with a stranger more than twice his age, just because he liked the way she put on her stockings. I also think that said stranger over twice his age, probably shouldn't have let him in her house while she was undressed, and then proceed to sleep with him.I HATED everything about their "romantic" relationship, which I didn't find remotely romantic. Hanna withheld herself, was moody and distant, and prone to fits of anger. I felt she held Michael to much too high expectations - if you're in a relationship with an adolescent, don't expect the behavior of an adult. And I was particularly upset when she flew off the handle on their vacation together and hit Michael in the face, splitting his lip. How people can say that there relationship was "beautiful" or in any way healthy is beyond me.We see the repercussions that the relationship had on Michael through the rest of the book. If it was such a beautiful relationship, why did he have so many issues later? He felt ashamed for not telling anyone about her, he felt guilty for not writing to her in prison, he felt guilty about her death - he felt so GUILTY and ASHAMED about EVERYTHING. Guilty and ashamed are not things that you should constantly feel if you're in love with someone.The second part of the book, I really enjoyed. I liked that the author explored the mentality of post-war Germany, and the ways the next generation were dealing with the sins of their parents. I found the trial interesting and informative. (This section is the reason this is shelved on my WW2 shelf.)One thing, though. Was anyone actually surprised by Hanna's big secret? I saw it coming almost instantly. I have heard that her illiteracy is supposed to be a metaphor for Germany's moral illiteracy during the war. If so... Whatever. It doesn't really change anything for me.By the third part, I just didn't care very much anymore. The only real question I had is this: why did Hanna even apply for clemency if she was just going to kill herself the day she was released? What is even the point? It seemed like she wanted Michael to rescue her - and I felt that way throughout the book. It all went back to an unhealthy relationship.Really, this is just 2.5 stars. 1.5 of those are for the second part. The rest combined is barely 1 star.

The book tells of the affair between a fifteen year old boy, Michael Berg, and an older woman, Hanna Schmitz, in post WWII Germany. But for Michael it is an unrequited love what Hanna really enjoys is hearing him read to her.One day Hanna just up sticks and disappears, Michael goes back to his former life but later finds out that Hanna was a concentration camp guard during the conflict and is to stand trial for her actions during that time. Hanna has another secret that she is willing to keep hidden from anyone at all costs, she is iliterate.On first impressions this seems like any young man's fantasy coming true, an affair with an older more experienced woman but later Michael learns that there is a price to pay for it in his future life and relationships. The author,Berhard Sclink, is a German law professor but at all times he keeps the language simple and accessible. At times it is childlike at others erotic without being salacious. However, this is a tale with many layers including guilt, betrayal and responsibilty. Prominent is the focus on the difference between the two generations. Just how much how should post WWII children view the actions of German non-combatants during the conflict. In particular were they blameless as to the terrible deeds perpetrated at the concentration camps or were they by omission equally guilty?How do the actions of the past affect those of the future and who should sit in judgment if all are equally guilty? This question was brought in sharp relief for me by the words of the car driver who gives Michael a lift when he asks whether be believed that the prison guards were cruel in their deeds or merely concientious of doing a good job?Personally I felt that it was a very thought provoking book but a had a few problems with it. Firstly the books that Michael chose to read to Hanna seemed far too mature for a fifteen year old boy and I was left unimpressed with the court portion. In particular I found it hard to rationalize that a person would rather be seen as guilty of war crimes rather than to admit to being iliterate. That said I did find it enjoyable and may even go and watch the movie adaptation. Something that I have tried to avoid in the past.

One day fifteen year old Michael is on his way home from school when he becomes violently ill. A 36 year old woman named Hanna spots his distress, cleans him up and walks him home. Michael lands in bed with hepatitis for several weeks and when he recovers his mom asks him to personally thank Hannah for her kindness. And boy does she ever . . .The two become bed-mates for a time and she enjoys listening to Michael read to her. Michael fancies himself a little in love with Hanna despite her odd, aloof behavior. He also struggles with keeping the affair a secret and behaving like a normal teenager. The affair comes to an end when Hanna spots Michael swimming with friends and doesn't acknowledge her. Hanna then disappears.Years later Michael is a law student sitting in a courtroom and learns that Hanna is on trial for murder and that she spent time as a concentration camp guard for the Nazi's. As the trial continues Michael realizes he knows a secret that can significantly reduce her sentence. But it's a secret that Hanna has kept to herself entire life and he's unsure if he should speak out when she refuses to defend herself.This is a story with some heavy moral dilemma's but it's ultimately a story of regret of wasted lives. It's a quick read but not one, I think, I will easily forget.

In his thought-provoking exploration of Vergangenheitsbewaeltigung Schlink presents the reader with a number of moral conundrums as well as with compelling portraits of the two principal characters. Since the reader comes to know the characters and experience the conundrums from the point of view of the narrating character only, the reader must decide both the accuracy and the completeness of the assessments given. Called to judge the actions of both characters, the reader experiences the difficulty of letting "justice pour down like waters and righteousness like an ever-flowing stream" in a world in which both justice and righteousness have lost their deontological moorings. The author here adumbrates his fascination with Homer's Odyssey, a fascination that will find its full realization in his recent work, Homecoming. Coming to terms with the past and finding the way home are activities that resonate with Germans living in the aftermath of World War II and the reunification of Germany. In their struggle to understand the past and to reconcile it with their lived present there are lessons for us all. The book is required reading in Germany. I recommend it for anyone who has ever felt the rain.

It's difficult for me to rate this book, because it has an interesting premise, and touches interesting themes and topics and aims to provide plenty of food for thought.But it's also very dull. The characters are not characters, but the ideas of them. The prose is stripped down to bare essentials, and after a while becomes tiring to read. The book is short, and it's not a good thing in this case - nothing is fleshed out, and the whole thing feels like the author wrote down ideas and points he wanted to present and ornamented them in the barest rudiments of characterization and dialogue. The storytelling is practiaclly nonexistant here, and the book reads like a fragment from the diary of the protagonist (maybe that was intentional) but the situations that are so familiar and powerful to him leave the reader indifferent - we're never "let in" and therefore fail to feel anything for the characters and their dilemmas. I was not shocked, I was not moved, I was not even interested and in the end the only two words that I could say were "So What?"

I had seen the movie before reading the book and I was so impressed with Kate Winslet's performance as Hanna. When I saw this book was just a $1.00 at half price books I knew I needed to read the book as well. It's a very moving story and even though the book followed the movie almost perfectly; the acting of my favorite actress made me like the movie better. Don't get me wrong the book is still really great and if interested should be read at least once!

A young teen, Michael Berg, agrees to read to a woman named Hanna. His infatuation with her turns to love. Many years later as a young law student, Michael again encounters Hanna who is now on trial. He is astounded that she won't defend herself until he learns her long hidden secret.
2.5I read this book twice. The first time I thought it was just me. Second time around, I realized it wasn't. It was quite dull.

My review: 4.5 of 5 starsBook + Movie Review â€“ The ReaderBoth book and movie discussed in detail so be aware of spoilers!
â€™Iâ€™m not frightened. Iâ€™m not frightened of anything. The more I suffer, the more I love. Danger will only increase my love. It will sharpen it, forgive its vice. I will be the only angel you need. You will leave life even more beautiful than you entered it. Heaven will take you back and look at you and say: Only one thing can make a soul complete and that thing is love.â€™
Itâ€™s rare that I ever decide to read the book after having already watched the movie. After watching â€˜The Readerâ€™ and loving it I did feel that the book would do a much better job at conveying the emotions (as is normal with books vs. movies) and I so wanted to experience that.Compared to the book, I felt the movie really lacked in sufficiently presenting the true emotion behind Michaelâ€™s actions. What was disconcerting to me at first was when Michael was first introduced he seemed to me like a silly boy with a crush (even though yes, he was only 15) and their relationship was not easily understandable in the least. Kate Winslet won an Academy Award for her role in this movie, and for good reason. She did an absolutely amazing job at playing the part of Hanna Schmitz, a shadowy and secretive woman. She was dynamic and incredible but also strange; you never truly understand her actions until all is revealed. And once revealed, well, my heart broke for her.Michael and Hannaâ€™s relationship on film and on print was fiery and despite their taboo relationship was still full of passion. The fact that their relationship was taboo was never really addressed in either the book or movie. Of course they kept their relationship secret but they never went to great lengths in order to keep it that way. When they went on vacation together Michael referenced the fact that he could say she was his mother but was still unable to stop himself form kissing her on the lips in the full light of day. It could be interpreted either as the thrill of doing something he knows is wrong/taboo but I think it was more the fact that he was so incredibly happy to be with her that he was willing to take any chance. One scene in particular I found to be quite ironic was where Michael was reading to her and it was a very detailed sex scene. She stops him and says, â€œThis is disgusting. Where did you get this?â€ Michael responds, â€œBorrowed it from someone at school.â€ Hanna says, â€œWell, you should be ashamed.â€A few scenes in particular were missing from the movie that I felt were vital elements of the story as a whole. For one, the philosophical conversation between Michael and his father. It was clear he was dealing with some heavy decisions throughout the entirety of the trial but it went deeper than it was portrayed on film. In the book when he was struggling to decide whether or not to come forward about Hannaâ€™s illiteracy his father said to him:
â€œ...I see absolutely no justification for setting other peoples views of what is good for them above their own ideas of what is good for themselves.â€
The conversation instead occurred between him and his teacher, but I donâ€™t feel it had the needed effect that the conversation with his father caused in the book.The single most vital scene that I felt was missing in the movie was the scene at the pool when he saw Hanna for the last time. That last encounter set in motion the guilt that would haunt him for the rest of his life. The fact that he failed to acknowledge her in front of his friends was the whole reason he thought she had left and that he had drove her away by his inaction. There were a few other various details that were changed in the movie (like the ending) but nonetheless, I felt it was a remarkable book to movie portrayal. I felt that both the book and movie were brilliantly done and is one of the few instances where both can be appreciated in their own regards.
Expected a story about a analphabetic child molester. Got a story about a female, analphabetic child molesting Nazi. Wasn't disappointed, though.

non credo di anticipare nulla di piÃ¹ di quanto scritto nella trama del film sui giornali, ma nel caso non vogliate saperne troppo non leggete!A voce alta Ã¨ un romanzo che fa discutere, perchÃ© si presta a molte interpretazioni e a diversi piani di lettura, rilanciato anche dall'uscita del film the reader con il quale kate winslet ha vinto l'oscar come miglior attrice protagonista.michael Ã¨ un ragazzo di quindici anni che intreccia una relazione sentimentale con la trentaseienne hanna.siamo a berlino nel dopoguerra e la relazione tra i due Ã¨ tutt'altro che platonica: michael vive i primi turbamenti e la propria iniziazione sessuale in un completo sconvolgimento di sensi ed emozioni; emozioni esaltate durante gli incontri con l'amante nei quali il ragazzo le legge ad alta voce alcuni tra i piÃ¹ bei classici della letteratura mondiale; fino all'improvvisa quanto imprevista scomparsa della donna dalla sua vita.la incontrerÃ  nuovamente molti anni dopo, ormai studente di legge, durante un processo: hanna Ã¨ una delle imputate in un processo al nazismo, accusata di non aver cercato di impedire durante un incendio la morte di trecento donne ebree, rinchiuse in una chiesa e la cui custodia era affidata a lei e ad altre guardiane.il turbamento di michael Ã¨ il metro di misura su cui si fonda l'intero romanzo: all'inizio le emozioni riguardano esclusivamente la sua persona. Ã¨ lui che si innamora, che prova un sentimento che lo avvolge interiormente e fisicamente, e vede la sua vita quotidiana modificata da questi sentimenti, fino ad un quasi totale rapimento delle sue azioni e dei suoi pensieri e allo stravolgimento della quotidianitÃ .nella seconda parte invece, quella del processo, il turbamento di michael Ã¨ tutto interiore e di carattere emotivo ma non sentimentale.michael si sente tradito, tradito in quanto essere umano.l'orrore della shoah Ã¨ troppo grande per lui, infinitamente piÃ¹ grande dell'amore che ha provato per hanna, piÃ¹ grande del vuoto lasciato dalla sua assenza.michael Ã¨ incapace di perdonarla.non lo farÃ  neanche quando avrÃ  la possibilitÃ  di salvarla.quello che invece mi sfugge Ã¨ il sentimento di hanna, nella quale sinceramente non riesco proprio a immedesimarmi, anche se la cura e la dedizione con cui in certi momenti si abbandona al ragazzo sono commoventi.hanna Ã¨ una donna a tutti gli effetti, cosÃ¬ come michael Ã¨ soltanto un ragazzo. in certi momenti il suo interesse sembra quasi materno, per poi sconfinare in un rapporto esclusivamente carnale e per poi, infine, diventare cerebrale.sembra quasi che hanna, una volta finita la guerra e chiusi i campi di concentramento, sia solamente alla ricerca di qualcuno di cui prendersi cura e che allo stesso tempo si prenda cura di lei, e che il coinvolgimento sessuale sia del tutto incidentale.resta poi del romanzo la presa di coscienza della generazione immediatamente successiva a quella che sposÃ² il nazismo: una generazione intera, quella dei giovani degli anni settanta, incapace di rassegnarsi a quanto accettato attivamente o passivamente dai propri genitori."non ci chiediamo come avete fatto a non accorgervi di quanto stava succedendo, ma come avete fatto quando l'avete capito a non uccidervi" Ã¨ una delle frasi che piÃ¹ mi ha colpito nel film: nel libro non Ã¨ presente ma riassume il senso dello scontro che avviene nel romanzo tra il professore e alcuni degli studenti di legge che assistono al processo ad hanna, un processo dove, il professore cerca di spiegare agli studenti, si dovrÃ  stabilire se le imputate avranno commesso reato in base alle leggi dell'epoca e non a quelle attuali e la triste considerazione su quanto la legge sia fatta di cavilli e non di moralitÃ .correva voce che sul lungomare fosse comparso un nuovo personaggio: la signora col cagnolino. 2017 Reading Challenge #2: A book that's been on your TBR list foy way too long.Estoy convencida de que los libros de alguna manera nos hablan de nosotros. Que los grandes autores conocen bien ese recurso que puede ser expreso o no, de apelar a nuestra experiencia, a nuestros sentimientos o a nuestras ideas mÃ¡s arraigadas para asÃ­ seducirnos con las historias que vamos leyendo.Enmarcada en la Alemania postnazi, inicia la crÃ³nica de Michael Berg, un muchacho de quince aÃ±os que se enamora de Hanna, una mujer de treinta y seis aÃ±os a la que conoce por designios del azar. Acontece entre ambos un apasionado affaire, donde Ã©l descubre el deseo y el placer en sus idÃ­licos encuentros y ella le conquista y somete de un modo casi imperceptible para un chiquillo, a la vez que le pide que lea en voz alta antes de amarse. AsÃ­ se definen, en esta primera parte, dos personajes perfectamente humanos. Apreciamos conforme pasan los dÃ­as, cÃ³mo el muchacho oscila entre la confianza y las inseguridades que suscitan una relaciÃ³n con una persona mayor, hasta que llega el fin de su amorÃ­o cuando de un momento a otro, Hanna desaparece sin dejar rastro.El lector es una lectura ligera, capÃ­tulos cortos que se siguen en un ritmo continuo y sin ambages, pero que dejan entrever cierta profundidad psicolÃ³gica y filosÃ³fica que finalmente se despliegan en la segunda parte, en donde una vez mÃ¡s el destino reÃºne a los amantes, en esta oportunidad en un juicio donde Michael, ahora estudiante de Derecho, presencia la acusaciÃ³n contra cinco mujeres entre las cuales se cuenta Hanna, por crÃ­menes cometidos en campos de concentraciÃ³n en los que fueran guardianas.A partir de aquÃ­ no hay tregua posible: Michael se debate entre la compresiÃ³n y la condena, la compasiÃ³n y la justicia; trata de descubrir quiÃ©n es en realidad la mujer a la que amÃ³ y quÃ© le llevÃ³ a cometer esas atrocidades. El autor deslumbra con una maestrÃ­a no solo para construir personajes verosÃ­miles y vivos, sino tambiÃ©n para sumirnos en esa amalgama de sentimientos que producen semejantes heridas abiertas en la historia, que van desde la vergÃ¼enza y la culpa hasta la intransigencia y la arrogancia. El final aunque es concebible, no deja de de ser inesperado y melancÃ³lico.

A veces un final un final doloroso hace que el recuerdo traicione la felicidad pasada. A lo mejor es que la Ãºnica felicidad verdadera es la que dura para siempre. Porque solo puede tener un final doloroso lo que ya era doloroso de por sÃ­, aunque no fuÃ©ramos conscientes de ello, aunque lo ignorÃ¡semos.

MÃ¡s allÃ¡ de la tenacidad y las temÃ¡ticas que abarca este libro, creo que es esencialmente recomendable por su capacidad revolver tantas emociones y dilemas que enfrentamos siendo jÃ³venes o adultos, que se superan o se arrastran, pero que en definitiva nos revelan mÃ¡s humanos.Una lectura realmente significativa.

It's funny, when stories like this happen in literature, they're touching, moving stories of the heart. But when they happen on the six o'clock news they're horrific stories of pedophilic rape between, say, a female schoolteacher and a student, and we gasp audibly, loud enough at least to make sure everyone hears. It's interesting how our sympathies change in these contexts, and the fact that we eat both of them up with intrigued hunger probably says something about latent desires we all have but won't admit.The Reader has all the elements of tried-and-true mechanical emotional manipulation: Age-gap love; freeze-dried just-add-water idyllic imagery of the lovers biking along the country road, their hair caught by the wind; protagonists who like reading; and, not insignificantly, a Holocaust backstory. It's all the stuff of Miramax "art" films and the NPR crowd. So, it's not surprising that Mr. Miramax himself, Harvey Weinstein, produced the film adaptation; the book reads like a skeletal treatment for one of his films.The book is an easy read; smooth as butter -- at least in the first half -- and sometimes lovely. And it's hard not to feel the sadness of the protagonist with his memories, regrets and the sense of betrayal of a love that was not quite what it seemed to be, or, which was exactly what it seemed to be despite the revelation of hard facts unknown at the time. But the book's tricks begin to show fairly early on -- the ease with which, for instance, he reduces and boils down the essence of their relationship to four bits of imagery should be charming but strikes me as a calculated and disingenuous trope -- and because of that I felt myself pulled away from the gravitas of the story; looking at it from a cool distance and refusing to let my emotions be pulled in and engaged. The book's so-called big revelations were telegraphed clearly and I'd seen them far in advance. It's impossible to really discuss what happens in the second half of the book without revealing spoilers. The second half degenerates into clunky, distanced and pedestrian storytelling and is less interesting than the more poetic first half, which at least benefits from a sense of concentrated longing. The details of Michael Berg's adult life are a complete bore and almost irrelevant to the story. The flavor of the trial is poorly captured due to the lack of dialogue that would give it more palpable drama. I think, overall, it's a fairly minor book; it adds little that's new to Holocaust lit, and all of you who were suckered by it can go back to your tea and your NPR.

I've read Le Liseur twice now in its French translation from the German. The film The Reader tracks the novel quite closely, with the only significant change one that comes at the very end, when Michael visits Hanna's grave. In the film he is accompanied by his daughter. In the novel, he goes alone. The story is a disturbing one, with its ultimately unanswered questions regarding guilt, shame, betrayal and responsibility. The novel can be read as the personal story of Michael Berg and Hanna Schmitz set in post-war Germany, but it can also be read as an allegory in which Hanna represents Germany, the country itself, and the generation of the parents, those who were adults during the Hitler years. Michael represents the next generation who were children or not yet born during the war. It is the lack of an accounting, of memory on the part of the parentsâ€™ generation that ultimately victimizes Michael and future generations, as their own silence and betrayal is a product of that of parents who didn't confront the past, who just moved on. This betrayal of memory on the part of the German populace after WWII is a subject that has been effectively explored by the writer, W.G. Sebald. Michael Berg is 15 when he becomes involved with Hanna, who at 36 is 21 years his senior. He initiates the relationship, but Hanna, as the adult, may be exploiting, and in a sense raping, him nonetheless. Hannaâ€™s secret and her secret shame is her illiteracy, an, unexplained in the novel, handicap which determines the course of her life, including her employment as a concentration camp guard during WWII and her later condemnation and imprisonment for what she did there. In fact, Hanna ultimately admits to more responsibility than she actually had in events surrounding a terrible fire in a locked church that killed all but two of the Jewish prisoners guarded by Hanna and several other women. Rather than admit her inability to read either the accusations against her or the book written by a girl who, along with her mother, survived the fire, Hanna is sentenced to life in prison.The course of Michael Bergâ€™s life is determined, in turn, by his relationship with Hanna and his feelings of betrayal both of her and by her.

Poi non so se questa cosa dello stereotipo della sensibilitÃ  tedesca tutta rigida e piena di contegno sia una realtÃ  effettivamente ed attualmente presente o solo una sorta di stereotipo. Eppure c'Ã¨ qualcosa di riscontrabile.

Romanzo secondo me bellissimo - occorre segnalare che il film non l'ho visto, anzi non ero neanche al corrente della sua esistenza finchÃ© non ho inserito il libro su goodreads e sono incappato in questa copertina dove si riconoscono due attori famosi (la mia copia possiede un'altra copertina) - chiaro e pulito nel linguaggio, asciutto e distaccato eppure in grado di mettere in moto emozioni forti.Sempre ottimo: sia quando narra la storia d'amore tra il 15enne Michael Berg e la 36enne Hanna Schmitz, sia quando affronta il tema dell'Olocausto e dei Lager, ma i temi toccati dal libro sono numerosi, alcuni approfonditi (la colpa, l'espiazione, il conflitto generazionale nella Germania post-nazista, l'analfabetismo, i limiti che dobbiamo imporre al nostro agire anche quando riteniamo di fare del bene a qualcuno) a volte appena sfiorati: tra questi ultimi mi ha colpito ad esempio una frase che pronuncia il padre di Michael parlando col figlio, cioÃ¨ di come il rapporto genitori-figli sia un problema di cui si sarebbe da sempre dovuta occupare la filosofia ed invece questa lo ha abbandonato in pessime mani, quelle dei pedagoghi.Ma questi sono solo pochi esempi estratti da un libro consigliatissimo, le cui riflessioni non sono mai banali, anzi provocano e confondono, stimolano domande, minano certezze, accendono interesse.

JÃ¡ se passaram vÃ¡rios dias desde que li esta estÃ³ria, mas parece que continuo com dificuldade em exprimir os meus sentimentos. Lembro-me que ha vÃ¡rios anos atras tinha visto alguns pedaÃ§os do filme e fiquei bastante emocionada com a estÃ³ria. EntÃ£o quando decidi ler o livro jÃ¡ tinha uma vaga ideia que iria marcar-me profundamente. Adorei o ambiente da estÃ³ria; a escrita do autor toca-nos profundamente e as personagens sÃ£o soberbas. A Hanna e o Michael vÃ£o permanecer comigo durante vÃ¡rios anos, tenho a certeza. O final destruÃ­u-me completamente. E para que ficasse ainda mais destruÃ­da, mal acabei de ler o livro tive que ir ver novamente o filme. E pronto, chorei tanto que no dia seguinte tinha os olhos tao inchados que ate me custava abri-los. Os actores foram excelentes. Enfim, Ã© uma estÃ³ria poderosa, que nos faz questionar as opÃ§Ãµes que escolhemos ao longo da vida. Mas sobretudo faz-nos pensar no impacto que um relacionamento, por mais curto que seja, com outra pessoa pode ter para sempre na nossa vida. Sem duvida que ficou um favorito da vida.

Me ha gustado, peroâ€¦ no lleguÃ© a entender a Hanna, ni tampoco a Michael. Hanna al principio me parecÃ­a una mujer muy frÃ­a y egoÃ­sta, pero me quede a cuadros cuando se descubre el pastel. Se podrÃ­a decir que despertÃ³ en mÃ­ sentimientos encontrados, por una parte y sin contar lo que hizo en el pasado, me daba mucha pena y entendÃ­a muchas cosas que hace, pero no puedo dejar a un lado lo que hizo y eso me producÃ­a mucha rabia, me dolÃ­a mucho lo que hizo y eso no tiene justificaciÃ³n alguna. Por otra parte tenemos a Michael, un personaje que no lo entendÃ­ mucho, es un poco raro. Al final del libro, se entiende muchas cosas sobre sus sentimientos de amor/culpa, pero lo sigo sintiendo extraÃ±o.La historia tambiÃ©n me ha tenido con sentimientos encontrados: me gusta la historia que cuenta y como la cuenta pero no puedo olvidar el pasado, es demasiado cruel para olvidarlo. Entonces no sÃ© que decirâ€¦ Es difÃ­cil de reseÃ±ar este libro, puf.

This book is a masterpiece in my opinion especially the way it was written. It was amazing the way it made me think so many times, in so many instances, what would I do? How would I have reacted to that moral decision I am forced to make? The Reader was so sensuous, sexy, disturbing, and conflicting. There are so many more words to describe how it made me feel during the reading of this book. Words that I cannot think of, cannot capture in my mind and put in this review. My feelings are simply indescribable. Time spent writing a review of this book is simply a waste of time for me because I just do not know what to say. There are other reviews which go into depth of the multiple issues brought up by the author Berhard Schlink. Just let me say that it should be your next book read.

Prosa ligera, historia previsible. Logra eludir, sin ahondar, al contexto histÃ³rico de la Alemania de la posguerra, evocando preconcepciones ya enraizadas en la cultura occidental acerca del resentimiento hacia la generaciÃ³n que albergÃ³ al nazismo. En opiniÃ³n personal, el mayor logro del texto es elevar cuestionamientos jurÃ­dicos, filosÃ³ficos y morales que cimbran la opiniÃ³n generalizada y llevan a revalorizar, replantear y rejuzgar a partÃ­cipes del nazismo. La historia de amor que subraya el escrito es pasional, ingenua y adolescente, pero escapa la obsesiÃ³n. Es mero devenir, maduraciÃ³n, agonÃ­a procesal.

There's something strange about this novel. The events in this novel span from the time the narrator is an adolescent until he is middle-aged, yet his voice and perspective remain the same throughout the book. Maybe he is just not very bright and lacks the ability to look back on his younger self. Or maybe it is to do with the translation. If you have nothing better read, go for it, otherwise pass on it.

I was looking through Goodreads and realized I didn't mark this book as read. So fixing that now.It's been a couple years since I read this, but I remember enjoying it and that it definitely left me thinking for a while after I finished it. I really want to reread it as a more mature reader now and see if I get anything new from it.

It just means a lot to me . Now I can watch the remaining final hour of the movie , to which I relate , also .

This book was given to me at the end of high school by my favourite teacher (of literature) as a farewell and encouragement for the studying years to come. I did not really liked it at the time - the Holocaust was a subject I disliked to read about, having done too much about WWII in school. Plus it is not a very pleasant topic. I read it, I forgot it. I then saw the movie, it's a good one!Fast forward a few years and I saw the audiobook version of it in my local library. I thought that having "the reader" read to me was an interesting mise en abyme. I heard it again & watched the movie again.It's a very interesting story about guilt. The one of the people who partook in the Holocaust, even though by mere circumstances, & the one of the generation that followed. The character of Hanna is hard to understand & I still can't really decide about how I feel about her. (view spoiler)[ Her suicide made me sad, but at the same time had a feel of justice about it - like she had finally recognised the pain she had partook in inflicting. Sure, she paid by going to prison, for something she was not fully responsible for, but it feels like she only understood what she had done once she read about the testimonies. Shame she did not make things right by Michael. (hide spoiler)]Also, re-discovering this book have prompt me to write to my teacher after all these years to thank her for the good influence she had on me, tell her about my life now and asking about hers. We (as a modern society & myself as an individual) complain so so much about everything & sometimes it's good to stop, feel & express some gratitude about what we have been given in life. Esp. in light of the horrors society has done (is doing now?) & how lucky we are to have not lived through them but simply read about it in the comfort of our reading sofa.If you have read this review until the end (thanks!), maybe take some time to think of someone who has had a good influence on you & write/text/email them about it. You will see that it makes you and them feel really good.

â€œSo I was still guilty. And if I was not guilty because one cannot be guilty of betraying a criminal, then I was guilty of having loved a criminal.â€ A long time ago I have seen a movie, "The Reader", with Kate Winslet playing one of the main characters, Hanna Schmitz. I thought the movie was stunning and Kate Winslet gave a performance of her lifetime, later rewarded by an Oscar. I must say that the book is just as a good as the movie. It is very philosophical, full of thoughts and analysis of past events, sometimes read as a stream of consciousness. The book is comprised of several parts. The first part reminded me a lot of "Call me by your name" - it talks in detail about a forbidden and passionate love affair between the main protagonist Michael, who at the time is 15 year old, with Hanna Schmitz, a 30+ German woman. This part is very subtle, nostalgic and full of raw emotion, despite the fact that it is an illicit affair. The next part takes place years later when Hanna is put on a trial along with other SS guards for the crimes she has committed in a concentration camp she worked back in 1944. That part is much more philosophical and explores tough moral questions as well as aspects of guilt and remorse that second-generation Germans have to deal with after the war was over. Michael ponders all this in addition to questioning and reassessing his feelings for Hanna now that he knows what she was involved in during the war. This book was incredibly thought-provoking and made me sympathize and try to understand Hanna despite the horrible crimes she has committed. I am surprised by the relatively low rating this book has - I highly recommend it as a very valuable and unforgettable read!

Aan interessante themaâ€™s geen gebrek, en wat mij nog het meest intrigeerde, is dat dit boek een beeld schept van het schuldgevoel waar Duitsland mee opgezadeld zat na de holocaust, zelfs bij die generaties die er niets mee te maken hadden.Dat het boek, ondanks deze themaâ€™s, me toch niet 100% wist te raken, is vreemd. Ik vermoed dat het komt door de schrijfstijl van Bernhard Schlink. Als ik er een woord voor kan bedenken, is het â€˜degelijkâ€™. Maar met â€˜degelijkheidâ€™ schrijf je geen fantastisch boek.Van dit boek valt een emotioneler, sprankelender geheel te maken. Nu (be)schrijft Schlink met een zekere afstandelijkheid. Een afstandelijk boek werkt voor mij maar als de afstandelijkheid op een bepaald moment (hoe kort ook, zie The Remains of the Day) doorbroken wordt. Of als het boek zich focust op ideeÃ«n, maar daarvoor is dit boek dan weer te kort en niet diepgravend genoeg.Ik dÃ©nk dat dat mijn probleem was met dit boek. Het is een verhaal dat enorm veel potentieel bevat om uitgesproken krachtig te zijn, maar het wordt gewoon te neutraal overgebracht. Ik heb de film nog niet gezien, maar het zou me niet verbazen mocht die (met dit basismateriaal) me wel meer raken. Al begrijp ik wel niet goed dat Ralph Fiennes (Â°1962) iemand speelt die 21 jaar jonger is dan Kate Winslet (Â°1975). Maar dit terzijde.

I watched the movie, The Reader, over ten years ago and had put the book on my to read list. I recently pick this copy up at a second hand store and found myself quickly reading as I forgot some of the story line. I have mixed feelings about this book and I think that might have been the authors goal. The Reader is set in post WWII Germany and deals with the aftermath and consequences of a Nazi run country as the next generation is trying to come to terms with the Holocaust. The book is almost entirely an inner dialogue by Michael from the age of 15 until later on in his adult life. He attempts to come to terms with a childhood rendezvous with an older woman. This portion of the book was difficult for me to process because the sexual exploitation he experienced at a young age really defined who he became, but he didn't seem to fully understand that. The second half of the book deals with post WWII trials and really looked at who should be responsible for their actions.I would recommend this book, but a fair warning that it is not for the faint of heart. If you like books filled with action, character dialogue, and big plot twists then this book is not for you. If you enjoy historical fiction and want be forced to examine your inner thoughts in regards to morality while getting into the soul of the narrator, then this book is for you!

I haven't seen the movie yet, only a preview on a DVD a few weeks ago* (which reminded me I had the book on my shelf), but I have to say: while reading this I kept thinking God this would make a great film! And Kate Winslet would be great as Hanna! I like to think that if the movie hadn't already been made and put the idea in my head, it would have been a prophetic thought.When Michael Berg was fifteen he became sick with Hepatitis; several months of convalescence later, he goes back to visit the woman who helped him when he threw up on the street, to thank her. A quiet, strong woman in her thirties, Hanna works as a tram conductor and lives a solitary life. Catching a glimpse of her taking off her stockings, Michael flees in shame when she notices him looking. But a week of obsessing over her sees him returning, and they quickly become lovers.He keeps his relationship with her a secret. At her insistence, he picks up his studies and manages to make up for his lost time while sick. He loves Hanna and, in a way, feels she has ruined him for any other woman - which becomes clear when Hanna suddenly disappears and Michael tries to move on. While at university studying law, he takes part in a seminar which involves sitting in on a trial of people accused of war crimes when with the Nazis during World War II. He has spent so long cultivating a dispassionate, cold shell that Michael feels nothing when he sees that one of the women on trial is Hanna.He is there for every day of the trial, but only once do they make eye contact. He can't understand why Hanna is not defending herself as well as she could, why she is letting the other women on trial blame her for everything - until he realises what her real secret, her real shame is. If he explained it to the judge, there would be no way Hanna could be convicted of these heinous crimes at Auschwitz and another labour camp - but he wrestles with his moral and ethical right to do so.Schlink was born in 1944 and is a Law Professor in Berlin. Certainly, while reading this, I felt like the author had been there, seen that. Narrated by Michael at some later stage in his life, it reads like a real life - and in a way it is: a great many lives given voice in one slim novel. One of the questions Michael raises concerns the children, like himself, of the generation who sat by and did nothing while the Nazis persecuted and plundered. I never really thought about it before, but I can imagine, thanks to Michael, how hard it would have been for this post-war generation to respect their parents, and understand them without having lived through it themselves to truly know what it must have been like.Apart from that, this book - and Michael - doesn't judge. The relationship between a fifteen year old and a woman twice his age isn't judged - neither is it ever exposed. Hanna's involvement in Auschwitz is judged by the court but not by Michael, who instead tries to understand Hanna and her motivations. He also tries to understand his own feelings for Hanna, but is often lost in the nostalgia of his adolescent love affair. The Reader isn't about black and white, or good and evil - it's about all the grey bits that make up the moral and ethical complexities and contradictions of humans. It isn't about having a conclusion, about coming to a final understanding, but the process of reaching an understanding and the futility of a conclusion.I admit that as I was reading this I didn't pay much attention to the details, only to the narrative and the characters. I wouldn't be surprised if there are many things I overlooked, symbolism and recurring themes and such. On a re-read, I would focus more closely on what else Michael chooses to tell us, and why. This would be a great novel to study: deceptively simple, it harbours secrets barely tapped at.*Rented the movie a few weeks ago but only got halfway through. It was disappointing because, though done well and the acting was great etc., it was just a visualisation of the book and gave/offered nothing new.

As a general rule, I consider the word â€œeroticâ€ in any book publicist lingo a euphemism for soft porn, so when I perused the description of Bernhard Schlinkâ€™s novel I wasnâ€™t sure if it would be worth bothering with despite its intriguing (to a booklady such as myself) title. The first half of the book did indeed seem to fit my expectations of little more than titillation under the guise of literary searching. However, if the reader (small â€œRâ€) can overlook the blatant sexuality inherent in a young manâ€™s premature and blighted â€˜awakeningâ€™ which predominates the beginning of The Reader, there are aspects of the book which definitely make it worthwhile.Michael Bern is fifteen when he meets Hanna Schmitz, who is more than twice his age. What starts off as a physical affair turns into something quite different, a voyage of discovery through the Great Books of Literature. Homerâ€™s Odyssey provides the thematical basis for the rest of the book which is that although our destiny is ever homeward, in fact we can never return to the same â€˜homeâ€™ and certainly we canâ€™t if we intend to reach this â€“ or any â€“ destination via physical or mental means. Indeed, the entire purpose of Literature is to change anyone who steps into its proverbial river. In this respect, Schlinkâ€™s novel is an archetype in much the same vein as Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress ; one will be both the richer â€“ and the poorer (in terms of lost innocence) â€“ for setting out on a journey of reading. I believe that is why both authors tie sexuality to the art of reading. Valuable insights/qualities in The Reader include: the folly and volatility of youthful self-perception; the complexity of the human creature, i.e., the fallen from Grace still possess a great desire to do Good, see Justice and know Truth; unanswerable questions, at least to those lacking any spiritual dimension or basis and a severe critique on books and reading.Based on my initial prejudices about this book I obtained it from the library as opposed to purchasing my own copy in which I usually highlight favorite quotes, outline and/or make notes to myself. As such, I was forced to make use of removable page tabs to indicate notable passages; I stopped marking such places when I reached fifteen. However, the ultimate insight can be found on page 157. A more mature Michael is trying to come to grips with Hannaâ€™s role in The Holocaust and his own shared responsibility for her crimes, despite the fact he was born after World War II. Here is what he says:â€˜I wanted simultaneously to understand Hannaâ€™s crime and condemn it. But it was too terrible for that. When I tried to understand it, I had the feeling I was failing to condemn it as it must be condemned. When I condemned it as it must be condemned, there was no room for understanding. But even as I wanted to understand Hanna, failing to understand her meant betraying her all over again. I could not resolve this. I wanted to pose myself both tasksâ€”understanding and condemnation. But it was impossible to do both.â€™ Indeed, perhaps that also describes the position I find myself in as a reviewer of The Reader. As an incredibly insightful book which I did not like, Iâ€™ve struggled with how to rate it. Ultimately, Iâ€™m settling on two stars but only as a compromise between my distaste for the story's somewhat cynical and morose perspective and my appreciation of the truths the author offers. I am reminded of Sophie Scholl and Dietrich Bonhoeffer, two German martyrs of the same era who found something worth living â€“ and dying â€“ for much greater than reading.

Previewâ€¦I chose to delve into Bernhard Schlinkâ€™s novel â€œThe Reader,â€ because, at only 218 pages, it seemed like a short and sweet selection. Although the actual word count was small, the story within was huge on meaning and teeming with deeply resonating themes. I found myself setting it down, time and time again, so that I could reflect on a series of particularly poignant passages.â€œThe Readerâ€ is a novel told in three parts. We begin with our narrator at age 15, growing up in the precarious climate of post-war Germany. Coming home from school one day, Michael becomes overwhelmed by sickness. An unknown woman cleans him up and sees him safely home.Later on Michael seeks out this woman to offer his thanks. Although there is a 21-year age difference between the boy and his benefactor, Hanna, the sexual attraction is undeniable. The two give themselves to each other physically, while holding back on the emotional entanglements of love. For months they continue on with their routine affair, which includes Hanna bathing Michael, Michael reading aloud to Hanna from various works of classic literature, and the two consummating their amorphous relationship. Until, without any warning, Hanna completely disappears.Years later, their paths intersect once more. As a young law student, Michael is observing the war crime trials of a group of female SS guards pertaining to a specific atrocity that led to the deaths of more than 300 Jewish women. Hanna is among the accused.Michael is sent into frenzied introspection. How could he have ever cared for such a heartless criminal? Was it just Hanna, whom he loved undeservingly, or should he have held back love to all of his elders involved in this tumultuous time period, everyone including his own parents though they were not active participants?Michael is haunted by his memory of Hanna, unable to carry-on healthy adult relationships. He doesnâ€™t know whether to be angry at her for spoiling his innocence, and he doesnâ€™t know how he feels now upon reflection. Unable to escape her ubiquitous presence in his mind, he strikes up a clouded correspondence with her. He reads aloud to her, just as they had always done before. Recording his dictations, he mails the tapes to her in prison with no formal salutations or small talk â€” just the tapes.Upon Hannaâ€™s approaching release from prison, Michael must determine what the nature of their relationship is and whether or not to allow her into his life once more. Now, as it has been throughout her entire life, Hanna must decide whether it is more important to speak the truth or to protect oneself from shame.A powerful journey, â€œThe Readerâ€ asks us to examine our own relations to our countries, our loved ones and ourselves, and it points out that sometimes lifeâ€™s most important relationships elude definition.You may like this book ifâ€¦you like introspective novels, you are interested in post-war Germany and the Holocaust, you enjoy novels that are written in simple, yet powerful, language, you like novels that ask the question: "what would you do in this situation?", you are interested in courtroom drama and the Nuremberg trials, you want to understand the meaning of the title (itâ€™s been perfectly selected), you enjoyed the Oscar-winning film adaptation from 2008, you like being emotionally overcome by your reading selections, you like nontraditional â€œloveâ€ stories, you have a dark sentimentality when it comes to the arts.You may not like this book ifâ€¦you prefer not to read about something so emotionally raw as the Holocaust, you need the questions to be answered if they are going to be asked, you canâ€™t get past the love affair between the boy and the woman.

I will promise you that there will be no spoilers but I will give you the structure of the main plot (whatever that means).I just finished reading this long overdue romantic/dramatic novel by Bernard Schlink. This is one of the first two books (the other one was Mysterious Benedict Society)I came to the bookstore a long time ago (probably four years ago) that I took note of and remembered it ever since so when I found this book in Booksale, a secondhand bookstore, just imagine my joy!The book is a love story between a fifteen year old boy and a thirty seven year old woman, that's how the story started. They fall in love (first part), they fall apart (second part) and they fall out of love (third part).Itâ€™s only two hundred pages long and it could have been finished in just three or four hours but I finished it in one week. (Reasons: TV series and university life) The first part was my favorite part of all â€˜cause there is a ten percent probability that Iâ€™m a pervert. It was an erotic love story, indeed, as the summary at the end of the book says. The second part, years later of part one, which slowed me down gets a little philosophical and becomes a little bit of a crime novel but the good news was that it still remained a Bernard Schlink love story even if this part may seem like a scene from a crime novel. (Wait, he also write crime novels, right?) The third part is another years later and it is the best in the book. Itâ€™s a summary of the second part and a reminiscing of the first part. It includes what happened next to both of their lives and the last three chapters made me cry so damn hard.The book is very personal to me, I have no valid reasons why, but only because it touched me in some way. The edition that I bought had Kate Winslet on the cover which was fine by me but the thing that I really liked about the book is the font, the way the short chapters and parts made readers want more, the language of Schlink and the (hopefully) accurate translator and of course its emotional grounds.The movie adaptation will be reviewed (for the sake of writing something for this blog) on Saturday. I have it on my phone and watching it by parts, which could be not a good idea.Thanks for reading, I hope youâ€™ll get your own copy soon. (Or you could borrow mine if you lived near Quezon City, Philippines)Further reading says the last page: Crime and Punishment. (Putting it in my reading list for next year)
Love love loved. It wasn't what I expected but it really didn't disappoint at all. There's so much I want to say but I'm not quite ready to put it in to words yet.

It's not always that I finish a book and stare at my surroundings while still pondering should I exclaim "Wow" or try to decipher why I am sad. It's not always that I go numb for a while after finishing the book and a particular character keep hitting my head like a hammer on the nail. Michael is 15 year old and one day on his way to school he falls sick and is rescued by Hannah, a 36 year old street car conductor. What follows is a sensual encounter between the two and both continue a furtive courtship full of passion, intense love-making, vacations and romance. Michael becomes bewitched by Hana and falls in love with her but her silences perturbs him. She keeps mum about her past life and is hardly ever seen in public. She asks Michael to read to her and they spend much time with books- Michael reading her popular German classics. One day Hannah disappears without any trace or explanation. Life moves on and Michael joins law school. He is supposed to attend a trial as a part of his course, where he sees Hannah again. She is being tried for a hideous crime but it doesn't take Michael to realize that during the trial, through her obscure arguments having various loopholes, her momentary blank stares and her peculiar silence, she is trying to guard a secret- a secret about herself that she doesn't want anyone to know, which Michael is soon to find out."The Reader" is a hard-hitting tale of passion, love, guilt and a meditation on choices one makes in life. The story has mention of holocaust and it takes place in Post-war Germany and you might want to step in the shoes of someone who has been through the tragic era to actually understand Hannah's behavior and her secret. The book, towards the end, will also leave you wondering- wondering about who was right and who was wrong or if no one was right or wrong and it was just circumstances cunningly setting things the way they came out to be. Very strongly recommended. Find other interesting reviews on our blog "The BookTrack" here- https://thebooktrack.wordpress.com/Also join our facebook group for Freak Deals on books, recommendations, discussions and connect to readers from all across the world-https://www.facebook.com/groups/thebo...

4.5/5 â€” A book of questions about humanity, not eroticism nor the HolocaustWhat is right, wrong? What is bad, good? I think that most people can answer those questions easily enough when the definitions are broad and abstract. It depends on their history, their worldview. In The Reader we are given complex circumstances in which to face those questions. Michael is in the thick of it, wrestling between emotion and rationality not only within his own mind but in his social world with Hanna and everyone else. And that's the way life really presents the ideas and subsequent decisions of morality, ethics, action and inaction, guilt, forgiveness, love, hate, indifference. Not as they are defined on paper in a classroom but when you're out on the street. To me, there was the contrast between Michael's relationships with his father and Hanna that illustrated such a difference. The cold philosopher versus the layered beloved. The decisions become harder for Michael, and us. No matter the torments of Michael or Hanna or the reader, there is always this evidence of answer, which I quote from the book:
The truth of what one says lies in what one does.
I haven't even mentioned the story of the book, which I just finished. To my mind, it is a good one. It must be, to leave me in such deep thought. Doesn't that speak to the strength of a story? That a reader immediately reflects on his qualities of belief, and not only his, but of humanity? I think so. I've asked many questions here. This is a book of questions. While telling his story, Michael asks an abundance of them. They are for himself, which is also to say that they are for the reader. Like us, Michael must settle his struggles for himself. But that might not be possible. Some things do not resolve, do not end. Perhaps a piece is missing or a fork in the road is too difficult a choice. Yet, we naturally desire to close things. This leaves us in peril. 
Now to escape involves not just running away, but arriving somewhere.
Getting there can take a lifetime, or a life.

Beyond words.!!!A rare feat.!!!It doesn't happen daily that one comes across a book that doesn't let you even bite your nails. Out of my habit,I did bite my nails in the beginning,but as the story progressed,I decided to stop biting my nails since it was causing me distraction,however tiny it was. So you can see how much interested I was in the book..Throughout the book,I felt three themes as the prominent ones-love,shame and literacy(or reading).. Even though other themes like holocaust is there,these were the currents that guided the story. LOVE..There are all kinds of love in this world,but never the same love twice..How true does Fitzgerald sound.!!The love in this story,the love between Hanna and Michael,seems so strange and yet when we see its many dimensions,it doesn't appear so strange at all. The love story between two people so distant in their age and social position.. Age never has been a barrier in love.. Still..Michael's position in the story seems desperate.. He never outgrows his childhood fascination and tries to see Hanna in all the women who come into his life.. No matter how much he grow up,he still remains that 15-year old at his heart.. Shame..Shame is yet another factor which plays a big role in the story,along with guilt. Michael's shame makes him distant from others. His feeling of guilt never lets him be honest to anybody,not even to his wife. Hanna's feeling of shame(of being called an illiterate) brings her downfall,keeping her behind bars till her death. She decides to outgrow her sensitivities only at a later stage of her life,when Michael starts sending the tapes. Literacy..Reading.. ha.. we are back at my favorite spot.. How wonderful Hanna must have felt when an entire new universe was opened to her in Michael's voice.! It is contagious,the way she loved listening to books. It would have been fun,to have a reader like that.. The book is so good that it wouldn't let you do anything else till it is finished. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

When I saw this book in a thrift store a week ago, in the hands of woman I barely knew, I said to myself that I will never get out of this store without it carefully tucked between my armpit. Luckily, the woman brought it down and I paid for it first thing when she left the store. Truly, good books will find you.The story revolves around Michael Berg, a fifteen year old German boy and his affair with a woman twice his age, Hannah. They made love every afternoon. Eventually, their afternoon ritual included reading books aloud. Michael read it to Hannah. Hannahâ€™s a great listener. But one day, she left.. And everything followed after that. Michael Berg was left craving for her. Turned out Hanna has a secret past. And another secret, which she finds shameful.I found The Reader more than what I bargained for. Itâ€™s a thought provoking book with post World War II issues and moral conundrums to ponder in every page. The book gives us glimpse of what Germany looks like after the second World War, how coming to terms with the past and finding the way home are activities that resonate with Germans living in the aftermath of World War II and the reunification of Germany. I admire the depth of every character. Readers will be called to judge the actions of both characters, and by that I experienced the difficulty of letting â€œjustice pour down like waters and righteousness like an ever-flowing streamâ€ in a world in which both justice and righteousness have lost their deontological moorings.I recommend it for anyone who has ever felt the rain. I have to say that at first, I only read it for the sexual parts. I was there, craving alongside with Michael, but mind you, the book is more than that.

THE READER has been billed as everything from a holocaust story to a love story. It has been touted as a â€œmust readâ€ and has appeared on the LA Times Book of the Year list, as well as being an Oprah selection. (Being selected by Oprah should have been a dead give-awayâ€¦..I have yet to like anything she selects).At any rate, one would think that this story of the relationship (both emotional and sexual) between a fifteen year old boy and a 40 year old woman played out against the backdrop of the Holocaust would present a compelling read, but if these were your expectations then you, like I, would be sadly disappointed.The lovers donâ€™t really share anything remotely related to love, Hannah is secretive and remote and as a couple the two protagonists are distant and unsympathetic (almost appearing as observers in their own lives rather that participants). The courtroom scenes are bland, and the final revelation of â€œHannahâ€™s secretâ€ is an almost laughable â€œsinâ€ when compared to the horrors of the concentration camps. This is one of those â€œwhat is itâ€ stories. Is it supposed to be the story of a countries collective guilt, a coming of age tale, a crusade for literacy, or just the mundane tale of a basically self-absorbed, insensitive woman and an impressionable young boy? Whatever the author intended, all that comes across is a bland recitation of dates, times, facts and suppositions which fail to engage the reader.How Hollywood ever chose this monochromatic book as appropriate fodder for a movie is beyond me. Too bad there is no rating of less than one star for that is what this book deserves.

Rarely does a book just ram into my heart and mind like The Reader did and then leave me feeling deeply satisfied with the whole experience. I've yet to see the movie but suspect it will not disappoint.Anyone who has seen the movie (probably more people than have read the book) will know the whole plot but I don't want to give it away. Easily half of the greatness of the book is the way the plot is revealed and I for one, did not see any of it coming. Each revelation caused me to catch my breath and marvel.The theme of guilt is strong and tough and hit me where I live because of my ancestry (German) and religious upbringing (Lutheran). Schlink creates a stew of desire, sin and lost dreams but the broth is guilt: personal, familial, societal and judicial. If that sounds daunting and heavy, it is; but the writing is so perfect and seems to soothe the reader, seems to indicate that it will be alright in the end. Until the end, when nothing is right.Michael Berg, a teen just recovering from a long illness, with hormones raging and longing for a closeness with his father that he will never have, tells the story from his viewpoint. He is a typical European postwar individual, growing up in a world with few ideals.Hannah is a mature woman with a hard, cynical veneer that barely hides all manner of conflicts as mysterious to Michael as they are to herself. Once they begin a relationship, they are locked together by forces that neither understand. In an admirable economy of words, Schlink takes us through the years, the twists and turns that seem to ruin Michael's life, until we see that the ruin is mankind's.

*******SPOILERS!!!****Early in the book it would appear that Michael has become involved in a "Tea & Sympathy" type relationship with Anna. In addition to the sexual activities, his times spent with her increasingly required that he read to her a broad and varied assortment of literature. He,as a 15 year old, became adept at hiding his liasons with this much older woman from everyone.Despite his feelings of love for her, there are many aspects of her behavior which puzzled him. After many months of this sexual relationship, she moved away without any explanation.As one continues through this book and his growth into maturity,it is quite apparent that Michael has erected a shell of coolness about himself. He appears aloof to others and finds difficulty in his personal relationships. At one point in this story he questions the reader whether it has been observed that he has never mentioned his mother throughout the book.Rather than describe a complete synopsis here,it is sufficient to state that much turmoil and horror develop as this novel continues. Schlink has done well with his character development of both Anna and Michael as the book progresses. He has evoked much analysis of the motives and actions of both main characters, which continue to remain open to many interpretations.I managed to view the DVD of "The Reader" upon conclusion of my reading. The movie captured this story very well, with minimal changes which were necessary to describe certain scenes in the book.

I admit it. This book sat on my shelf a while, and was almost doomed to obscurity when I found out it had been chosen as one for the club by Oprah. But once I picked it up, I whizzed through it.At first, I wondered if the style of writing- distant, reserved- was a function of the translation from the original German. But in retrospect, I don't think so. The reserve that Michael and Hannah have through much of their relationship- the withholding of information from each other- and the somewhat clinical catharsis that Michael claims for writing the book, are well served by the coolness in language. This is not a novel of passion, though it does have passion in it, but a novel of exploration and examination. It is to the author's credit and to his translator Carol Brown Janeway, that the book reads so easily and so well.The story explores extremely difficult subjects, including the Holocaust. But it is also about coming to terms with guilt. And there are so many types of guilt and so many reactions explored in the pages.I imagine this was a book popular with bookclubs all over the place.PS My review of this book was published in our local paper on March 27,2009http://charleston.net/news/2009/mar/2...

What an incredible book.And the film too.I'm now a fan of both Bernhard Schlink and Kate Winslet.This podcast was amazing: http://www.podcastchart.com/podcasts/...The question of guilt, proximity and living beyond the past are dealt with and I already feel I need to go back and read this book again.Dinner needs cooking, the clothes need bringing in from the line and the children are calling.... Will return to edit this later this evening.8/7/16:I have not forgotten that I had intended to return and write this properly...Read an article from The Guardian : Schlink says the main theme of The Reader is this generational divide and accommodation. "It is definitely not a book about the Holocaust. It is a book about how the second generation attempted to come to terms with the Holocaust and the role in it played by their fathers' generation." Still meaning to go back and listen to the podcast above.

3.5. I picked this up at World Book Night and was spurred to read it after seeing Didi's 4 star review. It's very well-written (and presumably well translated). Schlink's style verges on floral, foregrounding emotion without slipping into sheer nostalgia. Something I assumed early on (the "deep secret" of the blurb) turned out to be the big reveal, which dampened my enjoyment somewhat. Schlink is great at undercutting tension of plot point reveals in favour of the characters' emotions and actions that follow, which I liked. At times, though, it wound up feeling a tad predictable. What it lacks in plot it makes up for in fantastic use of metaphor and in raising ethical questions on a personal level. With a few reservations, it's a great, short read, and definitely one of those good books for the bookish.

Desgarradora historia que nos deja con ganas de mÃ¡s. Que maravillosa historia he leÃ­do en menos de tres horas. Todo me fascinÃ³, desde la maravillosa prosa hasta Michael, nuestro gran protagonista. Es una historia sumamente interesante que me hizo comprender mucho acerca del tema de la Segunda Guerra Mundial. Los personajesEsto es lo mÃ¡s flojo de la historia. No hay muchos personajes y los que hay estÃ¡n algo desdibujados y poco descritos. Michael, el protagonista, es el mejor personaje de todos. Wow okay. The sexual content in the first quarter of this was just weird, but I was really interested in this once we got past that. I'm excited for the class discussions about this one!

This is one of those books that you can read and re-read and never tired of. Bernhard Schlink takes fiction and turn it into this believable story so full and rich that I had to go check if it really were fiction and not a memoir.The characters becomes a part of you, you live through them, you see through them, you taste, smell and feel exactly what they do.Michael and Henna - their story - will be with me for ever. The truths they teach will be a guidance to me for as long as I live.Also I must add, this is not a 'war' story, but the second world war does play a great part of it.This is not a 'love' story, but love plays it's part like it does in each of our lifes. What this is, is a treasure, and the choice is yours - open it up, or let it be.

I wish I'd read this before seeing the film. The film seemed to me, from what I remember of it, to be a fairly good adaptation, but it lacks the moral debate that seems to me to be what drives this book. It's a novel, at first, about attraction and desire, but then moves to a much deeper treatise on moral philosophy, conscience, and identity. I felt for Hanna, I really did. She was tragic, but realistically so - her life got caught up with circumstances and external events in a way that could happen to anyone. Can we pass judgement on her without taking into account her life and circumstances? I don't think I can. My anger lies with our narrator, The Reader himself. I wish he'd spoken up for her.

The prose is spare, in fact, very simple. I am not a fast reader and for me to read over 100 pages a day is very unusual. There is nothing wrong with the prose, just that it wasn't very interesting to me.The story is one I had not encountered before - post-war Germany beginning in the late 50s. The first person narrator does not think about the war as he has not experienced it. It is only until he gets a bit older that he must think about the holocaust.I think the author could have done so much more with his idea. The use of the first person shuts down a more fully explored characterization. The ending is emotional, to be sure, but we get to it too abruptly.

For starters- I am surprised this book received anything less than 4 stars. I thought it was fantastic. The Reader was a short, yet profound read. I found the character development to be meticulous, and I suppose if you aren't patient in your reading, that could be confused with a boring book. I, however, rather enjoy extremely well thought out characters. The story was raw and honest. I could feel emotions moving through this book.

Started book at 8pm last night. Resumed reading at 5am. Handed coffee. Barely noticed. I don't know how many stars to give this book. 1, 15, 100? This work is that thought provoking and provocative. Will sleep on and digest before writing review. Thank you goes to my dear friend Jennifer - sleep on it and digest before committing to rating or writing a review.This is a definite PLEASE PUT ON YOUR TO-READ LIST.I haven't come across anything quite like this before.

This was a sweet love story; it never felt like fiction in the least for me. I loved the lady in the story and her love and till today I can visualize how she must have conducted herself, talked, etc. The book just was so real. I wish to read more books like it! My heart went out for the lady a lot as I could imagine her pain... and the realities of life that follows... I just hope to find more books like that, and also to read other books by the same author.
