There are a lot of complaints here about this book being dry, and the writing falling flat and distant. On my view, that is this exactly what makes this book work- think about all the distasteful, traumatic novels that are written about the subject of the Holocaust. I'm not saying that the subject itself is not traumatic, but the fact that some people take advantage of it in an attempt to mirror the suffering in order to make money is simply sick. Besides, there is usually no greater reflection inside them than the universally acknowledged truth that Nazis were horrible. Furthermore, the sparse tone in "The Reader" was supposed to mirror the "numbness" felt by Michael and people in general, the anesthetic effect that treated the War as an everyday subject, and spared our protagonist of feelings and of the questions that accompanied them. Yes, it was the questions that he was afraid of- just like Hanna, who didn't even know some questions could be asked. The numbness Hanna felt was a numbness of thought, which allowed her to live only in the present; never having planned a thing. That of course contrasts Michael's obsession for History, in the way that he is obsessed with Hanna, because his past and the German past were the same. But I'm getting off-topic here- I was talking about questions. When one doesn't question, one is prone to have the answers given to him. That was what allowed Nazism to happen. Numbness of thought. I think Adorno wrote something like this in "Education after Auschwitz", but I could be mistaken. Anyway, that's where the illiteracy plays a part- a metaphore for not being able to think. Reading and writing, active thinking, are able to surpress yhis, the book is trying to say. It's not just that, though- I suspect it's also about art, and the fact that art is a questioning force. A force of nature, and feeling. Movement. Indeed, the moment when Michael starts the reccording sessions is a very powerful one. He can't communicate. He's lost whatever he had when he was young, and he doesn't know how to feel anymore, so he feels through books. Books that allow him to be both distant and close to Hanna at the same time. Subjectively speaking, I think that Michael loved Hanna only because she was a blank to him, so he could fill her with whatever he wanted. And, then, she suddenly gained a past, which gave new meaning to his adolescent memories. What is the truth, who is Hanna, who is he... He loved, he loves her. Not quite her, though. But his ignorance on the First Part could be compared to her ignorance. And he is as ashamed of her as she is of being illiterate. I don't think the question of the book was whether Hanna was actually a bad person- as much as the last pages try to advocate for her and show us her side (another interesting aspect of the book- Parte 1: idealized Hanna; Part 2:demonized Hanna; Part 3: mature conclusions. Although further analysis would contradict this simple generalization), it is easy to distrust her good intentions. That is, however, for one to decide, that is one's opinion, and, to be honest, maybe it doesn't even have an answer. People aren't judged for what they are, they are judged- and convicted- for what they've done. Now, are we what we've done? Is Existentialism truly a Humanism? Or do we actually need tools in order to become ourselves? Who are we?Michael's observations were at times more poetic than the story itself- whenever he wonders off, it's to point out an aspect of everyone's lives that no one had noticed yet- basic principle for a good book. He speaks about the happy pasts spoiled by dark truths, even if things were happy and happened a long time ago. He speaks of Germans rebelling against their country as the same as them rebelling against their parents.He speaks of the abstract world his father lived in as if the window in his room was a painting. Those were the ones I heard. His conversation with his father, by the way, was one of the most believable dialogues I have ever read. When he realizes that his father has regretted his past, later. Not that he'd had a Nazi past. He was just... absent. And he thought of that, later, but he was acting as if he'd always been who he was in the present, or as if the past didn't matter, or as if it hurt too much to think of the past. And Michael understood. That was brilliant. Generally, it was a pretty good book. The tree stars rathing is merely based on personal taste and opinions- it disturbed me that, along with all the questions Berg was supposely asking himself, he did not once consider that Hanna had abused him. But I guess it's because he felt guilty of every single one of his actions as a teenager. On the other hand, that only happened because he blamed Hanna. It's true that the Daughter later on makes a remark on the subject, but the book could have gone a little further on the matter without having become another disgusting work designed to attract sadists. He could simply have written a chapter about it, and that would be it. Although I think the hypothesis seems to somewhat perpetually permeate "The Reader", and that was the effect Schlink was searching for; a subtle hint. Still, I was under the impression that it was on the outside, and Michael never really gave it a thought- he didn't even need to recognize anything, he'd just... give it a thought. Anyway, that is my opinion. Moreover- and more objectively-, while I appreciate the message and the metaphores, I don't think "The Reader" should rely solely on this. It's not that I think time will forget about this book- time never forgets, we have learned. But you see, he talks about a lot of things, but never really insists on them. He insists on the metaphores and messages, to make sure you get them right, and as a 21st century reader I find this medieval practice rather annoying. None of this is translating my feeling towards the book, however. It is possible I can't quite explain why I didn't think this book was tremendously special. The plot was interesting enough, but it wasn't as interesting as The New York Trilogy for instance. It was philosophical enough, but it didn't come anywhere close to Chekhov or J.D. Salinger. When I think about it, I see a house sustaining itself without walls or windows, I see a ground and beams emerging from the ground, and the beams are connected to other beams framing an empty roof. Not that I know what that means. Probably that there is too much visible structure in this book, now that I have a chance to actually understand my impression. Yeah, that's it. Three stars. Perhaps one day I'll read it again.

Is it bad that I really liked this book? From some of the other reviews, I should hate this book. I should think it's fluff or cheesy or banal or pointless or underdeveloped, but I enjoyed it! Okay, it's short, so there's maybe not as much character development as one might like (we never really learn much about Hanna, and come to think of it, we don't learn *much* about Michael, either), but I still thought it was enough of a story to keep me reading for hours at a time. For me, this was a forget-all-of-your-responsibilities-for-the-day book; not many of my chores or tasks have gotten done the past two days, but man, I tore through that book! (And again, yes, it's short, so it's easier to tear through, but whatever.)I enjoyed Michael's contemplations and ponderings about the war, the Holocaust, the camp guards' roles, the villagers' roles during the Holocaust, and the later generations' responsibilities to history. And I liked the story: yes, the 15-year-old boy getting it on with the 36-year-old woman is a little overdone, but at least it wasn't done poorly here; if the trial hadn't been included in most synopses of the book, I would have been surprised by it; I was surprised by the twist of Hanna's shortcoming that was revealed; and I was certainly surprised by the ending, and really liked the way it was handled over the last few chapters.I was actually on a five-star path with this until I read reviews of it about halfway through. Then I changed my thoughts to four stars because I obviously must be missing something. Darn all you people who trashed it! You made me doubt my enjoyment of it!

I have had this book on my shelf for far too long. I am glad to have finally got around to reading it. I remember when the book became a movie, my mother-in-law was watching it at my house while baby sitting our son. I ended up seeing the ending of the movie but at that time I was not reading and wasn't worried about spoilers. My impression of the book before I started reading was that it took place around World War II and involved a trial.After finishing part one of the book I was surprised that it was all about the relationship between Hanna and Michael, nothing about World War II. The age difference is prominent in the story; Michael is 15 and Hanna is stated as twice his age. Of course this is an inappropriate relationship but somehow in this story it works. As a reader I feel conflicted. â€œImagine someone is racing intentionally towards his own destruction and you can save him â€“ do you go ahead and save him?â€Wow, part three of the book is gut wrenching. I had forgotten one of the main plot twits at the end and I was in tears. I thought this book was about many things; history, holocaust, coming-of-age but ultimately it was about relationships. At first very uncomfortable about the relationship between Hanna and Michael but by the end I thought is the most beautiful but complex relationship I have read about. I think this is one of those rare books that pack quite a punch in a mere 200 pages. I know this is a book and story that will stay with me for a long time. I am so looking forward to the movie as I love Kate Winslet and Ralph Fieness.

Lima bintang untuk novelnya, lima bintang untuk filmnya. Keduanya keren!Dilatarbelakangi dengan cerita soal kamp konsentrasi di zaman Nazi, Sang Juru Baca bercerita tentang Michael dan Hanna yang saling jatuh cinta. Setelah menjalani hubungan selama satu musim panas (termasuk kesenangan Hanna dibacakan cerita oleh Michael), tiba-tiba Hanna menghilang dan Michael nggak bisa move on dibuatnya.Aduh, tema nggak-bisa-move-on ini memang bikin meringis. Kesetiaan seseorang terhadap seseorang lainnya, entah kenapa, selalu terasa pedih. Nggak cuma setahun dua tahun tapi puluhan tahun. Bagaimana mungkin seseorang terjebak perasaan di masa lalu sampai selama itu? Hanya pemilik perasaan yang kuat yang mampu bertahan.Belum lagi, kemudian, terjadi pertentangan batin antara mencintai dan membenci. Kau punya semua alasan untuk membenci seseorang, tetapi kau juga punya semua alasan untuk mencintainya. Bubarrrr!!!â€œKetika aku mencoba memahami, aku merasa gagal untuk mengutuknya sebagaimana perbuatan itu seharusnya dikutuk. Ketika aku mengutuknya sebagaimana harus mengutuknya, tidak ada lagi ruang untuk memahami. ... Aku ingin mengambil sikap di antara kedua tugas: memahami dan mengutuk. Tapi mustahil untuk melakukan keduanya.â€-Hal. 164

Een 15 jarige jongen wordt verliefd op een oudere vrouw, hij is verslaafd aan haar en leest haar voor.Ze verdwijnt plots en hij ziet haar terug als hoofdverdachte op een proces tegen kampbewaaksters. Ze wordt veroordeeld en hij stuurt haar in de gevangenis cassettes waarop hij voorleest. Het wordt ook duidelijk waarom hij haar vroeger moest voorlezen. Een boek over kwetsen en gekwetst worden, schuld en schaamte, collectief en persoonlijk in de BRD na de oorlog.

It was very difficult to really get involved in this book, seeing as it was so short. All of the descriptions felt very rushed and cold, and I just.... didn't really care all that much? I also remember that I didn't much care for the movie, either, when I saw it a few years ago.Too bad, when this was supposed to be a tale of passion, and love, and redemption, and all that jazz. I can't even give it a properly sized review because I just didn't care about it enough.

2.75This book kicked off pretty disturbing before it turned into something fairly interesting. I liked the court part and the ethical questions and literate aspects of the story (the reading, the "audiobooking", the illiterate storyline)So I liked it okay I guess. Even though the first part was a little uncomfortable to read and I had no idea that the plot of this book would discuss national socialism. This was my first book for the #7in7readathon!

I read Bernhard Schlinkâ€™s â€˜Homecomingâ€™ last year and liked it very much. I have wanted to read other books by him since then, especially his more famous book â€˜The Readerâ€™. So when German Literature Month arrived this year I added â€˜The Readerâ€™ to my â€˜Must readâ€™ list. I finished reading it today. Here is what I think.I am not going to bore you with the plot outline of the story, as you have probably seen the movie version of â€˜The Readerâ€™ (for which Kate Winslet won an Oscar). What I would like to say after reading the book is this. The movie stays more or less faithful to the book with some minor liberties to the screenplay. When I read the book and the parts about Hanna, Kate Winsletâ€™s face kept coming to my mind. That is one of the problems of seeing the movie version before reading the book. Which one is better â€“ the movie or the book? I saw the movie a few years back when it came out and I can only talk about what I remember now about the impression the movie created on me at that time. With our memory being unreliable most times, I would take my own comparison with a pinch of salt. But if I stick my neck out and make the comparison, I would say that the movie and the book were good in different ways. The movie was good in terms of creating a visual picture of the story and saying things which cannot be said in words. The book is good with respect to the philosophical discussions which are explored through the narratorâ€™s voice, which is difficult to do in a movie. The reasoning behind Hannaâ€™s reluctance to reveal her secret is also better explained in the book. It also leaves many clues to the central mystery which I donâ€™t remember the movie doing. The book also mentions many German books and writers â€“ Intrigues and Love by Schiller, Schnitzler, Heller, Fontane, Heine Morike, Kafka, Frisch, Johnson, Bachmann, Lenz â€“ one can make a â€˜TBRâ€™ list out of it ïŠ The things about Bernhard Schlinkâ€™s prose in â€˜Homecomingâ€™ that I liked very much were all there in â€˜The Readerâ€™ â€“ the deceptively simple prose which hides the depth of the philosophical ideas and questions he addresses, the insightful observations on different things, the quotable quotes in every chapter. I thought that as I knew the story already, the book wouldnâ€™t affect me that much. But inspite of that, the ending was still heartbreaking. Hanna is a beautiful, haunting heroine and I will never forget her. I wish things had turned out differently. If you have seen the movie version of â€˜The Readerâ€™, I donâ€™t know whether I should recommend the book to you. It is good in its own right, but all the surprises have been revealed if you have already watched the movie. But if you havenâ€™t watched the movie, then I would recommend that you read the book first and then watch the movie. I will leave you with some of my favourite passages from the book. Then I began to betray her. Not that I gave away any secrets or exposed Hanna. I didnâ€™t reveal anything that I should have kept to myself. I kept something to myself that I should have revealed. I didnâ€™t acknowledge her. I know that disavowal is an unusual form of betrayal. From the outside it is impossible to tell if you are disowning someone or simply exercising discretion, being considerate, avoiding embarrassments and sources of irritation. But you, who are doing the disowning, you know what youâ€™re doing. And disavowal pulls the underpinnings away from a relationship just as surely as other more flamboyant types of betrayal. â€˜Iâ€¦I meanâ€¦so what would you have done?â€™ Hanna meant it as a serious question. She did not know what she should or could have done differently, and therefore wanted to hear from the judge, who seemed to know everything, what he would have done. Everything was quiet for a moment. It is not the custom at German trials for defendants to question the judges. But now the question had been asked, and everyone was waiting for the judgeâ€™s answer. He had to answer; he could not ignore the question or brush it away with a reprimand or a dismissive counterquestion. It was clear to everyone, it was clear to him too, and I understood why he had adopted an expression of irritation as his defining feature. It was his mask. Behind it, he could take a little time to find an answer. But not too long; the longer he took, the greater the tension and expectation, and the better his answer had to be.Now escape involves not just running away, but arriving somewhere. And the past I arrived in as a legal historian was no less alive than the present. It is also not true, as outsiders might assume, that one can merely observe the richness of life in the past, whereas one can participate in the present. Doing history means building bridges between the past and the present, observing both banks of the river, taking an active part on both sides.Have you read â€˜The Readerâ€™ by Bernhard Schlink? What do you think about it?

Powerful, shocking, heartbreaking. Strange sad journey of a trauma before & after the relationships that developed. This is a different type of holocaust book, from a very different perspective. The horrors & the ripple of influence go on long after the camps were closed & the offenders were punished. Great read.
it was the best !

Per vergogna? La donna che si Ã¨ amata, e che rimane nel cuore per tutta la vita non merita dâ€™essere scagionata da una colpa orrenda di cui non Ã¨ responsabile? Ma poi per buon cuore registra su nastro un buon numero di libri e glieli invia in carcere.Â â€œAl tempo stesso mi chiedo, e cominciai a chiedermelo giÃ  allora: ma cosa doveva e deve farsene, la mia generazione di nati dopo, delle informazioni sulle atrocitÃ  dello sterminio degli ebrei? Noi non dobbiamo pensare di poter comprendere ciÃ² che Ã¨ incomprensibile, non possiamo comparare ciÃ² che Ã¨ incomparabile, non possiamo indagare, perchÃ© chi indaga sulle atrocitÃ , anche se non le mette in discussione, ne fa comunque oggetto di comunicazione e non ottiene che qualcosa di fronte a cui puÃ² solo ammutolire per l'orrore, la colpa e la vergogna. Dobbiamo solo ammutolire per l'orrore, la colpa e la vergogna? A quale scopo? No, non Ã¨ che l'ardore della rielaborazione e lo zelo di far luce, con cui avevo partecipato al seminario, fossero andati perduti durante il dibattimento. Ma che solo pochi venissero condannati e puniti e che noi, la generazione venuta dopo, ci ritrovassimo ammutoliti dall'orrore, dalla colpa e dalla vergogna: era giusto che fosse cosÃ¬?â€Â A quale scopo? Io dico: allo scopo di mantenere viva la memoria in modo che lâ€™orrore non si compia nuovamente. E allo scopo di crescere nuove coscienze che traggano insegnamento dalla Storia.Se Ã¨ vero che le colpe dei padri non devono ricadere sui figli (e per figli intendo la generazione dei venuti dopo) Ã¨ altrettanto vero che i figli hanno lâ€™obbligo morale di non reiterare le colpe dei padri. Questo vale per la Germania, come per lâ€™Italia o qualunque altra nazione.Non ci si deve vergognare, ma indignare, sÃ¬.Â Bella scrittura, ma distaccata, fredda. La â€œStoriaâ€ sfiorata. The Reader, by Bernhard Schlink, takes place in postwar Germany. Michael Berg's high school year is interrupted by hepititis. The last day he managed to stumble into school, he didn't make it home on his own. He'd thrown up on Banhofstrasse, where a brusque, determined woman cleaned him up, carried his school books, and walked him home.Months later, when Michael was well again, he bought flowers, returned to Banhofstrasse, introduced himself, and thanked this woman, as he was expected to do. That is how Michael comes to meet Hanna again. What follows is an affair between the 15-year-old Michael and the thirty-something Hanna, in which Hanna has the upper hand. An important part of their time together involves her insistence that Michael read to her, which he does, reluctantly at first, and then with enthusiasm. During this period, Michael is consumed with this affair, arranges his social life around it, spends time choosing books to read, and daydreams about Hanna. Then, one day, she is gone. She's quit her job and moved out of her apartment with warning. By this point, the reader (of this novel) is certainly wondering about Hanna: why is this attractive youngish woman so alone and why would she want sex with a 15-year-old boy? She must have a problem, this isn't normal, and in our culture, it would be a crime.Hanna is indeed hiding something, as Michael is to discover some years down the road, as a law student, when he witnesses a trial in which Hanna is one of the defendants. She is accused of a war crime from the days she spent as a prison guard, working for the SS. Is this why Hanna has moved from place to place, always alone? No, but that is what the jury is led to believe, and Hanna does not defend herself against the worst of accusations because she is still in hiding, unwilling to reveal a certain personal flaw. In fact, Hanna had chosen to work for the SS over another job to hide this secret, a choice I cannot understand and find repugnant and amoral. During this part of the novel, author Bernhard Schlink addresses the generation gap of postwar Germany.Parental expectations, from which every generation must free itself, were nullified by the fact that these parents had failed to measure up during the Third Reich or after it ended. How could those who had committed Nazi crimes or watched them happen or looked away while they were happening or tolerated the criminals among them after 1945 or even accepted them--how could they have anything to say to their children? Michael Berg has a unique perspective, for someone of his generation. After all, he has been in love with a former Nazi. His relationship with Hanna had already adversely affected his emotional life and relationships, but now, at the trial, he was suddenly facing moral issues, as well.At this point, he is no longer in love with Hanna, but he is again consumed with trying to understand her, and when one day he realizes what her secret is, he struggles with what he should do with this knowledge. Michael has always carried around guilt about Hanna, a feeling that he's somehow betrayed her, which I never completely understood. However, it is understandable, at this point in his life, that he would not want to turn his back on someone he had cared for. And so, in the end, Michael Berg does what he feels is right by Hanna and makes him feel most comfortable. I understand Michael's choices, but Hanna remains an enigma to me. I cannot understand the way she lived, and perhaps she is meant to represent a generation that feared certain types of exposure so much that they would fall in line and willingly do what most people would find unthinkable and horrible. I would add that Hanna's secret flaw could have been corrected, but instead, she seems to have developed a one-track mind for hiding it.At the same time, I do not enjoy having such unsympathetic feelings towards Hanna. It does make me feel uncomfortable to judge her that way. And, I suppose, that is the art of Bernhard Schlink. The Reader is just 218 pages, but it packs a wallop, exploring all the gray areas in moral questions, and is definitely worth the read. I am grateful this was made into a movie, since it reminded me to finally read this book!

I have this terrible habit of reading reviews thoroughly before fully diving into a book and then sort of forming my own opinion around those of others. . . In this way, as I read I seek for flaws that other readers found, not giving myself a chance I need. This has almost happened to The Reader as well, but somehow, this book has taken my heart and mind captive so powerfully that I could barely remember what others thought of it. . . This story has touched my heart powerfully. It is written in a peculiar, almost juristical style, which is nearly as curmudgeonly and at times incomprehensibly cold as Michael himself. He holds himself at distance: from the story, from Hanna and even from the reader. It is almost like the author is the cold, impersonal reader Michael, emotionless and distant. Nothing more than that. But even in this language, there is some sort of peculiar charm that draws you to the book, it's beautiful in an odd way, like the late fall. His narrative is not bulky at all. It does not paralyze your own thinking, but gives you space for your own analysis. For me that was an undoubted advantage.At the beginning I was rather apprehensive of the love story line between Michael and Hanna. You see, I don't tend to enjoy erotic things much, they scare me off. But surprisingly, their affair is written about beautifully, it's nothing vulgar or low-minded. In this narrative there is some purity, even, and almost pristine simplicity. I was personally very impressed by Hanna's tender admiring of Michael's intellectual achievement and the fact that someday he, just like his father, would also be writing books. This reveals her humble, strong nature. Despite her personal limitations, she is not envious or spiteful. There is something very soft, very compassionate about her, there is also a great yearning for knowledge. In spite of her own meager education level, she is intelligent and realizes the burthen of her guilt. She seeks redemption and is yet ready to bear responsibility, unlike Michael. Hanna is obedient to duty and never repines. In my eyes, Hanna is an example of an incredibly strong woman. She astounded me.For me, The Reader is a deeply philosophical novel, touching on many controversial subjects. It is not your stereotypical Holocaust novel, even though it is about Holocaust in every fiber. It is a novel about acceptance of the horrors of the past, about healing. It challenges us, encouraging us to ask ourselves a question that Hanna asked of the judge: What would YOU do if you were in my place? This is a novel of forgiveness, without which you can't move forward.I loved how the relationship with Hanna became a sort of make or break moment for Michael, as this affair allowed him to see the horrendous story of holocaust and concentration camps from a different angle, and therefore make a step toward reconciliation with the past of his nation and the world. It is a poignant, lively novel of that first step, bitter and painful, yet important.Schlink does not give you any direct answers, but instead provides you with rich food for thought.

"At first I wanted to write our story in order to be free of it. But the memories wouldn't come back for that. Then I realized our story was slipping away from me and i wanted to recapture it by writing, but that didn't coax up the memories either. For the last few years I've left our story alone. I've made peace with it. And it came back, detail for detail and in such a fully rounded fashion, with it's own direction and it's own sense of completion, that is no longer makes me sad. What a sad story, I thought for so long. Not that I now think it was happy. BUT I THINK IT IS TRUE, AND THUS THE QUESTION OF WHETHER IS IS SAD OR HAPPY HAS NO MEANING WHATEVER. "Part 1:This is a love story- but not really. Micheal is 15 when we are introduced to him, that is also when he meets an older lady, in her 30's. He is sick, she helps. He goes to thank her and it becomes something way more than innocent. They pretty much start going at it right of the bat. He loves her. She in her own way loves him- but is always seemingly off somewhere in her own head. While it was hard to get past their age difference, the story itself was still charming. A part of me really didn't like Hannah, but our main character is so enthralled with her it's hard not to want her to be a part of his life.Part 2:Hannah Skips town. No goodbye. Michael beats himself up. He feels guilty. He's mad at her. He's mad at himself. He throws himself into school at a Univerity. He becomes hard, he is no longer the light-hearted lover-boy of previous years. He tries to feel nothing. Enter a trail his class is going to. Ennter subject on Trial= Hannah. He lies to himself, he say's he feels nothing.Part 3:She is convicted of some pretty terrible crimes. He hates himself for being able to love someone who could allow such things to happen. He feels guilty again. She remains in jail for 18 years. He somewhat lives, but is always compelled to keep somewhat in toch with her. (I really don't wan't to say much here, I don't want to give away the story.) Is what they had truely love? will it last all the years? Will he get over his guilt? Does she really love hm? Is she a bad person?"Does everyone feel this way? When I was Young, I was perpetually overconfident or insecure. Either I felt Completely useless, unattractive and worthless, or I was pretty much a sucess, and everything I did was bound to succeed. When I was confident, I could overcome the hardest challenges. But all it took was the smallest setback for me to be sure that I was utterly worthless. Regaining my self-confidence had nothing to do with success; every goal I set myself, every recognition I craved made anything I actually did seem paltry by comparison, and whether I experienced it as a failure or triumph was utterly dependent on my mood."For most of us who are Reader's, this book will tug at your hearstrings. Like I said this is a love story- but not really- it is sooo much more than that. It is a hauntingly beuatiful tale of post war romance and selfworth.Sidenote: I cannot wait to see Kate winslet in this role. She is going to bring Hannah to life!

Si puÃ² tradire un traditore? Il Michael quindicenne conosce per caso Hanna giovane donna di trentasei anni. Comincia ad intrattenere con lei una relazione prima solo sessuale e che pian piano diventa qualcosa di piÃ¹. Dal corpo si passa alle parole. E mentre il giovane si innamora perdutamente di lei, unico riferimento di tenerezza della sua vita e ne fa lâ€™unica donna possibile che continuerÃ  a ricercare allâ€™infinito, lei Ã¨ schiva, a volte insensibile e lâ€™unica cosa che chiede ai lori incontri sono le parole. Lui legge per lei ad alta voce. E lei sembra che solo in quel momento si interessi a qualcosa. Poi allâ€™improvviso la ragazza scompare. Lui si sente tradito cosÃ¬ e deve fare i conti con questo abbandono che gli ottunde i sensi. Sopravvive in spensieratezza a volte ma non sarÃ  mai la stessa cosa. Allâ€™improvviso perÃ² lei riappare nella sua vita. Eâ€™ imputata in un processo come una delle guardie delle S.S. in un campo vicino Auschwitz, accusata di avere portato alla morte donne, moltissime donne. Il cerchio dellâ€™indifferenza si stringe attorno a lei. E lui ne fa parte, coscientemente. Conosciamo davvero chi ci sta vicino? Sappiamo cosa pensa nella parte piÃ¹ profonda del proprio essere, le esperienze che lo hanno portato da noi? Michael ritrova una donna che per salvare il proprio segreto diventa una criminale. E come possiamo salvare gli altri se gli altri non vogliono essere salvati? Il libro diventa un grido contro tutti quelli che una volta chiusa la tragica esperienza dei campi di concentramento, sono tornati alle loro vite, normalmente, in posti di potere, sono diventati mariti, padri, nonni nellâ€™indifferenza di chi stava accanto, sapeva e non ha parlato. La misura della sofferenza umana Ã¨ colma. Tutto quello che tracima scompare. Riflessioni amare accompagnano la lettura di questo libro. Di coscienza e di memoria indelebile. Michael e Hanna si ritroveranno legati da un filo indelebile fatto di parole che solo la morte potrÃ  spezzare.

Es uno de esos libros que simplemente te llegan al corazÃ³n. Nos encontramos con protagonistas que enriquecen la historia. Esta llena de anÃ©cdotas y bellas palabras, nos habla de amor, de dolor y de carencias.

" Imagine there's an operation, and the patient is a drug user and the drugs are incompatible with the anesthetic, but the patient is ashamed of being an addict and does not want to tell the anesthesiologist - do you talk to the anesthesiologist? Imagine a trial and a defendant who will be convicted if he doesn't admit to being left-handed - do you tell the judge what's going on? Imagine he's gay, and could not have committed the crime because he's gay, but is ashamed of being gay. It isn't a question of whether the defendant should be ashamed of being left-handed or gay - just imagine that he is."This story is being narrated by Micheal Berg who recollects love affair between him and a woman who was twice his age. The affair startsoff awkwardly and grows passionately. Then one day, his lover, Hanna who was illogical, complicated yet real leaves him without any intimidation. Micheal, after she leaves feels that he had betrayed her somehow. Next time, they meet each other is at a trial where she is one of the defendants and Micheal being a law student.This book puts forward a lot of questions, question on ethics, moral and love. I love the flow of the story even though I felt that it was being dragged slightly in between. It is one of the books where you had no expectations whatsoever from it while starting and that would turn out to be a masterpiece. The picture of Nazi camps and sufferings of those involved in it are given so vividly and honestly. I don't really know how many books are out there that talk about feelings of those guards of the camps.Â The observations on how the future generations then would try to cope up with the history the previous generation left them with are quite important and accurate.This book is deep, quite disturbing yet beautifully written. It talks about complications of characters in a way that could be related to anyone who reads it.In an instance, Micheal decribles how Hanna thinks all the authors and stories she was being read to as contemporaries because she didn't know much about the history. I think this book should be treated as one because it acts as a metaphor.The book gets dull at places but I was asking myself how else how could it be, how else would you tell such a story!Â For I'm the one who started this book with zero expectations and slightly turned off with the back and forth erotism in the beginning, this book worked well for me in second and third parts. Overall it is a powerful story to be told.

Socrates worried that the latest technology--writing, reading--would corrupt minds because they would no longer be required to carry information in their heads since they could always refer to it in a book or from a library. Then there's The Reader.Sure, the premise of this novel concerns statutory rape, but Lolita concerns the same, plus kidnapping and murder and it it gets good reviews. This is my second time through this novel (and in the meantime, I read Lolita, a prerequisite to reading The Reader) and I respect Schlink's novel more in this reading.I respect it in its perspective; since the narrator is the victim, his perspective rises as a plea for clemency--for himself and his old-love. I respect it because he chronicles his inner psychological trauma and how he works out his grief. I respect it because I think (thanks, John Gardner) that all great fiction must have the moral dilemma, the ethical question as a key ingredient. Hanna Schmitz used young Michael Berg [German for mountain] as a sex toy. She used him as a means to ascend to the top of the mountain--something like a chairlift at a ski resort. Michael Berg used Hanna Schmitz as a sex toy. He used her for his own sexual gratification and romantic ideals--something like an Everywoman who could please him in his puerile lusts. The reading is what saves this novel. The fact that narrative unites these two desperate common people into one union redeems the novel and makes it worthy. You know, should have a twinge of blush when we read books like this too. It gratifies. Ahem! There is a whiff of voyeurism in each tale that we read; as spectators, we experience the pleasure via language. Hanna Schmitz serves as a despicable, power-crazed woman who volunteered for the SS in order to victimize others in her middle-management-authoritarian role as a prison guard. Meanwhile young Michael Berg suffers from his protracted role as the young stud, all the while learning how to satisfy her sexually. I guess I learned from this something that physicists already know about the molecular world: Like matter, exchanging heat but retaining molecular identity, humans exchange heat but retain the identity of memory, imagination, and the present. Here nothing gets lost in the translation.

At first glance The Reader tells the story of a 15-year-old boy who has an affair with a woman in her thirties and how it affects him for the rest of his life. That is only the outer layer of the story though: as soon as you look deeper you see that more than anything it is about Germany after WW2, about shame and guilt, right and wrong, struggling with finding an identity for a generation that is coming to terms with the past and picking up the pieces. And it's not just my or some critic's opinion, Mr. Schlink tells us as much himself when Michael ponders his generation and its heritage, and tries to understand the past. Another reason that leads me to believe that this book is less about the relationship of Michael and Hanna and more about the German society after the war is that at no time does Michael ask in the book how could Hanna do what she did to him but there's plenty of times when he talks about how could the Germans allow the atrocities to happen, how could they not stand up to it all, how could they accept the former fascists back into society. It is as if he is more scarred by that than by having his whole life ruined by and eventually, in a way, devoted to a woman who didn't seem to care about the consequences of her actions. One of the strongest features of this book is its elegantly spare, declarative prose. There are few explanations, just simple statements of facts that are offered to us without reservation. There are reflections on morality, humanity, right and wrong, and they too are so simple that they give the novel depth without rendering it unreadable. Yet as positively unflowery as the writing is the author manages to tell us exactly who his characters are, allows us to discover them gradually and without inflicting his own conclusions upon us, creates perfectly complete portraits with a few well-chosen words and well-placed sencentes. There is a lot of story in a book that is barely two hundred pages long and since we only get Michael's side of it by no means does Mr. Schlink tell us all there is to tell. There is plenty to think about and I hope that if you haven't read this book that you will add it to your to-read list. It is most definitely worth a day or a weekend of your time. Read more of my reviews at Bibliophile's Corner

I think that â€œDer Vorleserâ€ opens quite a new field, a new perspective, and because of its many levels offers so much to so different readers.Although revolving around Germany and war as its building blocks, this is not a novel about World War II. Nor is it about the Holocaust. Nor National Socialism. But it is about the confrontation of two generation, about perspective and about the many aspects of responsibility. Being all that, it is also a deeply personal story, but with its solipsism contributing greatly to a transition from individual to universal level. Starting off as a liaison between a teenage boy and a mature woman (a schoolboyâ€™s dream not unlike Giuseppe Tornatoreâ€™s â€œMalenaâ€), the story abruptly ends in order to be re-evaluated from a quite different angle. Thanks to the rich, emotional approach this account could easily make a short form of its own. But it is not even the beginning yet, and with a deep incision where the protagonist, now a young man in his twenties, and his former lover meet again under entirely different circumstances, the reader will have to go back to see some subtle details in a story of passion and tenderness as a foreshadow. The strength of the narrative lies in its first-person-focus: like the protagonist, the reader gradually comes to realize things that, at least afterwards, seem to have been so plain to see. In a language that I could only describe as â€œpureâ€, giving hints rather than illustrating, but doing so with utmost precision, and extending altogether through several decades, the rich plot emphasises the emotions of betrayal and loyalty, responsibility and guilt and remorse. A striking feature of this novel is how reflective it is, extending all sentiments through so many levels and layers: betrayal of a friend, betrayal of a lover, betrayal of the family (or loyalty as the mirror image of betrayal), responsibility for oneâ€™s own actions, responsibility for the generation of the fathers, responsibility for the truth, responsibility in the name of humanity and all the nuances and thin lines in between. With its intense storyline, this novel can be read as a thrilling account of events, but still there is so much more to it that the sujet itself cannot even begin to cover. I imagine that everyone who liked Julian Barnesâ€™ â€œThe Sense of an Endingâ€ would enjoy this book as well. And the other way around.

So this is one of those novels that haunts you long after you put it down and it's surprising, for such a short and quick read. I'm giving this book 5 stars. And I'm going to guess this is much better than the movie although I've not seen it. I'll start in the beginning. The eroticism in the earlier chapters doesn't really linger in the readers mind after the author addresses the real issue, in fact, I think from both Hanna and Michael's as well as for the readers (us, I mean) it's merely a distraction. Following are the layers I looked at while reading this. In one layer, this is a bildungsroman, the physical/mental maturity of Michael Berg. As an adult he must come to terms with the past, the history of the Nazi crimes, so it's a story of the conflict of the the post-war generation in Germany. And I believe Hanna's character is a symbol to everything Michael feels about their past, feeling of betrayal, guilt and love; he cannot draw a line and say this is this or that. Then it's a great historical exploration, makes the readers (us) question whether the history we believe is completely correct? and perhaps there will be things that we will never learn (view spoiler)[ like how no-one other than two characters in the novel, never learned that Hanna never was the person in charge  (hide spoiler)] The novel gives you a different angle to look at Holocaust and it's refreshing. I find here at GRs there are quite a number of readers who seems to "enjoy" Holocaust Fiction, and I sometimes see some biased reviews. I think the book comes as a challenge to them as well, look at it from a different angle! "We are not denying it but look closer." At the same time it tells the readers and well the readers and the listeners in the story; that actions, no matter what the circumstances might have been, will have consequences. To sum up, Hanna is the gem in the tale in the end, I wonder, if she a person or a metaphor in a level I haven't understood. Her nakedness, her choices and actions literary and metaphorically contrasts heavily with her secret she hides. Does her nakedness question the ignorance? I was completely blown away by the story because the philosophical questions it raises are haunting. Recommended**

I started this on audio and picked it up in print. I realized after I finished that half of the riveting nature of the plot was the artfulness of the reader Campbell Scott. It must have been very difficult to pick a reader for "The Reader", but they did a fantastic job. When I picked the book back up in print with the idea that I'd be better able to pick up on nuance in plot and writing, I was disappointed. Frankly, the writing wasn't as good as I'd thought (though I rarely claim to be a good judge of that). This book is usually noted to be a novel of eroticism, but the narrator reads in an almost monotone that becomes intimate without any unnecessary inflection. I give the audio a lauded 5 stars and the text a disappointed 3 stars in comparison. An adult Michael Berg recollects the woman who set his life on its path. As a 15 year old boy who had become a bit of an introspective intellect in his confinement following Hepatitis, he met and was intrigued by 36 year old Hannah. The past and present blend as Michael and Hannah have a strange summer love affair in which the author artfully dances around propriety and eroticism. Hannah, with a mysterious past, is obviously troubled, and (like a car wreck in slow motion) we watch as she becomes the mysterious and troubled past for Michael. The love affair ends as oddly and abruptly as it began. So ends Part 1 of 3 of the book. In Part 2 we watch as Michael, now in Law School, is assigned to audit the trial in which Hannah is tried for a crime she is accused of committing as a Nazi guard of Auschwitz in WWII (20 years after the fact). I was surprised by how riveted I was by this part of the book. Legal proceedings almost always glaze my eyes over, but the author (who is a lawyer and judge) writes this, too, as if it were just another part of their love story. I won't give anything away here, though. Part 3 (where I picked up the text) takes place another 18 years later... just read it. Better yet, pick up or download the audio.

Aun conteniendo una historia sencilla (narrada con un estilo que recuerda al mejor Proust, especialmente las partes en las que el protagonista recuerda los pormenores, detalles y sensaciones que conformaban su adolescencia), las temÃ¡ticas que subyacen de su lectura pesan al ser planteadas. La imposibilidad de conectar o entender en su total plenitud las desgracias de nuestra historia; las responsabilidades que acarrearon las distintas generaciones alemanas tras el horror del Holocausto (desde los que no se sublevaron para sobrevivir durante la guerra, hasta los que no denunciaron que muchos de los implicados en la barbarie permanecieran en puestos privilegiados de la vida pÃºblica); y la irreversibilidad de los hechos que nos marcan en las edades tempranas, condicionando el resto de nuestra vida (asÃ­ como las acciones y preferencias que irÃ¡n naciendo en nosotros).Michael serÃ¡ incapaz de separar las sensaciones que le provocÃ³ su separaciÃ³n de Hanna con lo que deberÃ­a sentir por los crÃ­menes que cometiÃ³. Pero juzgando a su antiguo amor, se juzga a sÃ­ mismo, y a un paÃ­s entero.

When Michael Berg is 15, he has an affair with Hanna Schmitz, who is over twice his age. The affair does eventually come to an end, but their lives are intertwined afterwards.This book should have been passionate, challenging, and emotionally wrenching. But I just felt too distanced from everything. Iâ€™m trying to decide if this is because itâ€™s told from Michaelâ€™s point of view and heâ€™s a detached kind of guy, but mostly I donâ€™t care. I see what it could have been versus what it is and Iâ€™m frustrated.I think the big conflict at the heart of the novel was supposed to be condemnation versus understanding and how hard it is, or even impossible, to feel both at the same time. I think I was supposed to question what I would have done in each characterâ€™s place, but I was too aggravated with Michael to have room for introspection. I was too busy wondering if the jackass was ever going to grow some balls and help Hanna out. (Sorry, Mama. But itâ€™s true.) I wanted to smack him. He let her down in so many ways and somehow always found a way to make it her fault. Hanna wasnâ€™t perfect either. In fact, they destroyed each other in round about ways, when they really could have been each otherâ€™s salvation. That may have been part of the point of the book also, but thatâ€™s not my kind of thing. Iâ€™m a die hard fan of the happy ending.Readers not requiring too much of an emotional attachment to their books will like this one. I think if I were that kind of reader I would definitely have enjoyed it more and been willing to think more about the conflicts it contains. But Iâ€™m not and so Iâ€™m left disliking it.

What a haunting book. At first I didn't think I'd like this novel, fresh on the heels of my reading Zusak's lyrical, tightly constructed flow (The Book Thief). This novel has a lot more exposition, which suits its more philosophical purpose. I now have a reading hangover, because I started one night (couldn't sleep once I started it) and had to finish it the next (couldn't sleep until I finished it).Schlink poses difficult questions that tie into the plot, like what ultimately motivates a character, how does she tick? This is a good one for a book club, because it raises so many questions, and reading about a characters in the aftermath of Nazi Germany is something I hadn't yet encountered. Compelling, especially the "what makes them tick" part.Questions that go closer to personal experience, like why is it easier for people in relationships to act without verbally communicating why or what they're doing or intending, and what does their action ultimately mean? Can we ever know? Yet anyone who's ever been in a relationship has experienced these conundrums. My deep-seated urge to resolve these insolubles propelled me through the book and even calls for a second read. The author has a sense of keeping his reader at arm's length, engaging the reader to imagine and ask questions.Schlink effectively creates emotionally distant characters that nonetheless emotionally hooked me in, an art to pull off.

Michael Berg is a 15 year old German boy, who falls ill from hepatitis and literally collapses in front of Hanna Schmitz, a woman in her early 30s who tends to him and sends him home. Later she becomes his lover, and then she vanishes. Years later when he sees her next, Michael is a law student and she is on trial for war crimes. The Reader is an amazing work on so many levels - romantic, historic, psychological, philosophical, morality, even criminal justice, to name a few. The day I started reading this my aunt Harriet sent me an article she wrote about my Jewish great-grandmother having escaped Germany for America prior to the Holocaust, and about her family who perished in the camps. Harriet had an exchange student "sister" from Germany in highschool, and combined a visit to Grandma Sophie's birth home in 1975 with a reunion with her homestay sister. The two had a heated discussion about Harriet wanting to visit the concentration camps in Dachau, "Ika begged her not to go (her generation had not caused World War II and didn't want to be blamed for or even reminded of it)." For me, this book really gives the Holocaust scale. I can clearly see how subsequent generations have been affected. And as an illustration as to how power of the written word can affect someone! I'm so glad I read this before seeing the movie, loved this book, love that it's written by a German judge.

Typically, a book tells a story better than the movie from which it is made. In my opinion, the reverse is true of â€œThe Readerâ€. Translated into English from German, I found the prose at times awkward and flat. Nonetheless, the story set in post war Germany of an unusual, erotic relationship between a teenage boy (Michael Berg) and a woman (Hanna Schmidt) twice his age made for compelling reading. Themes of love, passion, betrayal, guilt and shame were quite movingly explored. In between showering and love-making, Berg spent much time reading the classics to Frau Schmidt, who ravenously lapped them up. The poignancy of the act of reading hit home only when Schmidt was unable to defend herself when being tried for war crimes in Auschwitz. The strange â€œmother-kidâ€ relationship left deeper imprints than Berg or Schmidt could ever anticipate. Bergâ€™s capacity to establish relationships with other women was irrevocably stunted. The story seems to suggest that love has the power to save or destroy; in it hope resides, which renders adversity tolerable. Hanna needed it but Berg was perversely too self-absorbed. Additionally, the novel suggests that a personâ€™s need to safeguard pride and dignity can be much stronger than life itself. Hanna kept her secret at great cost to herself. If you intend to read this novel, you will enjoy it much more if you do not first watch the movie.

I would never have read this book if I hadn't seen the movie first. Admittedly, it doesn't take much more time to read than to watch, and watching it is essentially the same as reading it. The Reader is one of those rare movies that doesn't lose its power in the process of transferral, but I suppose the book adds an extra layer of internal dialogue that is worth dipping into.Generally, I stay far away from WWII related anythings because they inspire a complicated range of emotion in me as a German. I don't really care to explain it; suffice it to say that I simply avoid it. The Reader isn't good or bad in that sense...it simply IS, raw and unadorned. The writing is sparse. The plot is disturbing. I'm giving it four stars because of its theme and its ability to move the audience without effort. Schlink isn't really trying to present something in a certain light, or to pass judgement, to inspire or agitate. The whole tone is matter-of-fact and somber, leaving the audience to its own devices and considerations. Its very simplicity is something that jumps up and down on the top of your frontal lobe, demanding attention. I really have no other way to describe it, and that description is likely vague and inadequate.Read it; The New York Times was right to name it a "noteable" book. Read it and make of it what you will.

I picked up The Reader to read about a young boy's affair with a Nazi-affiliated older woman.My expectations were simple: this would be a story of an idealistic minor, charmed by a deceptive woman, and what happens in the aftermath of his relationship when he sees her in a courtroom. Instead, I found it to be a story of a lonely woman, ashamed of her illiteracy, elegant in her cruel actions. The Reader is morally devastating. While there is no excuse for Hanna's actions regarding the war, there is also no redemption for our condemnation of her either. As we re-live the horrors of the Second World War, we realize how easy it is to be indifferent. Throughout the novel, as the protagonist - Michael Berg - transforms from a frail child to a cold, confused man, we recognize our own frailty and insensitivity. It's disturbing to see how we can identify with the perpetrators of the war in the same way we do with the victims of the war. I felt agitated, helpless, morally lost. The Reader is a short, simplistic read. But it's not easy. The vivid images Schlink creates are powerful in their impact. They slam against your consciousness - ideas, thoughts, feelings - with little relief. There is no answer, no guided road to a moral high ground. In the end, all we are left with is a sense of a broken, defeated life.

This novel is a brilliantly interwoven and complex study of an intriguing concept : how did ordinary people like, Hannah, a teenage school leaver exist under the Nazi regime, find work and go about their everyday lives, and then how did these same Germans come to terms with thier consciences in post war Germany when the Allies intervened to impose a programme of 'Denazification'. Of course thousands of Germans denied culpability and denied sympathising with Nazi philosophies, let alone collaborating in implementing their policies and assisting in the machinery of death within the camps. Post war Germany is trying to move on but has to wrestle with the immediate and terrible past. In addition the novel is a 'coming of age' and 'rites of 'passage' story of a post war German teenager who is learning about the Nazi atrocities committed by his parents' generation, and their varying degrees of culpability in the name of the German Fuhrer. The young man, Michael Berg, finds it difficult to move on after his passionate first love and then experiences his own betrayal and faces his own conscience and discovering denial is a common human characteristic, easily condemned in others but difficult to acknowledge in oneself.

3.5 stars.Well, I don't know where to start. This book is short but heavy. Not heavy in terms of weight but heavy in terms of emotions that it carries. With a postwar Germany as its background, what did you expect? The book starts on a lighter note with a 15 year old boy who happens to meet a woman. And then there's no looking back.The book takes you on a journey so unique in itself that you find yourself pondering on it. I got confused a couple of times during the reading and had to re-read what it was about. The book is mysterious, I think I can call it that.The secrets spill out one by one and everything changes. I don't want to spill the premise or what happens afterward, so I'm at a loss of what to write.In all, this book made me think a lot. I don't think there's one answer to anything in this book. It will make you agree and disagree with your own thoughts. It will make you want to change things. It will make you emotional and you will speculate to no end.This will make a wonderful book for a book club. I wish I had someone to discuss it out loud with, this is one of that kind.I think I loved this one but then again, I'm not sure. LOL! I will have to re-read it sometime soon. I think I will watch the movie too.

I like the book, the first few pages was weird. It is a story of a 15 year old boy, Michael Berg who had an affair with a woman twice his age, Hanna Schmitz. She works as a conductor of a street car and she has a mysterious background. She disappeared all of a sudden, without a word. They meet again on a trial where Michael is a law student while Hanna is on a trial for a crime. She was convicted for 18 years and Michael found out she was illiterate, her very own secret. It was hard for her to keep a secret that will make people put you down. She asks for people to read for her and tries to learn reading because of the cassettes containing stories that Michael recorded for her so she wouldn't be bored. She is a woman with a strong personality and determined to learn. She listens to the cassette while reading the same book so that she could follow it. At an old age, she learned how to write and read. Michael was proud of her, because of him she didn't stay illiterate.  There are some boring parts, but the essence was there's no obstacle in learning. Young or Old, we still learn things and do not be ashamed of your weakness. There's always a way to make your weakness turn to strong ones and boost your confidence..

Bien qu'il traite des camps de concentration, il ne verse pas dans l'outrance descriptive, les dÃ©tails sordides et ignobles que l'on ne connaÃ®t que trop bien de l'Holocauste nous sont ici Ã©pargnÃ©s (en gÃ©nÃ©ral). J'ai Ã©tÃ© tourmentÃ©e, en mÃªme temps que le narrateur, par toutes ces questions philosophiques et morales liÃ©es Ã  la responsabilitÃ© des actes nazis. On fait plus que de se poser l'Ã©ternelle question "et nous, qu'aurait-on fait Ã  leur place ?", l'auteur nous guide bien plus loin en ajoutant une caractÃ©ristique bien singuliÃ¨re au personnage principal fÃ©minin, Ã  cette gardienne de camp, qui rend la question encore plus insolvable.La premiÃ¨re partie m'avait parue un peu longue, bien que joliment contÃ©e, mais elle s'avÃ¨re Ãªtre indispensable, c'est un socle parfait pour le cÅ“ur de l'histoire. 4.5 sin duda. No pensÃ© que este corto libro me destruirÃ­a emocionalmente. Lo que parece ser una novela de un romance tabÃº acaba siendo una muestra de que el pasado nos persigue y nunca nos dejarÃ¡ tranquilos. Como de el recuerdo del primer amor hasta la culpa por la muerte de otras personas. Es un hermoso libro.

Really I don't understand why this book is considered to be #1 bestseller. So during reading many questions were risen.Sometimes I felt like I was struggling through really heavy writing, but the actual story itself and the moral questions that arise from its telling were really interesting and I surprised myself with how much I found myself contemplating this novel.Actually I like the book, and recommend it to all readers, who like deep meaning and thoughtful sentences.

Watched the film years ago and cried my heart out. I remembered the details of the film as it is still one of my favourite. Therefore, when I found out that it was adapted from a book, I searched for it.As I was already bias for having an idea on the content of the book before I read it, I recognize the characters thoroughly well. I could connect more with Michael as I watched the movie when I was younger, and now I understand the poor cruel reality of Hanna's life. Confessing to cry more than once would not be exaggerating for me. The shame, embarassment, pride and shackle, it ached my heart to read on how Hanna couldn't be saved from the injustice because of her dignity. And the fact she took her own life, it pained me greatly.For the writing, it is easy to read and not weighed down by adjectives or too much description. It punctuated perfectly, simply precise. I would categorized it as a masculine narration. And it isn't dry. It finishes off like a glass of red wine at the end of exhausting, emotional rollercoaster day.

I still don't know what to think about this book. The writing style is dry and flat, but I never stopped squirming throughout. I didn't just not like it - I actively disliked reading it. It's painful. But I think that is the point. The author intends to make the reader squirm as he demonstrates that morality is an illusion and that even what appears to be pure evil is incredibly complex and multidimensional. Perpetrators are victims, and victims are perpetrators. One thing's for sure: It's not a comfortable version of reality. Eesh.The prose is flat and emotionless, but it still left me with an ambivalence so intense I am still trying to work out whether this book is horrible or amazing. Let's just say: This was not a fun read. I'm still trying to shake off the angst. It would be easy to say, because I didn't enjoy it, that it's not "good." But actually, I think it might be very good. I'm not really sure. Let me know if you figure it out!

This is a potentially potent and mildly moving novel. There is an aura of something profound in it, something lying in the subtext, but I can't figure out what it is. And I cautiously suspect that it's not actually there. Being a thoroughly introspective novel, there is not much subtext. Everything resides in the words of the book, little in the spaces between; it neither beckons nor warrants speculation. It's a problem of the intensely intellectual first-person narrator. The Reader's reader reads every thought that can be thought by the narrator, so what thought is left for the thinking reader to think for herself?What The Reader graciously provides is a unique insight into a generation much ignored - the children of World War II-era Germans. How does one philosophically bear to live in a country responsible for the Holocaust? How do they absolve themselves of a crime they did not commit, yet feel guilt for nonetheless?

I'm not sure how I felt about this book as a whole. I loved part one. I was really into the love story and the pages flew by. Then I got to part two in the court and I kinda lost intrest. I think I seprated Hanna into two people. This teenage boys fantasy and the war criminal. Hanna the war criminal I felt nothing for, I didn't care if she went to jail or she didn't. The secret she keeps is stupid. I must admit I didn't pick up on it. I would be more intrested to know more about how the younger Germans dealt with the guilt of what their parents had done. I think the book picked up again in part three with the tapes and the sad ending. I had started to warm to her again by the end of the book even tho she didn't really deserve it. I do want to see the film now. I didn't get it for christmas :(

Originally posted on the Little Miss Nowhere blog.Rather than a review, this is taken from a blog post I wrote that compared the reception of the book in Germany and overseas."The Reader" was written by the German author Bernhard Schlink and published in 1995. The novel was internationally acclaimed and has been adapted into a movie starring Kate Winslet and Ralph Fiennes.While discussing the novel in class, my German teacher brought up an interesting point: the reaction and attention that the novel garnered in Germany was very different compared to those in America. This lead to me wondering why, and beginning to research for this blog post.Around 500.000 copies were sold in Germany, 200.000 in France, 100.000 in Great Britain and 750.000 in the USA. Worldwide, over a million copies have been sold and the novel has been published in over 25 languages.A profile of Bernhard Schlink, the author of the novel, that was written by Nicholas Wroe and published in "The Guardian" in 2002, presents the novel as reminiscent of the "Third Reich's moral illiteracy" and as incomparable with other novels published at the time.Although the novel has enjoyed remarkable success in the English-speaking world and become a "set text on school and university syllabuses internationally", it has been heavily criticised by others, such as the writer Frederick Raphael, who found the use of Hanna's illiteracy as an excuse for her crimes to be particularly problematic.Nicholas Wroe also presents Professor Frank Finley of Leeds University's dilemma in dealing with the novel due to the "problematic use of literacy" in it.The author states that people who have committed war crimes are now being depicted as normal people, and not evil people with no moral compass. While taking a "more subtle approach to perpetrators", The Reader is supposedly "more critical of Schlink's own generation". In order to highlight Schlink's opinion on the matter, Wroe quotes the author: "'There is the problem of loving and admiring these people yet knowing what they have done'".Schlink himself has announced that The Reader does not deal with the Holocaust, but instead focuses on how the second generation came to terms with their parents' crimes or actions during the war. After being criticised for having written what many thought to be an autobiographical novel, Schlink commented that "[w]e can only write what we know[...]". He also brought up an interesting point: According to him, the older generation was less likely to criticise the book than younger people.I'd like to compare two reviews found in the German newspaper "Die Welt" and the American "New York Times" respectively.Suzanne Ruta, the author of a review of "The Reader"published in 1997, uses the words "star-crossed lovers" to describe Michael and Hanna during their time together. Hanna Schmitz, at least according to Ruta, is Michael's "great love". Yet the authors of the German review, David DeiÃŸner and Thomas Lindemann, explain that their love only causes the couple to feel loaded with guilt."He who understands, does not judge. He who judges, does not understand". The German authors state that it is this principle that leads to the great narrative energy that can be found in The Reader. This relation between the inability to comprehend and the haste with which some can surmise can also be witnessed in Ruta's review, in which she presents one of the questions that was asked by many after the war ended: "'What did you do in the war, Daddy?'". "What's so lucky about loving your suspect parents and losing your humanity[...]?", she asks, and brings up an important point: how can you begin to trust someone who you know has committed terrible crimes in their past?The German review goes even further to say that the novel is trying to expose the prejudiced and judgemental reader themselves. It does not simply, according to DeiÃŸner and Lindemann, attempt to find an ultimate solution to the problem by utilising Hanna's illiteracy, but to reveal the reader's own method when it comes to discernment of right and wrong.Ruta likens the novel to a "fairy tale, minus the happy ending", while the German review states that it is written in an almost cold manner, with absolutely no kitsch to be detected.Finally, Ruta deems the novel to be "moving, suggestive and ultimately hopeful", although she feels that the language is flat at times. DeiÃŸner and Lindemann, however, decide that the writing is its strong point, praising the author highly, while criticising the book's focus on the criminal, Hanna, stating that there is not enough austerity when dealing with such topics as this.A look at two additional reviews can specify the focal points that reviewers have chosen. Michael Stolleis wrote in the newspaper "Frankfurter Allgemeine" in 1995 that The Reader was an "idealistic developmental novel, a process of consciental realisation and maturity, the acceptance of someone's fault through their own death". Schlink's usage of language highlights this and reveals the author's own self-criticism. Stolleis declares The Reader to be Schlink's most personal book thus far.Andrea Cally of the Goethe-Institut also shares this opinion in her review. She describes Hanna as wary, keeping both Michael "and by extension the reader, at arms length (sic)". She lays emphasis on the fact that the story "mirrors the fate of many German people [...] during the Nazi era" and, similarly to DeiÃŸner and Lindemann, believes that Schlink also aimed to invite the reader to share the pain of the accused. She thinks that the novel analyses the Holocaust from every possible angle and that it attempts to underline the importance of empathy and forgiveness on the path to the future.Furthermore, Stolleis questions whether the novel is typical of its generation in its depiction of Michael as a young man who became interested in the Nazi movement. In his opinion, the plot becomes round and complete towards the end despite the conflicting messages that it may convey.To sum up, one can surmise that there are a great many similarities shared by the different reviews, regardless of which language they were written in. The German reviews, however, seem to lay more focus on praising the style of the author's writing, while the English reviews either criticise it or don't mention it at all. This can also be seen as a by-product of the English reviewers having read the book as a translation, and not the original. Additionally, the reviews written in English seem to take a more idealistic and hopeful take on the novel. The German reviewers are careful with such statements and prefer to lay emphasis on the maturity of the novel and the importance of the subject it portrays.One point that definitely struck a note with me was DeiÃŸner and Lindemann's criticism of the romantic take on the Holocaust that has been able to be observed in recent years. They reject the idea of a "soundtrack to mass murder", mentioning the award-winning 2004 film "Downfall". In my opinion, it would not be acceptable to present the events of the Second World War and the Nazi regime in a positive light. At the same time, movies and novels such as "The Reader"and "Downfall" may incentivise people who may not have heard about the Holocaust or taken much interest in it at school to learn more about these terrible events.Thus I believe that media can help to raise awareness of concrete issues that must be tackled, especially in regards to the rising interest in radicalised views that can be observed today. Though the stories they portray may not always be completely accurate, if they can infuse people with enough enthusiasm to study about yesterday's mistakes, it may allow them to prevent similar circumstances in the future.

Read in a matter of minutes; not a book I would usually consider reading, rather a book I felt I should read. I'm glad I did, it was wonderful; beautifully written, absolutely heart breaking.I do not feel the "immoral" relationship that takes place (which puts a lot of people off reading) is a shocking one, nor are any of the scenes - of which none are explicit - perverse. I actually feel - despite Hanna and Michael's age difference - the choice was as much his as it was hers and therefore, such as in 'Lolita' by Vladimir Nabokov, this was more about the actual relationship than a moral debate to be raged over. More-so the story was about them and their love than it was ever about an illicit companionship.I felt sympathy for both Hanna and Michael for differing reasons; my heart ached for them both.

I bought this book 3 years ago at a book sale. The cover intrigued me and I didn't know what the story was about. Last weekend I had the pleasure of taking a ride with The Reader and experiencing such emotional and philosophical turmoil, I almost had half the mind to stop reading it altogether! The story starts out slow and before long you're wondering if what Michel Berg does is right? And then he explores his sound of mind and what he should be feeling in regards for Hanna's actions.I can't say I loved this book and it moved me much, but there are many hidden nooks that a reader such as ourselves can discover buried truths in. I understand how this became a movie and the trailer looked really appealing. I sort of liked the style of writing but maybe I'm just not into that deep kind of reading?

E' una lettura di cui non sono sicura che mi rimarrÃ  qualcosa, trascorso del tempo.Il primo blocco tematico del libro (sono in tutto tre) Ã¨ incentrato sullâ€™amore morboso: lâ€™io narrante, Michael, Ã¨ un uomo ormai adulto che ricorda la sua adolescenza; a quindici anni aveva intrapreso infatti una morbosa relazione sessuale con una donna piÃ¹ che trentenne, Hannah. Lâ€™incontro Ã¨ del tutto casuale â€“il protagonista Ã¨ colto da un malore e viene soccorso dalla donna- e, se il passaggio successivo Ã¨ ovvio (Michael, rimessosi, si reca da lei per ringraziarla), non lo Ã¨ altrettanto il successivo: Michael sente, e non a torto, che la donna prova interesse sessuale nei suoi confronti. http://ghettodeilettori.blogspot.com/...

Schlink es una apuesta segura. Si lo que leemos inicialmente es una bonita historia de amor entre un adolescente y una mujer madura, el autor no se conforma con ello y consigue hilar varias tramas que se entrecruzan, desde el punto de vista del futuro cuando ambos se vuelven a encontrar.La culpa, la incertidumbre, la pasiÃ³n y el recuerdo son sÃ³lo alguno de los temas que van apareciendo conforme vamos leyendo.El alemÃ¡n es un autor que sabe medir los tiempos, y como si se tratara de un compositor, conjuga silencios cuando son necesarios, creando una atmÃ³sfera muy particular y demostrando que en muchas ocasiones, menos es mÃ¡s.https://lahierbaroja.wordpress.com/20...

This was a very difficult book to rate. I read it after watching the movie and, in this case, I think that was a mistake. I thought the film surpassed the book in bringing out the moral ambiguity of the story.The Reader is about 15-year-old Michael Berg, who has an affair with Hanna, a woman more than twice his age. One day she disappears, and he expects to never see her again. Years later, he runs into her at a trial where she is accused of a Nazi crime. Michael must then wrestle with the implications of their relationship and whether he owes her anything. This book is a classic that does deserve credit. The questions it raises regarding morality and accountability leave a deep and long lasting impression.

In the beginning, I despised Hanna then, I was mad at her. In the middle, I despised the main character, then I was mad at him. In the end I hated both of them yet could not stop myself from forgeving and pittying them.I never read a novel about people so out of touch with their feelings yet their feelings are all there is for the reader.Could degnity lead one to confess to what would lead him to life imprisonment? How could the movie capture all of those feelings? How could it capture the one thing that kept him so attatched to Hanna for more than thirty years; her smell?!!Okay Abdullah, tell me about the movie.

This book proved to be a very interesting read about the Holocaust. It did not deny the evil that was done, but instead concentrated on issues of guilt and culpability. It starts out as love affair of a young man and an older woman and then changes direction when facts are revealed about the woman. The novel it is written in the first person and we see the world through the eyes of the young man. I was of the impression that the way he narrates the story that he had some insight into his life, but like many of us, there were areas that he found difficult to analyse. The style balances an efficient prose with genuine character development. All in all a thought provoking read.

Hanna's question 'What would you have done?' sounds interesting.Who should be guilty? German people who were used (by Hitler)to kill Jews ? How about who didn't kill but kept silence about Genocide ? And how about generals who ordered to kill Jews? Are these unanswerable questions? But I won't agree that being illiterate is an excuse for what she had done.And I am disappointed at Michael who is guilty for having a relationship with Hanna.He shouldn't be.Hanna loves him and he loves Hanna.That's all.

I had a detailed review, but my computer froze, so now you get a list).Eh. I didn't feel it. Why?1) The writing.It was dry and self-important. Two very big no-nos.2) The plot.The main point kept seeming to change.3) The characters. Allow me to break this up a lil' more comprehensively.A. Michael went through no emotional growth in the span of over twenty yearsB. Michael was iceberg material, hardly did he show any warmth, which is ironic as throughout the novel he continuously claims that Hanna is detached, when in fact the both are.

"The Reader" was a compelling and fast read wherein the story of a powerful, illicit, and secret first love intersects with one of the darkest chapters of history--the aftermath of WWII in Germany. I enjoyed Schlink's clear and direct prose style. He raises some important moral, social, and philosophical questions that resonated for this reader long after I finished the novel, but he never does it in a way that is overbearing or detracts from the story.

I will be interested to see how the movie of this book was made. The book is very thought-provoking; there are no easy answers. What shapes a life? This book explores how is it we do not see/are unable to anticipate these things as they are happening and what consequences they will have. The author did a very good job concealing his hand and the allowing the outcomes to unfold and blindside me: I only anticipated one of the key mysteries.

I didn't know what to expect when I picked up this novel. I just knew that it was about a boy who falls in love with an elder women. That's it.And I read in like two or three sittings. It is very well written and I could feel with the first-person narrator and how he had to fight with his feelings and his thoughts.It really is an interesting novel. And although it does not have a happy ending, it does have a closed ending. And it still is a really good ending.So, go and read this book!
