Heralded as the late blooming of an author who had already been lauded with more prizes than a kid in a Kinder-egg factory, this book, according to many, is the best thing ever to happen to the apocalypse. I read this hot on the heels of a two day sprint through World War Z: An Oral History of the Zombie War by Max Brooks. Clearly rather than feeling that spring has now sprung, the over-long British winter has rendered my outlook bleak and dystopian. Don't worry - it's not altered any of my other fundamental personality traits and I am still a confirmed vegetarian and not about to start chewing on the puny office-based limbs of work colleagues any time soon.The first thing that many people comment on is how they struggled to get beyond all the "bleak". Bleak? This book makes the surface of the moon look like Disney's Magic Kingdom. Some might even be happier to try and transit into space without the aid of the appropriate astronautical equipment and watch their lungs get sucked up and out of their mouths like a double headed balloon on a sinewy string, rather than attempt to survive in the post-apocalyptic world as described by Cormac McCarthy. The man and the boy are making their way across a landscape ravaged by an undescribed event which has ended the world, reduced the population and covered everything with ash. One might speculate that god finally extinguished his cosmic cigarette and used planet earth as a convenient ashtray. The new world is empty of birds and animals, water and air are contaminated and food is scarce. Survivors are divided into two camps - those who are desperate to find other members of humanity in order to create a new civilisation. To raise a community again and settle down somewhere safe. The other camp is desperate to find other members of humanity so they can settle down, light a big fire, hog-tie and BBQ them and use their brains for dipping sauce. The anonymity of the man and the boy add to the bleakness. By never revealing names or biographical details it is as if McCarthy is trying to encourage us not to care about them and to remind us that such things as names, place of birth and other identifiers are only important when there are enough people around the make such badges of individuality seem necessary. When it's just you left, why bother with a name? Ultimately you might care about their fate but you might also spend a long time hoping that deliverance will be through the merciful release of a swift death. This book seems to have divided goodreads into a love/loath camp. I'm erring towards the side of love for this but I can see why many others felt it was too one-sidedly dark.

Buddy read with Jeff and Kelly (and Mitchell) 13 July 2015UPDATE: Just realized I forgot to rate this one #n00b3.5 rounded up bcuz I'm nice like that :DKelly finished this in a day because she's a stinker, and I still dunno how Jeff's progress is. He may be lost in the wasteland. We may never fully know. Anyway, I'VE finally finished. It took me a little while to get into the rhythm of how McCarthy writes, but soon enough it was flowing along at a steady pace. This book is basically the granddaddy of all modern dystopia novels (well, this and The Jungle by Upton Sinclair-- another one I have yet to read), and I had to keep reminding myself of that fact because as it went along I was always strongly reminded of Ashfall (which I highly recommend if you haven't read it). It's not fair to say not a lot happens in this book, even though that's what it felt like sometimes-- you could tell from the back-and-forth dialogue between the man and the boy that there were so many things going on in their minds that weren't being said. I do think this is overhyped a little bit, and once I watch the movie again this will probably wind up on the liked-the-movie-better shelf, but mainly because I think I find it similar to Lord of the Rings -- almost excessively wordy and drawn-out in its meandering style, whereas the film adaptation streamlines a lot of that just by giving you sweeping shots of the landscape. I'm not discounting McCarthy's talent, not at all, I just think this is one aspect where the films can do something just as well as the books.I went through this book almost clinically; that is, I don't know that it ever sparked a lot of emotional response, until the end. Eyes welled up, the whole bit, and it surprised me because it really felt like it came out of nowhere. Here I'd spent the last two weeks with this book not feeling a whole lot of anything and then WHAM. If you're one of those few people like me who still hasn't read this book, be prepared for that ending. And now this leaves me debating whether or not I want to read another Cormac McCarthy book... hm...

On this road there are no godspoke men. They are gone and I am left and they have taken with them the world. Query: How does the never to be differ from what never was?
Whenever I read good dystopian literature, I am always convinced that I would rather be at ground zero and gone immediately than to deal with what comes after. In Cormac McCarthyâ€™s depiction of what would occur after the ultimate world destruction, a man and his son are survivors trying to find their way back to something that might resemble civilization. Although the father tells the boy there are other â€œgood guysâ€ out there, the further into this story I wandered, the more I doubted the truth of that statement. Perhaps the most harrowing thought was that this did not seem improbable as an end of the world scenario. After all, he who is ruthless will most likely survive he who is not. I canâ€™t really say this is an enjoyable book, but it is thought provoking and makes you hope that man will be wiser in the end than our imagination forebodes. I wonder if there is the kind of strength in people today that would allow them to deal with this kind of hardship. I know there would not be that kind of strength in me. 
He walked out in the grey light and stood and he saw for a brief moment the absolute truth of the world. The cold relentless circling of the intestate earth. Darkness implacable. The blind dogs of the sun in the their running. The crushing black vacuum of the universe. And somewhere two hunted animals trembling like ground-foxes in their cover. Borrowed time and borrowed world and borrowed eyes with which to sorrow it.
I know there are those who do not care for this book. It is bleak, sad and scary. However, forewarned is forearmed and lightness in a book on this subject would be misplaced.

There was a whole lot of road. And a whole lot of walking. And a whole lot of nothing.I made the unfortunate mistake of seeing the movie before reading this book. Despite picturing Viggo Mortensen walking that road, it did not bring this book to life -- the movie was far, far better. (As was The Lord of The Rings trilogy where Viggo also did a whole lot of walking, if I recall. But I digress.) McCarthy's very sparse prose doesn't do this story any credit: I felt like I was walking behind the ghost of Hemingway, who was trying to talk, but couldn't get through the cosmic plasma enough to communicate his thoughts clearly. You see, to use words sparingly, to good effect is one thing. To write as if you were talking while your throat had been cut is quite another.I bow my head in shame before all those who thought this was the best post-apocalyptic novel ever written. But ... nah. It's just not doing it for me. Empty, yes. Vacuous, more apt a description.The ending -- the part that always changes things for me -- raised this to three stars. (The last 30 pages or so turned it from a 1-star rating to a 3-star. Pull on my heart strings in a certain way, and it gets me every time.) Once again, a tip of the hat to Hollywood, they did it better. This was my first McCarthy book. It will also probably be my last. I wish I had heeded Robert Frost, Two roads diverged in a wood, and I/I took the one less traveled by,/And that has made all the difference.Sometimes, it's better to stick to the highway.
My emotions! My emotions!I enjoy stories in which nothing much happens. They interest me. I liked The Road. Nothing much happens.

Meraviglioso. Entra sul tappeto rosso nella top 5 dei cinque libri migliori che abbia mai letto. Fa male. Come fa male bruciarsi toccando la fiamma di una candela.Ti insegna che il fuoco brucia anche se non ci passi un dito in mezzo.
Ok so this book just didn't do much for me. I kept wanting answers and got none. I have to have the answers! :P

The living is sparse a few walk upon the land.The two of us, my son and i wonder the land constantly on the movenever in one place for more than a nightwe eat what we can find.Canned fruit in high numbers.My younger companion is constantly asking me questions of which the answer I can't really give honestly.Will we meet some good people?How many are alive?When will the road end and how?When the food is no more will people yonder resort to eating each other?In the quite times when I watch over him at night I read and I contemplate on the parallel life led in a great journey of survival on the road in a world gone to the dead in a book called The road by Cormac McCarthy. The story rings true to what we are faced with, everything i just mentioned of our day to day survival, the main characters find themselves in the same dilemma.The prose, language and simplistic storytelling communicates a story of hope and great significance,I hoped for the father and son to reach safety and good health. The story captivates and demands your attention in a continuing beautiful prose that provides hours of effortless reading taking you through their plight down a road that ends either in one of two fates safety or death.Loss, death I have witnessed itbut we will not submit to it we shall not part company we die and live together companions on this road.The son in the story also has this want to never be parted, the tragedy they are part of bonds them forever, a closeness that could not have been a fact in the world before the darkness spread upon the earth. I hope this struggle we are midst proves to be a lesson and aids any souls who read of this, those that find themselves too part of a struggle for survival, to not give up hope.These two roads/journeys.The odyssey explained here and in the novel The Road be carried forward eternally retold in time to the masses.For the greatness of the human endeavour, love, bond with hope against fears to survive. We have plenty fight in usThe fire is not out!Burning eternally in us and the characters unavoidable fates.Shocking, harrowing and heartbreaking this story was and so is our plight if I only had more time to add to this brief accounting of mine.As day is soon to come close I must catch only a few hours sleep,I must watch over my son while he sleeps for safety from the walking dead.My son must not have knowledge of this walking dead, as i wish for his heart to not beat unhealthily and his nightmares be more harrowing.They have no rest in searching out food,The flesh of man has never before been of such demand till now since the fallout and breakout. Indeed we possibly are all living on borrowed time like that of the two in 'The Road.'The sense of another world yonder, beautiful and peaceful, beckoning and calling for our souls is a surety an inevitable end that gives me hope and the conquering over the fear of dying.Cormac McCarthy commands the page with a lyrical style, originality and language his own trademark like that of another great writer that comes to mind who has expired but voice alive in his works, William Faulkner.The author is a genius, a true understander and writer of the plight of the people, tragedy, love and war, hopes and fears upon this terrible beauty. A dwelling place on borrowed time.For us and those characters contained in 'The Road.'(This is a review with a different approach using a fictional voice)
"Nghts dark beyond darkness and the days more gray each one than what had gone before. Like the onset of some cold glaucoma dimming away the world. His hand rose and fell softly with each precious breath.""He lay listening to the water drip in the woods. Bedrock, this. The cold and silence. The ashes of the late world carried on the bleak and temporal winds to and fro in the void. Carried forth and scattered and carried forth agin. Everything uncoupled from its shoring. Unsupported in the ashen air. Sustained by a breath, trembling and brief. If only my heart were stone.""In those first years the roads were peopled with refugees shrouded up in their clothing. Wearing masks and goggles, sitting in their rags by the side of the road like ruined aviators. Their barrows heaped with shoddy. Towing wagons or carts. Their eyes bright in their skulls. Creedless shells of men tottering down the causeways like migrants in a feverland. The frailty of everything revealed at last. Old and troubling issues resolved into nothingness and night. The last instance of a thing takes the class with it. Turns out the light and is gone. Look around you. Ever is a long time. But the boy knew what he knew. That ever is no time at all.""They squatted in the road and ate cold rice and cold beans that they'd cooked days ago. Already beginning to ferment. No place to make a fire that would not be seen. They slept huddled together in the rank quilts in the dark and the cold. He held the boy close to him. So thin. My heart, he said. My heart. But he knew that if he were a good father still it might well be as she said. That the boy was all that stood between him and death.""In a drawer he found a candle. Now way to light it. He put it in his pocket. He walked out in the gray light and stood and he saw for a brief moment the absolute truth of the world. The cold relentless circling of the intense earth. Darkness implacable. The blind dogs of the sun in their running. The crushing black vacuum of the universe. And somewhere two hunted animals trembling like ground foxes in their cover. Borrowed time and borrowed world and borrowed eyes with which to sorrow it.""The land was gullied and eroded and barren. The bones of dead creatures sprawled in the washes. Middens of anonymous trash. Farmhouses in the fields scoured of their paint and the clapboards spooned and sprung from the wallstuds. All of it shadowless and without feature. The road descended through a jungle of dead kudzu. A marsh where the dead reeds lay over the water. Beyond the edge of the fields the sullen haze hung over the earth and sky alike. By late afternoon it had begun to snow and they went on with the tarp over them and the wet snow hissing on the plastic." "They slept more and more. More than once they woke sprawled in the road like traffic victims. The sleep of death.""They trekked out along the crescent sweep of beach, keeping to the firmer sand below the tidewrack. They stood, their clothes flapping softly. Glass floats covered with a gray crust. The bones of seabirds. At the tide line a woven mat of weeds and the ribs of fishes in their millions stretching along the shore as far as eye could see like an isocline of death. One vast salt sepulchre. Senseless. Senseless."

Review for Chimes (May 11, 2007)â€œThe blackness he woke to on those nights was sightless and impenetrable. A blackness to hurt your ears with listening. Often he had to get up. No sound but the wind in the trees. He rose and stood tottering in that cold autistic dark with his arms outheld for balance while the vestibular calculations in his skull cranked out their reckonings.â€In his new novel â€œThe Road,â€ Cormac McCarthy portrays the journey of a father and son across a bleak, post-apocalyptic world in stark, muscular prose. The plot, structure, style, characters and dialogue are all barren, echoing the landscape through which the unnamed characters traverse.McCarthy never explains why or how the world is barren and dead. All we know is that a father and son are pushing their shopping cart of canned food, a map, a tarp and a loaded pistol down empty roads, seeking the coast or a warmer climate for winter. The rest of the world, it seems, has either reverted to cannibalism or died.The structure of the book reinforces its bleak tone. Its 240 pages (in large font, mind you) are composed not of chapters, but of small narrative or descriptive nuggets that are never more than one page long. The sentences, too, are short, punchy and at times lyrical, reminiscent of Ernest Hemingway. This style, like Hemingwayâ€™s, is intensely effective for a short story or novella â€“ just read â€œThe Old Man and the Seaâ€ sometime â€“ but halfway through the book, the short sentences lose their impact and become tiresome.But McCarthy goes beyond Hemingway at times and ends up trying too hard. For example, in the following passage, the son spots a corpse in the road (they seem to appear nearly every other page) and asks his father about it:Who is it? said the boy.I donâ€™t know. Who is anybody?â€œAll horror all the timeâ€ seems to be McCarthyâ€™s mantra, and while post-apocalyptic literature certainly requires the theme of hopelessness, it need not dominate the work like it does in â€œThe Road.â€ For example, Samuel Beckettâ€™s play â€œEndgameâ€ is equally bleak, yet one laughs at its absurdity through the whole production. Instead, McCarthy over-emphasizes the darkness, making the novel predictable and boring on occasion.Despite these faults, the general critical response to â€œThe Roadâ€ has been positive. In the last three weeks, it won the 2007 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction and was selected for Oprahâ€™s Book Club.While the Pulitzers arenâ€™t perfect in their selections (e.g. â€œGileadâ€), their praise of â€œThe Roadâ€ is warranted. Digging beneath the structure, style and tone, one finds at the core of the novel the classic father-son story of tension of love, frustration and the inability to communicate.Another way to see the father-son relationship is as an allegory. The ever-cautious father represents Survival. He frequently threatens, steals from and sometimes even kills other people to save his son and himself. The son, contrarily, represents Compassion. He often pesters his father to assist the ravaged, desperate people they encounter. The novel, then, becomes the inner struggle between serving oneself and serving others.A final interpretation is to see â€œThe Roadâ€ as an attempt to face mortality. An old, accomplished writer at the end of his life, McCarthy faces the mystery that lies beyond the grave. Perhaps the darkness of the post-apocalyptic world is the darkness of death, and the father and son are our wandering souls searching to make sense of the incomprehensible terror of the present and the rapidly fading memories of the past.In â€œThe Road,â€ Cormac McCarthy brings his audience into a grim and barren landscape through his (tiringly) stark prose, forcing them to confront the possibility of a dismal future. As a graduating senior, I hope I wonâ€™t have to relate.

Very, very dark. Apocalyptic. The story of a journey to a better place, in a world destroyed by events unexplained - in a world where, in all probability, there is no better place. A man and a boy. A battle with the elements, with the lack of food and water and with other survivors.It's bleak, grim in extremis, but I loved it!

I co-host the Glowburn podcast; a podcast about post-apocalyptic roleplaying. I've been a fan of the post-apocalyptic genre since I was very young, being raised as the son of a military man during the cold war. It seemed fated that one day the bombs would drop and we would all wake carrying guns openly in the streets fighting four-armed, two-headed mutants with glowing eyes.Or at least, that's what we wanted to believe.But that's fantasy.The Road hits closer to potential reality. And it isn't glitz and guns and heroic escapes. It's about survival and scraping by in a gray, boring landscape where most of the other inhabitants - when you can find them - want to rape you, kill you, then eat you. Every step is tedious and terrifying.And yet, somehow, McCarthy has carved out a thing of dark beauty here. Part of the beauty is due to the sheer economy of words the author uses. Much of the dread is unspoken, implied between the words.He woke whimpering in the night and the man held him. Shh, he said. Shh. It's okay.I had a bad dream.I know.Should I tell you what it was?If you want to.I had this penguin that you wound up and it would waddle and flap its flippers. And we were in that house that we used to live in and it came around the corner but nobody had wound it up and it was really scary.Okay.It was a lot scarier in the dream.I know. Dreams can be really scary.Why did I have that scary dream?I don't know. But its okay now. I'm going to put some wood on the fire. You go to sleep.The boy didn't answer. Then he said: The winder wasnt turning.Simple, and easy to gloss over, but on reflection, this little vignette is terrifying in that it opens a window on a little boys fear of the unexplained, the inexplicable. And much of the world he inhabits, with his guardian father, goes unexplained. There are many answers to many questions, few of which provide any hope.So hope has to be made on the fly. Faith has to be lit and stoked from within.The boy sat tottering. The man watched him that he not topple into the flames. He kicked in the sand for the boy's hips and shoulders where he would sleep and he sat holding him while he tousled his hair before the fire to dry it. All of this like some ancient anointing. So be it. Evoke the forms. Where you've nothing else construct ceremonies out of the air and breathe upon them.And this, after the man had washed the boy's hair of the brains of a dead man who had tried to kidnap the boy from his father. Tried . . .Still, hope is hard to come by.They scrabbled through the charred ruins of houses they would not have entered before. A corpse floating in the black water of a basement among the trash and rusting duct-work. He stood in a livingroom partly burned and open to the sky. The waterbuckled boards sloping away into the yard. Soggy volumes in a bookcase. He took one down and opened it and then put it back. Everything damp. Rotting. In a drawer he found a candle. No way to light it. He put it in his pocket. He walked out in the gray light and stood and he saw for a brief moment the absolute truth of the world. The cold relentless circling of the intestate earth. Darkness implacable. The blind dogs of the sun in their running. The crushing black vacuum of the universe. And somewhere two hunted animals trembling like ground-foxes in their cover. Borrowed time and borrowed world and borrowed eyes with which to sorrow it.There is no triumph in such a world. Only pyrrhic victory and a dim candleflame of hope against the gale winds of decay. But there is, in the end, love and memory, which keep that dim flame lit until the last inch of wick is finally, quietly, consumed.

My Rating: 3.4/5â€œThere is no God and we are his prophets.â€ â€œYou have my whole heart. You always did.â€ â€œIf trouble comes when you least expect it then maybe the thing to do is to always expect it.â€ â€œKeep a little fire burning; however small, however hidden.â€ â€œWhere men can't live gods fare no better.â€ â€œQuery: How does the never to be differ from what never was?â€ I once said to my friend, "We are living in Damnation. We may need to look out for that thirty minutes of paradise" and that's how I felt while reading this novel. This is definitely one of the best books I have read but still, It was hell going through the first half of the novel. Even though it was a Pulitzer winner.... yeah and how did it win it anyway? The story was fantastic. The dialogues were raw and they felt more connected somehow and I really like them. The characters were well written and overall the novel was good. Except... the writing style, the prose, the author's adamant nature on not using punctuation and stuff.It was really hard to read because of it. Sometimes, some of the stuff he wrote didn't make sense at all. That's why I only gave a 3.4 for at least a 4 deserving novel.This one broke my heart at the same time made me realize some stuff too.Thank you for reading the review.

Such a beautifully written book depicting the bleakness, deprivation and darkness of a post-apocalyptic world. No animals, fish or birds, the ground is burnt and the trees are dying. Just a man and a boy walking along an eerily deserted road, scavenging for food, avoiding gangs of thugs who would steal from them or worse. Unable to help anyone else and knowing that they will probably die when no more tinned food can be found. But still there is love as they look out for each other and head south to the coast and there is also hope that they will find others like them and a future to fight for.

Wow. This may be one of the saddest books that I have ever read, yet I couldn't stop reading.Essentially, I've been hearing rumblings on the Internet now and again that McCarthy is the Faulkner of our age, so I grabbed this book haphazardly off the shelf from the library to give him a look.The premise of the book is pretty basic: a catastrophe has occurred and a father and son are trying to survive. One could assume that the catastrophe is of the nuclear bomb variety and that the setting is America, though this is never explicitly stated. One might also assume that this is never stated because the people remaining are either unaware of the details or else it is just not important anymore when faced with the bigger picture of day-to-day survival. The boy and his father are staying close to a road that is taking them South, as they believe that the warmer climate will eliminate that particular variable to their continued existence. Their most valuable possessions are a gun with two bullets in the chamber and a shopping cart. As they travel the road, the two major concerns are the search for food and the avoidance of other people. The reason to avoid others is because the disaster has caused humanity's worst face to show itself. Any stranger brings a high potential for harm. While the nicer ones may only take your possessions and leave you to certain death, there are others (that seem to travel in groups) that have a penchant for rape or cannibalism. There is a kind of melancholy inspiration that can be found here. The boy often echoes the words heard from his father that they are "the good guys" and "keeping the fire". What this means to me is that they choose to persist in maintaining their humanity and not degrading it like the marauding cannibal rapists or cashing out early like the boy's mother chose to do (which would be a tempting option for anyone in a similar situation).The prose of this book is also a curious thing. It is very sparse, almost to the point of being minimalistic. Basically, it is all scenery and dialog, with only the occasional glimpses into dreams or thoughts. I didn't think that I was going to like the writing style when I first began reading, but I am now of the opinion that it is crucial in making the story so effective. It forces the reader to become more engrossed in the microcosm that is the boy and his father. If we had been given all of the background behind the disaster, etc, I think it would have detracted from the story in the long run.My only possible complaint with this book is the way that the dialog is printed. The punctuation is also very sparse, and there are no real chapter divisions to speak of. Each paragraph is written as a block of text, and the dialog is printed within a block of text with a character's utterance starting a new indented line. There are no quotation marks and none of the ",said the boy" business that readers are used to. This caused me to sometimes lose track during verbal exchanges between the father and son as far as who was saying what. At first I also thought that the dialog was too stilted and the characters were hollow. I then started reflecting on the things that people most often chat about, such as work, school, television shows and movies. In a world such as this, where a rusty can of peaches meant more than all of the movies one has ever seen, I'm pretty sure all of our dialog would become stilted rather quickly.Sadly, I found this to be totally believable for a post apocalyptic type novel. One only needs to look back at footage from New Orleans during Hurricane Katrina to realize that when the chips are down, human beings can get really ugly really fast. Although I loved this book, I wouldn't recommend reading it for anyone who is uncomfortable about getting all freaked out and then rushing to the grocery store to stock up on non-perishable food items. I'm going to have to look this up again, but wasn't this book on Oprah's list awhile back? If I'm correct about that, I am now totally intrigued by the prospect of how magnificiently awful it must have went over with the soccer mom demographic that we assume makes up a majority of her viewers.

Wow! I wasn't too sure about The Road going in. I've heard all the talk about the lack of punctuation, the confusing dialogue. As an English teacher, incorrect punctuation is usually offensive to me, but holy hell! I was completely ravished by this book! I love, love, LOVE post-apocalyptic stories (except the endless loop of recycled YA tropes that all end up with teenagers saving the world--yeah, right!). Interesting that so many of these books are massive tomes--The Stand, The Passage, Swan Song: great stories, all. Not one of them, not even my beloved Stand, managed to make me feel the gritty reality of what it might actually be like to survive in a post-apocalyptic world like The Road did, and in such a succinct format.I felt like the lack of punctuation actually reflects this world that Man and Boy live in, where the mundane structures we surround ourselves with no longer matter. That applies to the bleak prose, as well. Their world is so grey, so cold, so desolate--how better to express it than with such stark diction?I found the Boy's outlook interesting. I know he represents the good side of humanity, the qualities that used to abound (in some people) in the world that was no longer. I was still not quite convinced of his reactions to the people he met. I would have thought, having never known anything but the terrible, dangerous life of a survivor, that he would be mistrustful, suspicious, self-protective. Instead, he abounds with compassion and tolerance. Where does this come from? He's never really been around other people, from the sounds of it--he and his father spend all their time pretty much fleeing encounters with other people. The ones they do have are almost always unpleasant. I mean, it's not like the people they meet are just rude; they are actively trying to kill them. The child sees the cellar with the captured victims chained, awaiting their turn to be the entree of the day. He sees the horrifying sight of a newborn baby, butchered and spitted over a fire like a woodland animal. Still, he wants to invite strangers into their midst, share their precious food stores, even after being on the brink of starvation himself more than once, knowing that there is no guarantee they will find more. Even his father, his role model, the only person he can observe to learn behavior as children do, does not practice this generous acceptance. So . . . why? Is it just because he's so lonely and starved for human interaction that he's willing to risk death? Something to ponder!The ending, also, was just a little pat, but I'm willing to overlook that. It would have been more in keeping with the tone of the book if the convenient stranger had started pinching the boy's arm to see how much meat was on his bones--that's what I half-way expected! Still, I loved the book so much that I was willing to accept this hopeful ending.I don't know what my love for and fascination with these apocalyptic stories says about me. I mean, there are no good types of apocalypses where the world is overwhelmed with rainbows and fairies that grant wishes. Nope, just pestilence, nuclear detonations, and the undead. Oh, well, what can I say? I'm a ghoul, and I'm at peace with it! If you have ghoulish tendencies and can overlook some missing commas and apostrophes, I highly recommend this!

This is one of my favorite books. It has its detractors, and of course, your mileage might vary, but here are a few quick observations about Cormac McCarthy's brilliant The Road. 1. This book made me cry. You've heard of the iceberg technique of storytelling? The one Hemingway championed? This book is the textbook example of it. The father-son relationship, which is absolutely the axis on which the entire novel turns, is so full of raw emotion and undying love and unwavering loyalty that it brings me to tears. And not so much by what the father and son say, but rather by what they don't say, and yet how clearly their emotions still resonate with the reader. I'd like to think that I'd behave like this dad if ever my son and I faced a situation this harrowing because, imperfect though the father might be, everything he does grows from his love of his boy. I admire that. And respect it deeply. There's an iceberg of love inside many of us men, even if one can't always see it. This book expressed that truth beautifully. 2. Folks sometimes get hung up on McCarthy's unique punctuation (or lack of punctuation) style. As though a writer of his abilities needs to resort to some stripped-down gimmick in some desperate attempt to garner attention. Okay, so maybe the no-quotation-marks thing isn't for you, and I can respect that, but let's be real here--McCarthy doesn't need to use gimmicks of any kind. He's a genius. And for me, the form of this novel is part of why it moved me so deeply. Each book is different, and each author must find the right voice, form, and style to express his or her ideas. In The Road (and other McCarthy books), his style reduces the distance between reader and character to the point where we can feel each one of the father's labored respirations. Our throats tighten with emotion and fear as we swing wildly from one extreme emotion to another. There are no impediments to our readerly intimacy. And again, McCarthy executes this beautifully. 3. Lastly, I should mention that I read The Road several years ago and have not gone back to it yet. But doesn't that illustrate just how powerfully it affected me? I'm writing about it now, and though I don't have a Matt Damonesque Good Will Hunting memory, I can remember vividly several moments from the novel. I remember many exchanges between father and son. I remember ash coating the ground like a newly-fallen scrim of snow. And I remember two horrific moments that gave me nightmares and haunt me still--one with something roasting over a fire and another one involving a horrible revelation in a basement. And that's where I'll end. The Road, in my earnest opinion, is a horror novel. Many of you will disagree with this assessment, perhaps because you see horror as a genre populated merely by vampires, werewolves, and masked serial killers. And while horror can feature those tropes, it can also be lyrical, heartfelt, and as literary as any other genre. The Road, of course, is all of those things, and it's damned frightening as well. Both in its plot and in its implications. It also happens to be one of the most loving and life-affirming books I've ever read, and I can think of few tales that more deserve a five-star rating.

Cormac McCarthy is truly a literary genius. With a completely unique style, unconventionally developed yet very relatable characters and a situation that is both heartbreaking and intimate, The Road takes a somewhat tired post-apocalyptic genre and makes a very human story, both tragic and life affirming. Never before have I read a book so bleak. The oppression of the scorched landscape is a constant struggle both for the characters and the reader. I was actually slowed down, feeling my energy drained as book moved forward. However, this is countered by the loving, though never idealized, relationship between the unnamed father and son. Their love throughout the journey is the only source of light, even when strained by the harsh decisions need in the dead world. I'll be very careful who I recommend The Road to, and do suggest a steady stream of cartoons between reading sessions, but the reward of truly remarkable reading experience is well worth the pain of the journey.

The futility of continuing on for any purpose other than to express love, but that is enough, and so he does, with no hope of any reward other than that which he feels in the moment.Is it a fearful look into what McCarthy feels is a possible future? Is it an allegory for everyone's approach to what we know is certain death?Whatever McCarthy's purpose, which could well encompass both of the above and more, The Road is an utterly compelling read. The sparse sentences express emotion in so few words yet with such power. The absence of names makes the story universal. The only part that did not ring true for me was the ending. Why, among the possible choices, was this ending chosen? ... any thoughts on that?

I don't think me and Cormac McCarthy get along very well. This is the second book of his I've read (blood meridian) that has sorely left me wanting some form of structured narrative, or just more of a story in general. The prose in this book is poetic in places. It's a real shame theres not a huge amount of story to back it up. The 'whys' of this book aren't answered, the man and the boy are referred to as such, no character names and the dialogue is the most annoying I've ever encountered:The boy "I'm scared"The man "It's okay"THE END!If this book was longer it might've warranted a four star. As it is, it feels like a bit of a short story.
This book broke my heart in ways I couldn't have imagined they existed. It has the most emotionally heartbreaking/warming love story between a father and his son I've ever come across in books.

This took me an embarrassing amount of time to read, and it's not that I didn't enjoy it, I just gave it the lowest priority out of two other books I'm reading at the same time. Not to be daunted by the jabs and subsequent emoticon ditto given to me for a review of another Oprah book I'll once again show that I'm not one to overlook the Queen of All Media and creator of literary tastes among the generally not-so-well read and hark once again on Oprah and her choices of books. This book makes no sense as an Oprah book, and it's sad in away that it is one, not sad in that boo-hoo I'm going to lose a favorite author to the masses kind of way, but because too many people who read this just because it is an Oprah book just don't deserve to read it. That's right, they don't deserve it and they will not realize that they are reading something truly great and moving, and just think they are reading some kind of staccato nonsense about a man and his boy walking around on a road and not really saying too much to each other. This book isn't for the uninitiated into the writing of Cormac McCarthy, I'm not sure what I would think of this book if I hadn't read most of his other books before this one. The same could be said of No Country for Old Men too though, both of these books have their strength in being beautiful while being held against the world he has created for his characters in books like Suttree and The Border Trilogy. In McCarthy's stoic world these books are probably about as close to an overflowing of emotion that one is going to find, and he puts that emotion quite subtly into the experiences of the boy and the child. He doesn't hark on it, just like he never seems to feel the need to really give the reader a real sense of what is going on in the world that these two characters are living in. The world is post-apocalyptic, but the reasons are never really given. Some really bad shit happened after whatever it is happened, but again the reader doesn't know exactly what that was. Why are they wearing pieces of cloth over their mouths sometime? Why did the tar on the road melt? Why did some people cut their fingers off? What sent the masses onto the road, something that was bad enough to scare the shit out of everyone, but not bad enough to kill them, and something that left people living on the road for years. The average reader I think will find the lack of answers annoying, but it's in the very slight clues and sparse flashback scenes that little tantalizing bits of information are given, and I think it was McCarthy's idea to leave it to the reader to fill in the blanks. Not because it's the lazy way out, but because the speculation and ultimate unknowing is more satisfying to the imagination while reading the book, then any answer and author could give. We've all read about the end of the world, there are even plenty of 'road' apocalypse books (like The Stand), and to get into the details of why the world ended and why all the crazy shit is going on ignores the central crux of the story, the relationship of two people , a father trying to raise his son in a world that is on it's death bed. There is a sense of futility to the book that's as if it came out of a Beckett novel, but unlike the characters of Beckett who are trapped most of the time in the absurdity of a lack of hope, McCarthy chooses to have his characters continue to slowly trudge on towards something better even if there is nothing better out there. This book isn't for everybody, and I can't imagine what it would be like coming to this novel after the generally melodramatic family stories that Oprah normally chooses for her readers, maybe it will be a good thing for them. I don't know. I'm running out of characters quickly, but I'll throw in my one pet theory of the novel, and I have no basis for this, but it's sort of how I saw the man when I read the book. The Man is Suttree.

I have read a lot of post-apocalyptic fiction and â€œThe Roadâ€ by Cormac McCarthy is probably in a tie with â€œOn the Beachâ€ by Nevil Shute for the most depressing example of the genre ever written. It was so relentless that I was very surprised by the ending.As I was reading, I kept hearing Spencer Tracyâ€™s voice narrating in my head the way he narrated the voice-over in the movie version of â€œThe Old Man and the Sea.â€ In fact, within a couple of pages, I noticed a great similarity between McCormacâ€™s style in â€œThe Roadâ€ and Hemingwayâ€™s signature style. If anything, heâ€™s even sparer than Hemingway. His words and sentences arenâ€™t just short, the punctuation is even leaner. He doesnâ€™t use any apostrophes for contractions and he doesnâ€™t use any quotation marks for dialogue. He doesnâ€™t even have chapters, just very frequent page breaks. The characters have no names, just â€œthe manâ€ and â€œthe boyâ€. Sometimes, they are referred to as father and son. Let me state flat-out that I hate Hemingway. I suffered through a couple of his short stories and â€œThe Sun Also Risesâ€ only because I had to as an English lit major. However, I think McCarthyâ€™s writing in â€œThe Roadâ€ is effective. It fits the story of a father and son just trying to stay alive on a barren, devastated planet. I have to admit that Iâ€™m really torn on the ending. I canâ€™t decide if itâ€™s a cheat or not. It certainly was a twist and it raised more questions than it answered. I think it would have been more true to the narrative if it had ended differently. It almost seemed as if McCormac ran out of steam and just decided to end it. Despite the possibly flawed ending (and Iâ€™m still not sure it was flawed), I must shamelessly admit that it made me cry. If you decide to read â€œThe Roadâ€, I highly recommend that you have a humorous book on hand to start reading as soon as you finish. Youâ€™re going to need some humor when youâ€™re done.I suppose I should also add my reasoning for only giving it three stars. While it does have a lot of critical acclaim and people really like this book, I didn't find it to be particularly creative. I've been down this road before in numerous post-apocalyptic books and films, many of which were done much better. I liked it, but I didn't love it and I definitely wasn't blown away by it.

This is a very dark book. It is a sort of a post- apocalyptic western told as a long, somewhat poetic nightmare. It is about a man and his son who survived the Apocalypse (some sort of a global fire, not many details are revealed) . They are waking up each day walking towards the South hoping to live another day. Why are they going south? The only reason stated in the book is the hope that it would be warmer. Every day they face death, starvation, disease, extreme cold, hopelessness. There is no long term goal, only the need to survive but not with all cost. The man and the child are â€the good guysâ€ and they are trying not to hurt other human beings even if sometimes it is impossible. The are constantly on the run from cannibals hordes that are hunting any survivor.All the world is grey, unknown, the toxic ash is everywhere. There are some glimpses in the past that offer slight information on how things came to be but not much. The prose is very repetitive, there are very few concrete details with not record of time. The repetitiveness might help to introduce the reader into the bleak, hopeless atmosphere but, in my opinion, does not make the book an attractive read. There is a lot of small conversation between the man and the boy which is almost the same every time. â€We have to get goingâ€, â€Are you ok?â€, â€Iâ€™m okâ€, â€œIâ€™m scaredâ€, â€œitâ€™s ok, donâ€™t be scaredâ€. The dialog is not separately marked and you have to guess who is saying what. Not that it actually matters.I think that this repetitiveness of the banal dialogue and of some of the descriptions was the main thing that I did not enjoy about the book. I did not manage to care about the characters or to get involve in story. The language is poetic in some parts and there are some interesting abstract comments about life and death but otherwise it failed to impress me. All I felt was the cold. The author made a good job to make me feel cold all the time I was reading the book. That probably happened because the weather outside is also bleak and cold and in sink with the atmosphere of the book. I sort of feel guilty I did not like this book more as I know it is seen as a masterpiece.

I joined a real life book club for the first time and THE ROAD was our book to read. I had never heard of it but I learned it had won the Pulitzer Prize in 2007 and in 2009 the book was adapted into a movie. I was pretty excited to know it had all these great accomplishments and we were going to read it. Unfortunately, for me, I was bored throughout the book. The story was one continuously long chapter that added to the feeling of dragging on. It was descriptively written which added to the essence of how bleak the world had become. While all that was well done it made me tired of reading about this world. I know this book was written a few years before the tv show The Walking Dead had started but I kept waiting for zombies to jump out and attack the two characters (a young son and a dad). No, there aren't any zombies in this book but it had that desperate how are we going to survive and keep the bad people away feel to it. Even though I'm in the minority in my thoughts about this book there are many articles that call it a 'masterpiece.' Those who like worst case scenarios and survival type books should give this one a try. It's set in a post-apocalyptic world with a boy and his dad relying on each other. Really it's a love story between a parent and a child.  How far would you go to protect your child if the apocalypse happened?STANDALONE

Esa descripciÃ³n de un mundo post-apocalÃ­ptico envuelto en penumbra, hambre, desolaciÃ³n, canibalismo... ha sido agobiante. Hay libros de los que uno lee que, cuando se enfrenta al momento en que tiene que hablar sobre Ã©l, encuentra las palabras adecuadas, precisas, que lo describen a la perfecciÃ³n. Existen otros con los que ocurre algo opuesto: sabemos quÃ© nos produjo pero ponerlo en palabras no es fÃ¡cil. Y hay un tercer grupo de libros que, teniendo en cuenta que es hasta complicado explicarnos a nosotros mismos quÃ© nos transmitiÃ³, mÃ¡s arduo serÃ¡ contÃ¡rselo a otra persona. Por ende, acertar en los conceptos para describirlo serÃ¡ algo mÃ¡s complejo aÃºn. La carretera se ubica en este Ãºltimo grupo. La premisa de la novela nos plantea un paisaje desolado, destruido por algo que no se sabe bien quÃ© fue. AllÃ­ viven (mejor dicho, tratan de sobrevivir), un padre, el hombre, y su hijo, el chico. De ellos dos poco sabemos, ni siquiera sus nombres; solamente que la supervivencia es el Ãºnico objetivo claro que tienen. PodrÃ­a parecer que el argumento tiene poco de originalidad. Es probable que asÃ­ sea. Pero a veces en las novelas no es necesario tener una gran cuota de originalidad si hay otros factores que hacen que la historia sobresalga de una manera especial. En el caso de La carretera, la clave estÃ¡ en cÃ³mo McCarthy puede contarla. En todo momento transmite el desamparo de los personajes, sus miedos, sus deseos, su tristeza; el hecho de permanecer juntos pase lo que pase. En ese paisaje sombrÃ­o, oscuro, inquietante y desesperanzador es donde ocurre todo. Decir "todo" puede dejar entrever que en la historia pasan muchas cosas, de esas que nos hacen sorprender, esos giros de trama. MentirÃ­a si dijera que en La carretera pasa eso. En esta novela, los hechos son, de alguna manera, predecibles. Los personajes buscan comida, la encuentra, no la encuentran, caminan, paran a descansar, divisan personas, se escapan. Lo que podrÃ­a pasar en cualquier novela postapocalÃ­ptica. Pero reitero, lo central en esta historia no es lo que pasa, sino la genial habilidad que tiene el autor para lograr que lo que sienten los personajes nos llegue. En todo momento, mientras leÃ­a, preponderÃ³ en mÃ­ un sentimiento que se me hace muy difÃ­cil describir con claridad. Las palabras quizÃ¡s mÃ¡s adecuadas para definirlo serÃ­an algo asÃ­ como miedo, intranquilidad, nervios, perturbaciÃ³n. Es una mezcla de todo eso. Â¿No son los buenos libros los que nos hacen sentir?La novela no da respiro en ningÃºn momento. No solo porque lo que pasa es atractivo para el lector, porque por lo menos para mÃ­, siempre es atrayente leer sobre mundos distÃ³picos (bien construidos, gracias), sino porque el autor tiene una forma de narrar que, literalmente, no deja que respiremos. Habitualmente, cuando uno enumera una lista de cosas, o de acciones, las separa con comas, y reciÃ©n une la penÃºltima y la Ãºltima acciÃ³n con una "y". Parece que McCarthy no se guÃ­a por las reglas normales de puntuaciÃ³n, y opta por dejar a un lado las comas y unir todo con yes. Esto genera que la lectura se haga mucho mÃ¡s vertiginosa y no nos deje tomar aliento en ningÃºn momento; porque de hecho, las comas son las que nos permiten hacer esto, son pausas no tan prolongadas como los puntos pero pausas al fin. Entonces, esta manera de encadenar los hechos junto con las acciones que se describen, hacen de La carretera una novela que, si uno se engancha rÃ¡pido en ella, se puede leer en unas horas. El hecho de haber tardado ocho dÃ­as en terminarla no da cuenta de esto, ya que en un principio sÃ­ me costÃ³ un poco acostumbrarme a la historia y a la prosa del autor, pero una vez que me adaptÃ©, la lectura fluyÃ³ con total naturalidad. La carretera es una novela que me encantÃ³ no solo por el tema que trata y por lo que consigue transmitir el autor, sino porque tambiÃ©n da lugar a reflexiones sobre nuestra vida cotidiana, la relaciÃ³n que tenemos con los otros, la supervivencia y el valor que le damos a nuestra existencia.

For its own genre (post-apocalypse) it is very strongly written - it is a Pulitzer winner anyway. It could show fears and emotions, horrors and crimes, hopes and despairs and many other human existential concerns very well. Especial language. Short sentences with sometimes no verb, short conversations between the father and the boy (who are unnamed). Descriptions of the ruined nature and planet earth were so precise that I could see them in pictures in my mind very easily. The good and the bad people and the father's prophetic inspirations. All in all, the subject was a little repetitive for me, I could relate it to Saramago's The Blindness and O'Connor's realistic and hard stories written in Hemingway's style but it was worth a read.

Terse and dark and introspective and brutal and masterful and flawed and the last one on my 2016 reread list. Okay? asked the man. Okay, said the boy.OLIVIER DELAYEAuthor of the SEBASTEN OF ATLANTIS series

Stopped at 30%. You know you're not going to finish it when you start skimming. I'm sorry McCarthy, I enjoyed the first 50 pages of your prose, but there's no discernible plot and I'm really getting bored.

In his latest novel, The Road, Pulitzer-prize winning author Cormac McCarthy chronicles the journey of a father and son in a post-apocalyptic world, where everything that made the world a beautiful place has been destroyed. Lacking civilization, the only ones that remain are victims of the unknown catastrophe desperately searching for salvation (the good guys) and those who have converted into cannibalism, victimizing passersby, to stay alive (the bad guys). The Road is a remarkably written novel, engaging the reader in a world of despair and hopelessness with language arranged so elegantly, it leaves images in your mind you never would have dreamed of.The father and son, both unnamed and without age, are suffering from starvation, the suicide of a wife and mother, and winterâ€™s frigid weather. They embark on a journey to reach the southeastern United States, in order to have a chance at life in a warm climate, with the knowledge that they may not be able to survive the winter. The father is devoted to keeping his son safe from attack and somewhat adequately nourished while trying to avoid thoughts of his wifeâ€™s death that seem to haunt both him and the son throughout the story. They find abandoned carts and houses full of food, but not without consequence. Human remains are scattered all over the landscape and the child has seen so much more than any adult in our world has likely ever witnessed. Despite having a childhood tainted with such gruesomeness, the son seems to be certain there exists some kind of ethical humanity beyond the melancholic road they are traveling.As a student with grammatical and mechanical rules embedded into my brain, I couldnâ€™t help but cringe at the run-on, punctuation-less sentences; but as a lover of words and the power that they hold, I put my years of English class knowledge behind me and embraced the fantastic imagery. The world McCarthy creates is so dreary that when he refers to â€œdead limbsâ€ in the woods, one cannot be sure whether he means broken tree branches or human extremities. He paints such a dull, gloomy life that even the snowflakes, one of natureâ€™s most beautiful and intricate creations, are gray from the ash covering the earth.McCarthy makes us wonder what our own lives would be like post-apocalypse. He forces us to question ourselves: Would I be able to survive? Would I have the strength to bear all the things that they have endured? There are no laws, no rules to live by, no sense of order in that world. The only true form of currency is the heartache those who are still alive feel for their past, present, and future.At first, I thought the only shortcoming of this novel lay in the conversation between father and son. The age of the son is unknown, though it is a common conception that he between six and eight years old. Repetitive and monotonous, I initially considered the dialogue hard to accept as realistic between a father and a child of that age. The more I thought about it, however, the more I came to believe that the exchanges of words were a mere representation of the world they lived in, which is exactly that: repetitive and monotonous. I suppose in a life after the apocalypse, there is nothing left to say. All the stories have been told, all questions have been asked, all memories have been recalled.McCarthyâ€™s choice of words in The Road create graphic and disturbing images in your mind. He describes a house filled with human bodies, both dead and barely alive, kept hostage by cannibalistic maniacs. He goes into great detail about the bodies strewn about, burned alive in their final resting place. Though his imagery bordered terrifying at times, what upset me the most was the colossal fear and desperation that lead the father to hand his son a pistol and tell him to commit suicide if the bad guys found him. â€œIf they find you you are going to have to do it. Do you understand? Shh. No crying. Do you hear me? You know how to do it. You put it in your mouth and point up. Do it quick and hard. Stop crying. Do you understand?â€ The idea of that tore through me; I couldnâ€™t wrap my mind around such a horrific experience for a child. For a novel in which nothing major occurs or is accomplished, The Road has a stunning way of keeping the reader engaged. It is simply a story of a journey for a father and son who are just trying to stay alive. Cormac McCarthy truly has a gift for language and creates a world for the reader he or she never would have imagined. The fluidity of words makes for a graceful storytelling of the unconscionable. While The Road offers a dark, gloomy post-apocalyptic tale that is nothing short of depressing, the beautiful vocabulary and imagery are what makes it so difficult to put down. I recommend this novel to those who are intrigued by language, and take time to think about life in ways they have never before.~ wrote this for class

I've always been a bit afraid to read The Road. From the movie, I knew it was a very bleak depressing story of a post apocalyptic world. Even though I'm a fan of this genre, I wasn't sure I wanted to revisit such a hopeless world.I was amazed to discover a very profound story of the love between a father and son. The hopelessness of the world took a back seat to the beautiful love story and McCarthy's incredible writing. I'm so glad I finally decided to pick this one up!

â€œWhen we're all gone at last then there'll be nobody here but death and his days will be numbered too. He'll be out in the road there with nothing to do and nobody to do it to. He'll say: where did everybody go? And that's how it will be." A masterpiece. Short, but resounding.The Road is overall one of the most haunting, chilling books I have ever read. It did not exactly get me into a festive mood for Christmas, but it was an amazing little book nonetheless.
