Bleak, boring, depressing as fuck and not many good qualities. Reviews and morehttps://edwardsghostengine.wordpress....So, Iâ€™m not quite sure what i was expecting when I went into this one, perhaps a detailed, violent and harrowing plot. Really the only one I had was harrowing because oh boy, there were feels at the endâ€¦Anyway, this book is basically one long journey featuring a father and son walking through a post apocalyptic America in an attempt to find warmer climates as a cold winter is setting in. The first problems I can think of with this book is the fact that thereâ€™s hardly any flashback to the characters pasts and thereâ€™s no description of how the world became that way. For me these things spoiled my liking of the book immensely. What was the boyâ€™s mother like? How exactly did she die? What were the characterâ€™s lives like before the apocalypse? If these things had even hints towards them it would have made the novel deeper for me.That leads me onto something else. None of the characters in the book had names, they were simply referred to as son, papa, the woman. the old man etc. This was one of the things I did like because by stripping the characters of their identities it also stripped them of a kind of personality making them mysteries in themselves and allowing readers to picture them and their personalities in their own ways. That was well done and well suited for this type of book I thought, but still would have liked more background history on the world at least.There was a lot less action and violence than what I was expecting. I would say in terms of violence and action this is a rather tame book, but there were a few disturbing scenes involving cannibalism and such which were vividly described. The writing style was also something I thought was well done as the landscape and the characters feelings were so well brought to life it made me feel as if I were on the road myself (this book certainly tainted me with its depression as I felt rather down when reading this, but there again the snowy weather I had recently probably didnâ€™t help).So, this was quite a well written book with a good medium speed pacing and a very well descried landscape. I will also mention I managed to get through this book quite quickly even though I thought there could have been more action and run ins with outcasts. But there again this book was probably intended to be about the journey and the relationship between father and son in the most harshest of situations. The ending was a bit too abrupt for me and it was left open because to me I didnâ€™t know whether the boy was in good hands at the end or not or whether heâ€™d fall victim to cannibalism laterâ€¦ oh these type of endings frustrate me! But what happened to them both before the endâ€¦.. FEELS!! IT EVEN MADE ME FUCKING CRY IN THE END!!! Oh I hate it when that happens :P :/

This was the SciFi selection for the Goodreads SciFi and Fantasy Book Club for the month of February 2009. Visit this link to see all of the discussions, group member reviews, etc.This review contains spoilers, but at least read this far: don't read this book. 
This book is vile. This book is a lie. It is a festering wasteland of despair and sadistic pathos pretending to contain some freakish remnant of love.
A father and son stumble through a dead killing land in the empty hope that life might actually survive at some coastline to the south.Something has killed everything but humans, leaving the unlucky survivors to rot away in a hell of starvation and scavenging and the constant dread of roving bands of cannibals.The death that has turned the world gray has apparently killed the birds, the fish and every single plant though hundreds of miles of trudging, many years after the cataclysm -- and every corpse mummifies, so perhaps even the microbes and fungi are dead? Yet wounds can still fester and old food goes bad.So this must be somehow allegorical -- but what awesome hopelessness is McCarthy trying to illuminate? This is a story of humans that have become the walking dead. McCarthy and his characters have apparently confused the will to survive and sustain some pitiful remnant of decency as if it is meaningful and a reason to persist in a supremely hopeless existence.The author is a mighty craftsman with his prose, and the story is haunting -- but the final result is a foul nightmare, best forgotten.

Few things can encapsulate both the abject and sublime--but this does.This is definitely one of those books where less is more. The writing is concise, almost to the point of being terse. There is space between the words and contained within it is more emotion than you could imagine. I have not felt this level of distillation since reading Hemingway.This is bleak, dark, and relentless. It is also pulls you forward. There's no stopping. You're on the road. The pacing is wonderful. It's a constant surge of the sea against you as you read. Riding one up one wave and plummeting down the trough. At some point, you think the sea will calm, that you'll have a moment to catch your breath, but it just pulls you, throws you. 
Take my hand. I don't want you to see this.What you put in your head is there forever?Yes.It's okay Papa.It's okay?They're already there.I don't want you to look.They'll still be there.

Life is an illusion. Death is a reality.And The Road is what you take from one to another.Staying on The Road, being aware of the Road, accepting The Road Is what the journey is all about!What you do, is up to you!

This is a book about the moral standing of Earth. I donâ€™t care what you say about it, the harrowing romantic tale of two people lost in the post-apocalyptic wilderness; granted. But it does not stop there. It is about so much more. It is a spectacular novel and it is extremely sad. Not only because of its bleak content and its hollowness, but because of its hinting towards a depravity that could not be written about fully, because it has yet to be understood. This acknowledgement of a future with so little hope that it can be counted by the heads of two lonely people, well its too overwhelming to be realized by civilization so far.To start off though, this dude mccarthy is a mind bending brilliant auteur, so strategically careful with his placement, but also so casual. He is so knowledgeable, but he doesnâ€™t piss it all out like a giant of encyclopedic knowledge. His characters give impressions of being strong, sturdy central characters with a great idea about the world about them and most of all a strong keen idea about survival. That is the brilliance of his main characters, blue-collar, seemingly anonymous overmen. The good-willed nobodys who would survive the apocalypse. But there is not this burrowing gravity that lingers there either, dramatizing the strong rational directness of these brilliant men. They get caught up in the same Godotian nonsense that plagues everyoneâ€™s waking life, only in this nonexistence that suddenly has become:In a discussion about crows flying to Mars: What if they tried and they got half way or something and then they were too tired. Would they fall back down?Well. They really count get half way because theyâ€™d be in space and thereâ€™s not any air in space so they wouldnâ€™t be able to fly and besides it would be too cold and theyâ€™d freeze to death.Oh.Anyway they wouldnâ€™t know where Mars was.Do we know where Mars is?Sort of.If we had a spaceship could we go there?Well. If you had a really good spaceship and you had people to help you I suppose you could go.Would there be food and stuff when you got there?No. Thereâ€™s nothing there.Oh.They sat for a long time. The book has a pulse being strangled. Two people dying, straight dying trying to travel cross country, plagued by a civilization completely destroyed: There was a lingering odor of cows in the barn and he stood there thinking about cows and he realized they were extinct. Was that true? There could be a cow somewhere being fed and cared for. Could there? Fed what? Saved for what? A lover of nature visualizes the holocaust of nature and mans subsequent holocaust when all forms of regeneration are cut off. People go insane. The man protecting his child creates this archetype of good guys versus bad guys (which is basically characterized pending on cannibalism) and is their main justification for surviving. They are the good guys, â€œThis is what the good guys do. They keep trying. They donâ€™t give up.â€ The bleakness of the book is characterized by simple, resolute statements about the end of civilization. They find a can of coca-cola and he gives it to the boy. Drink it slow, he says. This is going to be the last time I have one of these, isnâ€™t it, the boy asks. Yes, the man says. The statements made are hidden, but they are incredibly dense with the missing hope that is so much taken advantage by in our copious successful civilization. What is a planet without god, â€œWhere men canâ€™t live gods fare no better.â€The boy is a harbinger of guilt, an outdated cause. Survival by monkeys without a preternatural sense of survival, all that exists is the monolith of anger from 2001. What is catharsis? Emotional realizing in literature. This book is the desert of catharsis. Starving, bleak, and barely alive. Itâ€™s only points of clarity are as dry as a sweltering nothing: â€Okay.â€â€œI thought so.â€â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€ And there is a menacing refreshment of the memories that come to haunt the man, remembering what civilization was and how or why God punished (or for that matter man punished himself) with the onslaught of a horrible de-civilization in which man has denigrated to worse than primitive form, either eating his brethren or raping or defiling him for no other purpose other to instate some form of the hierarchy lost to the evaporation of the social contract, and the defamation of anything resembling sanity: Standing at the edge of a winter field among rough men. The boyâ€™s age. A little older. Watching while they opened up the rocky hillside ground with pick and mattock and brought to light a great bolus of serpents perhaps a hundred in number. Collected there for a common warmth. The dull tubes of them beginning to move sluggishly in the cold hard light. Like the bowels of some great beast exposed to the day. The men poured gasoline on them and burned them alive, having no remedy for evil but only for the image of it as they conceived it to be. The burning snakes twisted horribly and some crawled burning across the floor of the grotto to illuminate its darker recesses. As they were mute there were no screams of pain and the men watched them burn and writhe and blacken in just such silence themselves and they disbanded in silence in the winter dusk each with his own thoughts to go home to their suppers.
What a lachrymose tale! The Desolate post-apocalyptic landscape matched McCarthy's laconic prose so perfectly.

Having given out 25 copies of 'A Tale of Two Cities' for World Book Night on April 23rd I then received a copy of 'The Road' from someone else in the same system. Having never read this before I was pleased to pick it up and know that, hopefully, I was one of the first links in a long chain for this book as it gets passed from hand to hand and maybe country to country over the years ahead. The idea of the fellowship and community aspect to Bookcrossing is one I find wonderful, a sharing in the love of books and of reading; enabling others to draw strength and perhaps experience new ideas and reflections, enabling someone to force their way through scary undergrowth and stumbling out onto a whole new prairie set for exploration. This is what World Book Night is all about and the supreme irony was not lost on me that the book I get to read is one in which that new vista of experience encountered is one of hopelessness and ashen destruction and isolation.This book is extraordinary. The story is superficially simple in its telling but cavernous in the chasms and horrors that open out as you stumble with the unnamed man and his son through a world totally destroyed in living memory by some horrendous cataclysm. The disaster hangs across the narrative not only in the corpses and destruction and burnt out civilization that the characters encounter but simply by the ash and smoke and stinking clouds which hang over everything, blocking out the sun, enshrouding everything with a paralyzing greyness and chill. The simplicity and starkness of the language, the repetition and shortness of the sentences, the inability of the man to fully communicate with his son, the continual circling of their conversation seemingly over the same tired subjects is incredibly powerful i found. Society has broken down into a simple need to survive, the ability to communicate beyond these needs withers on the vine. Cannibalism is rampant and though the father promises his son they would never indulge he is unable to prevent others even to the extent of fleeing what is in effect a larder of live humans or encountering the charring body of a new born baby who only the day earlier we had seen still in the protection of its mother's womb. This horror is described coldly and all the more horrifying for that. Fear results in pointless attacks, kill or be killed and the man responds in defense of the son he adores and yet who he recognizes continually throughout the narrative is slowly moving out of his reach; not just physically but because the shared experience they have is so circumscribed by hopelessness and the man's prior knowledge of birdsong and sunlight and safety are fairy stories the boy will grow out of as he sinks deeper into the ashen world through which he is forced to wade.Yesterday I read a fascinating thread on another person's review of this book from 2007. The whole debate ranting back and forth bouncing off symbolism and allegory and reality. One thing that struck me as i read the discussion was how the arguers seemed to refuse to allow works of literature to have lives of their own. One of the strengths of literature for me has always been that a book is given to be read but wherever it takes you, whatever it inspires or draws forth from you is a valid reaction. The book, in that sense, has a life of its own. It is, of course, perfectly sensible to seek to fathom what the writer was intending but whether McCarthy did write this as an allegory of death and dying or of compassion over survival or wrote it as a story of aimless hopelessness or as a footnote to his wider work. All these questions and interpretations are valid surely if what it does is make you think. I am not a writer myself but i can only suppose that whatever his over-riding intention in composing this work was, the lights it succeeds in turning on or indeed off in the lives and thoughts of others is an enormous credit for him in any literary league table.A continual refrain of the man and his son was of they're being good guys, the carriers of the fire; towards the end the man sees the boy framed with a lightness which gives him a final hope. 'Goodness will find the little boy. It always has. It will again'. The story can never be seen as a hope-filled one but it seems to hint in whispered tones at its end that the human spirit is one in whch love, if not necessarily triumphant, will at least survive. In amidst all the horror and degradation and vicious brutality a choice can be made, that choice can be to love, to pity, to protect and thus to pass on the spark of goodness which is indestructible.

To be printed in the March 27 edition of Coastal View News:With a dearth of adornment and minimal superfluous dialogue in â€œThe Road,â€ Cormac McCarthy pulls readers and co-travelers into the depths of the darkest hell with only a pinprick of light as reprieve. This narrow beam of light, of hope, appears so dim that it threatens to be extinguished at any instant, but with beauty and clarity, McCarthy rests the fate of mankind on that pinprick, and in doing so produces a work of art in â€œThe Road.â€A nameless father and his son wheel an old shopping cart over a vacant road, through a smoldering volcano of a worldâ€”a world that has been utterly destroyed by something that is not explicitly revealed, but which was surely caused by humankind. Not more than two sentences into the story, McCarthy lays the setting: â€œNights dark beyond darkness and the days more gray each one than what had gone before.â€ This father and his boy have been traveling for an unknown period of time toward the American coast, the object of their journey, without having any clue what hope this destination might hold for them.There are few people left in this post-apocalyptic world, and most that are still alive are vicious cannibalsâ€”the bad guys. In contrast, the boy and his father are â€œthe good guys,â€ or so they hope, somehow attempting to strike a delicate balance between survival and goodness. The father is primarily concerned with their survival and the son is primarily concerned with their goodness. In a dying world that is being destroyed by thieves, murders and eaters of mankind, goodness is the only reason to survive for this nearly defenseless pair. As the ashy filth blankets them more fully each and every step, the boy and his father struggle to stay pure. â€œYou are not the one who has to worry about everything,â€ said the father to his son, referring to the means of survival. â€œYes I am â€¦ I am the one,â€ responded the boy, referring to the means of goodness.The matured and life-worn father knows there is little or nothing to hope for. â€œHe saw for a brief moment the absolute truth of the world. The cold relentless circling of the intestate earth. Darkness implacable.â€ But the boy, naÃ¯ve and perhaps unrealistically idealistic, â€œwas all that stood between him and death.â€ The relationship between father and son and the power of hope between them takes on a new, ontologically real form. Hope and goodness become more than just ideas, they become real entities. To the father, his son is the literal embodiment of hope, goodness and faith. â€œHe knew that the child was his warrant. He said: If he is not the word of God God never spoke.â€Despite an awareness of the feeble light glowing in his son, the father is continually tempted to succumb to the darknessâ€”to give in to hopeless immorality, to play the game of survival common to the rest of the world, to call it quits, to commit suicide. Yet, the boy, who repeatedly asks â€œAre we still the good guys?â€ is a thread with just enough fiber to cling to.On this journey through a destitute America, McCarthy not only speaks to the future, but also to the present condition of mankind. What is a person to hope for, to look to, amidst so much evil? In â€œThe Road,â€ McCarthy rarely steps out from behind his characters, but when he does it is a clue to what he is attempting to communicate in this story. The first striking example of this communication comes in the beginning: â€œAll things of grace and beauty such that one holds them to oneâ€™s heart have a common provenance in pain. Their birth in grief and ashes.â€ The son, who was technically born after the apocalyptic cataclysm, becomes the fatherâ€™s symbol of beauty born from the devastation, like a phoenix rising from its own ashes. The second and perhaps only other example of direct thematic communication comes at the very denouement of the story, and carries a message so powerful that it should stick with a reader for a very long time.â€œThe Roadâ€ is a stroke of darkest genius from a Nietzchean soul. But whereas Nietzsche sees only darkness, McCarthy sees that pinprick of light in humanity that may be just enough to live by. â€œGoodness will find the little boy. It always has. It will again.â€

The Road is a short and powerful post-apocalyptic novel. Bleak and disturbing on many levels and so emotional at the same time. I will never complain again that there is nothing to eat in the house when there is actually nothing I want to eat in the house. We forget how truly blessed we are most days. This book is a swift kick in the tookus to make you remember.This novel centers around a nameless man and his boy who are fighting to survive an unimaginable catastrophe. They are the "good guys" left in a sad, grey, world where survival means finding food and shelter while staying a step ahead of the "bad guys". The man and his love for his son is a thing of beauty in this cruel and sometimes gruesome story. A true story of a parents' role as protector, provider and teacher.You may find this story hard to stomach and digest. I told a friend I felt hollowed out and was a weepy mess at the end of The Road. I truly was. Early in the story, the man tells the boy that "you forget what you want to remember and remember what you want to forget". I may want to forget parts of this book, but I don't see that happening any time soon.
Brilliant, bleak, and overpoweringly beautiful.

Opening Sentence: â€œâ€¦When he woke in the woods in the dark and the cold of the night heâ€™d reach out to touch the child sleeping beside himâ€¦â€Like many of Ophraâ€™s picks The Road is full of angst and gloom. But I didnâ€™t choose it because it was one of her picks, in fact when she announced it as her pick I toyed with not reading it â€“ as so many of her picks are so depressing and hard to read. I also ordered it from the library long before it was even announced as the winner of the Pulitzer Prize, so I didnâ€™t pick it because of that. No, I chose The Road because I am on the New York Times Notable Book Challenge and it was on the list for notable books for 2006.So is it worth all the hype? Oh yes, I really think so. The end of the world has occurred. The landscape is burnt, no animals, no birds, no fishes, and very few people. There is a man and his young boy â€“ very young â€“ his mother died after the end of the world â€“ she was pregnant with him at the time. The two â€˜heroesâ€™ start nowhere in particular, and seem to have no aim in mind as they journey along the road â€“ just heading south and to the sea. We never learn what the man expects to find when he reaches his destination, or even what his destination might be. The story is just a snapshot of their life, starting on page one and finishing at the end. The Man and the child spend their time hiding from the â€œbadâ€ people. These are people, mostly men, who will kill you and eat you. People have become food on the hoof so to speak. As the food ran out â€“ humans became the only source. The little boy is convinced that there must be other good people, but the man is certain there isnâ€™t. As they travel through the burnt out landscape, they forage for any cans of food that may have escaped discovery over the previous few years. They meet a few people, most of which either try to kill them, or try to steal from them. They do help one person, but the man leaves him behind to the little boysâ€™ distress.There is no punctuation â€“ my pet hate â€“ BUT as humans and the set parameters that life exists in breaks down â€“ what is the use of punctuation? There will be no-on around to care.Despite the fact you learn precious little about these two characters they are very real, and through their eyes you witness the death of humanity, the breakdown of society, the struggle for survival in a world that no longer sustains human life.Is there any hope, any point in reading the book? Well, there is always hope. And when one door closes, then sometimes another door opens. The book is well written, evocative and thought provoking. It will scare you, make you disagree, and then wonder if there could be any truth. We all like to think we are civilized people. But take our civilization away and what will we become?So the answer to the previous question is yes, read The Road, you may hate it, you may wonder what the fuss is, but some of you may just end up being as awed as I was.

2017 Reading Challenge #14: A book involving travel.

El mundo ha sido reducido a cenizas por lo que parece haber sido un holocausto nuclear. No sabemos a ciencia cierta quÃ© lo motivÃ³, pero eso tampoco importa. Bajo esta premisa y sumidos en un panorama por demÃ¡s desolador y cruel, un padre y su hijo emprenden un viaje a pie nada convencional. Se dirigen hacia el sur, donde suponen hallarÃ¡n â€œsalvaciÃ³nâ€, lo que quiera que ello signifique.
â€œTiempo prestado y mundo prestado y ojos prestados con que llorarloâ€.
Es asÃ­ como empieza una intensa historia sobre la relaciÃ³n de un padre y su hijo, que bien podrÃ­a ser la relaciÃ³n de cualquier padre e hijo que se enfrentan al terror y la desesperanza mÃ¡s crudas. Juntos van sorteando una serie de eventos brutalmente inhumanos (amenazas de bandas canÃ­bales, clima hostil y el hambre que arrecia con los dÃ­as).

La narrativa de McCarthy tiene de lapidaria lo que poseen de bÃ¡rbaros los vestigios de esta civilizaciÃ³n.He leÃ­do este libro sin un Ã¡pice de intriga, pero sin poder detenerme hasta que lo terminÃ© porque yo al igual que los protagonistas querÃ­a asir en mi alma la certeza de que sin importar la adversidad de las circunstancias ese vÃ­nculo filial se sobrepondrÃ­a ante la infamia y la muerte. Y sÃ­, puede que suene cursi, pero les aseguro que no es una historia-sensiblera-postapocalÃ­ptica mÃ¡s. Mi Ãºnico reparo quizÃ¡ sea que las descripciones ambientales del autor aunque son muy ricas, pueden tornarse algo monÃ³tonas (AjÃ¡ sÃ­, mira nos quedÃ³ claro que hace frÃ­o y hay cenizas por dondequiera). Por eso creo que durante toda la lectura no salÃ­a de mi mente la idea de que es una historia mÃ¡s cinematogrÃ¡fica que literaria, y eso su vez confiere un gran mÃ©rito a este escritor.Â¡No puedo creer que hayan transcurrido ya 10 aÃ±os desde la publicaciÃ³n original de esta magnÃ­fica novela y yo no supe de ella sino hasta el aÃ±o pasado! Estoy muy agradecida con la persona que me la recomendÃ³. Me alegra haber iniciado el aÃ±o con una lectura tan satisfactoria.
â€œTodas las cosas bellas y armÃ³nicas que uno conserva en su corazÃ³n tienen una procedencia comÃºn en el dolorâ€.

What to say about this book that has not been said already? Hmmm . . . it seems everything has been said already. I walk alone with my son. The sky is gray, the cold penetrates the shabby rags that were once nice clothes, and the road is covered in dust. I have not seen any living creature as long as I remember, except for some that I'd rather forget even existed. Humans, the evil ones. In my heart, I know that I'm going to die. Heck, chances are my son is going to die with me. But deep inside, inexplicably, I hold on to hope. It's not just an instinct to survive, it's hope. My son and I, we are the good ones, the fire-keepers. If only he would not be so naive, I would feel better about dying. I often think back to my wife, and how life once was. Was taking her life and trying to kill our son really the easier choice? What a drastic change. To say that everything is fucked-up would be an understatement. But this stupid hope keeps me going . . . all the way to the coast. There must be something better than this, there must be some place where the brutality has not devoured humanity. I think about the baby, the cellar, the hunters. They are so much stronger than us, but I will not descend into hell and eat my fellow men. No, I'd rather die. Must keep walking. The road is long. In all honesty, I'm not a fan of dystopian, post-apocalyptic literature. But this book has a lot going on for itself. The prose is tight, the language is good, and it is hauntingly realistic. At times too realistic.

A masterpiece of spare literary horror, as if a Beckett/Faulkner monstrosity had written a novelization of Night of the Living Dead, minus the humor and with less of the social commentary. (Regarding the absence of humor - I saw some humor in one passage regarding a "mae west floating in the seepage", which I initially saw in my mind's eye as an inflatable sex doll in dirty water, which would be humor of the black sort, but then I found out that a "mae west" is an inflatable life jacket.) I spent the majority of this book totally unmoved by what was calculated to move me, that is the father son relationship did not flutter my heart, in fact I viewed it as little more than a pre-calculated sensitive heart stringy prop like you see in many horror flicks. I also took issue with the good people/bad people dichotomy as being too pat and easy, ditto the absence/idealization of women. But then I was very moved by the ending. Somehow it seemed more authentic. And the final paragraph left me in awe.I don't entirely trust McCarthy. I have a suspicion that his last two books were actually written with movies in mind, a kind of aging novelist's 401-K. And I'm yet to consider him an indisputable Modern Master; though my personal verdict is not yet in, I have a feeling Suttree will put my socks on my hands and my underwear over my head and send me jibbering through the river dregs seeking a splayed mae west.

El estilo del autor Ã©pico, los dos personajes y su diÃ¡logos sublimes, sobre todo el padre, la ambientaciÃ³n grisÃ¡cea postapocalÃ­ptica espectacular y varias escenas muy crueles y sanguinarias de esas que se recuerdan para siempre. Aunque la pelÃ­cula me gusto incluso mÃ¡s, el libro sigue mereciendo mis 5 estrellas.

I just finished reading this book in one sitting (until 2:00 AM). Once you've started you have to find out how it ends, at least I did...even though you know it's probably going to be grim. A great book.

"Onde os homens nÃ£o conseguem viver, os deuses nÃ£o tÃªm melhor sorte. Vais ver. Ã‰ melhor estar sozinho. Por isso espero que nÃ£o seja verdade, o que acabaste de dizer, porque calcorrear a estrada com o derradeiro deus seria coisa terrÃ­vel e espero sinceramente que nÃ£o seja verdade."

Where's the beef?
 As Arlo Guthrie Jr. says in Alice's Restaurant "...it kind of starts out slow & then fizzles out altogether." And so it went.I've wanted to read this for some time now. This was supposed to be right up there with the classics in post-apocalyptic SF, but I knew McCarthy had an aversion to punctuation, an unforgivable sin. I don't even insist on proper punctuation since I'm not sure myself, but an honest attempt should be made. Leaving it out on purpose is the mark of the artistic poseur trying to obscure their deficiencies. American & English spelling is weird enough that leaving apostrophes out of contractions is ridiculous, even sadistic. "Cant" & "can't" are both fine words with completely different meanings & a reader shouldn't have to waste energy differentiating between them. Knowing this about McCarthy's writing thanks to the reviews of my GR friends, I never even attempted to read it in paper or ebook. I'd have just abandoned it in disgust & listening to it as an audio book removed these issues. The narrator was quite good supplying the proper punctuation through his craft, thankfully.Unfortunately, the writing wasn't very good. I don't ever want to read "OK" or "I don't know." in dialogue again. I adore well phrased allusions, but McCarthy's were often twaddle. What the hell is 'autistic dark'? What am I even supposed to make of 'vestibular calculations in his skull cranked out their reckonings'? I know all the words, but they evoke no more meaning or feel than the ravings of a syphilitic monkey. Not all were that bad & I was able to focus on the story, but...The story was pointless depression punctuated by moments of horror. I never found out what the apocalyptic event was, so the end was only slightly uncertain, a cheap shot. I don't mind uncertainty or even a depressing ending. On the Beach, A Canticle for Leibowitz, & Earth Abides all got high marks from me, although I have to say I preferred Alas, Babylon more. This book had all the depression of On the Beach & an even more ridiculous faith than A Canticle for Leibowitz without any of their redeeming features & shouldn't really be compared to any of them. It is not in the same class at all.A classic of post apocalyptic fiction needs to make some sense. Here we have no reason for it nor hope of redemption. I might as well have masturbated in sand - no payoff, just pointless pain. I'd warn everyone away from this, especially in any sort of print. As an audio book, I made it all the way through, but it's hours I could have spent listening to a good book.

MiloÅ¡, my son, I want to thank you for so many things. It will be years before you read this. Probably not until I am gone and you are sifting through the internet looking for scraps of me -- either to scream at or take comfort in -- but you will find this, I know it, and I am speaking to you from this hot July night, across however many years have passed, to tell you that I loved you deeper than blood, deeper than the parental bond. You are my hero. Everything about you fills me with awe. Your art blows my mind. Your athleticism is beautiful to behold. Your kindness and maturity constantly humble me. Your hair is glorious. Your imagination is ineluctable. The control you have of your temper, your ability to find calm when your storms are brewing, eclipses anything I could ever approach. Your passion for the smallest things is inspiring. And somehow we have become more than son and father. We have become friends. And that is the greatest stroke of luck I have ever experienced. So imagine what it means to me to have been given -- by you -- the opportunity to read The Road aloud. Every syllable of McCarthy's book is infused with love between the man and the boy, and you shared it with me, night after night, curled up in the red light of my head lamp, even though the nights are too hot in the summer and the girls were clamouring to get to bed. Yet once I started reading, the whole world that is melted away, and we found ourselves in that terrible, awful, seemingly inevitable world that will be, but there we were with each other, being reminded night after night that the fire is love, and we have it for each other because we let it in, we let it be. Soon you will grow older and you will drift away from me, but I will carry nights like tonight, nights when our tears were shared over the fate of the boy and the man, in my heart and mind until death, and maybe then, when my star stuff is returned to the universe, you will find this letter and read it one night (maybe even the night you finish reading this book to one of your children), and you will remember our love for one another, and you will be back in your childhood home as if you never left, and you will remember the hope of the fire that lifts The Road up beyond seeming hopelessness, and you will remember why we go on, and you will know that you were the greatest friend I ever had. I love you, MiloÅ¡. You are a beautiful being. You have the fire. And you are my fire. I hope your life, when you read this, is as wonderful as mine is because of you right now. Kiss the ones you love, my son, and know that you have always been loved yourself. Love, Me

A beautiful and disturbing book that I wanted to read in one sitting to be done with it and know what happens, while also wanting to stop reading and not know. Clearly, I have now finished it. It was bleak and desolate but I loved the man and the boy and so desperately wanted them to be OK, whatever OK might mean in their situation.

Unusually, I read this book in just two long sittings - very unusual for me these days. I just couldn't put it down.I appreciate that this seems to be a "marmite" book: people either really like it or they hate it - and I fell into the first camp, definitely.There's a hypnotic, elegiac, one-note meditative feeling about the prose, that drew me along that Road with nameless "man" and "boy". Their small victories, their hellishly hard day to day drag, the too-rare moments of glory when they come across an unpillaged store of supplies, the brief but always-catastrophic punctuations of meeting with other people (with the hope that once, just once, they might be friendly).The man's hoplessness always translated into optimism, for the boy's sake. Bringing the boy up right, in a world where "right" no longer really exists.We're never told what happened to the world, or how long ago it happened, and that adds to the feeling of dropping into this world.And the "nature" writing, if you can call it that when nature to all intents and purposes is gone. Is among the most beautiful and attentive that I've read in years.A definite 5* from me.

â€œListen to me, he said, when your dreams are of some world that never was or some world that never will be, and you're happy again, then you'll have given up. Do you understand? And you can't give up, I won't let you.â€
Well, this was a rough read that will keep me thinking for a while. The Road is one of those stories that works more than one level. You have a post-apocalyptic story about a man and his son trying to survive, going about their life one day a time in a brutal world, and that's already interesting to read about. But the symbolism of it all is on a whole different dimensionâ€”the entire book is an allegory of the human experience. And I don't think I need to tell you that the award-winning author Cormac McCarthy delivers this with an outstanding writing style. Simply brilliant!
The Road was an excellent book. Such a sad book but highly recommend to mature readers.

Me ha costado muchÃ­simo leerlo (casi un mes), y no por la longitud de la historia... sino por lo angustioso que es. Es una historia pausada, no de esas en las que pasan cosas constantemente, y aÃºn asÃ­ no puedes despegar los ojos de sus pÃ¡ginas. Las descripciones que hace el autor sobre el ambiente te meten tan de lleno en Ã©l que puedes hasta oler lo que estÃ¡ contando. Es claustrofÃ³bica. No apta para estÃ³magos sensibles, pero sÃ­ apta para cualquiera que busque leer sobre una verdadera historia de amor, la de un padre y un hijo. Intensa.

Through a twisted landscape of blackened trees and ash a man and his young son make their way along the road, pushing a shopping trolley of their few supplies. They are trying to make their way south through the United States, to the coast where perhaps, the man hopes, it will be warm. They are starving and frightened and filthy, just like everyone else - but unlike almost everyone else, they have not resorted to cannibalism in order to survive. His only reason for living is his defenceless son.While there is no explanation, only a few vague hints, as to how the earth ended up like this, it seems clear that it's an ecological disaster. It is the worst outcome, because the earth itself is ruined. It may recover, but not until a long, long time after the last remaining survivors are gone. When the last scavenged tin has been cracked open, the last bit of gasoline or diesel used up, the last clothes rotted away, there will be nothing to replace them with. And with ash coating the ground even ten years later (I estimate the boy to be about that age, and he was born after the apocalypse), nothing can be grown.There are stories that you read because they're great stories - the plot and the characters are all. And there are stories that you read because of how they're written, and you visit them again and again because of the language. The Road is the latter. It's like reading poetry - poetry that makes sense. It has a sparse quality, and the near-absence of commas, apostrophes, em dashes, speech marks etc heighten this. It is one of those books where the way it was written, and how it has been formatted, echoes the story within. It reads like the present tense even though it's in past, giving it a timeless quality that is as frightening as the people kept locked in a basement, slowly being eaten by their captors.I love the line, spoken by an old man they encounter on the road and, against the man's better judgement, feed, where he says: "Where men cant live gods fare no better." (p.172) I know what my interpretation of this is, but like the best of art there's always more than one.This post-apocalyptic world is literally hell on earth. McCarthy doesn't moralise or pass judgement, he simply tells this stark story and lets it speak for itself. I could read it again and again and get more from the language each time. The story itself is quiet, unassuming, with moments of tension and heartache. I would especially recommend this to anyone interested in writing or studying creative writing, because even if you don't like the story or the way it was written, you can still learn an awful lot from the masterful control McCarthy has over prose. He wields words like the steps in a dance, every nuance precise, every letter meant to be there.

The boy was sitting on the steps when he saw something move at the rear of the house across the road. A face was looking at him. A boy, about his age, wrapped in an out-sized wool coat with the sleeves turned back. He stood up. He ran across the road and up the drive. No one there. He looked toward the house and then he ran to the bottom of the yard through the dead weeds to a still black creek. Come back, he called. I wont hurt you. He was standing there crying when his father came sprinting across the road and seized him by the arm.What are you doing? he hissed. What are you doing?There's a little boy, Papa. There's a little boy.There's no little boy. What are you doing?Yes there is. I saw him.I told you to stay put. Didnt I tell you? Now we've got to go. Come on.I just wanted to see him, Papa. I just wanted to see him. The man took him by the arm and they went back up through the yard. The boy would not stop crying and he would not stop looking back. Come on, the man said. We've got to go.I want to see him, Papa.There's no one to see. Do you want to die? Is that what you want?I dont care, the boy said, sobbing. I dont care.The man stopped. He stopped and squatted and held him. I'm sorry, he said. Dont say that. You mustnt say that.They made their way back through the wet streets to the viaduct and collected the coats and the blanket from the car and went on to the railway embankment where they climbed up and crossed the tracks into the woods and got the cart and headed out to the highway.What if that little boy doesnt have anybody to take care of him? he said. What if he doesnt have a papa?There are people there. They were just hiding. He pushed the cart out into the road and stood there. He could see the tracks of the truck through the wet ash, faint and washed out, but there. He thought that he could smell them. The boy was pulling at his coat. Papa, he said.What?I'm afraid for that little boy.I know. But he'll be all rightWe should go get him, Papa. We could get him and take him with us. We could take him and we could take the dog. The dog could catch something to eat.We cant.And I'd give that little boy half of my food.Stop it. We cant.He was crying again. What about the little boy? he sobbed. What about the little boy?3 3/4 stars

I just finished reading â€œThe Roadâ€ and still have a lump in my throat, and my head is swirling with images. I should probably give myself time to swallow this lump in my throat before writing anything, but I think I will just get it over with.Unlike many reviewers, I never found â€œThe Roadâ€ to be depressing, dark yes, but not depressing - very touching in fact. Also, unlike many reviewers, I never found the grammatical liberties to be bothersome. An apocalyptic world, but really not so very different from the world we live in. Pushing our metaphorical carts along the road of life, ever fearful of the possibility of evil lurking around each bend. The boy - innocence, the future? - keeper of the flame, lighting the way ahead?As with many great works of literature, the meaning extracted is dependent on the perspective of the reader. There have been so many great reviews already written of this novel, I will keep it short and just say - read it!

I am not exaggerating when I say that this book gave me nightmares -- flesh-eating men wandering the woods, marauders following your every move, the daily struggle to find food and shelter. I woke up relieved that it was just a dream, but then remembered that McCarthy's ashen world could exist. The bleakness of "The Road" doesn't seem that far from the accounts of those who survived the nuclear bombs on Japan ("Hiroshima" by John Hersey is particularly memorable).Despite its dark nature, the writing is inarguably beautiful. I caught myself reading and rereading paragraphs to admire their rhythm.I'll be honest, I struggled to finish "The Road." But I willed myself to the end, having peeked ahead to discover that there is a somewhat optimistic ending. Had that bit of humanity not been there in the last chapter, why go through the struggle at all? Which is precisely why the man and his son kept plodding forward, trying to find hope.

The Road by Cormac McCarthy Â (I just realized this book never made it over to Booklikes from Goodreads. I read this back in 2012 and enjoyed it-as much as itÂ can be enjoyed, anyway.)Â This one was dark and depressing. The author has a strange writing style that took a little while to get used to. There are no commas and no quotation marks.Â There is very little dialogue going on.Â Â Despite the darkness and the ash that covers everything, I found the story to be hopeful. I also found the writing to be lyrical at times. The words the author chose really brought home the vast emptiness that the characters were facing. I enjoyed this book, but I'm pretty sure that I will never re-read it.

I am not really finished. I quit after 100 pages when I wanted to a bullet in my head. I need to scrub my mind of these depressing pages. It takes a lot to make Crime and Punishment look like a romp in the park but this book manages that.

Some musings on The Road and the genre of (post-)apocalypse: 1) (Post-)apocalyptic genre seems to me a very primal genre, an adaptive one, which is intimately concerned with life and death and the struggle for existence. The genre is crucially dependent on evolved properties of the human nature and mind, such as the emotion of fear which derives from human mind. â€œFearâ€ is the engine of the genre and the main reason for why genre exists. Humanityâ€™s obsession with apocalypse and post-apocalypse is rooted in ancient humans and these roots of modern (post-)apocalyptic are found in the earliest folklore, myths, and religions of all races and cultures. This is naturally to be expected of a form so closely linked with basic emotion of fear. The (post-)apocalyptic imagination is hard-wired into us, it has always existed and it will continue to exist since it is a natural genre, rather than just cultural, and it addresses the greatest fear of humanity: the end of life and fear of death, death of all humans. Manâ€™s worst fears come alive in this genre.Of course both culture and nature are crucial in shaping human mind but theses shapes that mind takes are limited by nature and vary within narrow bonds, that is, culture has a little room to maneuver, and when it does, it is in relation with nature. Nature can be compared with computer hardware, whereas culture is compared with operating system or software which is installed on the hardware.2) Some causes of apocalypse are man-made such as nuclear holocaust. Humans, through millions of years of adaptation and natural selection, have got installed in their mind some modules to fear some specific factors that endangered their lives, but since, for example, the atomic bomb is very recent, therefore humans need to learn to fear this danger because it is not natural, but constructed, and every fear that needs to be learned is culturally constructed. In this respect, one can conclude that all the cultural constructed fears are rooted in natural intrinsic fears of humanity, especially the fear of death. The popular belief, which derives from historicist approach to the genre, is that (post-)apocalyptic stories are the embodiment of the fears and anxieties of that specific time and, therefore (post-)apocalypse is entirely a cultural construction and invention. This is partly true, but these cultural fears, as mentioned before, are based on the evolved natural fears.3) Human mind, with the help of prefrontal lobes, enables humans to forecast and plan for future. The mechanism of planning and forecasting is dependent on imagery and emotion and also based on past and present experiences. As mentioned before, the emotion of fear is the heart of the genre, and a (post-)apocalyptic author experiences an emotion of fear and anxiety triggered by the environment, such as seeing a violent war or the melting of Antarcticaâ€™s ice, which in turn triggers in his mind an image of dark future based on this fearful experience. Through his imagination he forecasts what would happen, what the consequences would be, if this fearful event were taken to its most extreme level. The author presents the scenes on the paper in the form of a story, which can be regarded as a warning to all humanity. Apocalyptic thinking is a way people and authors cope with horrible and uncontrollable circumstances on the individual, local, or universal level. Of course, the coping method and forecasted future differ with person to person and writer to writer depending on his genes, environment he or she lives in, and the culture she or he comes from.Studying McCarthyâ€™s life discloses numerous important features of his novels and the reasons behind creating the post-apocalyptic world. In case of The Road, McCarthy had four experiences that resulted to his imagined apocalypse: 1. growing up in the south and seeing the gory violence of the society and the corrupt culture which made him to be pessimistic toward human nature; 2. his immersion in the science that aggravated his pessimism; 3. the September 11 attacks followed by the Iraq War which yet again made him believe that the world is an unstable place; 4. and being the sexagenarian father of a seven-year-old son in this violent society. These experiences triggered in him the fear of his moral son living in this violent and immoral society, which in turn triggered the image of dark future in McCarthyâ€™s mind. 4) Those (post-)apocalyptic works that stand the test of time in many cultures push the button of universal fears, that is, the fears that are natural and all humans share those fears and anxieties, or the fears that all the cultures have in common. The Road is not concerned with its local culture and societyâ€™s anxieties and traumas but mainly concerned with the universal fear of survival in a horrendous world. This will make it a classic.5) Fear-inducing stories like (post-)apocalyptic stories use the element of fear to logically scare and disturb its audience by bringing a calamity upon humanity, using natural and cultural underpinnings, and with this they increase the chances of humanityâ€™s survival. In these stories, humans rebalance themselves. These stories directly confront humans with their behavioral universals. The severe environmental disorientation these stories simulate characteristically shocks and sobers up their audiences to re-examine the way they live their lives, to acknowledge their human nature, to contemplate a future possibility, and to avoid present lethal mistakes that may lead to the disaster mentioned in the story. This is, in a nutshell, is the thematic structure of (post-)apocalyptic works like The Road, in which the author simulates a world where survival is a challenge, human values are lost, and todayâ€™s facilities are no more. This affects readers deeply in the sense that they rebalance themselves and re-examine the life they have now. On the whole, literary and nonliterary apocalyptic texts make a significant contribution to the continuity of human life.6) According to Erik Hage, since the boy is born after the apocalypse, and since the cultural and social beliefs and structure are obliterated, therefore the boy is a blank slate because there is not culture or society in this post-end world and also because the boy is not tainted by the pre-apocalyptic cultural and social beliefs, the ones that brought calamity upon humanity. I argue against the concept of tabula rasa which Erik Hage made use of to show the boyâ€™s moral behavior. One of the most important factors in shaping the boyâ€™s behavior is the role of stories his father tells him. Adopting Michelle Sugiyamaâ€™s theory about the function of the storiesâ€”stories are sources of vicarious experiences and low-cost sources of information, that they delight in order to instructâ€” one can concluded that the boyâ€™s goodness derives from the pre-apocalyptic moral stories that his father tells him.According to evolutionary psychology, humans are intrinsically both moral and immoral, and some individuals are more moral or immoral than the others based on their genes and environment they live. As the story suggests, the boy is intrinsically a morally superior person. The father also provided him an environment in which helps the boy to remain moral. The fatherâ€™s stories are filled with pre-apocalyptic values and good guys who help other people, which the son bases his behavior on those values and the deeds of the heroes. This is why the boy, till the middle of the novel, tries to help all the life he encounters: because he is both intrinsically and culturally a moral person.7) Studying the role of stories in shaping the boyâ€™s behavior also reveals the change in his worldview. When father and son take their journey to the south, the boy gets more exposed to the brutish post-apocalyptic environment. Though their arduous trek, the boy realizes the dysfunctionality of the pre-apocalyptic stories, with their moral values, in this present world, because he sees that practicing these moral traits may endanger his survival. According to evolutionary psychologists, every kind of human behavior is dependent on mind, genes, and environment. Different environments with their different stimulants lead the mind to develop differently and change the way in which the mind causes behavior. Therefore, the main reason for the behavioral change of the boy is the change of environment and its circumstances. The boyâ€™s behavior is changed in favor of survival depending on the various environmental triggers. Therefore, his idealistic and chivalric behavior is replaced by utilitarian version of morality. Although the boyâ€™s moral behavior is changed, McCarthy accomplishes to show his readers that the boy is still a moral figure, the one who â€œcarries the fireâ€ in the face of evil.8) Parental investment is much highlighted in this novel and one can claim that the emotional focal point of the story is the fatherâ€™s devotion to his son. The reason why McCarthy did not much meditate on the apocalypse itself is that he intended to focus on the survival psychology of his charactersâ€™ and especially the father. McCarthy wrote The Road mainly because of his son and a keen eye can notice that the character of the father is a version of McCarthy himself and the character of the boy is McCarthyâ€™s own son. Therefore the novel is mainly focused on the parent-offspring bond and filled with many examples of sacrifice and parental investment. The shining example of parental investment is the mother's suicide. She committed suicide to improve her husband and especially her sonâ€™s chances of survival without her being the burden. In this case, the motherâ€™s suicide is an adaptive behavior because she realizes that she has no chances of survival due to her psychological and physical exhaustion, therefore, by committing suicide she can assist the replicas of her genes (her son) and increase the survival of her son and husband by ceasing to use resources so that they could use instead. 9) Through the medium of The Road, McCarthy the father tackled two main issues that were giving him pain in his personal life: human morality and parenting. It is inferred that with all the wickedness in this world the father (McCarthy) fears the disability of protecting his son forever and one day the boy should stand on his feet all by himself. He the McCarthy believes that the society is getting worse every day and expresses a deep pessimism regarding humanityâ€™s self-destructiveness because of this violent society in which any moral expediency seems justified. His son, though a morally superior person, cannot heal this evilness and, as it is shown in the novel, the boy is reduced to a small child walking on the road but McCarthy believes that one should remain good in the face of evil whatever the circumstances are.

I knew Cormac McCarthy and I were going to have differences from the moment I opened The Road and discovered the dearth of quotation marks. Yes, Iâ€™m one of those readers, and this is going to be that type of review. Exits are located on both sides. For those of you who choose to remain on board, please fasten your seatbelts. In the event the review experiences a sudden loss in pressure, an oxygen mask will erupt from your computer in a disturbing fashion. If you have an infant, well, you only get the one mask, so I guess you have a tough choice to make.A copy of The Road was finally available during my most recent trip to the library. Prior to that, all of the library copies were on hold or checked out when I visited. I wasnâ€™t in a hurry to read this book, however, so I was content to wait. Having finally procured a copy, my feelings were largely indifferent. I had heard it is unapologetically bleak and sparse. I had also heard The Road is some kind of seminal work of post-apocalyptic fiction that has been responsible for numerous mind-blowing literary orgasms. Which brings me to my first â€¦Ways to Improve The Road: Read it aloud while having sex. I have not verified this myself, but it seems like this might improve many books. Plus itâ€™s multi-tasking, and so many people say they donâ€™t have enough time to read for pleasure these days.There is a tone to The Road. Some people call it poetic, and at a stretch one might even say itâ€™s melodious, but whatever one might call it, the tone is definitely there, and as a result, this novel sounds different from most novels. McCarthy creates the tone through the way he has structured the entire narrative, from the frequent transitions in time and place to the short, clipped dialogue unfettered by those oppressive quotation marks. Everything about the style of The Road is calculated to cultivate a certain atmosphere, one that is both distancing and intimate. I understand why some people find this book hauntingly beautiful or strangely enchantingâ€”but I do not share that opinion.There comes a point in every readerâ€™s life when he or she comes up against a book that forces a choice: when does a bookâ€™s stylistic idiosyncrasies preclude any enjoyment of story or plot? This point is different for everyone. As of this writing, two of the five books on my â€œdid not finishâ€ shelf are there because, try as I might, the way the book had been written interfered with my ability to read and enjoy it. I was particularly harsh on 
Blindness
, which also eschews the use of quotation marks. (McCarthy, to his credit, loves his paragraphs.) For many people, this is not a problem. For some people, like me, a book that abandons quotation marks instantly becomes a quagmire of lawlessness in which anything is possible: human sacrifice, cats and dogs living together â€¦ mass hysteria. Itâ€™s bad Road.Ways to Improve The Road: Add quotation marks. Stating the obvious, I know, but I feel like I should include this one, because it really is a simple fix. Just throw them in there so I know whatâ€™s dialogue and whatâ€™s narration. We can do wonderful things with ebooks these days â€¦ create a special quotation-marked edition! You can charge more, because the book has â€œbonus contentâ€!Realistically speaking, I acknowledge that the lack of quotation marks is a deliberate choice, and to change that would be to alter the statement McCarthy is making. Fine. I accept that, and we will indeed move on in a moment. I just needed to establish how much this small choice affected my reading of this book. I skimmed all but the first 30 pages, because they were pretty much the same. I might still have skimmed if there were quotation marks â€¦ but maybe not as much?I say the majority of the book was â€œpretty much the sameâ€ in the sense that there is very little variation in the types of events that transpire prior to the climax. This is partly because of the bleakness in tone, which is the result of a lonely, oppressive sense of sameness that pervades the story. No matter how far the man and his son travel, the situation is the same: few or no people, scarce resources, no civilisation. Their universe has shrunk so much. In this microcosm McCarthy creates the conflict: survival is ever-increasingly a struggle, and for what reason are they trying to survive? The contemplation of suicide is never far from the manâ€™s mind, and not just because that is what happened to his wife. This is not the type of post-apocalyptic fiction where a large group of survivors bands together to rebuild their shattered lives: these two characters are, for all intents and purposes, castaways; they are marooned in their own homeland.Ways to Improve The Road: Listen to a version read by Werner Herzog. Thereâ€™s just something about the way he reads, the combination of his accent and his intonation and his utterly dry approach to something like Whereâ€™s Waldo. I think it would both highlight and improve the tone of The Road.McCarthy never specifies the mechanism of this particular apocalypse. I am totally cool with that. However, I would have liked to know more about how the man became so distrustful of strangers. Why did he never find a small group of people he could call a familyâ€”neighbours, coworkers, etc.? Iâ€™m sure there is a sensible reason, but without something to call an anchor, the manâ€™s insistent distrust of every other human being seems more pathologically antisocial than anything else. In general, the interaction between the man and the boy irks me because of the way the man does nothing but talk in vague generalities. He tells the boy that they are â€œgood guysâ€ who still â€œcarry the fireâ€ and need to avoid â€œbad guysâ€. Yet he never seems to improve upon this shaky moral framework. We seldom witness him instructing his son on survival tactics. They just blunder from one place to the next with only the destination of the coast in mind.I canâ€™t say with certainty what I would do if I found myself alone with a son in the middle of the wilderness and no smartphone. The more I read about post-apocalyptic or zombie fiction or see games like Fallout 3, the more I realize I am not cut out for a life that does not involve several hours of reading and web-surfing followed by one or more Star Trek re-runs: if The Road or its ilk are what life will be like after someone hits the button, then I hope I donâ€™t survive the opening salvo. Iâ€™d like to think I would be the guy who retains or re-invents knowledge vital to my groupâ€™s survival, but I think we all know Iâ€™d probably just be the redshirt. Still, on the off chance that I do survive the actual apocalypse, I will not be using The Road as my survival guide.Ways to Improve The Road: Add a subplot. Any subplot.The Road is about the relationship between father and son. Though they labour constantly under the the threat of external conflict and confrontation, most of the bookâ€™s conflict comes from an existential angst. The father knows (or suspects) early in the book that he is dying, but he tries to hide this from his son for as long as possible. So most of the book is a chronicle of the hardships these two face as they travel southwest toward the coast, where they hope to find a more hospitable winter habitation.Unfortunately, I didnâ€™t find this chronicle very riveting: the hardships are episodic and not all that interesting; the ending is predictable but extremely well-written. I just wish there were more here. Iâ€™m not sure how else to put that. The book doesnâ€™t feel shallow, but it does feel like it could be denser. It could use some more substanceâ€”for example, more flashbacks to the man, his wife, and their infant, more about their story before she left and the world became so dark. Yes â€¦ more context.I rather suspected that I wouldnâ€™t fall head-over-heels in love with The Road, and I didnâ€™t expect to hate it, so I guess this book met my lukewarm expectations. Itâ€™s not bad, but it fails to engage me on that fundamental emotional level necessary for a book thatâ€™s all about the visceral. The somewhat experimental stylistic choices McCarthy makes actually undermine my enjoyment of the bookâ€”and while that is a very personal judgement on my part, itâ€™s something to bear in mind: whatâ€™s essential to one readerâ€™s enjoyment is a hindrance to anotherâ€™s. On Goodreads I am always reminded of the diversity of opinions on any book; I love that I can be exposed to so many different tastes and points of view here! This is particularly true of The Road, and whatever its flaws may be, it merits the type of discussion itâ€™s been getting.Ways to Improve The Road: Read it with a friend or friends. Discuss (preferably over pie)!

Non Ã¨ che ho molto da dire, se non che Ã¨ una delle letture piÃ¹ intense che ho avuto modo di fare nell'ultimo periodo. Si tratta di un viaggio, lungo una strada, o forse piÃ¹. Un viaggio di un uomo e di un bambino, che sospingono un carrello del supermarket in quello che Ã¨ un mondo ormai andato in rovina, annerito, incenerito, grigio, senza piÃ¹ umanitÃ . O meglio, con poca, pochissima umanitÃ . Sia in termini numerici - veramente pochissimi sopravvissuti -, sia in termini di "sentimento".Dialoghi secchi, poche parole, tanta paura. Un freddo. Romanzo spoglio di dettagli appartenenti ad un mondo ormai vecchio, andato, perduto. Ma pieno di un sentire antico come il mondo. Cormac McCarthy is some sort of literary cupid. I love The Road despite myself, and all because of what the book made me feel; or perhaps I have affection because the book made me feel anything at all, which so much contemporary literature fails to do. A father-son tale. A travel narrative. A meditation on the human condition when human instincts are stripped to their barest. I dig it.But at face value, my reasons for loving this book seem to be outnumbered by what I would qualify as some considerable flaws. To start, this book convinced me that Cormac McCarthy, in the tradition of many respected American (straight) male authors, knows jack squat about women, or at the very least that this great authorâ€™s powers of exposition suffer greatly in the face of a female subject. The slim sections of this book that detail the mother's role in the narrative felt, to me, to be out of place, partially because the juxtaposition of the motherâ€™s long-winded explanations of herself against the terseness of the dialogue shared by the boy and man throughout the rest of the novel made her seem perhaps a bit crazy or extremely out of touch. This resulted in small sections of narrative that felt to me to be poorly written; as if McCarthy sticks so closely to terse, jutting, simple dialogue because larger expositions are a deep weakness. She enters at moments of desperation, sure, but this justification seems unsatisfactory to me; McCarthy would never let a character get away so easily. He fails here in my eyes because I am holding him to his own standard.I also remained unconvinced, by the bookâ€™s end, of the sonâ€™s role as some sort of post-modern, post-apocalyptic messiah. Yes: the boy remains the most hopeful, compassionate and therefore morally and emotionally compelling part of this book. But he is all the more compelling for me when I think of him as just that: a boy, with potential for some higher meaning that neednâ€™t be expressed explicitly. I resisted the moments when McCarthy tended to reach for allegory by allowing the boy and the man to recognize the boyâ€™s potential meaning, perhaps because articulating it or giving it a name in a work so concerned with sentiments that escape language proved to be unsatisfying.And yetâ€¦ This book reminded me that I had a pulse, and that is the consummate qualification for greatness, as far as I am concerned. Beyond that, it became the first thing Iâ€™d think about each day and the last thing Iâ€™d consider each night while reading it. The mood of the prose, the lack of attention to what caused this apocalypse, the glimpses of horror and overall sweeping gestures of tenderness and sadness... all brilliant.Afterward, I found it impossible to pick up anything else because I remained so immersed in its world and in its language. I donâ€™t really know what else to say about it. It moved me. Very deeply.

I have a friend who lives in constant fear of some life altering event. She has at least a year... probably closer to two years food supply which includes 1,000 pounds of wheat. Seriously, I'm not kidding. She constantly reminds me to store enough food because in the event of some cataclysmic disaster grocery stores would be over run and our food supply would be decimated in less than three days. How's that for a feel good story?So I just finished reading The Road... another well written Cormac McCarthy novel. I breezed through the book despite it's dark tone. My only criticism is that "the boy" character at times seems so mature and full or wisdom, yet also able to fall apart on a whim. The lack of consistency in "the boy" personality made his character a bit unbelievable to me. I'd rather the kid act like a scared, whiny kid all the time rather than his token moments of yoda-isms which didn't ring true to me. I thought "the man" character was great and look forward to seeing the movie with Viggo Mortensen in the role... seems like great casting.My take away from this book and why I mentioned my paranoid friend is this... the real fear in terms of an apocalyptic event is not how much food you have in your pantry or garage, but how would you protect that food and how could you possibly transport 1,000 pounds of wheat to warmer climates? You can't.The Road is a dark, but realistic "what if" kind of book that forces us to take a hard look at humanity at it's worst--when survival instincts kick in and it's every man for himself and God for us all--if you believe in a higher power, that is. McCarthy's real achievement is creating a dystopian world which still offers hope... however small. Hope is what keeps all of us going down the road in our own crazy world.

This story is about a man and his boy struggling for survival in a world destroyed by some sort of cataclysmic event. Iâ€™ve read a few reviews of this book and the movie version (which I have not seen) and knew what I was getting into but I have to admit that I wasnâ€™t quite prepared for the absolute funk this book put me into while listening to it. It is about struggling to survive amongst the bleakest of odds. Itâ€™s dark and itâ€™s so very sad. It's terrible and awful with such painful moments of loveliness. There is very little dialogue and the conversations between the man and his boy are always very brief but the author manages to convey the desperation facing the pair and the strong bond and love between them.Iâ€™ve heard the writing style is difficult when read in book form but this wasnâ€™t an issue with the audiobook. The narrator, Tom Stechschulte, was awesome and amazing and his gritty voice perfectly suited to the material. If you enjoy audiobooks and are in the right head space for a story so grim I recommend finding a copy of this audio version. Just make sure you have something that makes you happy nearby after youâ€™re finished because youâ€™ll need it.My booklikes friend recommends  Cute Overload . It worked for me!

A father and his son struggling for survival in a cold, sun-devoid and pillaged post-apocalyptic world. McCarthy does a wonderful job depicting the heaviness of this god forsaken world and what would become of humanity and Earth in the (not-so-unlikely) possibility of an apocalypse; the discouragement, depression and fear/horror ruling in this world; the kindness and innocence of the child; the fatherly love that transcends through every gesture, the struggle (interior and exterior) of the parent to keep his son alive, as he is his only reason to live and the hope of a possible future for humanity.For those who say that the book is too gloomy and oppressive and repetitive, I have just one question: how would you expect a post-apocalyptic world without sun and almost entirely lacking survival means to be anything other than this? IMHO, these things are exactly the ones that make it so painful real! 
 â€œYou forget what you want to remember, and you remember what you want to forget.â€â€œWhat's the bravest thing you ever did?He spat in the road a bloody phlegm. Getting up this morning, he said.â€ â€œIf you break little promises, you'll break big ones.â€  â€œWhat he could bear in the waking world he could not by night and he sat awake for fear the dream would return.â€
