E' terribilmente desolante, ma in un modo cosÃ¬ poetico da essere straziante ed irrinunciabile. Incide la mente ed il cuore come un bisturi, e poi ti ricopre di cenere. L'uomo e il bambino che camminano verso sud, spingendo un carrello della spesa con tutti i loro averi nel mezzo del nulla, non solo materiale ma umano (tenuti in vita solo dall'affetto che portano l'uno per l'altro) non si dimenticano facilmente. E riempiono di domande sul nostro quotidiano, sui nostri rapporti. La prosa Ã¨ scarna come il panorama che li circonda, bruciato da una non meglio definita catastrofe (ambientale, nucleare? non si sa). Anche il rapporto che lega padre e figlio Ã¨ bruciante di un calore bianco che riesce a tenerli in vita nonostante la vita non ci sia piÃ¹. In mezzo a questa desolazione, Mac Carthy riesce a vincere la tentazione di non dare speranze, e in chiusura lascia acceso una fiammella che forse potrÃ  riaccendere l'umanitÃ . Ps: il contesto ricorda l'Eternauta (una delle piÃ¹ grandi graphic novel mai disegnate).

I'm a bit torn with this one.On the one hand I found the writing beautifully haunting, but on the other hand the story itself is dark and depressing and leaves me with several questions yet unanswered. I hate being left with questions!There were also several strange grammar conventions, mainly the missing quotes around dialogue and repetition of certain words (I'm Okay!) that drove me crazy, but the descriptions of the landscape was where the author's prose really hit home.The ashes of the late world carried on the bleak and temporal winds to and fro in the void. Sustained by a breath, trembling and brief. If only my heart were stone.This isn't a book for everyone, but if you want to see what life really would be like in a Post-Apocalyptic scenario, this is probably as close as you hopefully will get.

Wow. This story is both horrible and beautiful and the writing is stunning in it's simplicity. I loved it and was relieved when I came to the end... I'll never forget this book, I don't think. If you haven't read it yet, please do. It's worth it.

Cormac McCarthy's The Road is one of those books that you feel you really shouldn't miss out on. The reviews have been overwhelmingly glowing. I picked it up to read on the basis of these reviews and despite its recently being chosen as Oprah Winfrey's latest selection for her book club."It may be the saddest, most haunting book he's ever written, or that you'll ever read," says the reviewer for The Village Voice, who also goes on to say, "the tender precariousness of The Road's human relationships is what finally makes it such a beautiful, difficult, near perfect work."The Guardian's reviewer comments that "part of the achievement of The Road is its poetic description of landscapes from which the possibility of poetry would seem to have been stripped, along with their ability to support life." The world of The Road is dark and bleak, uniformly dead. The people are dead, the wildlife is dead, the foliage is dead. These are not landscapes that would seem to lend themselves to poetry or to compelling description, but McCarthy manages to mine the landscapes for the poetry of their very existence.The Powell's Books reviewer, Tom Chiarella, writes, countering temptations to read The Road as a warning, a tract, or a metaphor,But you shouldn't read this book for the metaphoric possibilities of change in the life of mankind. You know all that crap already. Yeah, yeah, we're headed for doom. You should read this book because it is exactly what a book about our future ought to be: the knife wound of our inconvenient truths, laid bare in a world that will just plain scare the piss out of you on a windy night.In The New York Review of Books, Michael Chabon writes,The paradox in every part and sentence of the post-apocalyptic narrativeâ€”evoking even as it deniesâ€”is repeated as if fractally by The Road as a whole. . . . This paradox, like a brutal syllogism, leads McCarthy, almost one senses in spite of himself, to conclude The Road on a note of possible redemption that while moving and reassuring is prepared for neither by one's reading of his prior work nor, perhaps, by the novel itself. In order to destroy the world, it becomes necessary to save it.Possible redemption? I find much of Chabon's review insightful, but I do not see any redemption in this book. The final paragraph of the novel is the only break in the bleak and overwhelming trip the father and son have made:Once there were brook trout in the streams in the mountains. You could see them standing in the amber current where the white edges of their fins wimpled softly in the flow. They smelled of moss in your hand. Polished and muscular and torsional. On their backs were vermiculate patterns that were maps of the world in its becoming. Maps and mazes. Of a thing which could not be put back. Not be made right again. In the deep glens where they lived all things were older than man and they hummed of mystery. (286-7)This final section of The Road may gesture toward a better world, but it is a world that no longer exists. At the end of the novel, all fish are dead, all streams are polluted and dead or dying, and the boy does not even have memories of the world that is described in this final paragraph. These "maps of the world in its becoming" are long since gone, as is the world they mapped, and this world can "not be made right again." This seems to be something other than hope. Nostalgia, perhaps. Loss. Regret. A sense of the insignificance of humanity. But not hope.Chabon also writes, more convincingly, of The Road's treatment of the father-son relationship that is at the heart of the novel:The Road is not a record of fatherly fidelity; it is a testament to the abyss of a parent's greatest fears. The fear of leaving your child alone, of dying before your child has reached adulthood and learned to work the mechanisms and face the dangers of the world, or found a new partner to face them with. The fear of one day being obliged for your child's own good, for his peace and comfort, to do violence to him or even end his life. And, above all, the fear of knowingâ€” as every parent fearsâ€”that you have left your children a world more damaged, more poisoned, more base and violent and cheerless and toxic, more doomed, than the one you inherited. It is in the audacity and single-mindedness with which The Road extends the metaphor of a father's guilt and heartbreak over abandoning his son to shift for himself in a ruined, friendless world that The Road finds its great power to move and horrify the reader.Despite the earlier injunctions (in Chiarella's review) against reading The Road as metaphor, this virtually demands it be seen as such. It is certainly about this generational anxiety, this burden of responsibility, but this burden of responsibility cannot stop at the boundaries of personal relationships. The precept of the Iroquois that "in every deliberation we must consider the impact on the seventh generation... even if it requires having skin as thick as the bark of a pine" calls upon the same sense of human responsibility that McCarthy's father feels for his son. We may not know exactly what happened to cause this apocalypse in The Road, but this vagueness allows us to envision the many ways in which our actions today could condemn future generations to such a diminished and hopeless life.In this light, perhaps most interesting is the commentary by the reviewer for The Modern Word. He writes, "Ultimately, The Road suggests that no matter how bleak our existence, we must live life as if it has meaning. As if our progenitors are watching; as if there is a line separating the good guys from the bad guys." And perhaps, as if our descendants are watching.This is precisely what the father and son in the book try to do, at some times with more energy and heart than at other times. They are driven by a desire, a need, to be "good guys," to separate themselves from those who steal others' means of survival, those who hold people captive until they can eat them, those who kill and eat children. They live to hold themselves apart from the others they encounter on the road. The horrors of becoming one of those others is illustrated most dramatically in a scene in which they come across an abandoned campsite with "a charred human infant headless and gutted and blackening on the spit" (198).In this quest to be good guys, to do the right thing, to survive, however, there are choices to be made. At what point does a father sacrifice his own son to protect him from rape and cannibalism? Can he do such a thing? How long does he have to force himself to remain alive to protect his son? How long will he be capable of doing such a thing?To make this obvious as a decision to be made, McCarthy includes memories of the boy's mother, who killed herself before he had a chance to know her but after the event that ruined the world. "We're survivors," the father told her, but she did not believe him. "What in God's name are you talking about? We're not survivors. We're the walking dead in a horror film" (55). He begs her not to kill herself, to stay with him and their son. Her reply, over the course of the conversation, is chilling in the way that it so thoroughly captures the hopelessness and despair of the situation:I didn't bring myself to this. I was brought. And now I'm done. . . . You cant protect us You say you would die for us but what good is that? I'd take him with me if it werent for you. You know I would. It's the right thing to do. . . . Sooner or later they will catch us and they will kill us. They will rape me. They'll rape him. They are going to rape us and kill us and eat us and you wont face it. You'd rather wait for it to happen. But I cant. I cant. . . . You talk about taking a stand but there is no stand to take. My heart was ripped out of me the night he was born so dont ask for sorrow now. There is none. . . . As for me my only hope is for eternal nothingness and I hope it with all my heart. (56-7)The father cannot make this choice, though. He knows the need to live, to protect his son from the horrors of this new world, to protect his life. And the son, though he cannot protect his father from the horrors, knows that he bears responsibility as well. As the book progresses and the father weakens, the son begins to watch him, guarding him, holding him accountable for eating his share and for doing the right thing. This is most revealed after an encounter with a thief. The father and son recover their stolen things, but the father cannot resist taking the thief's few meager belongings in retaliation, even as the boy begs him to leave him something, recognizing that they have just condemned the man to death just as surely as if they'd killed him themselves.Just help him, Papa. Just help him. The man looked back up the road. He was just hungry, Papa. He's going to die. He's going to die anyway. He's so scared, Papa. The man squatted and looked at him. I'm scared, he said. Do you understand? I'm scared. The boy didn't answer. He just sat there with his head bowed, sobbing. You're not the one who has to worry about everything. The boy said something but he couldnt understand him. What? he said. He looked up, his wet and grimy face. Yes I am, he said. I am the one. (259)He is the one who ends up worrying about and trying to care for his father. And he is the one who survives, who has to worry about living with the other survivors, who has to continue to worry about the moral obligations of survival in this changed world.Not much happens in the novel and when it does happen it is described in a spare, understated manner. No dramatics or histrionics here. The world may have ended, but there's no point in screaming about it. This lean style, coupled with the short segmented writing (the novel is constructed from over 200 short sections, not quite chapters, some of which could be fit anywhere in the novel), the rarity of dialogue or human contact, and the repetitive nature of the story, simultaneously gives the narrative a sense of the ordinariness of affairs in this strange new world and provides a slowly but steadily ratcheted-up sense of drama. Encounters with the bizarre and horrific are described matter-of-factly, but the sheer magnitude of these things, the way the world continues to reveal death at every turn, lends them a weight that the straightforward description and delivery would not necessarily if these encounters were discrete events. This is truly a novel in which the cumulative effect is greater than the sum of its parts.The novel is moving because it frightens with its realism and deadens with its matter-of-factness. This is a world that we want to avoid, but, despite the surface differences (post-apocalyptic barrens and roving bands of cannibals), it is a world, McCarthy seems to say, that is not so far removed from our own.

Nobody wants to be here and nobody wants to leave.It is in this state of utter bewilderment, shock and tears, that I present to you my first Goodreads review after a two month absence, at the least. So, I guess, this is a hello! All I can say about this book, is that it is a punch in the gut, a tear in the heart and a horror to the mind. It's repulsive, startling, full of emotion.After a lot of thinking, I don't think I can possibly rate this book, and saying this, I'm becoming more and more sceptical of the entire 'rating-books-with-a -single-star' system. Can we really sum up a book using little, plain stars - when it is anything but plain? Of course, I'm being a bit of a hypocrite here, criticizing the whole rating system, because I for one, always try to rate books, but... I just never realized how meaningless they are; how little they tell us about the book itself, apart from a general, subjective opinion. This book was one of the most terrifying objects I have ever seen - the story it holds is brutal, exhilaratingly daunting and bleak. I had to thoroughly remind myself that what I had just read was fictional, wasn't real, was not happening in this day and age. Truly, it shook me to the core. My opinion on: âœ - The plot: When you think of the word apocalypse, the first few words that come to mind, most likely are: chaos, zombies, adventure. Yet, this book completely tossed these connotations out the window, replacing them with a plotline, focusing more on routine, whilst still letting survival play the major role in this post-apocalyptic wasteland. Many people will say that this book is monotonous - the characters walk down the road, light a fire, sleep underneath thin blankets, shiver from the cold cold - and then all of that played on repeat, like a frozen mixtape. And, yes, this is true, yet this constant repetion of actions, whilst sometimes tough to read through over and over again, is key in the portrayal of the loving bond between father and son, and their way of everyday life, and survival.It's like our routine - walking up, eating breakfast, going to school/work, etc., but in extreme mode. The strangeness of this book settles upon the fact that the reader doesn't really know what happened to cause this tragedy, that the two characters managed to live through. Although there are many possible reasons and hints throughout the novel, the very thought that something like that could, potentially, happen one day, is petrifying. Ultimately, it's all up to us - humans and the way we treat one another. âœ - The characters: By characters, I mean the two main characters. The incredible bond between father and son was what really stood out in this book to me, personally. Their dependence on one another - the father on his son's heart; the boy on his father's rational, logical thinking - was phenomenally written. They were each other's anchors. I felt so much affection for both of them - truthfully, they could easily be real people. When in trouble, my pulse raised alongside them, when they were finally rewarded, I remember feeling all warm inside too. As a fifteen year old, I felt so torn between the two character's way of living. I felt that at times I related more to the young boy's loving opinions on the world and his empathetic, naive affection for everybody, and, at times, agreed more with the father. That's the universal beauty of this book - one is able to see it through different perspectives, and through the perspective of time. âœ - The atmosphere: This, hands down, has got to be the most terrifying book I have ever read.And, as someone who rarely ever reaches for books, regarded as 'scary' - I think it's safe to say that even the most avid horror lovers out there, will flinch at least once during this story. The irony is that there are no supernatural creatures. Forget zombies, curses, figures of death. In this book, humans are the monsters. And, that's probably the most terrifying aspect of it. Cormac McCarthy delivers a truly disgusting and raw portrayal of the human nature and the extent people will go to, in order to survive. I think it's only decent to warm, that some, if not many, scenes in this book are disturbing to the mind . And, I honestly don't recommend reading this book before bed. After finishing it, I was left in complete shock and disbelief, having to remind myself that what I had just read was a figment of somebody's imagination, that it was a nothing but a work of fiction. But, then again, that's the power of good fiction - it makes you feel something. If a story leaves you shattered mentally after the last page, it's only fair to say that the author did a damn good job. An interesting (probably not so interesting, though) fact is that, after attending a literature class, I had the opportunity to take part in a interesting discussion about the symbolism and allegory found in this book, and was left dumbfounded to find that there were two possible endings to the story, depending on perspective. I'd be more than willing to chat with someone on that matter, so if you've read the book and want to chat, feel free to message me. To wrap this review up, The Road was a long chain of different emotions, reactions and opinions. And, like I said earlier on, I just cannot, in any shape or form, rate it fairly. All I know is that there is nothing more scarier than the human race, and what the human mind is capable of creating. Once again, I'd like to remind that whilst this book is immensely unnerving in its gore and imagery, it is also eye-opening, and for that reason, worth a read.

#1: I loved this book. #2: If you didn't like this book that's ok too. #3: I'm not one of those self-centered ridiculous reviewers that think if you hated a book I love (or visa versa) that makes you some kind of moron. No, actually that just means we don't like the same types of books. Anyway, that aside, here are my takeaways from Cormac McCarthy's The Road:This book contained some of my favorite literary tools. One thing I specifically look for in my reading material is that the characters are treated as being real entities. Meaning, when I start reading a book, I love it when it just drops you into the middle of what's going without any explanation of how they got there or what exactly is going on. It's like this person(s) has their own life and situations they are dealing with but we are fortunate enough to get to pull back the veil for only a short amount of time to see just a section of their life. No crazy back story and ridiculous Epilogue that tries to tie everything up together in a nice little bow. Because of this, there are many things in this book that I love and appreciate that seems to grate on other readers of this book:*No quotation marks-this doesn't bother me because it's pretty easy to tell the difference between a little boy talking and a man. If I need to stop a conversation because I can't tell whose talking, a kid or a full grown adult, that's pretty sad.*No chapters-Guess what people?!! Life isn't magically separated into nice well put together chapters. It's one long continuous moment and then it's done. Period. We may speak about "new chapters in our lives" but last time I checked life isn't segregated into a clear chapter ending and clear chapter beginning. So don't expect to be able to "just read one more chapter" and then break. There are sections that are separated by asterisks to indicate a significant amount of time lapse and I would suggest breaking at those areas if needed. *I appreciate the fact that the MC's are never given names. It's only supposed to be the two of them wondering through a post-apocalyptic wasteland so what's the point of names? This also makes the characters more relateable in my opinion because they are so nondescript and "everyman".*I've seen many reviewers get upset because the events of the apocalypse are not explained. That's because this book isn't about the apocalypse. Go read an over the top zombie novel if that's the only thing you're looking for. This is basically a kind of [insert end of world scenario here] so that, again, it can be more relateable. It could be about any kind of apocalypse out there. Also, its mentioned in the book that its been many years since it happened. Its no longer the primary characteristic of the story. The boy seems like he could be about 8-10 years old and he was just born when it happened. If its been that long why would expect the author to go back and rehash all that happened? If that were the plan, he wouldn't have started out the story that long AFTER the event. It's been so long the boy doesn't even know what Coca Cola is so really the event that happened to put them in that scenario is no longer even remotely relevant as the ash filled gray world is literally all the boy even knows.*I loved that nothing of real tremendous importance happened throughout the story because again, that's life. Life isn't big explosions and page after page of melodrama. I feel like this book portrayed about as true of a dystopian future as you could get. Not because of any thrilling event but because of the total lack of them. Days and days and days on the road without any human contact and without any visual stimuli then a random happenstance with some crazies which is just as quickly over. I would make an assumption that if it's that long into a post-apocalyptic world that would be pretty accurate.*I've seen comments on other reviews about how this was too depressing and the characters didn't try hard enough to find things to be happy about. Really? You've been living 10 years (guessing) in a wasteland without hardly anything to eat, no clean water, no clean air, and killer bandits, but yeah you're totally right, it should be a no brainer that these characters should be happy go lucky and talking each others ears off all the time. I'm sure that's how you would be.In conclusion:If you need a book that has over-exaggerated characters, wildly descriptive imagery, and any and all reasons to suspend belief...then this is not the book for you. There are no dragons, fiery explosions, western style standoffs, pointless monologueing, witches, aliens, zombies, love triangles or high school valley-girl dialogue. This is not Harry Potter, World War Z, Ender's Game, Twilight or any other highly commercialized fiction novel. This is a simple story about a man and a boy doing their best to survive in a world that has long forgotten about the insignificance and annoyance of the human race. Having nothing else but the other to push them to keep going.I will definitely be reading more McCarthy books.

Noites de trevas mais densas do que as prÃ³prias trevas e cada dia mais cinzento do que o anterior.â€ Assim se inicia o romance de Cormac McCarthy que tem como protagonistas um pai e um filho que deambulam num cenÃ¡rio pÃ³s-apocaliptÃ­co, por bosques repletos de Ã¡rvores queimadas, calcinadas, numa paisagem Ã¡rida e estÃ©ril, com chuva permanente e um frio desolador, incÃªndios florestais e neve cinzenta, poeiras e cinzas negras, numa destruiÃ§Ã£o sem limites, com cadÃ¡veres humanos ressequidos e mumificados de pele negra.Ã‰ nesta paisagem de â€œinverno nuclearâ€ que pai e filho percorrem, com o objectivo final de chegar Ã  costa, numa luta permanente pela sobrevivÃªncia fÃ­sica e emocional, nomeadamente, pela fuga aos â€œhomens mausâ€, numa relaÃ§Ã£o de amor e protecÃ§Ã£o sem limites e sem esperanÃ§a, na procura de um â€œmundoâ€ que jÃ¡ nÃ£o existe, nem provavelmente voltarÃ¡ a existir. â€œA Estradaâ€ pode ser considerado como um romance de ficÃ§Ã£o cientÃ­fica ou romance de â€œhorrorâ€, com uma narrativa fragmentada, sÃ³bria e opressiva, em que a moralidade assume particular relevÃ¢ncia, nomeadamente, no relacionamento afectivo entre pai e filho, e em que apesar da amplitude e dimensÃ£o das paisagens e dos cenÃ¡rios envolventes, sentimos permanentemente uma claustrofobia avassaladora.A adaptaÃ§Ã£o cinematogrÃ¡fica era inevitÃ¡vel e agora sÃ³ me resta ver o filme realizado por John Hillcoat protagonizado por Viggo Mortensen, Charlize Theron e Kodi Smit-McPhee.

Let me start by saying...I went into this book not really knowing what I was in for. I picked it because it fit in with a reading challenge I was doing.The first thing to bother me was the really off-putting POV that the whole story was written in. I felt like a perverse stalker.And let me tell you, things did not get better. There was pretty much no plot, no real characterisation, and nothing fundamentally exciting actually happened. Even when it got that that climax I felt nothing! Nothing for anyone.Considering I normally have emotional reactions to books, this just went towards proving to me that this book did absolutely nothing for me.My verdict: But that's not enough...P.S If you want a rather more articulate, yet no less scathing review, check out Michael J. Sullivan's review: https://www.goodreads.com/review/show...

So, I am late to the party as usual with one of the most popular post-apocalyptic novels published in the 21st Century (I guess along with World War Z, which I have also not read), and multi award winning as well!Helped by the fact I came down sick over the long weekend, this was a pretty quick read. I am trying to work around spoilers here - but have I ever read a book in which so little actually happens between the starting situation and the situation a few pages from the end? I can't recall one...But the book is quite entrancing with its bleakness. There is a grey, colourless beauty in its futility, it's grimness, it's lack of hope. The reduction of all people to a baseness of survivalist greed, without a level of trust, or expectation of anything other than competing to survive. Sad and stark, and with only vague clues as to the cause of the apocalypse, there is little explained, but a level of confusion - of dreams, or memories, of the random, perhaps, causing enough doubt for the reader to wonder if clues were missed (maybe I did?).Personally I thought the writing lived up to the hype, I enjoyed the read, but I will surely be looking for something more upbeat to read next!4 stars.

And nothing bad is going to happen to us. That's right. Because we're carrying the fire.Magnificient, harrowing and heartbreaking.In a post-apocalyptic world a father and his son are trying to survive. For the father, trying to save and protect his son, the only thing left to remind him of the beautiful past, before all that went away:The frailty of everything revealed at last. Old and troubling issues resolved into nothingness and night. The last instance of a thing takes the class with it. Turns out the light and is gone. Look around you. Ever is a long timeThe grey, dark ash ridden world, which so beautifully is described throughout this tale:The world shrinking down about a raw core of parsible entities. The names of things slowly following those things into oblivion. Colors. The names of birds. Things to eat. Finally the names of things one believed to be true.And finally, when all comes to an end:Is it real? The fire? Yes it is. Where is it? I don't know where it is. Yes you do. It's inside you. It was always there. I can see it.

spoilersI read The Road in a couple of days. It's content is very repetitive. The author never tells us exactly what happened, but gives us little hints as we go along.This book won the Pulitzer and many other awards. I didn't see the father/son relationship, or their road trip to nowhere at any odds, as anything heroic.I'm not a fan of this book.

It is difficult to describe this book. It is bleak and depressing, yet hard to put down. It is sad, yet full of hope. It is amazingly crafted. It's such a beautiful story of a father and son.Second time reading this and even though I know how it ends, I can't help but shed some tears.
Wow! Amazing writing, excellent narrator (Audiobook)! Time well spent!!!

(My full review of this book is much longer than the excerpt seen below; find it in its entirety at the Chicago Center for Literature and Photography [cclapcenter.com].)So when I first heard that it was Cormac McCarthy who authored the Pulitzer-winning ultra-bleak post-apocalyptic thriller The Road, like a lot of people my first thought was, "Wait a minute, isn't he that dude who writes them frilly Westerns that are so loved by those Oprah zombies and that get made into precious award-winning films starring that dreamy Matt Damon?" And indeed, McCarthy's most well-known novel, All the Pretty Horses, is guilty of all the things just mentioned, which I suppose is what has made me lump McCarthy's name in my head all these years with such schlockmeisters as Larry McMurtry and Nicholas Sparks. But the more I've heard about The Road this year, and the more that people I admire can't seemingly shut up about it, and the more I investigate McCarthy's life and career because of it, the more I'm realizing that the picture I've had of him and his work in my head all these years is quite wrong; that McCarthy is actually a lot more known for extremely bloody and violent meditations on the limits of human depravity, using such genres as Westerns not in an attempt to sell more potboilers to desperate loners at supermarkets, but rather as a convenient metaphor for the utter lawlessness and anarchy that humankind is at its basest and least civilized.And this is in fact the very first thing to understand about 2006's The Road if you don't already, something that may possibly stop you from actually reading it -- that it is without a doubt the most bleak, unrelentlessly hopeless look at humanity perhaps ever caught in a mainstream novel (certainly an award-winning, Oprah-loving novel), a book that on almost every page displays not even the tiniest hint of a reason why the human race would ever be worth saving. And there's a very good reason for this, too, because McCarthy is trying to examine a very important and basic question about humanity here, one that almost can't be explored without an ultra-bleak post-apocalyptic setting; of just why it is that some humans continue to have hope in the face of such overwhelming odds, and why it is that others give up in the same situations at the specific moments they do.It's a fascinating thing to explore, of course, especially in this age of Bushism and government-sanctioned torture...

There is little plot in The Road, and that is good; the story is tedious, repetitious and slow, and that too is good; the story is about two characters and the way they love each other, and this is very good; all the information you need about McCarthy's future world is there if you want to do the work, and doing the work is also good; when it comes down to it The Road is very good no matter the complaints you may read or hear to the contrary.That is all I can say for now. I need to let The Road settle in my consciousness to see where it will land in my pantheon of books.What I can say is that it moved me deeply, the prose was a wonder, and I think it is one of the best father/son relationships I have ever encountered.If my strong feelings deepen this book will rise in my estimation; if my feelings weaken it may wound this book terminally for me. Only time will tell.But one final comment I must make is that anyone who compares The Road to Blindness -- or worse states that the latter is greater than the former -- is one whose opinions are necessarily suspect. The former is genuine, realistic, stark, unwavering; the latter is an unimaginative debacle posing as deep allegory. Read the former and steer clear of the latter.

I read this book part of the BookTubeAThon 2018. This is for the challenge Read and watch a book to movie adaptation. It is hosted by Ariel Bissett, you can find more information on: https://www.booktubeathon.comI recently asked for recommendation for good dystopian book and was recommended The Road by Cormac McCarthy. I found this book so dark, eerie and the relationship between the man and the son was so realistic in the circumstance. You can feel that love that man has for his son, the desire to protect him at all cost. The absolute trust the son has towards his father like all children have to their parents. You can feel the bleakness of this world, the pure darkness and there was moments where I held my breath because I was so emotional attached to the man and son. I loved the writing style, the short sentences, the minimal words highlighted to me how tired these characters are. They would have no energy to speak in long and complicated proses.  4.25 stars
One of the most moving and emotionally devastating books I have ever read. I am still reeling and I think I will be processing this for quite some time.

I read this book by accident. Strange but true.I was just getting into audiobooks. A friend lent me an old Mp3 player with a few titles on it. I thought I was going to listen to Kerouac's "On the Road" but instead I started Cormac's dark odyssey. I of course knew I'd made a mistake right away. But it was too late: the narrative had me. I listened to it when I was lying near my young son's bed waiting for him to fall asleep. It terrified me the way few books can. I was scared for the man and his son. I gasped audibly when they were in danger. I cried pitifully at the end.A few years later I returned to this book when I was going through a divorce. Unable to see my son as often as I wanted, I read through the desperate trek of a father clinging to his boy in a nuclear wasteland. I didn't gasp on this second read. But I did cry again.McCarthy's prose is bleak and sad. Yet this is a book about a parent's love: what we try to do for our children and the horrible moment in which we know we can't do enough and they have to go on without us.I don't recommend this book. I don't even like to talk about it. But I do ask readers who are parents if they've read it and if they have I feel a bond with them.Carac

Apocalyptic western with slow prose dry as ashes and succulent as nature's breath. Every day the man and the boy face death and the constant collapsing of hope, knowing no future nor reason for why they still exist. All the world is grey in the unknown, save for chance meetings with cannibals and flashes of the past that offer the barest glimpse of how things came to be. There is another story behind the walking existence offered here, but that is left up to the reader to parse together from descriptions of burned landscape and dried corpses, extinct species and no food left save for the walkers. It is a story as smooth as a flow of movement with no record of time, only a slow soft degradation into the wasteland. The ending brings a small glimpse of something akin to hope, a contentment found with humans who have found in each other something more than the monsters they are surrounded by.

I read McCarthy in 1993 because my best undergrad friend and intellectual rival, Scott Parker, was a fan. I read Child of God and loved it- a simple, deeply chilling narrative of a mad man. In 2000, I read Cities of the Plain, meh.This novel, The Road, was more like Child of God, in that it depicts the basest, scariest elements of human nature without flinching. It is also stark and universal by leaving main characters and places nameless, timeless. It tells of the toil to survive and protect one's progeny even in the face of the end of the world. And though the outlook is entirely bleak, one holds onto hope throughout the story and in the end finds some reward.

â€œLa strada era deserta. Sotto di loro, nella piccola valle, la serpentina quieta e grigia di un fiume. Precisa e immobile. Lungo la riva un ammasso di canne morte. Tutto bene? Chiese l'uomo. Il bambino annuÃ¬. Poi s'incamminarono sull'asfalto in una luce di piombo, strusciando i piedi nella cenere, l'uno il mondo intero dell'altro.â€Angosciante ma bellissimo libro. Per me Ã¨ un romanzo avvincente, spettacolare, ricco di tensione e di curiositÃ  per il destino dei due protagonisti, padre e figlio. Al centro di tutto c'Ã¨ il loro struggente rapporto, la loro forza nel mantenere intatti i propri valori ("noi portiamo il fuoco") in una realtÃ  dove di valori non ne esistono piÃ¹. Lo stile di McCarthy, scarno, asciutto e senza fronzoli, ha reso la lettura molto scorrevole. Non ci sono capitoli ma solo brevi paragrafi che raccontano episodi, dialoghi, sogni, flashback... Ã¨ un modo di scrivere fatto apposta per dire e non dire, per lasciare volutamente molte cose all'immaginazione. Proprio come il finale che rimane aperto per lasciare un barlume di speranza... Iniziato un sabato pomeriggio alle 4 e alle 10 della domenica mattina lo avevo finito. PerchÃ© Ã¨ un romanzo avvincente, spettacolare, ricco di tensione e di curiositÃ  per il destino dei due personaggi. E inoltre lo stile di McCarthy rende la lettura molto scorrevole. PerchÃ© non ci sono capitoli. Il romanzo Ã¨ strutturato in brevi paragrafi che raccontano episodi, dialoghi, sogni, flashback. La scrittura Ã¨ scarna, asciutta, senza fronzoli. Basti pensare che i dialoghi sono solo dei botta e risposta, senza precisazioni come "lui disse" - "egli rispose", e la punteggiatura tipica dei dialoghi Ã¨ totalmente assente. La storia Ã¨ molto semplice. Un padre e un figlio, senza nome, senza niente tranne un carrello arrugginito con dentro poco cibo e pochi averi percorrono una strada verso sud. Vanno verso il mare. Non vengono mai specificati nomi di luoghi ma probabilmente le vicende si svolgono in America e i due protagonisti stanno andando verso il Golfo del Messico. Lo scenario Ã¨ apocalittico, il mondo Ã¨ stato distrutto da una catastrofe non meglio specificata (forse un disastro nucleare o un meteorite). Ogni forma di vita, animale o vegetale, Ã¨ stata spazzata via, i pochi sopravvissuti non hanno piÃ¹ nulla di umano e attraversano quest'immensa terra desolata in cerca di cibo come morti che camminano. E spesso il "cibo" Ã¨ un altro essere umano... Si succedono cosÃ¬ una serie di episodi e incontri: la visita alla casa d'infanzia dell'uomo; l'esplorazione di un supermarket abbandonato, il figlio che beve per la prima volta una lattina di coca cola; gli esseri umani tenuti prigionieri come scorte di cibo; il neonato allo spiedo; il vecchio sperduto e sotto shock; il ladro; il treno abbandonato, il bunker sotterraneo pieno di cibo; la nave arenata... La madre del bambino compare in un paio di flashback ma non viene detto chiaramente se si Ã¨ uccisa o se Ã¨ solo fuggita. Nel finale infatti, dopo la morte del padre, il bambino viene raggiunto da un uomo che gli dice che per sopravvivere dovrÃ  unirsi a lui e al suo gruppo di "buoni". LÃ¬ il bambino ritrova "la donna" e da come viene descritto l'incontro sembra proprio che sia la madre. Ma la scrittura di McCarthy dice e non dice, alcune cose vengono volutamente lasciate all'immaginazione. Proprio come il finale che rimane aperto per lasciare un barlume di speranza.

When I was about fifteen, I watched American History X. And it was, I guess, really good. It was shocking, and it was brutal, and I think it made me cry. It probably crushed some of my illusions at just the right time. But was it that great? Quite apart from the fact that the ending was a cop-out, I'm not convinced. I have this niggling worm of a feeling somewhere deep inside my inner ear that it's somehow... easier to write (or make films about) deep heavy shit like that. You know, all happy families are the same, all unhappy families are different in their own way kind of thing. For all that I love extreme racial tension and post-apocalyptic journeys, I'm much more impressed by a book about a woman going to buy some flowers. I'd rather read about some ordinary girl trying to decide who to marry than about death and destruction. Provided it's beautifully written and perfectly realised, of course (which it has been. Extra points if you can guess which books I'm referring to). This is Tolstoy to Chekhov stuff, and I choose Chekhov.But really, what the fuck am I talking about? This book was very nearly great. The pacing was brilliant, I liked the weird new vocabulary and the lack of punctuation, the dialogue between the man and the boy was brilliant. And I've always thought that despite almost everything, life was still worth living because of the art and the music and the sheer inexplicable worthiness of learning stuff. But here you have a book where all of those things are gone. Every single book was swollen with damp! I could deal with everything else, but a post-apocalyptic world without books, I couldn't deal with. But then at the end it turned out there was something to live for, and I won't spoil it, it's clichÃ©d enough to guess, but well done enough that it doesn't matter. Tears are cheap, but I didn't shed any. So I liked it a lot, and I'm going to go see the movie when it comes out ($6 tickets at Nova on a Monday, bargain), and what's more I'm going to hope the movie doesn't slaughter the book, and I'm going to avoid Justin Clemens' discussion of same, because he's an idiot. I also think there may well be something in what Bram said in his review:"I bet more than a few writers and would-be writers read this and thought, â€œDamn, if only I had written this first,â€ rather than the actually true statement of â€œDamn, I wish I could write something like this.â€ "But I didn't love this book. I still prefer Chekhov.

A man and his son, journey south through post-apocalypic America (we assume). Travelling to escape the winter, which equiped as they are with rotten blankets and worn shoes will never survive. Reading McCarthy will put you into this world, you'll taste ash as you read, glance over your shoulder, and check whether your revolver is close at hand. By far the key strength of this novel is the setting, its not just basic setting description, McCarthy uses some unusual devices to communicate just how haunted the world has become. There are no names, not for the father or the son, or any of the places they visit. The author uses no quotation marks, a tactic that makes us feel the stifling scilence of the road. On a brief tangent, there is a totally bizarre paragraph on page 87 which I can't quite figure. The narration slips into first person, and doesn't contain any spoilers so I'll plonk it right here. "The dog that he remembers followed us for two days. I tried to coax it to come but it would not. I made a noose of wire to catch it. There were three cartridges in the pistol. None to spare. She walked away down the road. The boy looked after her and then looked a me and then he looked at the dog and he began to cry and beg for the dog's life and I promised I would not hurt the dog. A trellis of a dog with the hide stretched over it. The next day it was gone. That is the dog he remembers. He doesn't remember any little boys." I initially thought is was narration from some bad guys stalking our protaganists, but that doesn't pan out, and this is the only slip into first person narrative in the novel. (any insights into this section would be more than welcome!!) The Road is an excellent read for something a bit less fluffy, don't expect some action flick in novel form, expect a heart-breaking tale of strength and humanity.

A lot of books get hyped and you go to read them and they are a real let-down. Most recently for me it was The Story of Edgar Sawtelle. And I probably had a bit of an attitude before even picking up The Road -- Pulitzer Prize winner, Oprah Book Club selection, now a "major motion picture"...yeah, yeah, yeah. All this praise and worship was a little bit nauseating. So for the first book of 2009 I decided to see if The Road could bear up under the weight of such gargantuan, exhaustive praise. In short, absolutely, unequivocally yes. I just couldn't help but be awed by McCarthy's spare prose. The Road is a real exercise in discipline. There are no extra words...none. The writing is fluid like poetry. The imagery moves from stark to hauntingly beautiful. Of all the books I've ever read on the end-of-the-world scenario, this one is bare bones, as ugly and scary as it can get. McCarthy leaves very little room for hope. It's a desolate story he is weaving and he doesn't back down or flinch for a second. Gotta respect him for that.

There is no later. This is later. All things that of grace and beauty such that one holds them to one's heart have a common provenance in pain. Their birth in grief and ashes. So, he whispered to the sleeping boy, I have you.In a post apocalyptic world, a man and his son walk the ruined and damaged earth of charred trees, ashy waters. Scavenging for food and always on the move, always hoping. This book is so stark and depressing that I had to read it in bits and portions but still has such heartbreakingly tender moments. I have never rooted for characters in fiction as I did for the pair and McCarthy's ability to deliver breathtaking yet precise words without overbearing paragraphs delving into description is outstanding.I found it interesting that McCarthy does not use quotation marks or semi colons in his prose. A great introduction to a brilliant writer, I hope to read more of his works.

Reading "The Road", you can focus on the surroundings, the post apocalyptic world, the devastation, loss and horror - it certainly is everywhere in this book. It would be easy to lose sight of hope. What does survive even in this austere and hostile place is the love of the father for his son, his memories of a world and a life with beauty, and integrity. Their trek is a journey of hope. In the bleakest of times if humanity survives, hope persists.

Loved it in spite of Oprah. Gripping, wrenching, terrifying.

Authors often exploit a post-apocalyptic setting for vigilante heroics or for expounding a rebuke of human hubris. Cormac McCarthy circumvents these easy genre conventions. He uses it as a scalpel to peel away the layers defining humanity. Legal, social, cultural, philosophical and religious structure â€” gone! Strip away all that veneer and what remains? Even the will to survive is an inadequate answer.What is remarkable is McCarthy's ability to immerse the reader in this bleak landscape. He eschews a parade of horror at the outset. Instead, he provides disorienting examples of sensory erasure. The story opens at night. Only dreams have color.  â€œWaking in the cold dawn it all turned to ash instantly. Like certain ancient frescoes entombed for centuries suddenly exposed to the day.â€ (Location 195) A dream monster suggests the erasure of both form and color.  â€œAnd on the far shore a creature that raised its dripping mouth from the rimstone pool and stared into the light with eyes dead white and sightless as the eggs of spiders.â€ (Location 38) Sound is not an interruption of silence. It is silence in another form: the sound of rainfall and waterflow suggests in its monotony merely white noise. Even the sense of time has been erased.  â€œHe thought the month was October but he wasnt sure. He hadnt kept a calendar for years.â€ (Location 38) McCarthy unsettles us with the notion of shifting memory as well. The very act of re-summoning a memory re-shapes it through context until memories become more fiction than private reality. The man attempts to preserve vestiges of some memories by wrapping them in the stories he tells his son. McCarthy forces us to witness the awfulness of these eroding memories. The man discards the photo of his dead wife, along with his useless wallet. He no longer understood how to keep her a part of their lives. He stops telling his son the stories. He shows the boy his childhood home but those memories are corrupted by the reality of its destroyed and vacant condition. The lacunae created by faded memories become filled with present horrors.  â€œYou forget what you want to remember and you remember what you want to forget.â€ (Location 116)Even the punctuation McCarthy has chosen, stripped of apostrophes, commas and quotation marks, reinforces a visual experience of absences.Death is everywhere. The characters must wear masks to filter out the ash that fills the air. At first, the human corpses McCarthy presents are uncannily ordinary, like stage-dressing or props:  â€œFossil tracks in the dried sludge. A corpse in a doorway dried to leather.â€ (Location 109) McCarthy will save his horrors for more effective use. Against this landscape, the smallest chance intervals of relief are striking. The man propels the cart with his son and their possessions like a bobsledder, and elicits a smile. A field of dessicated apples in the dirt provides precious sustainance for another day or two. The two unnamed characters, the man and the boy, make their way through a ruined world. That anonymity is yet another erasure â€” of identities. It gives this story the feel of an allegory. McCarthy summons just such an image in his first paragraph:  â€œIn the dream...he had wandered in a cave where the child led him by the hand. Their light playing over the wet flowstone walls. Like pilgrims in a fable swallowed up and lost among the inward parts of some granitic beast.â€ (Location 32)The third person narrative reinforces that allegorical feeling. Passages of dialog are spare: exchanges of fear, reassurance, impotence and resolve. Dreams are one of the few conduits into the man's inner thoughts. The man's dreams are never nightmares. That would confer too subjective a viewpoint. After all, the real nightmare is the world they inhabit.McCarthy's word choices promote a sense of temporal ambiguity. The â€œFallâ€ is represented literarily as well as literally, mined from historic, feral and primal suggestions. The man struggles to find his balance in the dark:  â€œAn old chronicle. To seek out the upright. No fall but preceded by a declination. He took great marching steps into the nothingness, counting them against his return. Upright to what? Something nameless in the night, lode or matrix.â€ (Location 141) Lode: channel or burden? Matrix: mold or birth origin? (Look up the etymologies and definitions).McCarthy adheres to a disciplined agnosticism. God is both a thing longed for and a thing despised:  â€œAre you there? He whispered. Will I see you at last? Have you a neck by which to throttle you? Have you a heart? Damn you eternally have you a soul?â€ (Location 109) God is both animus and hollow promise. These contradictions appear later in the voice of an old man named Ely:  â€œNobody wants to be here and nobody wants to leave.â€ (location 1573)  â€œThere is no god and we are his prophets.â€ (Location 1582) (view spoiler)[ For this reason, I did not find the ending hopeful, but a continuation of McCarthy's questions about uncertainty. The man does not stay alive for himself, but for his son. As long as there is someone else to stay alive for, life is worth continuing. (hide spoiler)]McCarthy's answer to the question of what is left is uncertainty. Logic ordains that both the man and the boy will perish. Yet, time after time, they are lucky. They stumble upon a safe spot for the night, or a can of unspoiled rations. We watch these events with a similar uncertainty. As long as there is uncertainty, these two figures will continue to haunt our thoughts. I tried to read this book several years ago, and could not get beyond the first page. In the intervening time, something has changed. I no longer look upon human nature with optimism. With the loss of optimism, an acceptance of uncertainty may be all that connects us.NOTES:James Wood is always a reviewer worth reading. Here is his review of THE ROADhttps://newrepublic.com/article/64041...

Ãˆ il racconto di un viaggio, un cammino faticoso e irto di pericoli, per chilometri e chilometri attraverso un paesaggio desolato, incenerito e saccheggiato, con tutto ciÃ² che si possiede trasportato su un malandato carrello della spesa. La catastrofe che si Ã¨ abbattuta sul mondo ne ha cancellato ogni intervento operato dallâ€™umanitÃ  e dalla natura nei secoli; la stessa civiltÃ , la storia e il progresso sono annientati, dimenticati. I pochi sopravvissuti al disastro non conservano piÃ¹ nulla di umano e vagano alla ricerca disperata di cibo, spaventati dagli orrori che vedono intorno a loro o imbestialiti dallâ€™istinto di sopravvivenza. In questo paesaggio di buio, freddo, cenere, pioggia e devastazione brilla il legame tra un uomo e il suo bambino, padre e figlio non meglio identificati. Il loro rapporto Ã¨ fatto di piccoli gesti, sguardi struggenti e brevi frasi concise che denotano uno sconfinato reciproco amore, senza cedimenti e senza incertezze. La prosa secca ed essenziale Ã¨ straordinariamente evocativa e ben si adatta alle atmosfere sterili e soffocanti, alla disperata malinconia dei ricordi e alla lucida disillusione presente. Anche nello stile, tuttavia, guizzano a tratti inattesi bagliori che con la loro intensitÃ  colpiscono al cuore il lettore come lame affilate. I encountered my first issue on page four. It was intense enmity at first sight."He thought the month was October but he wasnt sure. He hadnt kept a calendar for years."Apostrophes!? What happened to those magical things? Then, on page five..."The boy turned in the blankets. Then he opened his eyes. Hi, Papa, he said.I'm right here.I know."Quotation marks? Where art thou? Like they often say, you don't appreciate things until they're gone - and, in this case, I was starting to sincerely appreciate proper grammar.I'm slightly joking. The concise, spare, and experimental prose served McCarthy's purpose well in this story. It conveyed the themes of the book and touched on many truths of mankind in general. I give props to Cormac McCarthy for some of his more pulchritudinous passages:"No list of things to be done. The day providential to itself. The hour. There is no later. This is later. All things of grace and beauty such that one holds them to one's heart have a common provenance in pain. Their birth in grief and ashes. So, he whispered to the sleeping boy. I have you."The Road has received myriad lauds and a lot of love. Despite this, I didn't effusively enjoy the book. The stilted writing style made it difficult for me to connect with the characters. Near the end of the novel, I remember annotating "this is the scene where I should be crying... but I'm not." I recognize the feat McCarthy has achieved by publishing this heartbreaking post-apocalyptic novel, but, personally, I couldn't bring myself to like it more than any other okay book. Possibly because for every wonderfully-written passage or page, I had to trudge through 25 average ones.Overall, I would recommend The Road to those who find pleasure in reading about dark, despairing situations as well as those who like experimental, post-apocalyptic fiction. The relationship between the father and his son acts as the best attribute of the book, as it reminds readers of the strength of human connection and how much love can endure and accomplish.*review cross-posted on my blog, the quiet voice.

I've waited a few days after finishing to write something about this book, hoping to achieve a fair and balanced opinion of this Pulitzer-prize winning novel.And trying to figure out WHY it won said prize.I think it's a Harry Potter thing. I may have mentioned this before, but a friend told me a story about her non-fantasy-reading friend, who read a Harry Potter novel. Said person was like, "Wow! It was AMAZING! It's like the author created a Whole Different World!" The concept had never occurred to her, let alone that there's a whole genre of novels that "create whole new worlds."Likewise, I think the people that are impressed by "The Road" have probably never read a post-apocalyptic novel.Maybe it's just that I read the 1965 novel by John Christopher "The Ragged Edge" just a couple of months ago, and it's fresh in my mind... but, IMHO, "The Road" verges on plagiarism. It's the SAME EXACT STORY. OK, so "The Road" takes place a little bit further after the disaster, and the kid travelling with the man through the post-apocalyptic wasteland is his biological son, not an adopted orphan, and "The Ragged Edge" has a few more characters thrown in. But they've even got nearly the same scene on a ship! How likely is that?Basically, I think Cormac McCarthy probably read the other novel at some point, said, "I can do this better," and threw in some religious allegory, made it clear that Man was responsible for the disaster (although that's hardly original, either), and wrote it in poetic language. But you know what? I LIKE full sentences and punctuation. OK, occasionally sentence fragments can be used effectively. But the whole book is sentence fragments! And leaving out apostrophes from contractions is just distracting, annoying, and serves no poetic purpose.Ah well; I am sure many readers out there will disagree with me, but that's my honest opinion!

I read this purely on the fact that is was the selection of the month for the club. To be honest, it is not something that I would have picked up myself despite the award of a Pulitzer Prize.I didn't like it. Sure, I recognized the sparse writing style which lent an artsy feel to the prose (and was probably what earned it the Pulitzer and is why I give it 2 stars instead of 1), but the book was an ordeal from start to finish. It had no purpose what so ever except to make the reader feel like they were in a post-apocalyptic world where hope had been completely extinguished â€¦ and it worked. Ultimately that is what doomed the book with me â€¦ at the end I sat back and simply asked a very basic question â€¦ So? Was there a message? Maybe â€¦ life goes on? Egads, even the interminable â€œand so it goesâ€ from slaughter house five was better then this drekk. What about the relationship between the father and the son? Was it really love, so was it simple a reason to continue? I donâ€™t really know, but I suspect that there really was not as much there as it would seem. The boyâ€™s existence was simply an enabler for the fatherâ€™s continued existence. Neither character showed any character development over some 287 pages so what really was the point of the story? I have happily traded this book away on book mooch.com

The Road is a contemporary novel by Cormac Mcarthy, the novels fits the past apocalyptic genre.It tells the story of a man and a child after some unnamed catastrophe takes place in the world and the survivors of the disaster are bound with the need to persevere and to fight to stay alive.Mcarthy depicts the violence and the cruelty of humans. Through their journey -the man and child-, we see how the relationship between the two is extremely strong. The father, through it all, emphasized on the importance of how the child must "carry the fire" and be one of the good guys.It was a good book, I would recommend it for those who like the post-apocalyptic genre.

I selected it because both my husband and son-in-law recommended it, also because it has so many high ratings. I found it repetitive, bleak, pointlessly depressing with no joy at all with certainly no hope of redemption in the end.

The Road was a 2-star novel until the last EIGHT pages, at which I actually shed tears, then immediately awarded 4-stars. (Truth be told, if I re-reviewed Cormac McCarthy's book sometime in the near- to mid-future, which I never do, I might retroactively award 5 stars.) Why? Why so mercurial? Why all this fuss? Why not an unequivocal appraisal?Because the last EIGHT pages whipsawed me to a place the preceding pages were unable to take me. The last pages unveiled a vision of the story I had previously missed. The ending was quick, not altogether unexpected, but it amplified the message the book was steadily making right in front of me the whole time, while, glibly, I ambled along at 400 words per minute.The Road is a story simply of a boy and his Papa trudging their way to the coast in a purposely undefined post-apocalyptic America. They remain unnamed, without personal description, and there are only four other characters whose total combined dialogue would fit on one-half a page. So in essence, this is a Waiting-For-Godot-style interaction between father and son. The story is written with overriding asepticism so McCarthy could focus us on the relationship between two characters. Brilliant. The characters and the apocalypse are purposely undefined; the dialogue is purposely truncated and staccato; there are no chaptersâ€”on purpose; hell, there aren't even any quotation marks in the whole book! Background, narration, foreshadowing, author's voiceâ€”things critical to fictionâ€”are all eliminated from The Road as unnecessary accouterments, plebeian writing tools, sophomoric things that would only get in the way of the simple but powerful relationship. And the result is a story distilled to its essence.On their way to the coast, we glimpse how humans become feral after the annihilation of civilization. We realize how difficult survival would be in this gray world. Other authors would pursue the images or emotion of a burnt world. McCarthy is on an opposite tack. You, the reader, must landscape almost the entire exterior.The last EIGHT pages made me realize that The Road is actually a poem in disguise. I'm not a big fan of poetry, and that's why I was breezing through. Stop. But I know from poetry that simplicity, rhythm, chorus, and the absolute precision of word selection and placement has a synergistic effect on the whole. So, McCarthy has written an epic poem of filial love, again, distilled to its essence. The words between father and son are simple, direct, and lyrical. There is a universe of meaning within--just like the simplest poems of Robert Frost or Emily Dickinson. Some may find this a haunting story. Some may feel this a beautiful, hopeful story. Maybe people feel it's a haunting story simply because they do find beauty in a such a horrible, terminal environment. Either way The Road won a Pulitzer because it touched so many people in such a visceral way. Visceral, and yet, I betcha that many people don't know why.McCormick did something I found very neat with his language. He covered the reader with a tide of obscure vocabulary, some I couldn't even find in the dictionary. The word 'salitter' for example; it's only--and most recent--use was apparently in a poem from the 18th century. However, 'salitter' and the other words have such an exacting definition and relevance to the story, that I look back and realize, like poetry, McCormack was compressing his story and needed to imbue every word with the most perfect meaning available to the English language. New words: pipeclayed, firedrake, rachitic, siwash, claggy, woad, chert, patterans, windrow, wrack, tidewrack, isocline, salitter, crozzled, loess

Well, it's not often you can call a Cormac McCarthy book "sweet." It's also not often you're tempted to call a post-apocalyptic novel filled with rapist cannibals "sweet." Yet, The Road is surprisingly hopeful (on a Cormac McCarthy scale), presenting a world filled with the same unfathomable darkness and mystery that characterizes most of McCarthy's work, yet showing two people who struggle on regardless of that darkness: a father and his son, who "carry the flame." We never learn why nearly everything is dead. As is often the case with McCarthy's work, he leaves out the details that aren't essential. What we do know is that a man survived a huge event that killed nearly everything, and he has a young son. The son was born after the event happened, and only knows what he's heard from his father about the world before. With a map that is so old that it's a bunch of numbered pieces, they trace their path to the coast. They travel toward the coast for the sake of having some destination, although they don't know what they'll find there.As always, McCarthy's writing is evocative, sparse and with the customary lack of punctuation. He could write books with no plot and just description and they'd still be worth reading. But the relationship between the father and his son is what makes The Road such a terrific book. The dialogue between them is just so fraggin good. McCarthy doesn't need to tell you anything about their relationship, about their feelings, about their struggles: it all comes through naturally in their conversation. It's all so believable, so natural, and often so hilarious. The father is struggling to survive, but he's more concerned about keeping his son alive. The son is often angered by the fact that they can't save everyone they come across. The father often makes small concessions to the son, but when they come across a starving old man, he refuses to do more than give him a meal and let him stay with them for one night. He remains a realist about their very limited resources and their ability to truly trust others. The biggest threats are starvation and dehydration, but they also have to watch out for the organized groups of cannibals who roam the road. It seems that more humans survived the apocalypse than any other kind of animal, or else the humans were able to survive the aftermath better. Either way, many people have turned to cannibalism, since it is the most readily available type of food. This makes some of the meetings with other people out on the road quite scary, since our main characters don't know what to expect from any chance encounters.So, why is it five stars? I don't often give books a full five, but I feel The Road deserves it because of a combination of factors. 1: The characters are full and rich and believable and I loved them. 2: This is the strongest depiction of a post-apocalyptic world that I've encountered in fiction or in film. You never need to suspend your disbelief; everything feels too real for the fantasy to be even slightly fractured. 3: The book is concise, taking less than 300 pages to tell its complete story (which has a surprisingly strong ending considering the bleakness of the world). And, 4: looking back, I can't find anything at all to fault. I recommend this one to any and everyone.

Trostlosigkeit, alles ist grau. Nachts ist kein Mond sichtbar, die Tage sind kurz, die Sonne wird nie wirklich sichtbar. Alles ist von Asche bedeckt. Nichts lebt, die BÃ¤ume sind tot, die Pflanzen, es gibt keine Tiere. Nur ein paar Menschen. Sie scheiden sich in die BÃ¶sen, deren Ãœberlebensstrategie Kannibalismus heiÃŸt. Und dann gibt es die Guten, unter ihnen ein Vater und sein Sohn. Sie bleiben namenlos. Sie versuchen sich von alten Konserven, die sie hier und da finden, zu ernÃ¤hren. Sie frieren, erleben NÃ¤sse, sind mÃ¼de und hungrig, fliehen auf ihrem Weg in den SÃ¼den immer wieder vor den BÃ¶sen. Das ist an Trostlosigkeit nicht zu Ã¼berbieten und obwohl auf ihrem Weg so sehr viel nicht passiert, bzw. nur Dinge, die fÃ¼r jeden Leser erwartbar sind, ist das ungemein fesselnd. Das liegt an der beklemmenden Tristesse, aber mehr noch an der Schilderung dieser Vater-Sohn-Beziehung. Der Vater recht nÃ¼chtern, lediglich um das Ãœberleben des Sohnes bemÃ¼ht, daher zwangslÃ¤ufig misstrauisch und pragmatisch, der Sohn immer wieder Mitleid empfindend â€“ mit einem Hund, einem Kind, einem alten Mann. Zwei Geisteshaltungen, die nicht nur einen Generationenkonflikt andeuten oder ihr Lebensalter zu charakterisieren zu scheinen, sondern Haltungen, wie man zu einer Gesellschaft stehen kann, die es hier garnicht mehr gibt. Das ist eines der dÃ¼stersten, schwÃ¤rzesten BÃ¼cher, die ich je gelesen habe. Und dennoch ist es voll Liebe, Hoffnung und Menschlichkeit.

8/6 -- OK... I finished this last night, and am still pondering it. I had an idea about this book before I started, although I tried not to bias my own opinion before I even started the book by reading the opinions of others. This book caught me off-guard. I enjoyed the book as a whole. After the first few pages I was sucked in and lost in this gray existence, which is exactly what it is... existence, and barely that. After the first few pages, I had trouble finding a place to stop for the night and remember thinking that it was oddly fitting that I should have such a problem. My boyfriend asked me what the book was about, as I dragged it along with me for the better part of two evenings. (The poor guy didn't see my eyes the entire time.) I found that it was hard to describe to him... I tried to explain it, but he's not much of a reader, so he was disinterested, to say the least. I finally told him that it is the story of a man trying to ensure the survival of his son, and their journey to find a place where they can live. I tried to convey to him the constant sense of the father almost willing life to appear while at the same time mistrusting it and trying to make sure that his son doesn't lose the hope he holds of finding it. As far as the writing itself, it seemed to me that it was like a non-stop series of snapshots and memory-clips coming together to make a mosaic that are the characters' lives. No breaks in the story, no rest for the weary. About 10 pages from the end, I thought that the only glimmer of "the light at the end of the tunnel" would come in the form of a potentially overlooked seedling or something similar... That would have been a decent ending in my mind, but the actual one in the book is better, I think. All in all, I am glad that I read this one.

S.P.L.E.N.D.I.DDo you guys remember that Green Day song that you thought was about your high school;That's a costum design for this book , or maybe not. Anywas.I'm aching and sobbing internally after reading this book. It was too dark but it was realistic, and I was cringing the whole time I was reading, and I just want to get it out of my system but I know I won't EVER be able to forget it or not think about it, perhaps for every single day of my life.It was dark, it was gloomy, it was sad, it was MISERABLE. But I LOVED it. The little boy and his father's love for him were the only good left in the world, I WANNA CRY! Even despite the fact that it is not exactly what you would call a story, but just a journey instead. I sat for a while contemplating what I just read after I finished it, and tears flowed and flowed. I imagined the world to look something like this, but it was also covered with ash, so you could only imagine how it would be like to breath, let alone live there. This felt to me like yu could either go 1/5 or 5/5 with it, I would not think of an inbetween. And it certainly does deserve a five, I really don't simply give 5 stars. However, this book is one of those that i wish I never read because I know it would haunt me for good.

Maybe 70K words formatted to fill 287 pages, as quick a read as "Bridget Jones," but not as applicable to one's life? A simple story. The perfect beach read for pessimistic survivalists. A typical Cormac Mc world: unrelentingly humorless, brutal, often gorgeous (and often over-the-top) Faulknerian prose ("unremembered," "unravaged," etc), small oases of masculine affection among endless acres of burnt earth. As it's suggested in the book, the story itself is a nightmare we need to dream or else we've given up. Memorable. Worthwhile. Incredible ability to help you imagine scenes and landscapes through a pane of quick, spare, evocative prose. But subtextually it didn't seem to me on the same level as other otherworldly allegories like Blindness or Waiting for the Barbarians, maybe 'cause, in general there's something in McCarthy's prose that I respect but don't quite fully buy? Or maybe because this one's more about individual survival (as in his typical high-lit "Westerns") against starvation, the elements, stray bad guys etc, than the survival of societies, or surviving within one that's gone totally wacky? Anyway, definitely an enjoyable book about the destruction of humanity and the endurance of what's human, or some Oprah-ready blurboid like that.

2nd time reading this book. Have raised it one more star to a five.This book has me feeling very emotional. I knew what was going to happen but this time it really hit me with a punch. I don't know if it's being older and feeling the weight of what it means to be a parent. Being aware of one's mortality and knowing you will leave your child behind. What makes it worse is that the father is leaving his child in an apocalyptic world filled with bad guys, men who are cannibals. He must hold on long enough to find a safe place and good people with who to leave his son with. It's heart wrenching. The author does a great job of depicting a gray, barren world. The writing and dialogue is simple and subtle, fitting in with the scarcity of this new world, the despair that's all around them. And yet for all its bleakness, there is also the love this father has for his child, and it's the motivation that keeps this father going, this need to keep his child alive and safe. It's this love that's the sole source of light in this horrible new world.My heart couldn't take the end. I had to let the tears flow.

This book reminded me why I don't like "literary" fiction much -- Cormac McCarthy may be a polished writer who can turn a neat phrase, but that's pretty much all this story is. Strip away the repetitive, blunt dialogs between "The Man" and "The Boy" and McCarthy's carefully crafted descriptions of walking, hiding, opening jars, etc., and you've got a tale of a man and a boy walking down an endless road in a post-apocalyptic landscape. They walk and walk and walk and now and then they encounter someone, and then they walk some more, until the end. That's it. That's the story.I know, I'm supposed to appreciate McCarthy's beautiful, sparse prose, and the emotional depth conveyed by the father and son with these beautiful, sparse words. I got that. But I'd like a plot with the pretty words, please.

Spartan and bleak. Short and sharp and raw. Emotionally wrenching even when nothing much is happening. Better than I could have ever imagined a story set in a post-apocalypse wasteland could be. I really did like The Stand and all (let the record show 4 stars), but The Road makes The Stand look like so much Stephenie Meyer prattle. Sorry Mr. King, but in the immortal words of our esteemed president, Mr. McCarthy didn't just beat you, he spanked you.(I can say that about Mr. King because normally I count myself among his proponents and am confident he'll never read it.)As much as I enjoyed--no, that's not the right word--was captivated by The Road, I can't see it making a good movie. Viggo Mortensen will have to share top billing with the color grey. Hope I'm wrong.

A father and his young son walk along the road in a post-apocalyptic time. There is nothing alive except for a few lawless people that they must hide from. Ash covers the earth, and their only food is what they can scavange from abandoned homes. A pistol with two bullets is their only defense. In this bleak, dark journey to the warmer southern coast, the sole brightness is the love and devotion between the father and the son. The Road is a beautifully written, riveting story that I could not put down.

This is a very good book. Yes, it is bleak and uncompromising. Yes, it is unbearable at times. But the tale being told is absolutely compelling. The bond between the father and son is so true - to me at least. It affected me profoundly, particularly as when I read it my youngest son was the same age as the child in the book. It was so easy to imagine myself in the same position as the father in the book. Sadly if it were me it would have been a short book - we would have been dead by page 25.

This book is not for everyone. The tale is beautiful, dark and poignant, with no Deus Ex to save the day. ****** Vague Spoilers Below **************The point of this story is not that "everything will be OK". The point is that this father loves his son completely, and is staying alive only to protect him. As with all McCarthy books, the true purpose of reading him is his mastery over language. The prose/imagery are magnificent.

This book honestly just dragged for me. I found it to be rather repetitive. Granted, the dialogue is unique, but unfortunately it really didn't work for me. With this being a Pulitzer prize winner too, I really did expect more from this book. I feel like it's a damn shame I've had to give this book a two star rating, when it seems to be a book that is loved by many.

Such a dark and depressing book. I remember watching the movie. I would hope that our world would never get to become this horribly depressing and dangerous where all you are trying to do is survive and not be killed by others.

Decididamente, nÃ£o Ã© um livro de fÃ©rias.Negro, apocalÃ­ptico e deprimente, Ã© tambÃ©m um livro que mostra a resistÃªncia e a profundidade do amor dos pais pelos filhos.Recomendo-o, mas nÃ£o para pessoas mais sensÃ­veis.

Unrelentingly bleak. The ending, with the Statue of Liberty emerging from the beach, was a nice twist though. "You maniacs! You blew it up! Ah, damn you! God damn you all to hell!" As it turns out, it was Earth all along.
Endlessly bleak. But lucid, sparse prose.
read in 2012 - lived up to the hype - better review to come 4.5 stars

La novela narra los Ãºltimos dÃ­as de los Ãºltimos habitantes del planeta Tierra, en un escenario postpostapocalÃ­ptico (y digo postpost porque creo que hay muchas historias en las que la tragedia que terminÃ³ con todo acaba de ocurrir y se narran las estrategias de supervivencia de muchos y las muertes multitudinarias; acÃ¡ todo eso ya pasÃ³, ya se acabÃ³ todo, ya se muriÃ³ todo, toda la vegetaciÃ³n ha desaparecido, todos los animales, quedan sÃ³lo los ejemplares mÃ¡s resistentes, o los mÃ¡s necios, o los mÃ¡s suertudos, que luchan por sobrevivir porque... pues porque eso viene escrito en el ADN de toda criatura viva; por ahÃ­ hay un perro, por ahÃ­ una orquÃ­dea).No sabemos quÃ© pasÃ³: una guerra nuclear o un nuevo meteoro en Chicxulub. Pero las 200 pÃ¡ginas de la novela permiten que el lector se adentre en la desesperaciÃ³n y el hambre, que avance con los personajes esperando que algo ocurra, que el hallazgo de una bodega llena de conservas cambie para siempre su suerte. Vemos morir el lenguaje; vemos estrecharse a cada paso los lÃ­mites finÃ­simos entre "lo bueno" y "lo malo", conceptos con los que el hombre ha educado a este niÃ±o que naciÃ³ en el nuevo mundo; aceptamos la muerte como la Ãºnica salida lÃ³gica y, con los personajes, esperamos que eso no tenga que pasar justo ahora.La novela, en resumen, me gustÃ³ mucho. Me llenÃ³ de tristeza y de culpa (y de ganas de comer fruta).
